title: Indiana Jury Asks U.S. to Study Theft

Prof. R. Keith Farrell was granted Patent 3,916,143 this week for the process by which a beam of light is transmitted to the creature's skin through a fiber optic bundle. The pat Patents of the Week tern of the brand can be controlled by arranging the optic bundle in the shape desired.

title: Notes on People
description: Patricia Thornton, whose family in White Plains was told by the State Department Sept. 22 that she had been killed in the fighting in Angola, has arrived in Lisbon aboard one of the special flights for refugees from the Portuguese colony in Africa. The 32yearold black teacher, who attended junior high school in East Elmhurst, Queens, and went on to obtain her master's degree at the University of Wisconsin, had been arrested and released twice since midAugust, but told American officials in Luanda that she had not been mistreated.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL HALTS PLANT WORK
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had halted work on a new 110inch plate mill facility at its Burns Harbor, Ind., facility. A spokesman said the action was in line with the company's plans to stretch out capital expenditures.

title: Opera: Regine Crespin in Carmen
description: The title role in Carmen lends itself to other interpretations than the one we ordinarily see: the hipswinging gypsy temptress with a heart as big as a Spanish olive. Regine Crespin, singing her Metropolitan Opera Carmen on Thursday night, portrayed a sophisticated woman who could swing a hip when required but who plainly did not fit into a raffish smugglers band. An interesting approach, it has precedents in the Carmen of Victoria de los Angeles, to delve no further back than this generation.

title: U.S. Tells Its Envoy to Israel His Remarks Were Out of Turn

Y., including the head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, were indicted yesterday on charges involving an alleged scheme for many of the town's policemen to avoid paying income taxes on their offduty jobs as security guards for private companies.

title: Art:2 Shows and 2 Kinds of LandscapeNature in France
description: The landscape of France is quite special. Nowhere in the world have the negotiations between mankind and nature been so consistently and so variously successful. Nature in France is not a matter of extremes. France has no Grand Canyon, no Niagara Falls, no Congo, no Amazon. It has nothing that cannot be brought under human control. And nature in France is uniquely hospitable; what we want we can find.

title: Art: Sculptural Darin in Exter Marionettes
description: Alexandra Ester (18821949) was one of the most gifted and versatile artists of the modernist movement that flourished in Russia in the Sears just before, during and immediately after the Revolution of 1917.. She was a stage designer of genius and a painter of substantial accomplishment. She belonged to ine auoacious generation that made something new and special out of its keen understanding and appreciation of the Paris avantgarde, adapting Fauvist color and cubist form to cultural imperatives undreamed of by Matisse and Picasso.

title: McKay to Pilot N.F.L.
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) John McKay, one of football's most successful collegiate coaches for 15 years at the University of Southern California, became the newest and one of the highestpriced coaches in the National Football League today, taking over the reins of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In the reality of the National Basketball Association, a matchup of two players can't be isolated from their teammates. But in the romance of the N.B.A., a matchup is what pro basketball is all about. Tonight a matchup for all seasons, or at least the next five or six or maybe more, will begin when George McGinnis of the Philadelphia fifers goes muscleonmuscle with Spencer Haywood of the New York Knicks in a confrontation of power forwards. All the ingredients for a classic rivalry existage, sire, style geography, philosophy and chemistry. The 25Sports yearold McGinnis is 6 feet 8 inches and 235 pounds. The 26yearold Haywood is 68 and of 225 pounds. Each is a strong scorer and The Times brutal rehounder. The teams are connected by Amtrak and the idea of constructing title contender around a power forward. And the chemistry is unique. McGinnis was signed by the Knicks for $2.4million over six years but after the sanctity of the N.B.A. draft was upheld, the 76ers signed McGinnis for $3.2million over six years. Then the thoughtlessness of Wilt Chamberlain in ignoring the Knicks and the thoughtfulness of Bill Russell in trading Haywood to New York combined to provide the desperate Knicks with a replacement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Representatives of law enforcement agencies investigating the strangulation murders last month of two women from Bergen County, N. J., said today they had agreed not to release any information until the case was brought to completion. Kenneth Gribetz, Rockland County District Attorney; Joseph Woodcock, Bergen County Prosecutor, and Jonathan Goldstein, United States Attorney, said they did not want to jeopardize the investigation. The bodies of the two women, Susan Heynes, 26 years old, and Susan Reeve, 22, were found earlier this week in southeastern Rockland County.

In a policy statement on the city, Mr, Buckley contended that appointment of a Federal court trustee was the best way of guaranteeing continuation of vital services, reordering the city's debt and relieving fiscal pressure on the state.

title: ANNA L. WEISSBERGER
description: Anna Lenson Weissberger, widow of Harry Arnold Weissberger, who founded Advertising Artists, Inc., died Tuesday at the Montclair Nursing Home in Glen Cove, L. I. She was 91 years old.

title: Ford's Plan on Aid Displeases Sadat
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today he was displeased with President Ford's foreign  aid package, which would provide $1.5billion in military aid to Israel but none Ito Egypt.

title: BLUE SHIELD STUDIES POSSIBLE RATE RISE
description: NEWARK, Oct. 31 (UPI)Blue Shield officials said today that they would know by the end of November whether the four million members of the surgical plan would face another rate increase soon.

title: N.F.L. TV Woe Discounted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)A Congressional subcommittee chairman accused Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League today of using misleading and meaningless figures to combat legislation to extend the ban on television blackouts for sports events that are sold out.

title: BRONZE OF INDIAN SOLD FOR $150,000
description: A new auction record for lAmeriCan sculpture was set yesterday when Cyrus Edwin Dallin's 9foottall bronze of an American Indian was sold for $150,000 at Sotheby Parke Bernet to an Indiana private collector. It eclipsed the previous (high of $130,000 paid for Elie Nadelman's Tango in 1973.

title: Virginia Ingalls Sorem, 55, Fashion Aide for Penney's
description: Virginia Ingalls Sorem, fashion director for the corporate offices here of the J. C. Penney Company, Inc., died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was 55 years old and lived at 360 East 72d Street.

title: ARTHUR SACKETT, ENGINEER, 91, DIES
description: Arthur J. Sackett. chairman of Mason & HangerSilas Mason Company, Inc., engineers, who worked on major construction projects in the United States, died Thursday at his home in St. Augustine, Fla. He was 91 years old.

title: Aalto May Yet Become A Household Name Here
description: With furniture news these days focused primarily on revivalsfrom Chippendale to Le Corbusier, from Hepplewhite to Hoffmannthe continuing, mushrooming interest in Alvar Aalto seems anomalous.

title: Nyerere Wins Reelection Vith 92% of Tanzanian Vote
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Oct. 31 (Reuters)  Julius K. Nyerere has been reelected Tanzania's President for five years, winning nearly 92 per cent of the vote, it was announced today.

title: Arab Participation and Recognition in American Life Have Steadily Grown in 2 Years Since Oil Embargo
description: Barbara Walters, cohost of NBC's Today Show, was getting ready to sign off for the day, With Rosh haShanah, the wish New Year, approaching, she wished her Jewish viewers a Happy New Year. Then she added a Good Ramadan to the show's Arab friends.

title: Youth Held in 72 Brewster Train Theft
description: CARMEL, N, Y., Oct. 31A Putnam County youth, accused of stealing a locomotive from a railroad yard three years ago, was indicted yesterday by a Putnam County grand jury and charged with reckless endangerment in the first degree.

title: Assembly
description: In Tuesday's election, there is one contest in New York City for the State Assembly and there are two for the City Council. We make the following recommendations.

title: HEAD FUNDRAISER FOR FORD RESIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31David Packard, the chairman of President Ford's 1976 campaign finance committee, has resigned following a reported dispute over his approach to fund raising.

title: Soviet Spy Here Given 22Year Term
description: Sarkis 0. Paskalian, an Arnenian diamond cutter who pleaded guilty last month to charges of transmitting secret United States defense information to the Soviet Union, was sentenced yesterday to 22 years in prison by Federal Judgo Mark A. Costantino in Brooklvn.

title: Business Briefs
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 31 (AP)M ore than 1,000 pulp and papermill workers went on strike today in Nova Scotia, bringing to 31,000 the number of papenvorkers strike throughout Canada, union officials reported. The latest to leave their jobs were 600 workers at the Nova Scotia Forest Industries, Ltd., pulp mill at Point Tupper the Canso Strait and 450 employes at the BowatersMersey nei vsorint nlant in Liverpool.

title: Antiques: Tools as Art
description: Tools  the planes, axes, hatchets, saws, hammers, chisels, squares, augers and shears that colonists used to open the wilderness and shape this nation's houses, cities, farms and industrieshave over the last few years proved of consuming interest to more than 1,000 serious tool collectors.

title: Wings Rehire Allan
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Wings announced today that Bobby Allan would return to coach the National Lacrosse League team for the next three seasons. After leading the Wings to the regularseason title in 1974, Allan resigned to resume teaching commitments.

title: Books of The Times
description: CAN AMERICA WIN THE NEXT WAR? By Drew Middleton. 271 pages. Scribners. $8.95.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Music

title: Rate Bill Approved
description: The House has passed bill extending the present authority of Federal bank regulatory agencies to set interestrate ceilings on deposits. Page 39.

title: FRANCE AUTHORIZES PALESTINIAN OFFICE
description: PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP) The Palestine Liberation Organization was authorized by the French Government today to open an information and liaison office here, the first in a Western capital.

title: Prance Said to Bar Canada in Parley
description: PARIS, Oct. 31  French sources said today that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing had decided not to invite Canada to a midNovember economic conference, despite considerable pressure from the United States.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL ON BANKING RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) A bill extending the present authority of Federal bank regulatory agenceis to set interestrate ceilings on deposits was passed by the House today after it defeated, by 218 to 134, a proposal that would have allowed banks across the country to offer checking accounts that pay interest.

title: Tuesday's Ballot Includes Series of State Proposals
description: The only bumper stickers around in the closing days of New York's tepid offyear election campaign relate to the state equal rights amendment, which would ban discrimination against women.

title: The New York Times/Thomes Christian
description: NOT JUST FOR KIDS: Mary Pollit, dressed as a sheik, and Tessie Saller as geisha serve fellow members of older people's nutrition group at Halloween party in Clifton.

title: HEAD FUNDRAISER FOR FORD RESIGNS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31David Packard, the chairman of President Fords 1976. campaign finance committee, has resigned following a reported dispute over his approach to fund raising.

title: POTATO FUTURES END PRICE SLIDE
description: After a string of declining prices for the last 16 trading sessions, the May potato futures contract managed to move up yesterday. May contracts closed at 11.19 cents a pound on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up from 10.70 cents.

title: 3 PLEAD NO CONTEST ON STEEL RESTRAINT
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 (UPI)Executives of three steel coinpanies pleaded no contest today to Federal charges of conspiracy in restraint of trade in reinforcing steel bars.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES LOAN GUARANTEES TO ASSIST THE CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A House banking subcommittee voted 10 to 6 today to approve legislation that would give New York City up to $7billion in loan guarantees before or after a default.

title: ABRAHAM LENTZ
description: Abraham (Chubby) Lentz, host at the Brickman Hotel, South Fallsburg, N.Y., for 45 years, died Thursday of heart attack in Brooklyn, where he lived. He was 63 years old.

title: WALTER BURKE, 92, UTILITIES EXECUTIVE
description: KENNEBUNK, Me., Oct. 31Walter H. Burke, a retired public utilities executive who helped establish the first largescale electric power system in Greece, died Wednesday at the Webber Hospital in Biddeford. He was 92 years old.

title: Pistons 131, Rockets 127
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 (UPI)A 21S burst in the fourth period tonight helped the Detroit Pistons score a 131127 N.B.A. victory over the Houston Rockets despite a 40point performance by Calvin Murphy.

title: ACCORD REACHED NO EXPORT CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States and the other leading industrial nations have quietly reached agreement on new system of mutual information on the interest rates they charge on governmentsupported export credits.

title: WORLD AID URGED FOR ENVIRONMENT
description: DURHAM. N.C., Oct. 29International action to curb deleterious modification of the earth's atmosphere was recommended in general terms today by a conference convened by the National Institutes of Health.

title: $1 Drive for City Started
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 31 (AP)A campaign to have Americans send one dollar to Mayor Beame to show President Ford and Congress that the average American does not want to see New York City default will begin formally here tomorrow.

title: Music: A Series by Starker
description: Janos Starker, a cellist who has become one of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's favorite artists, began a series of BeethovenBrahms programs in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium Thursday night with Menahem Pressler as his partener at the piano. It is the third season in a row that Mr. Starker has given a museum series, and the audience overflowed onto the stage.

title: ALFRED P. HURRAH, FEDERAL JUDGE, 71
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 31 (AP)Senior Judge Alfred P. Murrah of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit died in a local hospital yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: OnceLively Beirut Grim and Desolate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 31 Beirut was once a lively, cosmopolitan place, a bit imitative, a bit nouveau riche, but undeniably a city of some consequence.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN ON AMEX, 0TC
description: Prices were moderately lower in reduced trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market. Brokers suggested that the encouraging news of what appeared to be the start of another round of prime rate reductionsto 71/2 per cent from 7/4 per centwas offset by uncertainties surrounding New York City's financial picture.

title: CHILE SAYS A PLOT BY LEFT IS BROKEN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 (Reuters)The Chilean national intelligence service said today that a Communist inspired plot to kill President Augusto Pinochet and set up a Marxist state in Chile had been broken.

title: Bernard Musnik, 72. Ad Man. Headed Publicis Corp. Here
description: Bernard Musnik, president since 1957 of Publicis Corporation, New York branch of leading French advertising agency, and head of Regie International, Inc., overseas publishers representatives, died Wednesday at his home, 103 East 84th Street. He was 72 years old.

title: NEWSPAPER TALKS TO RESUME MONDAY
description: Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and The New York Times are scheduled to renew their contract talks Monday in an effort to avert a possible strike threatened for Nov. 11.

title: Ken Regan/Camera Bob Dylan singing Thursday night in Plymouth, Mass.
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., Oct. 31Bob Dylan has always had a sense of occasion, and so it seemed only appropriate for him to begin his latest, most unusual tour here in America's home town as Plymouth likes to call itself. For in its conception this surely the most American and most democratic of all of Mr. Dylan's performing ventures. Appraisal And on the basis of last night's 3 hour opening performance, it may turn out to be his most loving, as well. Popmusic superstars have drifted away from direct contact with their fans in recent years. Concertsincluding the concerts on Mr. Dylan's tour with the Band in early 1974take place in indoor basketball arenas or even more gigantic stadiums. As one woman from Plymouth who saw the show last night put it, Seeing Bob Dylan from the back of Madison Square Garden is like watching a flea circus.

title: AID TO HANDICAPPED BACKED IN CONGRESS
description: A SenateHouse conference, committee has approved a bill aimed at giving every handicapped child a free, adequate public education, the office of Senator Harrison A. Williams, Democrat of New Jersey, an nounced yesterday in Washington.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Oirs by Trlabglt Publications. Inc. The Daily Racine Form) Friday, Oct. 31. 58th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Greenwich Girl, 15, Bludgeoned to Death
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 31 The 15yearaid daughter of la Greenwich executive was found bludgeoned to death this afternoon in a clump of bushes 200 feet from her home in the exclusive Belle Haven estate section here.

title: A Profit Tax for Schools Fought in Seattle
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 31Business leaders in Washington State are believed to be fighting losing battle against a proposed 12 per cent tax on corporate profits.

title: Spain Faces Serious Economic Woes
description: PARIS, Oct. 31  Despite the miracle that produced one of the fastest growth rates in Europe over the last two decades, Spain faced serious economic problemsfrom rising unemployment and accelerating inflation to falling investmenteven before Generalissimo Francisco Franco was stricken by a heart attack last week.

title: House Panel Votes to Curb I.R.S. Access to Bank Data and Expand DayCare Tax Credit,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The House Ways and Means Committee finished its current round of work on the tax bill today by strengthening a provision relating to taxpayer rights and enlarging the tax credit for daycare expenses.

title: Stocks Drift Downward As Turnover Pace Slows
description: With trading again inhibited as investors tried to figure out what a New York City default would mean, the stock market drifted lower yesterday in the lightest trading in three weeks.

title: Beame Opposes Changes In Charter During Crisis
description: Mayor Beame declared himself opposed yesterday to all 10 proposals for revision of the New York City Charter, on the ground that the changes, whatever their merit, would be ilitimed and possibly too costly in light of the city's fiscal plight.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Soviet Space Station Tested;
description: MOSCOW. Oct. 31 (Reuters)  The Tass oress agency reported today that equipment aboard the orbiting Soviet space station Salyut4 was, being tested, increasing speculation that another manned, shot was imminent. Salyut4, launched last Dec. 26, has been visited by two crews that performed experiments in space.

title: W. T. Grant to Intensify StoreClosing Program
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which a month ago filed a bankruptcy petition in the largest retailing insolvency, announced last night that it would close almost all its stores in the Middle West and in the South. These, a total of 280 stores to be closed by late December, are in addition to 301 that the company announced previously would be closed by year's end.

title: Today's Other College Football Games
description: Scores on WQXR

title: U. S. Laws Needed to Assist City With Bankruptcy, Senators Told
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) A Justice Department official today urged prompt passage of legislation designed to assure that New York City could carry) on essential services during bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Princeton Harriers Take Big 3 Title
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31Craig Masback and Larry Tractenberg of Princeton tied for first place and with the thirdplace finish of Tom Hartshorne, a teammate, the Tigers won the 28th annual Big Three crosscountry championship today at the Yale Golf Course. Princeton had 21 points, Harvard 50 and Yale 60.

title: Sanitation Workers Sue Woodbridge Mayor for Libel
description: WOODBRIDGE, Oct. 31The union representing township sanitation workers filed a libel suit today against the town ship's Mayor, John Cassidy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CRIME RATE HERE IS STILL INCREASING
description: The rate of serious crime reported to the police in the city continued to increase last September, but at a slightly lower rate than earlier in the year.

title: Play Portraying the Lives Of Barrymores Is Revived
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 31In celebration of the United States Bicentennial, The Royal Family, a 1927 drawingroom comedy modeled on the life of the American theater's first family, the Barrymores, opened an 11day run at the McCarter Theater here last night.

title: Stage: 2 Soviet Plays
description: We know so little about the Soviet Union. We imagine a great deal, we sense the idea of a certain society, but our actual knowledge is shockingly limited. And one of the main sources of that limitation is the Soviet Union itself. It frankly does not want us to know. It does not even want its own people to know about the very fabric of its society.

title: Cost of Holding Key Man In Suffolk Dispute Studied
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Oct. 31Joseph P. Hoey, the special state prosecutor for Suffolk County, is investigating reports that Roger Barry Peterson, who has accused the Suffolk District Attorney of sodomy has been comfortably maintained by the police in a resort motel here, taken for boat rides, been permitted female companions and frequently escorted to bars.

title: FARM PRICESDROP 0.5% IPI A MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) Prices that farmers received for raw agricultural products; an important but erratic indicator for consumer food prices, declined onehalf of 1 per cent from Sept. 15 to Oct. 15, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: The $2 bill may make a comeback.

title: Two Are Shot Dead in Belfast As Factions in the I.R.A. Feud
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Oct. 31 (AP)The feud betweer the rival Official and Provisional wings of the Irish Republican Army brought two more violent deaths here today.

title: Juan Carlos and Cabinet Confer on Sahara Crisis
description: MADRID, Oct. 31  While Generalissimo Francisco Franco lay gravely ill, Prince Juan Carlos de BorbOn presided today over a fourhour Cabinet meeting largely devoted to the crisis in North Africa, where Algeria has warned of war if Morocco carries out her civilian march into the Sahara.

title: Conferees Drop Proposed Busing Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31A proposal to achieve more energy conservation by barring the busing of children beyond their neighborhood schools was killed today in a SenateHouse conference committee.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES LOAN GUARANTEES TO ASSIST THE CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 A House banking subcommittee voted 10 to 6 today to approve legislation that would give New York City up to $7billion in loan guarantees before or after a default.

title: U. S. Suit on Directorates Cites Cities Service, American Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) The Justice Department charged today that the Cities Service Company of Tulsa, Okla., and the American Natural Gas Company of New York have had interlocking directorates in violation of Federal antitrust laws.

title: NUCLEAR ACCORD WITH EGYPT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The United States and Egypt were reported today to be close to an agreement in principle allowing Egypt to purchase American nuclear fuel, technology and Dower reactors.

title: The OffYear Elections
description: TRENTON, Oct. 31  Next Tuesday's offyear elections, contrary to those with the usual pattern of dull, narrow issues that are devoid of any major political significance, promise to have important consequences for the state. For one thing, the fate of the Byrne administration's $922million bond issue will have an effect on New Jersey's economic recovery and on the state's capacity to maintain essential transportation and institutional services, to generate new housing, and to

title: Police Vote Slowdown
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 31 (AP)Some 100 of the city's 125 policemen said today they would answer only emergency calls and make arrests only for serious offenses. W. L. Dillingham, president of the local chapter of the Fraternal Order of Police, said the patrolmen had voted unanimously for work slowdown following the city council's refusal to grant 25 cent nay rise.

title: Bayh Says Rockefeller Can't Escape City Role
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP)Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, a Democratic Presidential hopeful, said today that Vice President Rockefeller could not escape responsibility for his role in New York City's fiscal crisis.

title: Southwest Forest Raises Price of Kraft Linerboard
description: Southwest Forest Industriesr announced yesterday it would1 increase the price for 42pound kraft linerboard to $215 a ton, from $200, effective Jan. 1. The company attributed the increase, to higher costs of labor, fuel and freizht.

title: Miss Heiser Has Nuptials
description: Charlene Anne Heiser, daughter of Maj. Gen. Rolland V. Heiser, U.S.A., Chief of Staff of the Seventh Army, and Mrs. Heiser, was married last evening to Grant G. Geiger 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn G. Geiger of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Orantes Defeated By Case in Manila
description: MANILA, Oct. 31 (AP)Ross Case of Australia upset topseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain in the quarterfinals of the Philippine International Tennis Grand Prix today. The scores were 46, 63. 62.

title: DRIVE IS OPENED ON RELIEF REFORM
description: A major nationwide campaign was opened yesterday at City Hall to press for swift action on a welfarereform bill that would make the Federal contribution to every state's welfare cost a uniform 75 per cent.

title: Good Ole Boy
description: SAVANNAH BEACH, Ga., Oct, 30Burt Reynolds is sprawled back on the couch in his studio trailer, talking to James Best about the sudden boom in moviemaking in the South.

title: Alter a Lull, Lebanese Fighting Again
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Nov. 1A lull in the factional fighting here yesterday followed a truce arranged late Wednesday night, but as night fell, there were heavy exchanges of rocket and mortar fire in the suburbs.

title: Bank of America Backs Federal Help for City
description: The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, issued a position paper yesterday reiterating its support of temporary Federal help to avert default in. New York Cityand terming President Ford's proposal for bankruptcy an unaccpetable alternative.

title: C. A. Hepp Marries Barbara Svenson
description: Barbara Louise Svenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. William Svenson of Morristown, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Christopher Antram Hepp, son of Mr. and Mrs. K. Kevin Hepp of Perrvsburg, Ohio.

description: Before this year's Indianapolis 500, Jimmy Caruthers, a driver described his battle with cancer as just another challenge; it's something that can happen to anyone, and

title: FordCongress Clash Balks Fuel Policy
description: Because no way has been found to reconcile those diametrically opposed points of view the country, despite what both sides recognize as a serious energy crisis, has in the two years since the Arab oil boycott been governed without a national energy policy.

title: Texas Subdues S.M.U. For 7th Victory, 3022
description: DALLAS, Nov. 1 (AP)Texas stunned by an early touchdown today, defeated the Mustangs. 3022, on Earl Campbell's bruising runs and three field goals by Russell Erxleben. The victory gave Texas the Southwest Conference lead with a 40 wonlost record. The Longhorns are 71 overall. S.M.U. is 35 and 13 in the confer

title: Janet Lindsay Burns Plans Bridal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry T. Burns of ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., and Dorset, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lindsay Burns, to Peter Saint Germain of New York. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice G. St. Germain of Montclair, N. J.

title: Beulah Bailey ThuII. Dies: State Tax Commission Aide
description: Beulah Bailey Thull. former research assistant to the New York State Tax Commission, and State Controller, died Thursday in Troy. N.Y.. where she lived. She was 84 years old.

title: Clamma Dale, Joy Simpson Win Naumburg Vocal Prizes
description: The Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's 1975 music competitions ended Friday with the naming of Clamma Dale and Joy Simpson as joint firstprize winners in the vocal division. Both are graduates o; the Juilliard School. Miss Dale is 27 years old and a New Yorker. Miss Simpson is 29 and from Philadelphia.

title: Track Lighting for the Home
description: Although track lighting is not a new interior lighting conceptit has been used for years in store displays, as well as in art galleries, museums and showrooms to highlight paintings, sculpture and other works of artits use in the home is a fairly recent innovation that is becoming increasingly popular.

title: BRIDGE
description: Contract bridge, as distinct from bridge and auction bridge, celebrated its 50th birthday last night. The first game was played November 1, 1925, by four young Harvard graduates aboard the United States Lines Finland, which was slightly north of the Panama Canal and headed for Havana.

title: Scientist, 75, Starts Days at 3 A.M.
description: PLAINFIELD  When Dr. Philip Levine of Plainfield receives the Melvyn H. Motolinsky Research Foundation Award at the Rutgers Medical School today, it will be one of a long series of honors for the renowned scientist.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Food
description: By Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey

title: Anniversaries
description: Handel

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: An 18story office building at 170 Broadway has been foreclosed by the Jessie Smith Noyes Foundation. The building's owner, Vesey Associates, of which Aaron Levine is a principal, had defaulted on a $1,007,000 second mortgage.

title: POOREST NATIONS TO GET BRITISH AID
description: LONDON. Nov. 1The British Government is overhauling its growing foreign aid program to focus on the rural needs of the poorest nations.

title: Reluctant Executives Get Househunting Aid
description: A national retail chain, seeking to transfer a manager from an outlying store to its New York City headquarters, encountered 10 refusals before filling the spot. When you get down to No. 11, said Ted Robinson of Homequity/Homerica, a company that arranges corporate relocations, you wonder if it's worth sending someone.

title: India and W.H.O in Big Drive To Prevent Revival of Smallpox
description: NEW DELHI  While World Health Organization officials watch for what they hope will be the last case of smallpox in Bangladesh, Indian doctors who have already stopped the spread of the viral disease march from house to house across the country and even exhume bodies as they check out more than 1,000 rumors a day to prevent reintroduction of the contagious disease that scars, blinds and kills.

title: REBELS ARE ACTIVE IN SOUTH THAILAND
description: PATTANI, Thailand. Nov. (AP)Bandits. Moslem separatists and Communist insurgents, who have been in the ThailandMalaysia border area for years have stepped up their activities in recent months, possibly because of the weapons made available since the end of the Indochina war, Thai military sources say.

title: New Role for School Nurses
description: PISCATAWAYOur goal is to change school nursing from BandAid service to comprehensive health care for the children and youth of New Jersey.

title: Corsets were gone forever
description: Fashion is more often a word of odium now than of praisehigh fashion, that is, not the fashion for denims or curly hair or makeup for gentlemen. Fashion suggests an expensive ideal for mindless bores. That is one way of putting it. The other way is that without Coco Chanel we would never have been released into denims at all.

title: Small Airports Are Plums for Developers
description: Sky Acres Airport is a bucolic, privately owned airfield nestled in the wooded hills north of Westchester. The deer that graze next to the runway scarcely notice the dozens of student pilots, Sunday pleasure flyers and airborne businessmen who take off and land every day in a steady stream of singleengine light planes.

title: Activities of Federal Agencies Raise Fourth Amendment Questions
description: WASHINGTONThe disclosures of the 10month investigation of United States intelligence agencies are so numerous and so complex that they may be likened to reading the Federal Budget or contemplating the number of stars in the solar system.

title: MIRIAM H. KELLOGG
description: Miriam Hassenplug Kellogg widow of Dr. E. Welles Kellogg. professor emeritus of surgery At Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, died yesterday in Southport, Conn. She war; Ri years old and lived at Lake Waramaug, Conn.

title: Nancy Lee Rueckert Is Fiancee Of T. A. Coughlin 3d, Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Rueckert of Hanover, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lee Rueckert of Alexandria, Va., to Thomas A. Coughlin 3d of Washington, a lawyer there with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Ford's Limited Vision
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1President Ford's handling of New York's financial crisis tells us more about the President than it does about the city.

title: The Winter Bear
description: In The Winter Bear Ruth Craft has written a poetic essay, combining prose, rhyme and near rhyme (don't try to analyze itjust let the rhythm flow). Erik Blegvad's illustrations, in muted shades of orange, brown and blue, and characterization and the warmth of emotion to this story of a simple excursion on a winter's day. So three set off in the cold still air with an apple or two (and plenty to wear). Blegvad creates the three visuallya girl and two boys. each with distinctive personality traits that remain consistent throughout the book. The Bear. on the other hand, is charac

title: 3 FAITHS IN DRIVE TO HELP JUDAISM
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1Three major faiths have joined in the sponsorship of seminars, the distribution of literature and the use of 16mm. films to promote a deeper understanding of Judaism, the Jewish people and the need for closer JewishChristian relationships.

title: Princeton Beaten By Bruins, 2416
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 1 After scoring two touchdowns within the first seven minutes of play to take 140 lead. Brown had to scramble in the final quarter to post a 2416 victory over Princeton today before a crowd of 17,500 at Palmer Stadium

title: Bahr's Field Goals Sink Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 3Football coaches generally agree that the kicking game is 30 to 40 per cent of the battle. But for Pnn State and Maryland today, it was closer to 99 per cent as Penn State won, 1513, scoring the decisive points halfway through the fourth quarter on Chris Bahr's third field goal of the day.

title: Shampoo Company Will Restock Lake
description: PASSAICChemicals from a shampoo plant in Clifton apparently drained into Hughes Lake in Third Ward Park here recently, killing 45 migrating and white ducks and thousands of fish. An official of the plant pledged last week to restore and restock the lake.

title: Isfahan Is Half The World
description: WHEN Shah Abbas the Great became ruler of Persia's Safawid dynasty in 1587, he chose Isfahan as his capital and undertook to make it eclipse all other cities. During his reign he built so many palaces, mosques, gardens, bridges that the inhabitants boasted: Isfahan nesfe JahanIsfahan is half the world. His immedrate successors continuea the beautification. According to a contemporary, Isfahan, a city of 600,000, had 162 mosques, 48 colleges, 273 public baths and no fewer than 1,802 caravanserais  open courtyards surrounded with buildings, which served as medieval tourist parks where travelers could find water for their camels and food and lodging for themselves.

title: Bikers Inmate Kills Himself
description: A 28yearold inmate on Rikers Island awaiting trial for murder was found hanging from the upper bunk of his cell yesterday, an apparent suicide.

title: Chase at His Best Shown at Parrish
description: SOUTHAMPTONThe Parrish Museum is known as the museum with the best William Merritt Chase collection in the country. By special agreement the Parrish displays works by the American artist with a certain regular frequency.

title: ExPriest Is Seeking Office
description: JERICHODaniel C. Mooney, a 34yearold Democratic nominee for Nassau County's proposed legislature, believes he has more than the average insight into human problems. He once was Roman Catholic priest. He now is a practicing lawyer.

title: For young readers
description: Up in Sister Bay is Charles Ferry's first novel. It is about a 17yearold boy named Robbie Van Epp who did a lot of growing up in Sawyer County, Wisconsin, the summer of 1939 when he saw his safe smalltown world being threatened by death and crime.

title: $100,000Ransom Bid Leads to Coast Arrest
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. (UPI)The police questioned today a man calling himself Death who, they say, demanded $100,000 for the life of a hostage but was arrested in a bus terminal as he sought to pick up the ransom.

title: Sealyham Rated Best In Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 1A saucy little Sealyham terrier came out of the East today to win the International Kennel Club's fall show. She was Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl, owned by Mr. Dorothy Wimer of Churchtown, Pa., and handled by Peter Green. Apparently she found the International Amphitheatre to her liking for the Welsh import triumphed here yesterday at the Stone City K.C. show and then led a field of 3,858 today in the second biggest event of the year. Only Santa Barbara, with 4,442, has been lareer.

title: Beame Rejects an Offer Of $3Billion Arab Loan
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he had turned down a secret loan offer, purportedly, from Arab sources, of up to $3billion for the financially ailing city because the terms were unacceptable and the sources of the money were obscure.

title: Briton Says Concorde Noise Is Unlikely to Be Improved
description: LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters)The chairman of British Airways, Sir David Nicholson, said that noise levels on takeoff for the supersonic airliner Concorde are unlikely to be improved, it has been revealed.

title: RUBIN SIDE LEADS IN BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov 1I A team of bridge experts headed by Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J., held a substantial lead at the start of today's play in the final playoff of the international team trial of The American Contract Bridge League here.

description: NEWARKCounselors from more than 140 high schools in New Jersey are expected to attend a breakfast, orientation and campus tour at Rutgers University on Friday.

description: CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. I (AP)  Stanford scored 28 points in the first half, then held off a secondhalf rally by Oregon State for a 2822 Pacific8 Conference victory today.

title: U.S. Rider Wins At Horse Show
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 1Rodney Jenkins, the only professional on the squad, scored a victory for the United States Equestrian Team when he rode No. 1 Spy to victory in the internationalopen jumper class tonight at the Washington International horse show.

description: BQLI Bulletin Board

title: CAM ERA VIEW
description: The photographer who presents a slide show to an audience is telling a story, and like all story tellers there are great ones and dull ones. Unfortunately many a guest has been forced to look at a slide show in which some pictures are upside down, sideways, reversed, or entirely out of sequenceall to the tune of such comments as: There's mother next to the Eiffel Tower, or There's father with the guard at the Tower of London, or Oops, that's the Macy Day Parade two years ago, but that shadow is where the strap fell the lens.

title: A Shower of Paper and Medallic Art for the BuyCentennial
description: Philately and numismatics, already two of the most popular hobbies in this country, are likely to gain even more followers duroqg the Bkentennial yearif vigorous merchandising has any effect. A Mind of philatelic and numismatic souvenirs, mostly of dubious value and mostly overpriced, is about to be unleashed the collector.

title: Solidarity Shows Cracks At State Labor Meeting
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 1  On the surface, the House of Labor meeting at the Concord Hotel stands united, but occasionally signs of a new coalition flickered through the threeday State A.F.L.C.I.O. convention that ended today.

title: SAN DIEGO STATE. SPLIT ON SECURITY
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 1The e ming of campus policemen at San Diego State University, following allegations of shocking coverup by the university authorities of an epidemic of rape and other crimes, produced sharp tensions this week among both students and faculty.

description: Pro Basketball

title: Proposed White Plains Charter Becomes Political Issue in City
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1  A proposed new Charter for White Plains that would strengthen the Mayor's role has become a political issue in the city during the waning days of a generally quiet political campaign.

title: Mindful of Oil and Ecology Dutch Are Returning to Bicycles by the Millions
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands  Every weekday morning, rain or shine, five million people in the Netherlands climb on their sturdy bicycles and motorbikes and go to work, school and shopping.

title: Chinese Report Population Of Tibetans is at 3 Million
description: NEW DELHI. Nov. 1 (Reuters)China has reported that three million Tibetans live in Tibet and in the neighboring Chinese provinces of Tsinghai, Szechwan, Kansu and Yunnan.

title: A Taste of the Past: 18thCentury Cooking Over an Open Hearth
description: SOUTH ORANGEGone are the days when food courses at most adult schools were limited to Chinese or gourmet cooking. Today, the gamut runs from seafood, as it is prepared in Spain, to vegetarian and Dutch, German and Swiss cookery.

title: ECHEVERRIA SEEKS TO PRESERVE ROLE
description: MEXICO CITYPresident Luis Echeverria Alvarez is apparently seeking to preserve his political influence in Mexico after he leaves office in December next year.

title: One and a half gentlemen of the press
description: Of all the groups busily learning the Lessons of the Watergate years, none has more sorting out still to do than the press. The difference between investigative reporting and simple scandalmongering, the consequences of turning reporters into stars, the line between interpretive writing and fictional inventionthese and other complications have generally been brushed aside in the celebration of the newspaperthattoppledaPresident. It is right that some of the harder questions are starting to be asked, and, in their wildly different ways, that is what these two books try to do.

title: Grant for Minority Study
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (UPI) The University of Pennsylvania has been awarded a $50,000 grant by the Gulf Oil Corporation, which is based here, to study minority employment opportunities.

title: Museum Schedules a Lecture on Gems
description: LINCROFTCommon gemstones, fundamentals of diamonds and purchasing hints will be among the topics to be discussed by Paul Reussille, Red Bank gemologist, at the Monmouth Museum today. The program will begin at 2 P.M.

title: Bankruptcy Politics
description: By Insisting that New York City must default on its obligations and go into formal bankruptcy before any Federal aid is made available, President Ford has chosen to make the city's problems into a national political issue. He has put the manufacture of a propaganda theme ahead of governing the nation.

title: Women Play Major Election Role
description: MINEOLARecent Interviews with local candidates from both parties and spokesmen for the Nassau County Democrats and Republicans bore out the fact that one minoritywomen in politicsis entering a period of political rising expectations and apparently believe it has a niche in the county's political destiny.

title: RUBIN SIDE LEADS IN BRIDGE TOURNEY
description: PALO ALTO, Nov. 1  A powerful display on a series of difficult deals in the international bridge team trials here this afternoon put Ira Rubin of Paramus, N.J., and his team in a commanding position at the halfway stage in the final playoff match.

title: Subways Are Still Losing Riders
description: The 47 busiest subway stations in Brooklyn and Queens have, with three exceptions, continued to lose riders since 1970 in areas as diverse as Coney Island, downtown Brooklyn and Main Street, Flushing.

title: Interceptions Aid 31to10 Triumph
description: SOUTH BEND. Ind., Nov. 1Even in its drydock years, Notre Dame's football team always seems to find a way to beat Navy.

title: CONCERN IS VOICED FOR ETHIOPIA JEWS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 1 A retired social worker from Westchester County who heads an organization that supports Ethiopian Jews said here that the ancient community of Falashas, as they are called, is in danger of cultural extinction.

title: Fictions by Helprin, Koster and Harington
description: . In this first collection of short stories, the 28yearold author Mark Helprin writes with ease and sureness about a young musician in Paris, a cattlerancher in Jamaica, a young girl who works in a typewriterribbon factory, a priest who goes to Vatican II to die, a soldier assigned to burial detail before a major battle in the Civil War. He writes of these and others with a compassionate understanding and a clean, lucid prose.

title: Long Island cygnets, cobs and pens
description: In the days before our manipulative consumer society had transformed adolescence into a major commercial market, the teens were a time of intense and unexpected enthusiasms. Usually these were left behind with the teens and forgotten as people moved on to the more prosaic pursuits of their working lives. Budd Schulberg is one of the people who didn't forget. His adult life has been continuously enriched by wellcultivated adolescent enthusiasmfor birds.

title: Bountiful Cranberry Crop Is Expected
description: CHATSWORTH  There should be a bountiful supply of cranberry sauces for the Thanksgiving table this year, The harvest is now at its peak, and experts believe that the price should be about right, too.

title: The Guest Word: A Publisher's Album
description: During his 60 years in publishing, Alfred A. Knopf has been an inveterate snapshotter of the people, Knopf authors and others, he met. A selection of his portraits accompanied by reminiscent commentary has been collected into a book called Sixty Photographs (Knopf. Cloth, $10. Paper, $5.95.). Mr. Knopf modestly declares that the interest in his pictures derives mainly from the subject not the photographer. The subjects, including eight Nobel Prize winners, are not, needless to say, youror hisAunt Min.

description: OXFORD, Ohio, Nov. (AP)  Sherman Smith, the quarterback, ran for three touchdowns to lead Miami of Ohio to a 3521 victory over Toledo today in a MidAmerican Conference.

description: EDGEWATER  For the Meehan family being involved in politics is second nature.

Kremlin may have in store for the man who has just been awarded the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize. To read the Soviet press on Dr. Sakharov is to get the impression that Joseph Stalin has come back to life.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It's nice to have wishes come true. When J. F. Burke's Location Shots was published early in 1974, many reviewers around the country hoped to meet Samuel Moses Kelly once more. Kelly was the hotel dick/private eye hero of the Burke book. He was black, raffish. tough and operated out of a hotel on Manhattan's West Side a seedy hotel that all too obviously was patterned atter the Ansonia on Broadway and 73d Street. He had a blonde girlfriend who looked goyish but was Jewish; she was a madam who operated a string of call girls but never plied her trade herself.

title: 11 Queens Libraries Kept Open By Protests
description: Eleven Queens public libraries scheduled to close yesterday will remain open until at least Nov. 15 because of strong, community protests and a racial discrimination suit filed in Federal court last week by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

His fantasy takes a frightening, but exhilarating step towards reality when Kip Statler, total jock, moves next door. Offering friendship, and the chance to team up with a winner, Kip infuses Mike with a will to win that carries him through a vic

description: Serglu Luca, violinist, and Emanuel Ax, pixnist, two of our younger musical artists of major talent, joined forces at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night to play violin and piano sonatas by Dvorak, Janacek and Bart& (No. 1).

title: Dave Anderson
description: Weary and dripping with perspiration, O. J. Simpson calls to a clubhouse boy in Atlanta Stadium for Coke after having galloped through the Falcons for 137 yards, a somewhat routine performance for the Buffalo Bills running back two seasons ago when he set a National Football League record with 2.003 yards. Before the clubhouse boy returned with the soft drink, O. J. was surrounded by newsmen. Patiently, the youngster waited outside the circle of newsmen for more than half an hour as O. J. answered questions. When the newsmen began to drift away, O. J. remembered the Coke and thanked the youngster. But on the first swallow, O. J shook his head.

title: Ford's Testimony Is Recorded for Fromme Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) President Ford gave videotaped testimony today as a defense witness in the California trial of Lynette Alice Fromme, who has been charged with attempting to assassinate him.

title: KEEP OPEN ADMISSIONS OF; For five years, the City University has offered an education to all highschool graduates. How have they done? Has quality education suffered? The questions may become pointless if the financial crunch worsens.
description: On April 22d, 1969, a group of students, most of them black, seized the South Campus of the City College of New York. In the popular mind, City is a fabled place. In the nineteenthirties, the brightest highschool graduates could not find jobs, so many of them eked out a Depression existence and studied at C.C.N.Y. The school became known as a proletarian Harvard, the only elite institution ever owned by the man in the street. Now black radicals were attacking City Collegeand the entire City University of New York (CUNY)on the grounds that they discriminated against the poor and the minorities. A mayoral campaign was in progress and the handling of the issue immediately became the subject of intense political debate. Mario Procaccino, the Democratic candidate, went to court to force the authorities to reopen C.C.N.Y., which had been closed down out of fear of violence. Then there was a fire in the Great Hall on the City campus.

title: Planners Approve Expansion of Dairy
description: Expansion of the Elmhurst Dairy in the South Jamaica section of Queens, bitterly opposed by neighboring owners of automobile junkyards, has been approved by the City Planning Commission on the ground that the preservation of the dairy industry is an important goal of New York City.

title: Voter Apathy of Concern in Suffolk
description: SELDENA major concern among candidates running in Suffolk County's general elections Tuesday is that too few voters will show up at the polls.

title: US. Is Moving to Control All of the Waterways
description: HAUPPAUGEDespite misgivings voiced by some Eastern Long Island towns that see home rule threatened, the Army Corps of Engineers is expected to adopt soon measures that eventually would give the Federal Government control over all the waters and wetlands in the nation.

title: PREMED STUDENTS RUIN RIVAS'
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. (AP)  John Hammarley had strong inspiration to become a doctorthe personal interest of a famous surgeon, Dr. Norman Shumway, who twice had given his ailing father a new heart.

title: Montclair Offering painting of Month
description: MONTCLAIRThe Montclair Museum has hit upon the ingenious idea of using its permanent collection in a new and refreshing way.

title: Losing String Ends at 34
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 1The longest losing streak In small college tootball ended today when Swarthmore defeated Muhlenberg, 1612. The Little Quakers hadn't won a game since November 1970, dropping 34 in a row.

title: New Life Is Returning to a LongDead Section of Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITYTwo blocks south of the Holland Tunnel toll booths, in the shadow of the meatpacking houses, a longdead, eightsquareblock section of this city is returning to life.

title: Group Winners Are Undecided In European Title Soccer Play
description: The European countries divide themselves into eight soccer playing groups every four years and compete for the European Championship. The competition, which used to be known as the Nations Cup, held between World Cup years. It keeps the national teams of each country busy and making money for their respective federations. West Germany won the competition in 1972, and it is one of the favorites for the prize in 1976, which is two years after the last World Cup final and two years before the next one in 1978. Besides West Germany, the Netherlands and England loom as the strongest candidates, although England lost to Czechoslovakia, 21, last Thursday in Bratislava.

title: Court Reform Proposals Overshadowed on Ballot
description: For the last two years, the two courtreform amendments on the ballot Tuesday have been the subject of intense, often hostile, debate among legislators and judges.

description: ITHACA, N. Y. Nov. 1Doug Jackson and Mike Delaney led Columbia to a 4219 victory over Cornell before a chilled crowd of 11,000 at Schoelkopf Field today settling two questions with one blow: Who owns New York and who is the Ivy League's cellar dweller?

title: Cholera Kills 3 in Portugal
description: COIMBRA, Portugal, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Three people have died of cholera in central Portugal and 200 other cases of the disease have been reported in the last few days, health, authorities have reported. They said the outbreak was probably caused by infected cockles from the estuary of the Mondego River, which flows through this old university town.

title: Unit Set Up to Muster Volunteer City Aid
description: Whether the city defaults or not, a group of prominent New Yorkers led by Osborn Elliott, chairman of the board and editor in chief of Newsweek, has decided that the best rernedy to the fiscal crisis available to the average citizen is a huge venture in selfhelp.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: One of the curiosities of the modern art world is the frequency with which magazine and documentary photographers who never set out to be recognized as artists are elevated to that rank by the guardians of our cultural heritage. A few museum and gallery exhibitions, a few respectful mentions by the right writers, and suddenly a mere street photographer is transformed into a charismatic figure of modern art.

title: China Says U.S. and Soviet Vie for Control of Iceland
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 1 (Agence FrancePresse)China has accused the United States and the Soviet Union of stepping up their rivalry to control Iceland.

title: LILCO Hearings This Week

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 1 (AP)Kansas State placed five of its runners among the top 10 finishers today in the Big Eight Conference crosscountry championships. Paced by Jeff Schemmel, Kansas State recorded its 10th Big Eight title. Schemmel led all the way to take individual honors in 25 minutes 22 seconds. Kansas State had a score of 25. Colorado was second with 73 points, followed by Iowa State University 87, Oklahoma State 96, Missouri 105, Oklahoma 127, Kansas 136, Nebraska 214.

Powers's work since Morte D'Urban, his only novel, won the National Book Award in 1963. It is nearly twenty years now since his last collection of short stories, the widely acclaimed Presence of Grace. Unfortunately for Powers's admirers (and I confess to be one) his new book is disappointment. Look

description: The 23rd Congregational Church Antiques Fair will be held opposite B. Altman & Co. in Manhasset on Tuesday through Thursday from noon to 10 P.M. and on Friday to 5 P.M

title: City to Be Seeking Ft. Totten as Park
description: The city's Parks Administration has received approval of the Board of Estimate to apply for 10.6 acres of land at Fort Totten on Little Neck Bay in Queens for eventual development of a recreational area.

title: Va. Tech Defeats Wm. and Mary. 247
description: NORFOLK. Va.. Nov. 1 (AP)  Michael Barnes and Phil Rogers each scored a touchdown in leading Virginia Tech to a 247 victory over William and Mary today in the 29th annual Oyster Bowl.

description: Opening This Week

title: The definitive Bernard Shaw
description: To review the Definitive Edition of Bernard Shaw's plays means to reread his oeuyre of 52 stage works and rethink Shaw's place in today's theater and letterswhich, in turn, means confronting one of the more curious cases in modern literature. For Shaw has, after enormous success, proceeded neither to a peaceful place in the Pantheon of continued popularity and respect, nor fallen into the blatant eclipse that sometimes unjustly overtakes celebrity before fatherkilling is duly su perseded by ancestorworship. With Shaw, it is not just a case of his reputation having reached that uncertain age, too old to be loved, too young to be venerated; rather, the animus of some of his most brilliant contemporaries continues to hound him a quartercentury after his death, even as legions of solid citizens maintain his flame burning at mediumhigh. Emble matically, our Canadian neighbors have a successfully ongoing Shaw Festival while our own most influential drama critic persists in considering Neil Simon more entertaining than Shaw.

title: Stony Brook Ties Miller Place, 1212
description: Kevin Forte passed 20 yards to Walt Brown for a fourthquarter Stony Brook touchdown yesterday that gave Stony Brook a 1212 tie with Miller Place. Stony Brook had lost 20 straight games before yesterday, but it missed a victory when a conversion run failed after the tying touchdown.

title: BRAIN HARM IN U.S. LAID TO FOOD LACK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 More than a million American infants and young children have either suffered stunting of their brains or are under risk of that kind of damage because Of maunutrition, a team of scientists has estimated on the basis of national nutrition data.

The composite index of leading indicators declined in September after seven months of increases. The August index, however was revised upward  The United States balance of trade registered a surplus of $976million, in September, the lowest since. April, reflecting an increase of oil and sugar imports. For the first nine months the U.S. showed a surplus of $8.4billion, compared with a $1.8billion surplus for the comparable 1974 period

The spokesman said the wedding took place last Wednesday in Puertecitos, Baja California. It was the first marriage for Miss Richard, 21 years old, who was Miss Louisiana in the 1973 Miss World contest. Mr. Fisher, 47, was formerly married to Debbie Reynolds, Elizabeth Taylor and Connie

title: For the Birth Damaged
description: Less thannormal lives are being led today by millions of persons because of the impact of such birth defects as mongolism and sicklecell anemia, among others. Authorities estimate that more than a million people reed hospital treatment each year because of such birth disorders.

description: Mike Butynes of Post College, runnerup last year, won individual honors yesterday in the 23d annual Collegiate Track Conference crosscountry championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: He's Boyish, He's Open, He's a Natural!
description: It was just five years ago that 20yearold Jeff Bridges, looking like a blond beach burn and with only two minor movies under his belt (one of which was never to be released), walked into direc for Peter Bogdanovich's office to audition for a role in The Last Picture Show. Bogdanovich did his best Jerry Lewis double take, Bridges remembers, and exclaimed: Jesus, you're the guy I'm looking for, but can you act? Nobody has asked that question lately.

description: An open house will be held today at the Vanderveer Park United Methodist Church at Glenwood Road and East 31st Street in the Flathush section of Brooklyn from 2 to 5 P.M.

description: Nothing lifts wintry spirits more than pots of tulips and daffodil bulb blooming in the living moms. Anyone can have them by planting a few pots of these bulbs now so they will grow roots and be ready for forcing when winter is cold and bleak.

At the edge of the swirling, pebbleclear Lorrain River, women pounded dirty clothes into submission while their children splashed and shrieked in the shade cast by a wooden, onelane. overhead bridee_

description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)A group of nuclear arms experts believes that nuclear war is likely to erupt by the end of this century and that a very nasty kind of world government may be the only way to prevent it.

description: Twice Born is the case history of an adopted child, told by that child, now grown. It is also a parable about the search for identity. The beginnings of this history were rooted in a natural curiosity, in childhood, about beginnings. At that time the adoptive mother nade the obligatory formal announcement about adoption to her then, 7yearold, adopted daughter. She feigned ignorance about the details and filled in of the blanks with

description: Letitia Chandler Lynn was married yesterday afternoon to Dominicus Rytis Valiunas in St. Luke's Chapel of Trinity Parish in Greenwich Village.

title: Kidnapped Briton Called Well
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Basil BurwoodTaylor, the honorary British Consul in Asmara who was kidnapped nine days ago is alive and well, according to a message received by his wife, a British Embassy spokesman said today. It was the first word of Mr. BurwoodTaylor's situation since he was seized by kidnappers in the Eritrean capital on Oct. 23.

title: Concert

description: TRENTON  Dr. Kemble Widmer of Princeton, a geologist and researcher of the American Revolution, will talk on the American Revolution and Its Citizens at a program to be held Nov. 16 at State Museum auditorium, 225 West State Street.

title: U.M.W. Aids Pension Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI)The United Mine Workers has announced it will make loans of up to $3million to guarantee the solvency of a hardpressed pension fund for anthracite coal miners. The union's executive board voted unanimously to make the loans after the Federal Government refused to come to the aid of the Anthracite Pension Fund.

title: Two pens and a world full of swords
description: Propaganda is the pornography of revolution: It titillates, instructs and, in its way, informs an eager audience. But it does not connect. At some critical juncture in their lives, most radical writers find that they would rather make revolution than write about it. Ever after, they work for ways to close the lingering distance between their pens and others swords.

title: Dulcia Coast Victor; No Bias Wins Here
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Nov. 1Dulcia, a 6yearold mare from Argentina, scored a stunning victory today as Bill Shoemaker brought her from last to heat Royal Glint by a neck in the first running of the $350,000 National Thoroughbred Championship at Santa Anita.

title: TV Notes: Who Jockeyed ABC Into First Place?
description: Of the brand names in network television, the one moving up in the market this year is ABC. The fact deserves attention because ABC is usually the brand left on the shelf. During the week ending Oct. 12, ABC was actually No. 1 in the

title: Encounter in Malta: You Have to Let Her Win. It's All She Has
description: THE road wound up through rockstrewn fields, gradually narrowing until it was a dusty lane, with the rocks swept into high stone hedges on both sides. They hid our rattling car from the farmers on the melon fields, and obscured from us all but the blazing Mediterranean blue sky. The October day in Malta was dazzling as spring. Then the rock walls fell away again, as the road descended and widened. Prickly pear trees took their place giant mouseears bristling with spikes, a sullen green against the dustcolored fields.

title: Peddling Restricted at Brooklyn College
description: Student peddling, a proliferating practice on college campuses these days, received a thumbs down last week from the administration of Brooklyn College.

title: CARTER'S SUPPORT IN SOUTH IS BROAD
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 1Jimmy Carter, the former Governor of Georgia, has captured broad support for the Democratic Presidential nomination among the progressive activists of the South in what could be vitally important complement to his progress in Iowa and, to his efforts in the early camoaign battlegrounds in North.

title: Simon and Garfunkel Last Time Together?
description: No American pop group was better liked or more successful in the sixties than Simon and Garfunkel, the team that fashioned what seemed an endless string of hitsfrom The Sounds of Silence to Mrs. Robinson, Bridge Over Troubled Waters and The Boxerbefore going their separate ways at the end of the decade. Now five years later, Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel have reunited to sing one song, which may be the best Simon has ever written.

description: Coach Bill Arnsparger was the first to admit that the Giants 3524 victory over the San Diego Chargers here yesterday wasn't pretty, but did it have to be a Frankenstein Meets Dracula horror show?

description: Outgoing

title: What's Doing in PALM BEACH
description: THE SETTINGPalm Beach acknowledges three compass pointsnorth and south, which mark the length of its 14mile strip, and east, which is the side that faces the Atlantic Ocean. On the other side is West Palm Beach which is supposed to be its sister city; but the sisters have a nodding acquaintance, hardly an intimacy. Palm Beachers mainly cross the town's three island bridges (the Marjorie Merriweather Post Memorial Causeway, the Royal Park Bridge and the Flagler Memorial Bridge) to go to the Good Samaritan Hospital, St. Mary's Hospital or to see an occasional movie. (There is only one cinema in Palm Beach and that will soon be torn down.) As to Miami, its neighbor to the south, Palm Beach is 68 miles and one thousand light years away. Palm Beach would prefer to ignore the creeping condominiums that have sprung up like poison ivy on its southern end. They are a threat to the cream  colored, well  manicured, stageset playground of the rich. So the Social Register has gone underground. They emerge like the groundhog  not in early spring but in high seasonto appear at charity balls, to frequent private parties or to go to their exclusive clubs. That chic understated longlegged lass undulating down Worth Avenue, with her Gucci bag keeping rhythm with her rotating hips, is not the socialite you think you've spotted, but an avid tourist from New Rochelle who is looking at you and wondering if you are anybody in the

title: HEARST CASE PUTS MANY IN TROUBLE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1Trouble continues to befall those who helped Patricia Hearst while she lived for 17 months as a fugitive from Federal bank robbery charges.

title: Canada Likes U.S. TVWithout Ads
description: OTTAWA  WWNY, the television channel in Watertown, N. Y., begins its broadcast day by playing The StarSpangled Banner and O Canada with the Canadian maple leaf flag flying right beside the stars and stripes.

title: Peter PearsThe Voice That Inspired Britten
description: Few critics would dispute the fact that Peter Pears is the preeminent English tenor of our age. To be sure, there are other tenors whose voices possess greater power and amplitude, who command a more varied vocal palette and have a wider range of roles. Pears however more than compensates for these conventional virtues with qualities that are uniquely his own. His tone, although modest, is impeccably pure; his diction is flawless; his intonation is true.

title: Finklin Leads C. W. Post To 6th Triumph, 24 to 13
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Nov. 1 Major Finklin, a senior tailback, rushed for 118 yards and scored two touchdowns and led C. W. Post to a 2913 victory over Northeastern University today.

title: Urban Azriculture to Be Discussed at Food Conference Saturday in Brooklyn
description: Guerrilla agricultureor the innovations and techniques that constitute a new surge in city horticulturewill be the focus of an upcoming, daylong Big Apple Farm and Food Conference to be held in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Spain Today: Law and Order and a Sense That Change Is Needed
description: MADRIDThe Spain that Generalissimo Francisco Franco Is leaving to his successor, Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, is much different from the one that he took over at the end of three years of civil war in 1939. But the political tystem he clamped down on the country almost four decades ago is basically unchanged and consequently has become Spain's greatest anomaly and most acute problem.

title: SELLING OF NOTES TO PUBLIC STUDIED
description: MERRICK, LI., NOV. 1 Concerned about the increasingly high cost of borrowing money from conventional sources as a result of New York City's fiscal plight, the Merrick School Board is exploring the possibility of selling shortterm county taxanticipation notes directly to the public in an effort to save on interest costs.

title: Nebraska Beats Missouri, 307
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 1 (AP)Nebraska scored on a fake punt play, with John O'Leary running 40 yards for a touchdown, and Vince Forragamo threw three scoring passes as the thirdranked Cornhuskers defeated Missouri, 307, In a Big Eight.Conference game today. The victory gave Nebraska an 80 wonlost record.

title: INVESTING
description: The Canadian oil and gas industry, devastated by a year and a half of political uncertainty, is beginning to recover.

title: Kings Point Routs Hofstra, 367
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 1The midshipmen who enjoyed the greatest job Otisfaction on the football field today were the two who fired an assertive salutecannon in the end zone every time the United States Merchant Marine Academy scored.

title: Roosevelt Takes VIII Lead
description: Roosevelt, a team rarely seen at the top of its conference in recent years, whipped Oyster Bay yesterday, 180, and took sole possession of first place in Conference VIII with a 44 record.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Toward the end of Milestones, an idiosyncratic, epic new American film by Robert Kramer and John Douglas, two men walk along a highway on the edge of what seems to be Detroit. The empty urban landscape has the desolate look of something marked for a renewal that will never come. In the distance we see the silhouettes of downtown office buildings. One of the men has a mustache. The other is bearded to the point of being as fully maned as a lion. They wear jeans and wind breakers and talk about old friends, about family relationships, about the Movement, a collective noun for the once New Left.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Tenafly, N. J., man was held in the Bergen County jail on charges of breaking and entering, while the police sought to determine if he was connected with the deaths of two young New Jersey women whose bodies were found last week in Rockland County. Robert R. Reldon, 35 years old, was arrested for atempting to rob the home of Richard Leeds in Closter, N.J. The police said they had not linked Mr Reldon to the deaths of Susan Reeve, 22, of Demarest, and Susan Heynes, 28, o fHaworth, but he was being held without bail.

title: Why Cuban Athletes Succeed
description: In the PanAmerican Games, which ended last Sunday in Mexico City, athletes from the United States won 38 per cent of the medals, a strong showing. Athletes from Cuba, with perhaps 5 per cent of the population of the United States, won 20 per cent of the medals, an astounding performance.

title: DoOvers
description: Tilden had two touchdowns called back in the third quarter yesterday in its 136 P.S.A.L. loss at home John Jay. The Division B Section I meeting developed into a brawl that saw three Tilden players tossed out, the police called in to maintain order and the Tilden Coach, Bernie Mars. lock his players in the dressing room avoid a postgame fight.

title: Benefit for Bennington
description: Bennington College will benefit from the Nov. 17 preview of Habeas Corpus at the Martin Beck Theater. Tickets, $50, $40 and $30, may he obtained front Ruth A. Nicholson, 130 East 63d Street.

title: NEW LAW BALKED FORD FRIDRAISER
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 1As a political fundraiser, David Packard had a double problem: He raised too little money in to large amounts.

title: Florida Defeats Auburn, 3114, To Stay Tied for First in S.E.C.
description: AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 1 (UPI) Jimmy DuBose rushed for 149 yards and one touchdown and Jimmy Fisher threw two scoring passes today to lead 10thranked Florida o a 3114 Southeastern Conference victory over Auburn.

title: Can a woman be liberated and married?
description: I can remember the exact moment when I was sure I was part of a liberated marriage. We were driving along a city street, my husband Alan at the wheel and the two kids, Steven, 8, and Alyssa, 5, in the back seat. Alyssa was clutching a grimy but beloved doll and tugging at the doll's equally grimy and shopworn dress. The overworked threads gave out and the sleeve pulled off. Alyssa looked at the sleeve and then, ignoring me, handed it to my husband and said, Will you sew it for me, Daddy?

title: City to Turn Off Lights In MoneySaving Move
description: The strings of decorative lights on the four East River bridges will not be turned on after dark and illumination of city playgrounds, parks, monuments and major highways will be reduced soon to trim $1.06million from the city's annual electrical costs of $120million.

title: 400,000 More Seats For 1976 Olympics Allocated for U.S.
description: More than 400.000 additional tickets for specific events in nest summer's Olympic Games in Montreal have been allocated to the United States, the Canadian Olympic Organizing Committee announced last week. They will be sold exclusively through Montgomery Ward stores and the Montgomery Ward Auto Club.

description: Canarsie scored with 20 seconds to play yesterday and defeated Brooklyn Tech, 128. in a Public Schools Athletic League Division A Section I game. Canarsie will meet Jefferson next Saturday for the section title.

description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON  In the main gymnasium of the West Hill Kindergarten Center  formerly the West Hill Elementary School  the dividing wall had been moved to make way for a 30foot parachute to be opened up and flattened out on the floor.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1It took Harvard, the Ivy League leader, just 3 minutes 58 seconds to score its first touchdown today in Franklin Field, and from there the Crimson went on to a 213 victory over Pennsylvania.

description: Being famous is quite nice at times, and not so nice at others. It's pleasant being recognized, and unpleasant being mobbed.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Senate officials last year cited the party organization of Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago for not filing required campaign financing reports, but the JusLice Department dropped the case without action, according to informed Government sources.

Yesterday afternoon, Dermot Burke made his first appear ance in the leading role of Death in Kurt Jooss's The Green Table, and Friday night Josh LimOn's The Moor's Pavane was added to the repertory for the first

title: Hidetoshi Tamura Weds Miss Bestecka
description: Ursula Bestecka, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Bestecki of New York, was married in Japan yesterday to Hidetoshi Tamura, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riichi Tamura of Tokyo. The Rev. Kodel Sato, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of SS. Peter and Paul in Koriyama, a Tokyo suburb.

description: EHRLICHLouls. UnveilIns on Sunday, Nov. 9, at 1:30, Cemetery Knoll Wood Park. Brooklyn, N.Y., Section E, Plot 449450. tin postponement.
