title: The Bowling Clinic
description: About 60 million people bowl at least once a week the National Bowling Council reports after an extensive survey, which means there are close to that many bowling styles. Some methods employed to get strikes are so novel that Candid Camera captured them on film in years past.

title: Adventures of Solzhenitsyn
description: Most journalists dream of writing novels in which they reveal truths that cannot be told when limited to the space of a newspaper or magazine article and the kind of facts that seldom let the truth shine through. Harrison Salisbury has chosen a dangerous truth as the subject of the roman clef he has written to fulfill that dream: the life of Aleksandr

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Is there a legal right to die? Is there a point beyond which life need no longer be preserved through technical means? These are among the questions that face the New Jersey judge who must make a decision in the Karen Quinlan case. The case has no clear precedents, and so his decision itself will become a precedent. The ruling also is likely to begin, rather than end, debate in the medical profession.

title: Isaac Bashevis Singer, also known as I
description: In The New Year Party, one of 20 stories in Isaac Bashevis Singer's new collection, a middleaged writer named I is going to a literary gathering: Riding along, I reproached myself for avoiding other writers and for staying away from their meetings and parties. The trouble was that the moment I met them they would give me the latest gossip of what this one had said of me and what another had written. Leftist writers xolded me for failing to promote world revolutions. The Zionists reproached me

title: Hester Street'Overpraised and Overdone
description: You evidently don't have to be Jewish to love Hester Street. Reviewers of diverse persuasions have found this film, set on the Lower East Side in 1896, sufficiently to their liking to provide copy for advertisements  pro

title: Vanity Books: Pay or Perish
description: Hal Fahner, a Chicagoarea sales executive, wrote a manuscript that no publisher would buy. So Mr. Fahner did what more people than ever seem to be doing these days: He bought a publisher.

title: 4 Americans Well Treated
description: WASHINGTON, Nov 1 State Department officials said they had received information that the four Americans held captive in Eritrea were being well treated.

title: Why the Russians Dance Circles Around Us
description: During the current dance season, Mikhail Baryshnilcov, Natalia Makarova and Rudolf Nureyev, three of the greatest dancers in the world, will be appearing with American Ballet Theater. We will be seeing Nureyev for the next two weeks in his own production of Raymonda'; Makarova and Baryshnikov will be dancing during Ballet Theater's sixweek repertory season that begins Dec. 22. These strong presences among usat different stages of their careersrepresent the most important infusion of Russian classical dancing since Diaghilev's Ballets Russes and the arrival of Balanchine. The Russian defectors constitute an elite and restless society of stars in search of Western partners, choreographers and companies. Behind the publicity, the jetting around the globe, the talk about superstars and the backstage gossip lie crucially important questions about dance. In what ways are the Russian dancers superior to American

title: Horace Mann Is Victor On Rabinowitz Heroics
description: Richard Rabinowitz ran, passed and kicked Horace Mann to a 1612 victory over Montclair Academy yesterday. Rabinowitz, a senior flanker, scored the first touchdown on a 23yard run and later threw a halfback pass of 54 yards to Mike Xohen for the other touchdown.

title: Colgate Fence Stirs Dispute on Land Rights in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITYThe state has put the ColgatePalmolive Company on notice that New Jersey holds riparian rights to the eightblock area around which the concern is erecting a fence for security reasons.

title: COLORADO RAMBLE IS DANCED BY PEREZ
description: Chaos is the unseen but not unfelt presence hovering over the work of movement coltagists, where one false move tan dissolve the focus of an otherwise carefully prepared dance schema. Rudy Perez, perhaps the most accomplished practitioner of the genre, rarely makes such a misstep. He showed has new and striking Colorado Ramble at Marymount Manhattan Theater on Friday evening.

title: ALAN BLACKMER, 72, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Alan R. Blackmer, who retired in 1968 as dean of faculty of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., after .43 years as an English teacher and innovative administratoc, died yesterday of cancer at his home in New London, N.H. He was 72 years old.

title: Home Clinic

We want to change the color to a tudor brown, but I have been given conflicting information on the kind of paint to use, how long it will last, and whether it will stick to aluminum. title: U.S.C. Ig Shocked By California, 2814
description: BERKELEY, Calif.. Nov. 1 (UPI)Chuck Muncie upstaged Ricky Bell today in a showcase performance that keyed California to a 2814 upset over fourthranked Southern California. Muncie rushed for 146 yards and grabbed six passes for 62 more in helping the Bears beat the Trojans for the first time in five seasons. The victory gave California a 41 wonlost record in the Pacific8 conference and a 53 mark over all. The Trojans lost their first game of the year after seven victories and had their undefeated string snapped at 18. Muncie did not score any of the Bears four touchdowns but he was the player who kept all four drives going and made most of the key yardage.

title: G. B. Shaw at 119 Indications of Immortality

At his own request he was returned to his home where, in the early morning, just 25 years ago today, he died.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The deliberate creation of folk materials by sophisticates for sophisticates is one of the riskiest tasks literaturein the theater or out of itcan undertake. Scott Joplin took his risks one way, Isaac Bashevis Singer takes them in another, anyone who aspires to the fabrication of legend long after the time of natural Iegenas and natural innocence is over and done with is doing a wirewalking act, without a net. Legend, folk fantasy, is the kind of thing that seems never to have been born but to have been plucked in passing from a bush or overheard as a tune drifting downwind; to force it into existence, to cultivate its qualities knowingly, is to rob it of its spontaneity and chance producing a folkfake. Mr. Joplin was surely flirting with a possible folkfake when he strove, in Treemonisha, to adapt the native imagery of backwoods Arkansasconjur men ruling recently freed plantation blacks through superstition, a saviorheroine who would lead them to literacy found as a babe beneath a treeto the musical structures of Sir Arthur Sullivan, if not of Puccini. He was of course a thoroughly educated, as well as melodically inspired, musician; but education in 1910 or thereabouts still meant learning about violins from Vienna, about recitative from Italy, about counterpoint, perhaps, from Great Britain. All of which was alien to his inspiration, which came from the pain and the lift and the liquid trill of his people. The clash ought to have been headon.

title: TV VIEW
description: Broadcasting tradition has given the U. S. Presidency an extremely powerful communications tool in the form of virtually automatic access to radio and television. But what broadcasting has given, it now seems to be in the process of taking away. And the maneuvering, on all sides, is predictably intricate. The tip of the political iceberg was clearly seen several weeks ago when CBS News, joined by NBC News, refused to carry a live broadcast of President Ford's address on tax and spending cuts. The address was carried by ABC News.

The President's proposal would have shortcircuited the new budget process voted by Congress and strongly endorsed by the White House. It would also have risked a rerun of the gostop policies of 197273, which helped reelect Mr. Nixon in 1972 but set the stage for inflation and recession in the following year.

title: The Shaker way

Accustomed as he was to the cozy environment of British parlors. Charles Dickens obviously found Shaker rooms not to his liking and wrote accordingly, We walked into grim room, where several grim hats were hanging on grim pegs, and the time was grimly told by a grim clock. Dickens came away with a distinct impression of the Shaker stylespare, relatively subdued in color and entirely free of cozy clutter.

title: Britain drills

As our helicopter put the Scottish coast far behind us, the advance craft of new breed of seafarer passed below  floating drilling rigs, supply boats, platforms, pipelaying barges, singly at first, then in such profusion as almost to seem, at times, to crowd the sea.

title: The radical/teacher and the poet/teacher
description: For the past 15 years, as social upheaval has continued to batter at American life, many different people have written about public school education in this country. The moral, political and intellectual perspectives from which these people have written have been as various as the professional identities a the people themselves. Writers, educators, analysts, poets, radicals, sociologistsall have turned their attention to the education of our children. When they have been good, these observers of the education scene, they have conveyed to us a world of large meaning to be found in this particular universe of human experience; when they have been brilliant they have made us see that this world of the children is the world, our world; when they have been bad they have, sadly, made of the experience a social abstraction.

title: Last of the Black Sox
description: On the day the World Series moved from Boston to Cincinnati, a man named Charles August Risberg died in a convalescent home in Red Bluff, Calif. Death came on his 81st birthday, exactly 56 years and four days after the Cincinnati Reds won a World Series for the first time. Swede Risberg helped them win it. He was the shortstop on the Chicago White Sox, Sports the losing team. Risberg was the last of survivor among the The Times eight Chicago players identified as Black Sox in all baseball literature composed since 1920who were ruled out of the game for life for selling out the 1919 series. In the eight games he batted 080 and made four errors, contributing somewhat more to the dump than some of his accomplices, somewhat less than others. More than Fred McMullin, for example, who went to bat twice as pinchhitter and got one single. McMullin was a utility infielder nobody tried to bribe but he overheard Chick Gandil, the ringleader, propositioning Risberg, declared himself in.

title: Renting a Villa On a Greek Isle
description: TRAVELERS have been glorifying the Greek islands ever since Odysseus took that package tour from Troy to Ithaca and shared bed and breakfast with the nymph Calypso. Most modern tourists, even those of us who live in Greece, usually taste only tidbits of island lifea few hours while the cruise ship is in port, maybe a day or two at a beach resort. So we were intrigued when my wife, Cokie, saw a sign in the window of a travel agency advertising villas for rem on Skiathos. One of the few green islands of Greece, Skiathos lies off the east coast of Thessaly; a tourist brochure promised an unusual combination of thick forbeaches.

title: Notes: Airlines Woo A New Kind of V.I.P.
description: THERE has traditionally been rigid pecking order in airline travel, the firstclass passenger receiving more comfortable seats, better food, more personal attention than his lowerpaying counterpart in the economy, or coach, section of the plane. But in recent years, a new and evergrowing class of passenger has emergedthe traveler paying even io*er charter or excursion fares. The pecking order has been upset: fullfare coach passengers (usually business people) are sitting in the same seats and receiving nothing more than their excursionfare neighbors. Now, however, the cashandcasteconscious airlines are moving to redress the unbalance. Several airlines havewith no particular fanfire started giving fullfare coach customers better treatment. Typical of the programs is that recently instituted by KLM, the Dutch airline.

title: TV Station Chases Money and RatingsIt's Channel
description: As the noncommercial system, public television is often thought to have a natural exemption from the competitive and economic drives that rule other stations on the dial. But officials of public station WNET/13 here say that they, are no less preoccupied with money and ratings than comi Imercial broadcasters are  alI though in a quite different way.

title: Ship Passes Through Canal
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 2 (AP)For the first time in at least 15 years a ship carrying cargo for Israel passed through the Suez Canal today. The voyage: by a Greek freighter loaded with Rumanian cement was made possible by the new Sinai accord.

title: WOMEN'S RIGHTS AND CITY CHARTER DOMINATE BALLOT
description: The final flurry of weekend efforts to stir interest in New York's offyear election was carried out yesterday, most of the activity keyed to the two judgments that dominate the ballotwhether the state should pass a women'srights amendment to its Constitution and whether the city should pass a package of amendments to its Charter.

title: ARMS AID REQUEST STIRS CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Preliminary Congressional analysis shows that the Federal deficit would have to be increased $800 million and Congressional budgetary guidelines raised $1.8 billion to accommodate President Ford's new $4.7 billion military aid package.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROOST AND RIPPLE Larry Hamlet's keyboard singing in the lounge of the midtown Steak and Brew restaurant, in the heart of Broadway's theater district, makes for a convenient precurtain or aftershow cocktail stop, although from outside you would hardly know he was there. Pedestrians using the blocklong corridor extending from the lobby of the Edison Hotel on West 47th Street, may want to investigate the music from the Steak and Brew entrance, just before 46th Street.

title: About New York
description: New York may be the most bookmarked patch of earth in the United States. According to sources that count such things, there are 1,600 outlets alone that deal in paperbacks in Manhattan and the Bronx. It is true that, in Manhattan at least, you cannot walk too far without running into racks loaded with books whose covers fairly scream for attention.

title: Rangers Beaten by Giacomin
description: In a drama last night that would have embarrassed a pulp fiction writer, Ed Giacomin returned to Madison Square Garden in the uniform of the rival Detroit Red Wings. With the cheers of the crowd behind him, the 36yearold goalie led his new team to a 64 beating of his old teammates, the Rangers.

title: French Rider Takes First Title
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 1France scored its first Victory in the Washington International Horse Show tonight, and fittingly, it was for the President's Cup, one of the most prestigious events.

title: Merchants Expecting a Bountiful Christmas Season
description: Merchants here and in other cities, encouraged by an improving sales rate in recent months, are anticipating a better Christmas season than lasts year with a bit of extra tinsel on the tree  increased profits because of better inventory controls.

title: 150 Jewish Feminists Ponder a Conflict
description: MONTCLAIR, Nov. 2About 150 women, many carrying babies, filled a lecture hall at Montclair State College yesterday to discuss the often conflicting problems of being Jew and a woman.

title: Books of The Times
description: Nothing more really needs to be said about what the typical Donald Barthelme fiction is up to. Gailons of ink have already been spilled to show that Mr. Barthelme, the author of four collections of short stories and a novel. Snow White, is writing after the death of fiction, when language, plot, and sensibility have all been worn out, and there is nothing left to do but shuffle the trash into novel permutations. So it should come as no particular surprise that Mr. Barthelme's new novel, The Dead Father, concerns the further death of deadness. The plotor whatever one can call the novel's skeleton of eventsconcerns a man of monumental proportionsDead but still with us, still with us, but deadwho is being led on a cable through some landscape of European culture  the whole great expanse of him running Irani the Avenue Pornmard to the Boulevard Grist. His retinue consists of three childrenfigures, Thomas, Julie and Emma, and the 19 men whose job it is to haul the cable. They seem to be looking for the Golden Fleece, though it does not prethem too greatly.

title: Profits Pace Up in 3d Quarter Propelled by Inventory Cutback
description: While corporate profits in the third quarter were sharply below the record highs of last year's third quarter, they ran sharply ahead of the first two quarters of 1975.

title: HelpWanted Ad Index Is Up a Point in Month
description: The helpwanted advertising index rose to 84 per cent of the 1967 average in September, 1 point over the revised August figure and at the July level, the Conference Board said over the weekend. The index stands 23 points below the level of a year ago.

title: Power Brokers Wield Extensive Influence at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2If the boyishlooking Arab were seen sipping his mint drink anywhere except in the Delegates Lounge here, he might hardly be noticed, yet he prominently helped gather support for the divisive draft resolution that would define Zionism as a form of racism.

title: Association of Bar Rates Judicial Candidates Here
description: Thirtynine judicial candidates who declined to he interviewed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York were rated as not approved for election because of their boycott, the Manhattanbased lawyers organization said yesterday.

title: W. Byers Unger, 77, Dead; Dartmouth Zoology Teacher
description: Dr. W. Byers Unger, a retired professor of zoology at Dartmouth College, where he taught from 1925 to 1965, died yesterday at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 77 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: Fewer Policemen, Firemen on Duty After Layoffs
description: Cuts in the city's expendifi tures these days are announced as drastic and massive: Dollars in the billions, policemen, firemen and sanitation laid off by the thousands, attrition accelerated for thousands more, superagencies dismantled, possible reorganizations of the city's vast Civil Service and pension, systems.

title: Dora Merande, Comedian Of Stage and Films, Dead
description: Doro Merande, character actress whose comic portrayals of sour, whiny, witchy old women on stage, screen and television provided laughter for large audiences, died Saturday at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. She was believed to be in her 70's, but kept her age a secret.

title: Arming Egypt
description: WASHINGTONThe Ford Administration has begun to prepare American public opinion for the gift of United States planes, missiles and military communications equipment to Egypt.

title: Power Brokers Wield Extensive Influence at the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2If the boyishlooking Arab were seen sipping his mint drink anywhere except in the Delegates Lounge here, he might hardly be noticed, yet he prominently helped gather support for the divisive draft resolution that would define Zionism as a form of racism.

title: Sterile Insects Used in Coast Battle on Fruit Flies
description: LOS ANGELES. Nov. 2Agriculture inspectors crossed their fingers last week and released millions of sterile fruit flies in the hope that the in would mate with wild fruit flies and break the breeding cycle.

title: 9 Black Colleges Will Give Criminal Justice Courses
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Nine black colleges and universities will take part in a Government project to develop professional training for criminal justice careers for blacks and other minority race members. The Justice Department's Law Enforcement Assistance Administration announced $751,000 grant to finance the 18month pilot project.

title: Theater: Don Juan
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1There was an ecumenical feeling at the Yale Repertory Theater last night. Heads of other regional and institutional theaters were in attendance to congratulate Robert Brustein, artistic director of the Yale company, on the opening of his newly redone theater.

title: 30 SENATORS OPPOSE WIDE PICKETING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Opponents of an Administrationbacked bill aimed at increasing the picketing power of striking construction work: ers said today that they had enlisted the support of about 30 senators for a filibuster to block the measure.

title: ANALYSTS PONDER MONETARY EASING
description: November trading opens today on Wall Street with prospects for further easing of credit conditions by the Federal Reserve, following the strong October rally by cor

title: Marjorie Swirsky Wed To Lawrence Zelner
description: Marjorie Ann Swirsky, membership secretary at the Brooklyn Museum, was mar ried yesterday afternoon to Lawrence Zelner of New York, a founder of Zelner & Badner, Inc., management consultants. Rabbi Eugene Sack performed the ceremony in Brooklyn at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Leo Jerome Swirsky, the bride's parents.

title: Antileftist Rally Held By LebaneseAmericans
description: More than 1,000 LebaneseAmericans demonstrated yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral and later at the United Nations to protest the killing and suffering in Beirut.

title: Humphrey Emphatically Refuses to Run
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota said today more categorically than ever that he had absolutely no intention of pursuing the Democratic Pres1 idential nomination.

title: Steelers Triumph Over Bengals, 3024
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 2As far as classic confrontations go within the National Football League, today's clash between the Cincinnati Bengals and the Pittsburgh Steelers was a bit of a bust. Pittsburgh won, 3024, but the game was not as close as one might believe. The Steelers led, 233, midway through the third quarter and their defense had held the Bengals to only 87 total yards before the Cincinnati machine got going.

title: Betty Friedan Suggests Women Must Develop Economic Allies
description: HARRIMAN, N.Y., Nov. 2 Betty Friedan, one of the nation's leading feminists and a pioneer leader in the women's movement for the last decade, believes that to achieve further economic gains, women must now turn toward the rest of society to find new allies and develop innovative ideas for the reform of fundamental social institutions, such as the work week, work hours and home work.

title: DE GUSTIBUS; Leftover Egg Yolk? Feed the Plants
description: New wine in old bottles, or something like that: In a recent column concerning a business executive and playwright named Armand Aulicino, we outlined several of his recipes that employed neither egg yolks nor butter nor cream.

title: Jimmy Carter's DarkHorse Campaign Adds Gains in New England to Those in the South and Iowa
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Jimmy Carter of Georgia, being described in Iowa and in several states of the South as a frontrunner among narkhorse candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, is also making impressive strides in New England. In Vermont, where Democrats expect to have a primary on March 2, Gov. Thomas P. Salmon commented last week, If I had to say who I sense is ahead at this point, it's Jimmy Carter. Robert Brannon will resign as party chairman in Vermont this month to join the Carter organization. In Maine, George Mitchell, the Democratic nominee for Governor last year, commented, The only activity that appears to exist is what Jimmy Carter is doing.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Alarm Foils Museum Burglary; 2 Held

title: Hearings Set on Use of Fund To Help Stem Youth Crime
description: Citing a soaring increase in juvenile crime, Frank J. Rogers, Commissioner of the State Division of Criminal Justice Services, has scheduled two days of hearings, here and in Albany to establish priorities for Federal funds available under a 1974 law authorizing grants to communitybased programs to prevent delinquency and seek rehabilitation.

title: Officer Who Questioned Missile Safety Is Ousted
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 2 (UPI)  The Air Force has officially dismissed an officer who questioned the safety of the American nuclear missile launching system. The Air Force Secretary approved the recommendation of a Warren Air Force aBse board of review that Maj. Harold L. Hering, 38 years old, of Mount Carmel, III., be retired.

title: Golf Club Sought in Greenwich Slaying
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 2 The Greenwich police issued a nationwide alarm tonight for the grip and shaft of a stainless steel golf club used in the bludgeoning death of 15yearold Martha Moxley last week.

title: Drug Is Found In Boxer's System
description: PHILADELPHIA. Nov. 2 (AP)  A member of the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission says a form of amphetamine was found in the system of a heavyweight boxer, Rochelle Norris, after he was knocked out by Duane Bobick on Oct. 14.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are interested in purchasing disabilityincome insurance, three distinct types individual, group and associationmay be available.

title: Civil War in Angola
description: With only eight days to go before Portugal's target date for granting independence to Angola, the prospects for peaceful transition to a viable African government in that country are nonexistent. The Marxistled Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), which controls the capital of Luanda, will undoubtedly go through the charade of setting up a Government National Union, but such a regime will control only portion of the national territory.

title: BEALL CHALLENGES CRITICISM BY AGNEW
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP)George Beall, former United States Attorney, who prosecuted Spiro T. Agnew, has reacted sharply to the former Vice President's statements charging that the Government case against him rested entirely on testimony of persons seeking to save their own necks.

title: Beirut Calmer Under a New Truce Plan,
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2A comparative calm prevailed here today as special committees representing rival factions began the long process of enforcing the 12th ceasefire in six weeks.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1975

title: Copperweld Loses in Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 (AP) The Copperweld Corporation, la major metal fabricator, has llost its bid to stop the takeover of the corporation. A threejudge appeals panel denied Copperweld's request Friday for an injunction against Societe metal, part of the to Rothschild empire, to buy the corporation. Copperweld's chairman, Phillip Smith, said his corporation now intends to reevaluate its appeal.

title: Candidates for Election
description: Following is a list of the raneidates for public office whose names will appear on the ballot in tomorrow's election, Party abbreviations are: R.. Republican; D., Democratic, C., Conservative: L., Liberal; U., United Tax Payers Party.

title: Services Today for Youth Found Dead in Raritan River
description: SAYERVILLE, Nov. 2 (UPI) Funeral services are scheduled tomorrow for a 17yearold Sayerville youth whose body was found last week floating in a branch of the'Raritan River with two bullets in the chest.

title: Reuss Says Some in G.O.P. Will Back Vote on City Aid
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss predicted yesterday that a number of Republican Congressmen who were turned off by President Ford's position opposing loan guarantees for New York City would support the House Banking Committee measure when it comes before the full committee today.

title: State G.O.P. Worried by Ford
description: Two days after President Ford's speech in which he promised to veto any bills providing Federal loan guarantees for New York City, State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx RepubliIan leader, was still steaming. He's throwing New York City to the dogs, and he's got no business doing it, the Senator said. It's destructive of the whole Republican party in the state.

title: FORD DISCHARGES SCHLESINGER AND COLBY AND ASKS KISSINGER TO GIVE UP HIS SECURITY POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2President Ford has dismissed Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger and William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence, in a major shuffling of his top national security posts.

title: RABIN SAYS U.S. RENEGES ON PACT
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 2Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin charged today that the United States had reneged on a commitment concerning American aid made by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger when he mediated the interim agreement on Sinai between Israel and Egypt.

title: President and Sadat Confer on Lebanon At Florida Meeting
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. President Ford and President Anwar elSadat of Egypt discussed the worsening civil strife in Lebanon here today I against a backdrop of awareness that neither the United States nor Egypt was in a position to intervene.

title: MANGIONE ENSEMBLE PLAYS AT CARNEGIE
description: Chuck Mangione, a musical son of Stan Kenton tempered by Henry Mancini, brought 34piece orchestra to Carnegie Hall cm Saturday evening to play his own compositions and arrangements.

title: $258,000 in Jewels Is Stolen From a Room in Regency Hotel
description: Jewels valued at $258,000 were reported stolen last night from a room at the Regency Hotel at Park Avenue and 61st Street, the police said.

title: EDUCATION BOARD CHIDED IN NEWARK
description: TRENTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)A special agent assigned to oversee fiscal reforms in the Newark school system said yesterday that past troubles had resulted from political interference by the Board of Education that had precipitated crises and harassed administrators.

title: 30 in Dance Hall Hurt In Panic Over Tear Gas
description: MOULTRIE, Ga., Nov. 2 (AP)  About 30 persons were injured, several seriously, in a rush for the door after a man detonated a tear gas canister inside a crowded dance hall last night, the authorities said. The man was not found.

title: Two Novices Are in FourWay Race In Essex County for 2 Assembly Seats
description: IRVINGTON, Nov. 2Ruth Margules a Republican, has much in common with Peter Shapiro, one of her Democratic opponents in the fourway race for two Assembly seats in the 28th District.

title: Bills Beat Jets. 2423
description: The Buffalo Bills defeated the New York Jets, 2423, yesterday at Shea Stadium cm a late touchdown pass play from Joe Ferguson to O.J. Sampson that covered 64 yards. Details on Page 51.

title: Jets Key Call SecondGuessed
description: They wait all spring, summer and fall for the Jets to return to Shea Stadium. And when the team does arrive, the fans have only seven chances to see them live.

title: Melvin Graff, a Cartoonist Of Captain Easy
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 2 (AP) Melvin J. Graff, a retired artist who drew the syndicated Sunday comic strip Captain Easy from 1959 to 1969, died yesterday after a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: THE LEADERS
description: 1Richard Petty, Dodge; SOO lays; 2:74:49; 97:02 m.p.h.; 56,835. 2Lennie Pond, Chevrolet, 499; 54,660. 3Darrel Waltrip, Chevrolet, 498; 53.305. 4Dave Marcia, Dodge, 494; 52.025. 5Benny Parsons, Chevrolet, 486; 51,500. 6Dick Brooks. Ford, 479; 51,200. 7 Coo Coo Marlin, Chevrolet, 478; 11,140. 8Cecil Gordon, Chevrolet, 450; 51,000. 9James Hylton, Chevrolet, 469; 5960. 13Bruce Hill, Chevrolet, 464; 5850.

title: Air of Uncertainty Dogs Coney Island
description: It is not easy to associate the seaside resort town of old people's memories  where waiters jobs were plentiful and visitors slept on the beach all night  with the desolate, rubblestrewn community that much of Coney Island has become over the years.

title: Udall's Guards Question Man in New Hampshire
description: LEBANON, N.H., Nov. 2 (UPI) Secret Service agents guarding a Presidential candidate, Representative Morris Udall, Democrat of Arizona, questioned and detained a New Jersey man this weekend for four hours before Mr. Udall arrived to campaign.

title: Yonkers Looks to Banking Group to Avert a Default
description: YONKERS, Nov. 2  The prospects of Yonkers's avoiding default have brightened, with imany of the city's major industries agreeing to prepay taxes due in January and substantive negotiations under way to form! a consortium of banks to buy, city notes.

title: Cultural Agencies Reducing Hours and Security
description: Cut, cut! moaned the director of a museum that receives substantial city funds. We can't cut back .any more. If we lose a few more guards, we'll have to go to a noday week.

title: Policeman Kills Another
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP)An offduty Baltimore police officer was accidentally shot and fatally wounded by another city policeman yesterday while the two reportedly checked to see that their weapons were loaded.

title: Venezuela, Its Oil Within Grasp, Needs Foreign Concerns
description: CARACAS. Venezuela  On New Year's Day Venc7u21a. the world's third largest petroleum exporter after Saudi Arabia and Iran, will become master of its chief natural resourceor will it?

title: Three Islands
description: There was dancing in the town plaza of Culebra few days ago as its 726 residents celebrated the departure of the United States Navy, which had long used part of the island off Puerto Rico for shelling and bombing practice and had once tried to take it over completely. The Navy's exit was one of those rare victories over Goliath for inhabitants of a tiny dot the ocean who were unwilling to be uprooted from their homes in the name of progress or security.

title: Students Flock to JobRelated Courses
description: STATE COLLEGE. Pa., Nov. 1The nation's troubled economy and the accompanying complications of the energy shortage are causing an unprecedented boom in business and energyrelated courses at collegesand universities across the country.

description: Deaths
