title: P.L.O. Favors Kissinger Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5Farouk Kaddoumy, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that the P.L.O. would welcome a meeting with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger but was not interested in any lower level diplomatic contacts.

title: 200 Peonle Gather on Ellis Island to Open a Drive for Funds to Restore and Refurbish
description: About 200 people debarked on a deserted island in New York Harbor yesterday morning to raise a flag and open a campaign to restore the landmark through which 16 million immigrants entered this country between 1892 and 1954.

title: Shark's Victim Recovers
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI)  An 18yearold surfer whose foot was mangled by a shark that leaped out of the water , and grabbed him has been released from a hospital after receiving 34 stitches on the wound. Scott Lee Hurst, of San Mateo, Fla., was lying face down on his sufboard off Crescent Beach Sunday, paddling with his hands, when the sixfoot shark attacked. The youh's feet were out of the water, sticking up in the air. He kicked at the shark's head and drove it away after being pulled underwater.

title: Maverick Is Back as Minneapolis Mayor
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5 Charles Stenvig, a 47yearold police lieutenant whose political career had appeared to be at an end, defeated incumbent Mayor Albert Hofstede in surprising upset yesterday to recapture the office he once held for two terms.

title: Memorial Services
description: MUSNIKBernard. A mernoral service of Thanksgiving for the life of Bernard Musnik will be held on Friday, November 7, at 11 A.M., at the Malone Francaise of New York University, 16 Washington Mews, Manhattan. lieu of flowers contributons to the HUnter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund will be appreciated.

title: Postal Workers Defended On IllegalOpening Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) The Postal Service said today that postal officials had not broken the law in connection with illegal mail opening by the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge John P. Fullam of Federal District Court in Philadelphia agreed to permit the bankrupt Penn Central enter into an agreement with New York State to finance part of the repairs for the firedamaged Poughkeepsie Bridge across the Hudson River. The bridge was damaged May 8, 1974, by a fire apparently caused by sparks from freight train passing over it, and has been out of service since then. Under a proposal by the State Department Transportation, that agency would pay $486,000 and the Penn Central $359,000.

title: GRUMMAN NET UP 24% IN 3D QUARTER
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Nov. 5The Grumman Corporation, one of the nation's largest defense contractors, reported today that the third quarter of 1975 was its best quarter since 1967 in terms of consolidated earnings.

title: Screen: 'Hiding Place':Story of Dutch Family During Occupation
description: Whenever someone in "The Hiding Place" says "God knows," he isn't expressing metaphorical despair. The character means exactly what he says. Because God does know, it's up to the Ten Boom family, a family of Dutch Christians living in Haarlem during the Nazi occupation, to rely on that knowledge to accept the terrible things that befall them after they are arrested for helping Jewish refugees."The Hiding Place," which opened yesterday at the Hudson and other theaters, is a pious movie about a very specific kind of faith. It was producedwith no apparent expenses sparedby an adjunct of the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association. "The Hiding Place" is not the sort of film that explores philosophical alternatives. It demonstrates its ideas as dramatically as it's possible to do when there's no real contest.This is not to say the Ten Booms aren't subjected to all sorts of tests, but their faith never wavers. This is a sad story, as well as a true one, based on a book written by Corrie Ten Boom, the only surviving member of the Ten Boom family, after she was released, through a clerical error, from the Ravensbrck concentration camp shortly before the end of the war.The cast includes Julie Harris and Jeannette Clift, as the two middle-age Ten Boom sisters, Arthur O'Connell as their father, and Eileen Heckart as a tough inmate who befriends the sisters on their way to Ravensbrck. The material is not the sort to test the skills of the performers, whose Dutch accents sound quite Swedish on occasion.The film was directed by James F. Collier on locations in the Netherlands and in Britain.

title: CHRYSLER PRESSED ON ITS BRITISH UNIT
description: LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuters)Members of Parliament and trade union leaders tonight pressed the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, John J. Riccardo, to maintain Chrysler's moneylosing British subsidiary but apparently received no firm assurances from him.

title: Order to Stop Oil Output
description: OSLO, Norway, Nov. 5 (AP)The State Administration of Oil and Gas ordered today the Phillips Petroleum Group to stop production from another platform in the Ekofisk area on the Norwegian sector of the North Sea continental shelf. The move followed reports about rust in fragments of the pipeline where an explosion on the Phillipsowned oil drilling platform Alpha, stationed in the Ekofisk area, caused three, deaths on Saturday.

title: F.D.A. HEAD URGES NEW DRUG POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP)Dr. Alexander M. Schmidt, Commissioner of Food and Drugs, proposed a new procedure today that he said would get important new medicines into the hands of medical specialists faster but keep them under Government control longer.

title: Scaasi Retrospective Evokes Nostalgia
description: Mamie Eisenhower and Sophia Loren sent in the same scoopedneck navy brocade dress of 1958Mrs. Eisenhower is still wearing hers. Rita Gam modeled it. Shelley Andreas, married six years, modeled her wedding dress. Her mother, Joyce Susskind, paraded across the stage of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center in her own red sequin dress of the same year.

title: Of New York City's Fiscal Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Nov. 7, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A G.M. Strike Threatened
description: DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP)Some 7600 hourly workers at General Motors Steering Gear Division in Saginaw, Mich., have threatened to go on strike at 10 A.M. Monday in a dispute involving production standards at the plant.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court in Trenton ruled yesterday that defendants sentenced under pleabargaining agreements might appeal those sentences within 45 days even if the agreement included a promise not to appeal. But the court said a defendant who reneged on a pledge not to appeal could face the loss of all benefits in the pleabargaining agreement.

title: Two Nationwide Polls Indicate Americans Favor Aid for City
description: Two nationwide polls, conducted independently of each other earlier this week, indicate that Aniericans strongly support Federal aid to beleaguered New York City and disI agree with President Ford's assumptions that a default by New York would not affect the rest of the country.

title: 10th Time for Bar Exam Is Ruled One Too Many
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP)Chester Potter's ambition to become a lawyer, has been squelched by a court ruling that he cannot take the New Jersey bar examination for the 10th time.

title: Miss Casals Victor
description: PARIS, Nov. 6 (Reuters)Rosemary Casals defeated Tina Holladay, 63, 63, in a firstround match of the French indoor women's tennis championships today.

title: Rain Stalls Japan Event
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7., Friday. (UPI)Rain caused postponement today for the second straight day of the quarterfinals of the men's singles in the $100,000 Japan open tennis championship.

title: COUNTER EDGES UP AS AMEX IS MIXED
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed in light trading yesterday but those in the overthecounter market increased as volume rose slightly.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: U.S. INFORMS I.L.O. OF INTENT TO QUIT
description: GENEVA, Nov. 6 (AP)The United States served formal notice to the International Labor Organization today that it intended to withdraw from the 125member United Nations body, the target of longstanding American charges of leftist political activity.

title: Books of The Times
description: Near the end of his unorthodox Memoirs, Tennessee Williams poses a disconcerting question. He asks us in effect to judge whether he is lunatic or relatively sane, although he quickly adds, just in case we've aleady decided against him, that he pleads non contendere to the charge, so long as he be permitted to go on writing, Now.

title: Contract for Algerian Gas Signed by Public Service
description: NEWARK, Nov. 6 (AP)Two East Coast utilities have announced a contract with Algeria's national oil and gas agencyk that officials say would sat iey much of the region's naturalgas needs until 1999. The

title: About New York
description: Tourists who visit New York usually take home more than memories. Although we might shudder at the comparison, they buy the same things that New Yorkers buy at their cruise stopsash trays, shaving mugs, T shirts and picture postcards bearing illustrations that will ever recall the New York excursion to anybody who rummages about in the attic years from now.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: Citizens
description: New York City residents pay twice as much  and in some cases, far more  for public assistance as the residents of six other major cities in the nation, a report released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission said.

title: Notes on People
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York presented its annual Family of Man award to President Ford, through his wife, Betty, at the New York Hilton Hotel last night after about 100 black church leaders and others protested outside.

title: A Top Leftist Guerrilla in Chile Seeks Refuge in Vatican Office
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 (AP)One of Chile's most wanted leftist guerrillas sought asylum with a woman friend tonight in the diplomatic residence of the Vatican in Chile, the national press service Orbe Teported.

title: EDWARD L. TATUM, NOBEL LAUREATE
description: Dr. Edward Lawrie Tatum, who helped prove that individual genes, the chemical units of heredity, are coded messages specifying the makeup of individual proteins, died Wednesday in his home at 450 East 63d Street after an extended illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Nixon Aides
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP)The White House never gave orders to use Richard M. Nixon's 1969 gift of personal papers to obtain a tax break for the President, a former White House attorney said yesterday.

title: 2dPeriod Knick Lapse Leads to 11196 Defeat
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6 In an implausible exchange of hot streaks, the New York Knicks lost to the Golden State Warriors tonight, 11196, as a, nearcapacity crowd of 11,575 wore itself out trying to follow the rollercoaster.

title: PRIME RATE SEEN DIPPING FURTHER
description: The continued decline in tommercial paper rates reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York could set off still another round of cuts in the prime interest rate  the rate commercial banks charge bluechip corporate borrowers.

title: 5 Convicted in a Scheme To Defraud Stock Clients
description: NEWARK, Nov. 6 (UPI)Four men and a woman were convicted today for their parts in a scheme to defraud more than $2.1 million from stock customers at one of the largest brokerage house on the East Coast.

title: DEFENSE FUND CUT VOTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $90.7 billion defense appropriations bill for the current fiscal year$7.1 billion, or 7 percent, below the Ford Administration's request.

title: The Rescue
description: The debate over what the Federal Government should or should not do for New York City has begun to take on the hazy quality of supposition and speculation that has enshrouded

title: ARRIVAL OF WEAPONS PERILS BEIRUT TRUCE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov 6The delivery of a shipload of arms to Christian forces in the Beirut area threatened today to disrupt efforts to transform the ceasefire of recent days into a firm peace agreement.

title: AUSTRALIA ASKS ITS BANKS FOR AID
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 6The Government called an urgent meeting of Australia's leading bankers today in an effort to raise emergency funds to avert chaos if the national budget is allowed to run out later this month.

title: Jersey High Court To Review Appeal For Carter Retrial
description: Bypassing a lower state court, the New Jersey Supreme Court announced yesterday that it would review directly the appeal of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis for a new trial on triplemurer charges.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 1.8% IN OCTOBER
description: Inflation surged ahead in October as the nation's Wholesale Price Index moved up by 1.8 percent, the largest monthly increase in a year, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Rocky's Not The One
description: The news conference at which Nelson Rockefeller outlined his reasons for declining to seek the VicePresidential nomination should have delivered a more important message to liberal Republicans. They are deluding themselves if they think Mr. Rockefeller now has a real chance to win the Republican Presidential nomination instead.

title: A Panel Subpoenas H.E.W. Secretary For Hospital Data
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6A House investigations subcommittee served a subpoena today on F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for failing to furnish hospital accreditation reports that the subcommittee had requested.

title: TV: It Need Not Be Shakespeare to Be Quality
description: Whenever the Issue of quality in television programming is raised, at least one broadcaster is sure to insist that the mass audience simply will not tune in to Shakespeare or the Philharmonic concerts. The issue is thus neatly muddled. Quality is made synonymous with highbrow, when in fact it can  or at least should be found anywhere. There are, for instanw, the rather humble category of situation comedy and the rather startling accomplishments of the Norman Lear factory and MTM Enterprises.

title: Monkey Brain Is Found Specialized, Like Man's
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6The brains of monkeys are more highly specialized, basically more humanlike in certain cognitive capacities than previously believed, a researcher reported here today.

title: Luanda Is Up Front in a War of Nerves
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 6At dusk yesterday a lone singleengine plane flew just over this city's main street dropping leaflets of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, the Zairesupported nationalist force that controls a sector of the country that begins some 40 miles from here.

title: N.F.L. Set To Process W.F. L. Pool
description: Commissioner Pete Razelle officially cleared the way last night for National Football League clubs to sign former World Football League players for this season. They tan do so until Nov. 26.

title: Kissinger Says Status Is Unchanged by ShakeUp
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Secretary of Stcte Henry A. Kissinger told a House committee today that despite the loss of his White House post he remained as influential as ever as President Ford's chief foreign policyadviser.

title: Massachusetts U. Official
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP) Dr. Roger J. Bulger, executive officer of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, has been named chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Worcester and dean of the medical school. University trustees made the appointment yesterday on the recommendation of the University of Massachusetts President, Robert C. Wood. Dr. Bulger succeeds Dr. Lamar L. Soutter. the school's first dean and chancellor, who retired earlier this year.

title: CORPORATE BONDS ARE WELLGREETED
description: A variety of new offerings sold well yesterday in the corporate bond market. In the taxexempt sector Pennsylvania's $100 million of new bonds also appeared to be off to a good start. In the corporate market, the European Investment Bank's $75 million of 9 percent notes, priced at par by underwriters headed by Kuhn Loeb, were said to be sold down to tag ends. Rated triple A by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's, the bank's notes reportedly attracted a good volume of retail buyers, including individuals and var ious institutional investors. The notes are due in 1982 and are not redeemable prior to maturity.

title: Gallup Poll Finds 61 Percent Favor Recognition of China
description: A survey of American opinion conducted by the Gallup organization for the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan has found that while 61 percent of those Dolled favored United States diplomatic recognition of the Communist Government in Peking, an even larger majority of 70 percent would not want to see American recognition of Taiwan withdrawn as part of an arrangement to recognize the Communist Government.

title: Senate Unit Says Cable Companies Aided in Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Fort almost three decades, three international telegraph companies secretly supplied to the United States Government copies of most of the messages they carried, the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence disclosed today.

title: Simon's Comic 'Sunshine Boys' Opens
description: For 47 years Al Lewis (George Burns) and Willy Clark (Walter Matthau) had been one of the most successful of all vaudeville comedy teams when they retired 11 years ago, and it's been 12 years since they actually spoke to each other off the stage. Willy hates Al with a fine passion, while Al, as he puts it, doesn't hate Willy; he simply can't stand him.At the start of Neil Simon's new film comedy, "The Sunshine Boys," a broadcasting genius has had the bright idea of reuniting Lewis and Clark in a TV special. The chaos that resultsa lot of it epically funny and all of it cheerfulis the sum and substance of "The Sunshine Boys," which was directed for the screen by Herbert Ross and opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, with the hall's annual Christmas show on the stage.The kind of retirement each man has slipped into describes their differences. Al lives contentedly in New Jersey wtih his married daughter, napping the afternoons away and awaiting the arrival of his grandchildren from school. Willy, who is a widower like Al, remains in the middle of Manhattan, the better to pursue his career as a single, lives in the Ansonia Hotel, plays cards at the Lambs, and occasionally reads for TV commercial jobs he never gets.Al's life is serene. Willy's life has become a continuum of grudgesagainst his nephew-agent Ben (Richard Benjamin), against door locks that never open the same way twice, against people who don't speak up and particularly against Al who, as Willy remembers it, "retired right in the middle of my career."Willie and Al, their mutual dislike and their similar habit of asking questions that have just been answered, are all that "The Sunshine Boys" has to offer, but with Walter Matthau at the top of his most antisocial form as Willy with George Burns giving a keenly funny, brilliantly straight performance as Al and with Mr. Simon delivering some of his best one-liners, the movie is extremely easy to take.It's only afterward you realize that two complex characters, as well as a unique personal and professional relationship, have been used upwastedin the interests of comedy no more substantial than the insults that Willy and Al throw at each other.There's a moment toward the end of the movie when you get an inkling of the story Mr. Simon chose not to explore. It's during a run-through of Lewis and Clark's "doctor" routinea recollection of the great Smith & Dale "Dr. Kronkhite" sketchand we are suddenly aware of the stage know-how and the heritage these two old actors represent, though the characters we've seen so far have been fairly standard versions of a couple of ill-humored old men approaching senility.Mr. Burns, now approaching 80, is old enough to be his co-star's father, but he works beautifully with Mr. Matthau, much in the manner in which he played straightman for so many years to his late wife, Gracie Allen. He looks and listens. He uses a minimum of gestures and, by appreciating the chaos he is witnessing, he gives comic importance to the entire enterprise.Without apparent strain, Mr. Simon has opened up his Broadway play to include a lot of local New York color, including a beautifully illogical confrontation between Willy and a garage mechanic when Willy, on his way to an audition, mistakes a garage on West 43d Street with the East 43d Street advertising agency he's looking for. Mr. Matthau is so good playing old men, we may never know when he finally becomes one.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 14%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.16 billion, up 11 percent from last year's $1.05 billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.85 billion, up 14 percent from the yearearlier $10.44 billion.

title: Oil Plan Is Approved
description: Congressional conferees agreed to an oilpricing plan that would lower gasoline prices for a year but then would let them rise gradually. The measure must still be approved by the House and Senate. Page 16.

title: KENNETH SUNA
description: Kenneth Suna, founder and president of Suna Bros. Inc., jewelry manufacturers, died Tuesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Free Once Again
description: Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller, liberated by his withdrawal as President Ford's prospective running mate, spoke as his own man at his news conference yesterday.

title: The Theater: Pinter's Homecoming
description: The crazyquilt version of The Homecoming that opened last night at the Wonderhorse Theater is not so much a reinterpretation of the Harold Pinter play as an insult to it. One thing that can be said about it is that it is consistent; it consistently undermines its source, vulgarizing it until it seems like a cheapjack corruption of the original.

title: The Pop Life
description: Patti Smith's first album Horses, should be in the stores about now. It's an extraordinary disk, and every minute of it is worth repeated rehearings, but you can learn about all you need to know of the essential Patti Smith by listening to the first 80 seconds of a song on the second side called Land.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 4.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 193.2 from 197.3 last week.

title: Heirlooms Feared Lost In Scottish Castle Blaze
description: INVERARAY, Scotland, Nov. 6 (AP)  There were fears today that hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of heirlooms, including a Gainsborough painting, were lost in a fire that swept the upper story of Inveraray Castle last night.

title: Sun Oil Increases Prices On Its Kerosene and Fuel
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had increased prices for kerosene No. 1 and NO.. 2 heating oil and diesel fuel by onehalf cent a gallon in those Midwestern areas where the company's prices were raised by 1 cent a gallon on Nov. 1. The move, which became effective yesterday, affects distillate prices in Iowa, Minnesota. Nebraska, the Dakotas and part of Wisconsin.

title: Dukakis Apologizes for Tax
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP)Gov. Michael S. Dukakis apologized (today in an address to the public for campaigning on a notax pledge last fall as a $3 billion state budget, accompanied by some $400 million in new taxes, was, being prepared for final House action. He urged the public to support legislators who voted for taxes and the budget, even though he believed that the compromise budget cut human services programs too deeply.

title: and in Congress
description: Congressional critics like Senator Proxmire and Representative Mahon do not dispute the Pentagon's arguments that the Soviet Union is engaged upon a major arms buildup. But they are challenging the view pressed by Mr. Schlesinger that this represents a trend that eventually could reverse the balance of power between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Oil Plan Is Approved
description: Congressional conferees agreed to an oilpricing plan that would lower gasoline prices for a year but then would let them rise gradually. The measure must still be approved by the House and Senate. Page 16.

title: People in Sports
description: Dorrell Johnson who led the Boston Red Sox into the World Series in his second year as manager; announced yesterday during a telephone news conference at Fenway Park that he had agreed to twoyear  contract. Salary terms were not disclosed, but Johnson presumably received a raise from the $45,000 a year he reportedly got in his original twoyear pact.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERNathaniel 5., beloved husband of Toby, devoted father of Paul and Geryl. Services Friday, 11:30 A.M., at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel, Lone Beach Rd. at Greystone, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Nov. 9, 65, the City's Darkest Day, Was a Bright Spot as Well
description: It will be 10 years ago on Sunday that New York's eight million people, together with 22 million others in eight states and in eastern Canada, experienced the largest electric power failure in history.

title: Congo Denies Role in Cabinda
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Republic, Nov. 6 (Reuters)The Congo Republic denied reports that its forces had entered Cabinda

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise indicated  Restated for change to LIFO 1975 1974

title: Louis H. Mueller, Founder Of Continental Air Lines, 79
description: Louis H. Mueller, founder of Continental Air Lines and a pioneer in commercial aviation in this country, died in San Francisco on Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: Consumer Unit Voted
description: The House approved a bill creating a Federal consumer protection agency by 9 votes, a margin so close that it seemed unlikely President Ford's threatened veto could be overriden. Page 12.

title: TRUSTEE IS ELECTED FOR BANKRUPT REA
description: REA Express Inc., the successor to the Railway Express Agency, was adjudicated a bankrupt yesterday by Judge John J. Galgay of the Federal Bankruptcy Court here. The court today is expected to qualil fy Orvis Sowerwine, a partner; in the Wail Street firm of Shearson Hayden Stone, asl bankruptcy trustee. He was !elected trustee yesterday.

title: Prison Hearings to Be Held
description: Peter Tufo, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, announced yesterday that in response to the Charter revision mandated by the voters Tuesday the board would hold public hearings on the constitutional crisis facing the city prison system brought about by overcrowding and budget cutbacks. The hearings are to be held early next month.

title: Another Big Blackout? Not if They Can Help It
description: GUILDERLAND, N.Y.The fiveyearold statewide power control room here, which looks like Mission Control for space flight, has one overriding purpose: to prevent any recurrence of the Great Blackout of Nov. 9, 1965, which plunged 30 million people into darkness.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell's Profit Declines
description: The Royal Dutch Shell Group, the second largest international petroleum enterprise after the Exxon Corporation, reported yesterday profit declines of 35.4 percent for the third quarter and 24.5 percent for this year's first nine months from the record earnings of 1974, when results were abnormally inflated.

title: Goldin Lists OutofState V enders With City Pacts
description: Seeking to dramatize the potential countrywide =Ise4uences of default by New York City, Comptroller Harrison I Goldin made public yesterday a list of 99 businesses in 22 states outside New York that hold $556 million in current contracts for work in the city.

title: Inquiry Begun at Zoo
description: MIAMI, Nov. 6 (UPI)The director of Crandon Park Zoo, has been asked to answer allogations by employees that several animals have been mistreated at the facility in the last five years, and some have died as a result. Arthur Peavy, jirector of Dade County Parks, said he had asked the zoo director, Dr. Gordon Hubbard, to answer the charges in writing.

title: WILLIAM MORGAN
description: William A. Morgan, who was a director, senior vice president and head of the fiduciary departments of the Bankers Trust Company at his retirement in 1967, died Sunday. He was 72 years old and lived on Sunset Lane in Rye, N. Y.

title: Flyers, Kings in 11 Tie
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. (AP)Ross Lonsberry's goal at 14 minutes 7 seconds of the second period gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 11 tie tonight with the. Los Angeles Kings.

title: Drill Instructor Charged
description: FORT LEONARD WOOD, Mo., Nov. 6 (AP)Military specifications have been filed against S.Sgt. Robert L. Roe Jr. for entorting money and favors from enlistees, a military spokesman said today. Sergeant Roe is the 10th drill instructor to face charges at the hig military com plex in the last two months.

title: Moroccans Enter Sahara And Meet No Resistance
description: IN SPANISH SAHARA, Nov. 6Tens of thousands of Moroccans, shouting the glory of Allah, crossed this colony's desert border near the Atlantic this morning to carry out the attempt by King Hassan II to annex Spanish Sahara without recourse to arms. They met no resistance.

title: LYNETTE FROMME CHIDES AN ENGINEER
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP)  Lynette Fromme chided a state engineer about the environment today as a judge finished questioning the last of 40 potential jurors for, her trial on charges of trying to kill President Ford.

title: About Real Estate
description: Here and there in the city especially in the outer reaches of Queens and Staten Island  small builders are still plying their trade. They are putting up lowrise housing for sale to the middleclass marketpeople earning perhaps $17,000 to $25,000 who prefer the suburban rather than the downtown environment.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7, Friday (AP)The ketch Great Britain H and France's Kriter II sailed into Sydney Harbor early today, both breaking the 106yearold speed record for the sailing voyage between London and Sydney.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Saturday about Alvar Aalto, the Finnish architect and furniture designer, Samuel Friedman was identified as founder and head of International Contract Furnishings Inc. He was a cofounder with Hal H. Stearns, who has since left the importing concern.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Investors Sue Bergman for Default

title: COURT RULES OUT WALLACE ORDER
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 6A state court judge held today that Gov. George C. Wallace had violated the Alabaima constitution by appropriating money by executive order in the absence of legislative approval of a state school budeet.

title: RULING DUE TODAY IN THE GANDHI CASE
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 6  The Supreme Court of India announced today that it would hand down a dgcision tomorrow in the electoral case of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, which has kept the country in political turmoil since June.

title: Assemblymen Voice Support of Steingut
description: As they did two years ago under strikingly similar circumstances, members of the State Assembly yesterday rallied behind an indicted Speaker.

title: Rockwell International
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a widely diversified industrial manufacturer, reported yesterday a 4.4 percent gain in earnings for the fiscal fourth quarter but a 22 per cent decline for the 12 months ended Sept. 30.

title: Jazz, $1.50 Seats Hit in Superdome
description: Some of the record pro basketball crowd of 26,511 watched Pete Maravich, and the New Orleans Jazz, defeat the Los Angles Lakers, 113110, Wednesday night from seats nine to 13 stories high at the Louisiana Superdome. The almost 8,000 fans who sat in the Terrace level could see Maravich's moves if they had good eyesight, but his uniform number was not visible. Maravich looked like a floppyhaired kewpie doll and Kareem AbdulJabbar like a big doll. But it didn't matter. The Jazz, winning six of their first seven games, are turning footballminded New Orleans to pro basketball.

title: Avon Products Dividend Up
description: Avon Products Inc. announced yesterday that it hadraised the quarterly dividend on its common stock to 40 cents a share from 37 cents. The dividend is payable Dec. 1 to shareholders of record Nov. 17.

title: Heirlooms Feared Lost In Scottish Castle Blaze
description: INVERARAY, Scotland, Nov. 6 (AP)  There were fears today that hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of heirlooms, including a Gainsborough painting, were lost in a fire that swept the upper story of Inveraray Castle last night.

title: Princeton Sets Sights on Harvard Upset
description: Princeton journeys to Harvard tomorrow to open the Big Three competition, Brown faces Cornell at Ithaca, and Yale meets Penn in the Bowl.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Saturday about Alvar Aalto, the Finnish architect and furniture designer, Samuel Friedman was identified as founder and head of International Contract Furnishings Inc. He was a cofounder with Hal H. Stearns, who has since left the importing concern.

title: People and Business
description: Two economists generally on opposite sides were united yesterday in their opposition to current Federal Reserve Board actions.

title: House Backs Consumer Unit, 208199
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The House of Representatives, in a surprisingly close vote, approved today a bill creating a Federal consumer protection agency, but by a margin that would be nowhere near enough to override an expected veto by President Ford.

title: Advertising
description: Don't ever tell Leo H. Rosenberg that advertising is a young man's business, He's 79 years old, has been an agency man for 50 of those years and plans to keep at it as long as his health holds out.

title: Worries Increase on Airliner Program
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced thirdquarter net earnings of $12.7 million yesterday, compared with $6.1 million for the like period in 1974.

title: Stage: Hello, Dolly!
description: Who would have guessed on that January night in 1964 that the Jerry Herman musical Hello, Dolly! was going to be one of the biggest Broadway hits of all time and that 12 seasons later we would still be reviewing it? The question is rhetorical.

title: U.S. Aides Tell Senators Of Arms Aid to Angolans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Two Administration officials told Senate committee today that the Administration was covertly supplying arms to liberation groups in Angola, according to officials with direct knowledge of the testimony, which was given in a closed session. Under Secretary of a Steate Joseph J. Sisco and William E. Colby, Director of Central Intelligence said that the Administration wanted Congressional support for a substantial amount of budgeted arms aids for Zaire, Ethiopia and Kenya. They defended both types of aid on the grounds that the United States needed bargaining chips with the Soviet Union and that it is as important to maintain the balance of power in Africa as it is anywhere else, the sources related.

title: Toyoda Leads Japan Golf
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 6 (Reuters)Akio Toyoda, a 35yearold Japanese golfer who has not won a tournament in 10 years as a professional golfer, posted a fiveunderpar 67 today to take the firstround lead in the $100,000 Sony classic. Two other Japanese, Takashi Murakami and Masaji Kusakabe, tied for second at 69. Billy Casper had a 72, the best score by the American contingent.

title: Episcopal Ordination of Women Seen No Bar to Catholic Reunion
description: Roman Catholic and Episcopal Church representatives said yesterday that if the Episcopal Church decided to authorize ordination of women, efforts of the two churches to achieve reunion would not be scuttled.

title: Exchange Will Plan A National Market
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would undertake the development of a national stock market plan.

title: ADM.CHARLESFOX, 80, EXCHIEF OF SUPPLY
description: Charles W. Fox, who retired as a vice admiral in 1953 after 40 years in the Navy, died Tuesday of leukemia in Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Silver Suring. Md.

title: OPEN GOVERNMENT BACKED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Senate voted unanimously today to require most of the Federal Government to open its meetings to the public.

title: FOREIGN BANKERS WORRY OVER CITY
description: Deep concern over the potential consequences of a New York City default has spread through the overseas banking community and could result in foreign withdrawals from New York banks if a default occurs, according to a survey and spot check of foreign bankers meeting here yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAMILY STYLE The seventh annual open house tonight from 7 o'clock to 10 o'clock at the Brooklyn Museum promises color and variety for all ages, featuring

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: ENERGY AIDE HELD ON BRIBE CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) A man identified as an official of the Federal Energy Administration was arrested in suburban Springfield, Va., motel tonight as he allegedly accepted a $10,000 bribe from coal brokerage company, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: Girl, 16, Who Died After Respirator Was Disconnected Is Buried on L.I.
description: SELDEN, L.T., Nov. 6Two hundred fifty classmates were among the mourners at the funeral today of Maryjane Dahl, a 16yearold terminally, ill patient who died Sunday. night at Nassau Hospital after a lifesustaining respirator, was, disconnected.

title: Tottering Dominoes
description: Governor Carey's warning that four state agencies face imminent default underscores the danger of far wider repercussions if New York City is allowed to slip into bankruptcy.

title: Israeli Arabs in Galilee Area Assail Government Plan to Acquire Land and Resettle Jews
description: NAZARETH, IsraelA multimilliondollar Government development plan for Galilee, denounced by its critics as a thinly disguised attempt to Judaicize the predominantly Arab area, has aroused and alarmed the Israeli Arabs who farm and own much of the land in this beautiful, mountainous region.

title: Swiss Franc Meeting Put Off
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 6 (Reuters) The entry of the Swiss franc into the Common Market joint currency float will be delayed because a meeting called to make final arrangments has been postponed, Common Market sources said. The Nov. 17 session of the community's ministers concerned with the joint float or snake ministers with their Swiss colleague has been put off because French and West German ministers will be unable to attend.

title: LEWENTHAL LEADS LITTLEHEARD MUSIC
description: Raymond Lewenthal has long been an ardent proselytizer of the Romantic revival, exploring littleknown byways of 19thcentury music. Wednesday night at Hunter College the pianist presided over the first installment of a fourpart series, presenting material that has been reposing unheard in archives and libraries for years.

title: Democrats on House Committee Are Divided on Tax Bill Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee met in closed session today in a fruitless attempt to reach agreement on the procedures they will use in bringing a tax bill before the House for a vote.

title: State Fails in Bid to Raise $150 Million for City Bills
description: The state failed yesterday to raise $150 million that the city needs to meet its debts through next week, but officials continued to express the conviction that the city would not default this month.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Mushrooms
description: The Northeast's wet October produced an excellent crop of wild mushrooms, and, as one night expect, at least one instance of poisoning.

title: More Executives Refusing to Relocate
description: Joseph Florino did not seem like a rebel. He seemed like an ordinary mobile American, ready to pack his family off, wherever the company sent them. After all, hadn't it been 12 times in 18 years?

title: FILIBUSTER STALLS PICKETING MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Senate opened debate today on the controversial common site picketing bill, touching off an immediate filibuster against it.

title: Firemen Sue to Block Stipends in Lieu of Pay
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 6Fire fighters and city officials will battle in court here tomorrow over a city plan to hire 16 Rutgers students as firemen at much less than regular pay.

title: GUILD PICKS TIMES AS STRIKE TARGET
description: The Citywide Coordinating Committee of the Newspaper Guild of New York designated The New York Times last night as the union's strike target next Tuesday if negotiators fail to reach a contract settlement by 7 A.M. on that day.

title: Compromise OilPrice Plan Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) A Congressional conference committee approved a compromise oil pricing plan tonight that would force gasoline prices down about four cents a gallon and let them rise gradually after that.

title: Democrats to Seek Rise of $2.2 Billion In Lid on Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)House Democratic leaders plan to ask for a $2.2 billion rise in a proposed ceiling on Government appropriations this year to provide for domestic jobs and meet commitments in the Middle East.

title: RIGGED ARMS DATA ON SOVIET ALLEGED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The House Intelligence Committee has obtained what its staff director today termed substantial information pointing to an effort within the Ford Administration to distort official American estimates of Soviet nuclear weapons strength and deployment.

title: Dr. Edwin S. Kopley, Headed An I.B.M. Computer School
description: Dr. Edwin S. Kopley, director of the I.B.M. Systems Research Institute, a school for advanced computer technology, died Monday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived at 22 Carthage Lane, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Nurses at Bellevue Stage a Sickout
description: Nearly 90 per cent of the registered murses at Bellevue Hospital failed to report for work yesterday and caused the diversion to other hospitals of almost all ambulances and police cars that would normally have brought patients to the city's largest emergency room.

title: Excerpts From Rockefeller Conference Explaining His Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Following are excerpts from Vice President Rockefeller's news conference today:

title: Moroccans Enter Sahara And Meet No Resistance
description: IN SPANISH SAHARA, Nov. 6Tens of thousands of Moroccans, shouting the glory of Allah, crossed this colony's desert border near the Atlantic this morning to carry out the attempt by King Hassan II to annex Spanish Sahara without recourse to arms. They met no resistance.

title: 10 in Offshore Boat Race
description: MIAMI, Nov. 6 (UN)The world offshore motor boat championship will be decided Saturday when a field of 10 starters race over a 200mile course in the Key West area. The defending champion, Carlos Bonomi, an Italian financier, enters the season's final race with four victories in his Martini & Rossi 35foot, aeromarine powered Cigarette. Bonomi also finished third on two occasions this year.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: This week, no explorations but six international sure bets. Pragmatically that is, offering proofs in their Russian, Chinese, Italian, English, French and Mexican puddings), each of these restaurants has to be among the most satisfactory in New York, since all have flourished for a long time in a business where you please the customersor else. So:

title: Top Jersey Senate Democrats To Push Soon for Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6New Jersey Senate Democratic leaders said this evening that they would move swiftly to push a modest state income tax through the upcoming lameduck legislative session, probably next month.

title: Ballet: New Team of Principals Buoys Raymonda
description: A new team of principals rode into the production of Raymonda with which American Ballet Theater is currently saddled at the Uris Theater. And while Gelsey Kirkland and Ivan Nagy were no worse than previous leads at times they were better their debut Wednesday night confirmed the weak and strong points of Rudolf Nureyev's version.

title: Television
description: 8:00 P.M. Sanford and Son (4)

title: CHESSIE SYSTEM BACKED BY U.S.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The United States Railway Association voted quick approval today of the Chessie system's strict terms for taking part in the vast Federal reorganization of the bankrupt Northeast railroads.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: INCOMING

title: Election Panel Bars Indirect Funding
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The Federal Election Commission moved today to insure that corporate and labor union political contributions, legal in some states but banned in Federal elections, cannot be used indirectly to help Presidential and Congressional candidates.

title: GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: Ford's Narrowing Base
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6President Ford is getting into trouble now because he seems to have forgotten, at least temporarily, why he was accepted overwhelmingly in the Congress as our first appointed President, and why he was so popular in the early months of his stewardship.

title: Lionel Trilling, 70, Critic, Teacher and Writer, Dies
description: Lionel Trilling, a literary critic of international reputation and University Professor Emeritus at Columbia, died Wednesday evening of cancer at his home, 35 Claremont Avenue. He was 70 years old.

title: Steingut and Son Are Charged In a 2Count Felony Indictment
description: Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, and his son, Robert, a Brooklyn Councilman at Large, were charged in a felony indictment yesterday with corruptly using their offices to arrange for a city job for a Bronx haberdasher in exchange for a $2,500 cash contribution to the younger Steingut's campaign.

title: Age Slows Poland's Jumpers
description: You think the Rangers are the only team at Madison Square Garden with troubles? The Polish equestrian team shares with the Rangers a common problemthe replacement of horses that have grown too old with young horses that still need development.

title: Drive Is Begun to Curb False Alarms in the City
description: Mayor Beame and Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan went to a street corner in the South Bronx yesterday morning to start a campaign against the growing number of false alarms in the city.

title: The Sadat Visit
description: Egypt and the United States have laid the foundations for a working relationship closer than they have known for twenty years. But on the one immediate issue that will dominate the coming months of ArabIsraeli diplomacy, the status of the Palestinian Arabs, the two countries have yet to start moving.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Russians Seeking to Purchase Reactor Parts From Japanese
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6Japanese manufacturers of nuclear re actors have begun negotiations aimed at selling to the Soviet Union major reactor components reportedly worth $1.7 billion.

title: Massachusetts U. Official
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP) Dr. Roger J. Bulger, executive officer of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences, has been named chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Worcester and dean of the medical school.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1975

title: Jewish Group Says Arabs Run Big Drive Against Israel in U.S.
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that the Arab states were spending $45 million annually to indoctrinate the American people against Israel and to conduct an antiZionist and antiSemitic campaign.

title: Christine Boit Bride of Maj. J. S. Crisp
description: Christine Grote Boit of Boston was married yesterday in London to Maj. John Simon Crisp, who is retiring this month from the British Army's Household Cavalry. The civil ceremony was followed by a reception at the Turf Club.

title: Redskins Owe Much to Doctor
description: If a George Allen football team beats the Giants Sunday for the 13th time in 13 times, don't blame Paul Lessack. He offered his services to the Giants, but they turned him down. Allen, on the other hand, hired himand look where the Redskins are.

title: COWLES REPORTS DROP IN EARNINGS
description: Cowles Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its net income in this year's first nine imonths fell to $2.2 million, or 56 cents a share, from the yearearlier $2.38 million, or 60 cents a share.

title: Chotiner Linked to Inquiry On Jai Alai in Bridgeport
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 6 The late Murray Chotiner, a Washington lawyer who was former President Nixon's chief trategist and political tutor for more than 20 years, was named in published reports today is the recipient of a substantial cash payment from the developer of a Bridgeport jaialai fronton.

title: Carey Lobbies in Washington for Help, Then Heads for Coast to Gain Backing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Governor Carey told Congressmen today that New York needed Federal help in solving its fiscal troubles, then set out for the West Coast to take the message to the rest of the nation.

title: Still New Under the Sun: Truth
description: PARIS A FAMOUS Fleet Street press lord once pinned up a notice in his paper's newsroom. It read: One Englishman is a story. Ten Frenchmen is story. One hundred Germans is a story. One thousand Indians is a story. Nothing ever happens in Chile.

title: MaliSoviet Flights Set
description: BAMAKO, Mali, Nov. (Agence FrancePresse) The Soviet airline Aeroflot has officially inaugurated a new 10hour service between Bamako and Moscow with its new Tupolev154 jetliner.

title: Another Big Blackout? Not if They Can Help It
description: GUILDERLAND, N.Y.The fiveyearold statewide power control room here, which looks like Mission Control for space flight, has one overriding purpose: to prevent any recurrence of the Great Blackout of Nov. 9, 1965, which plunged 30 million people into darkness.

title: For the Jets, a Tale of 5 Rejects
description: The New York Jets, who have lost five of their seven games, now go to Miami for a return match with the Dolphins, who have won six of their seven. In their last four defeats, the Jets defense has been penetrated, to use euphemism, for 141 points; in their last four victories, the Dolphins have scored 148. Bob Griese, the Miami quarterback, says this 37point average was made possible by the offensive line. After last Sunday's 4613 conquest of the Bears he praised Bob Kuechenbere in particular because

title: Knicks
description: AT LOS ANGELES TV, WOR, CHANNEL 9, 11 P.M.

title: North Korea Tells Australia It Must Close Its Embassy
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6 (AP)North Korea today told Australia to close its embassy in Pyongyang because it has systematically committed subversive activities, the official North Korean news agency reported.

title: Sarnoff's Departure Is Called Result of RCA Palace Revolt
description: A palace revolt within top management of the RCA Corporation forced Robert W. Sarnoff to resign Wednesday as chairman and chief executive officer, sources in the company indicated yesterday.

title: LABOR FIGHTS BILL TO MINI THE CITY LOAN GUARANTEES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations today opposed pending legislation that would. authorize loan guarantees to New York City, because it would empower a Federal board to abrogate union contracts unilaterally.

title: Jersey High Court To Review Appeal For Carter Retrial
description: Bypassing a lower state court, the New Jersey Supreme Court announced yesterday that it would review directly the appeal of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis for new trial on triplemurer charges.

title: Woman, 64. Is the Winner Of $250.000 in Lottery
description: WOODRIDGE, Nov. 6 (AP)Anastasia Garibaldi, 64 years old, of Pennsanken won $250,000 today in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing.

title: A Rare Look At the Gifted, 50 Years Later
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 6Today, many of them are whitehaired grandmothers and those who work are nearing retirement age, but in the 1920's they were precocious teenaged girls in California who were asked to be part of a longterm study of what becomes of gifted children.

title: Education Budget Rise Asked
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The State Department of Education says it will need a 58 percent budget increase to implement New Jersey's new school reform law and carry on their other functions.

title: Assault Charged In N.H.L.
description: TORONTO, Nov. 6 (AP)Dan Maloney of the National Hockey League's Detroit Red Whigs was charged with assault today following a fight with Brian Glennie of the Toronto Maple Leafs last night during a game at the Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: LABOR FIGHTS BILL TO ALLOW THE CITY LOAN GUARANTEES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Ori ganizations today opposed pending legislation that would authorize loan guarantees to. New York City, because it would empower a Federal board to abrogate union contracts unilaterally.

title: Seminar Is. Inconclusive On Disclosure of Bribes
description: A legal seminar wrestled here yesterday with the issue of what corporations have to tell investors about bribes and questionable payments.

title: WHOLESALE PRICES UP 18% IN OCTOBER
description: Inflation surged ahead in October as the nation's Wholesale Price .Index moved up by 1.8 percent, the largest monthly increase in a year, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: ACTION DROPPED BY COPPERWELD
description: Merger News

title: State Police Keeping Files On Thousands of Citizens
description: The New York State police have been maintaining filesmostly newspaper clippingson hundreds of thousands of individuals who have neither committed crimes nor are suspected of committing crimes, a report by a state investigator said yesterday.

title: Police Await Jury Report On Officer's Killing Boy
description: A police spokesman said yesterday that the results of a departmental investigation into the fatal shooting late Tuesday of a 16yearold Long Island youth by an offduty police officer would be withheld pending a grandjury inquiry into the matter.

title: Consumer Unit Voted.
description: The House approved a bill creating a Federal consumer protection agency by 9 votes, a margin so close that it seemed unlikely President Ford's threatened veto could be overriden. Page 12.

title: NationalPark Policy
description: VISALIA, Calif.Hangglider pilots are still flying off Glacier Point in Yosemite National Park. Initially, Assistant Secretary of the Interior Nathaniel P. Reed wanted to ban the sport in the national parks because hang gliding is not a form of use that is essential to the enjoyment of these areas.

title: Steingut and Son Named in 2 Counts
description: Stanley Steingut, Speaker of the State Assembly, and his son, Robert, a Brooklyn Councilman at Large, were charged in a felony indictment yesterday with corruptly using their offices to arrange for a city job for a Bronx haberdasher in exchange for a $2,500 cash contribution to the younger Steingut's campaign.

title: RIGGED ARMS DATA ON SOVIET ALLEGED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The House Intelligence Committee has obtained what its staff director today termed substantial information pointing to an effort within the Ford Administration to distort official American estimates of Soviet nuclear weapons strength and deployment.

title: Opponents Are Rated Favorites Over Giants and Jets Sunday
description: Two of the better teams will appear on local television on Sunday, the Redskins and the Dolphins. Unfortunately they will not be playing each other but working over the

title: CAPITAL OUTLAYS TO RISE IN 1976
description: Capital spending for new plant and equipment and renovation of old facilities will total $123.45 billion in 1976, McGrawHill publications said yesterday.

title: Common Market Backs Sale Of Grain to Egypt for 3 Years
description: BRUSSELS. Nov. 6The European Economic commission has received the go ahead from the nine member nations of the Common Market to conclude a sale of one million tons of grain a year to Egypt for the next three years at controlled prices.

title: More Executives Refusing to Relocate
description: Joseph Florino did not seem like a rebel. He seemed like an ordinary mobile American, ready to pack his family off, wherever the company sentthem. After all, hadn't it been 12 times in 18 years?

title: Lionel Trilling, 70, Critic, Teacher and Writer, Dies
description: Lionel Trilling, a literary critic of international reputation and University Professor Emeritus at Columbia, died Wednesday evening of cancer at his home, 35 Claremont Avenue. He was 70 years old.

title: American Childbirth Practices: Time of Change
description: A nurse in Richmond, Va., assesses how Americas childbirth practices have changed: Women no longer want to be patted on the head and told that everything will turn out all right.

title: The Rockefeller Smile Is Tardy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6It was Nelson A. Rockefeller's first formal news conference in Washington since he became Vice President, and there were wrinkles in his outofdate official flag.

title: MANILA IS ENLARGED UNDER MRS. MARCOS
description: MANILA, Nov. 6An enlarged Manila was created today by merging the city with 16 communities surrounding it, and President Ferdinand E. Marcos named his wife to head its government.

title: BENGALI GENERAL TAKES POWER ROLE
description: NEW DELHI, Friday, Nov. 7 Maj. Gen. Zaiur Rahman, who was dismissed this week as Chief of Staff of the Bangladesh Army, announced today that he had taken over as martial law administrator of the country.

title: Miller Hits Back at Opponents Within Miners
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 6Two leaders of the United Mine Workers of America struck back angrily today at critics within the union, threatening to uspend a dissident vice president and exhorting the 240,000 union members to file recall petitions against a majority of the 21member international executiveboard.

title: Rider Triple Enriches Triple
description: A triple payoff of $14,392 for $2 in the final racethe highest return after 63 programs at the meetingand a riding triple by George Martens rounded out a session at Belmont Park yesterday in which the youngest riders in the jockey colony were thrown into focus.

title: NORMAN H. PEARSON, AN ENGLISH SCHOLAR
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6Norman Holmes Pearson, a professor of English and American studies at Yale University and a scholar of American cultural and literary history, died last night at YaleNew Haven Hospital. He, was 66 years old and lived in Hamden.

title: Policy at the Pentagon
description: Though both men tried to play it downas does President FordSecretary of State Kissinger and exSecretary of Defense Schlesinger worked from opposite precepts in their designs for United States policy toward the Soviet Union.

title: Suit Is Filed to Bar New Law Ordering Thorough Schooling
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) Jersey City and the Greater Newark Urban Coalition have asked the State Supreme Court to invalidate a new school law adopted by the Legislature.

title: Ceilings on Immigration Urged by Canadian Panel
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 6Ceilings on immigration into Canada were proposed today by a joint parliamentary policy committee on which both Government and opposition parties were represented.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: Paterson, N.S.Christy Elliott, 169 pounds, Dublin, Ireland, outpointed Ray Ayala, 175, New York, 10 rounds.

title: Quality of Appointments To 9 U.S. Agencies Scored
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 More than half of the people appointed to nine Federal regulatory agencies in the last five years came from the industries they were named to regulate and thus faced potential conflict of interest problems, according to a Congressional chicly made public today.

title: World Bank Loans Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (Reuters)The World Bank announced today two loans totaling $60 million to help finance a flood recovery program in Rumania and one of $49 million for a major oil pipeline project in Yugoslavia. The loan to

title: Girl Is Kept From School, Cultist Is Held
description: MAYS LANDING, Nov. 6 (AP)On the advice of her selfproclaimed prophet, a 23yearold woman who has embraced a fledgling religious cult went to jail today for refusing to send her daughter to school.

title: Nov. 9, 65 the City's Darkest Day, Was a Bright Spot as Well
description: It will be 10 years ago on Sunday that New York's eight million people, together with 22 million others in eight states and in eastern Canada, experienced the largest electric power failure in history.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 6 (Reuters)Cook Industries Inc. of Memphis, Tenn., said today that it had sold an additional 1.1 million metric tons of United States corn to the Soviet Union. The sale lifts to 1.6 million metric tons the total amount of corn sold by Cook to the Soviet Union since the moratorium on further sales of United States grain to the Russians was lifted on Oct. 20.

title: Franco Fights on Amid Concern Over Spain's Political Paralysis
description: MADRID, Friday, Nov. 7Doctors indicated last night that Generalissimo Francisco Franco was holding his own in his fight to stay alive.

title: National Horse Show Summaries
description: MORNING EVENTS

title: F.T.C. Investigates Tampax On Anticompetitive Actions,
description: The Federal Trade Commisi sion has begun an investigation to determine whether Tampax Inc. has engaged in any anti! competitive practices, the corn; nano said yesterday.

title: FUTURES OF CORN SHOW A DECLINE
description: Corn prices failed to rise yesterday despite the fact that a rumor of another big sale of corn to the Soviet Union swept the Chicago Board of Trade. After the close of trading, Cook Industries confirmed that it had sold 1.1 million tons to the Russians.

title: Hearing Told Nuclear Cargoes Pose Threat of Disaster to City
description: The continued transportation of radioactive materials through the citya practice that is increasing with the reliance on nuclear energycould in the event of an accident have cataclysmic results, bringing death or serious injury to tens of thousands of New Yorkers, the director of the city's Bureau of Radiation Control testified yesterday.

title: S.I. COLLEGE STAFF AGREES TO PAY CUT
description: The employees of the Staten Island Community College, from the president to the plumbers, have agreed in principal to a voluntary pay cut rather than face layoffs if the college's budget is further reduced next spring, Dr. William M. Birenbaum, the college president, said yesterday.

title: Chase Realty Trust Fights to Survive, With Bankers Among Biggest Rooters
description: Five years ago, the Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, a new real estate lending organization, attracted stockholders and lenders with effort to penetrate the nation's thenbooming real estate market. It succeeded on all counts.

title: U.N. Council Calls on Morocco To Pull Out Saharan Marchers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 6The Security Council, informed by Spain that it had received what is considered an ultimatum from Morocco over the Spanish Sahara, called on Morocco tonight to immediately withdraw all its participants in the march into the desert territory.

title: Hearings Slated On Olympic Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)A White House Commission seeking to improve America's effort in the Olympic games will conduct hearings Monday and Tuesday in New York with top officials of the United States Olympic Committee appearing to testify.

title: Assemblymen Voice Support of Steingut
description: As they did two years ago under strikingly similar circumstances, members of the State Assembly yesterday rallled behind an indicted Sneaker.

title: Many Line Up at a Coop in Brooklyn To Get Their Names on Waiting List
description: More than 100 people, some dozing on beach chairs during the night and others in sleeping bags have been waiting in line since late Wednesday to get their names today on an apartment waiting list at a coveted cooperative housing development in Brooklyn.

title: Ceilings on Immigration Urged by Canadian Panell
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 6Ceilings on immigration into Canada were proposed today by a joint parliamentary policy'committee on which both Government and opposition parties were represented.

title: Chotiner Linked to Inquiry On Jai Alai in Bridgeport
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 6 The late Murray Chotiner, a Washington lawyer who was former President Nixon's chief strategist and political tutor for more than 20 years, was named in published reports today as the recipient of a substantial cash payment from the developer of a Bridgeport jaialai fronton.

title: G.M. AGREES TO FIX WHEELS ON PICKUPS
description: DETROIT, Nov. 6 (UPI)The General Motors Corporation agreed today to repair wheels on about 140,000 trucks built between 1960 and 1965, thus ending a fiveyear dispute with the Federal Government.

title: Connors and Ashe Gain Quarterfinals in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 6 (AP) Arthur Ashe and Jimmy Connors scored convincing straightset victories today and moved into the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament.

title: Salute to Birdland Given by Musicians Who Played There
description: The memory of Birdland, the Broadway nightclub of the 1950's that was known as the jazz corner of the world, was celebrated Wednesday evening in a Highlights of Jazz concert at New York University's Loeb Auditorium. The musi cians, all veterans of Birdland, included Buddy DeFranco, the clarinetist, who is returning to jazz after many years as leader of the Glenn Miller orchestra.

title: City Prepares Data for Congress on the Budget Deficit
description: Mayor Beame's office yesterday hurriedly prepared a series of answers for skittish Congressional leaders on the city's budget problems, in response to contentions that the budget deficit was actually much larger than depicted in the emergency plan to cut $724 million in three years.

title: State Police Keeping Files On Thousands of Citizens
description: The New York State police have been maintaining filesmostly newspaper clippingson hundreds of thousands of individuals who have neither committed crimes nor are suspected of committing crimes, a report by a state investigator said yesterday.

title: Guatemala Warns of Force as Britain Continues Belize BuildUp
description: Guatemala denounced the British military buildup in neighboring Belize yesterday and said it was prepared to meet force with force if necessary to back its territorial claims to the little Central American colony. Britain warned it would fight back if Guatemala attacked.

title: FOREIGN BANKERS WORRY OVER CITY
description: Deep concern over the potential consequences of a New York City default has spread through the overseas banking community and could result in foreign withdrawals from New York banks if a default occurs, according to a survey and spot check of foreign bankers meeting here yesterday.

title: Panel Drops Complaint on Leaks Filed Against Rep. Harrington
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The House ethics committee dismissed today a complaint that Representative Michael J. Harrington had illegally disclosed classified testimony about the Central Intelligence Agency's covert activities in Chile, thus preserving the committe's record of never having investigated a member of Congress.

title: Breast Cancer Project Called Success
description: Four out of fives women whose breast cancers were detected through a nationwide screening project were found to have an early stage of disease with a very high chance of being cured, according to a progress report issued yesterday.

title: Hayes Powers Bullets, 110 to 100, Over Sonics
description: LANDOVER, Md., Nov. 6 (AP)Elvin Hayes scored 27 points tonight and led the Washington Bullets to a 110100 victory over Seattle, their third straight triumph in the National Basketball Association.

title: Rockefeller Declares Party Squabbles Led to Move
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Vice President Rockefeller said today that party squabbles had led him to withdraw as President Ford's running mate next year, and he declined to rule himself out as a possible candidate for the Presidency.

title: FORD WILL PROMOTE INVESTING IN EGYPT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) President Ford has said he will urge American business to vigorously pursue investments in Egypt to help rebuild and strengthen that country's economy.

title: Bridge:
description: Voluntary contracts of five spades or five hearts represent a variation of an old sucker trap. Heads I win, tails you lose, becomes heads lose, tails nobody wins.

title: Nina Voronel Talks of Plays and Dissent in Soviet
description: As an underground playwright in the Soviet Union before she immigrated to Israel last December, Nina Voronel set out to write realistic plays. But, she said here this week, Soviet life is .so absurd that when write realistically, it becomes the theater of the absurd.

title: Rockefeller Declares Party Squabbles Led to Move
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Vice President Rockefeller said today that party squabbles had led him to withdraw as President Ford's running mate next year, and he declined to rule himself out as a possible candidate for the Presidency.

title: Natural Mother to Regain 2 of 4 Children Next Week
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Nassau County yesterday ordered that two young sisters I be returned by next Friday to their natural mother and that their two older sisters  who have been with the same foster parents  be placed in another foster home and ultimately be returned to their mother.

title: Stocks Up Moderately After Early Weakness
description: The stock market shrugged off some early weakness yesterday and closed moderately higher on news of efforts to pull New York City out of its fiscal crisis.

title: For Lillian Hellman, More Honors and a New Book
description: Lillian Hellman is being honored Sunday night at Circle in the Square for her contribution to the theater, to literature and to the protection of civil liberties. The evening in which many of Miss Hellman's friends will perform and read excerpts from her 12 plays and two books, is a benefit for the Committee for Public Justice, which she founded five years ago.

title: Freight Traffic Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States Irailroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 11.4 per cent below a year ago. Carloadings in the same period, which included the Veterans Day holiday, totaled 479,033 cars, 11.3 per cent below the corresponding holiday week of 1974. The American Trucking Associations reported intercity truck tonnage was 9.4 per cent below last year.

title: Brewers to Name Grammas as Pilot
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6 (UPI) Alex Grammas, 48yearold thirdbase coach of the Cincinnati Reds, was reported today to have agreed to terms with the Milwaukee Brewers and will be named their manager tomorrow.

title: HEARST JURY HEARS RELUCTANT WITNESS
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., Nov. 6 (AP)Martin Miller, who had previously refused to answer questions before a grand jury in the Patricia Hearst case, apparently cooperated with the panel today.

title: Blast and Fire Level Home Of Swainson Trial Witness
description: ST. CLAIR SHORES, Mich., Nov. 6 (UPI)An explosion land fire apparently touched off lby arsonists destroyed today the suburban Detroit home of a key Government witness in the recent bribery conspiracy trial of Justice John B. Swainson of the Michigan Supreme Court.

title: Ban on Throwaway Bottles Urged in Environmental Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI)  An environmental group sued today to halt the use of throwaway plastic soft drink and beer bottles, which it said are both a health threat and a hazard to the environment.

title: Market Place
description: Less than three weeks ago, the stock of a little noticed New Englandbased roofing and siding company was quoted in the overthecounter market at $43 bid. Yesterday it had climbed to $73 bid, a jump of 70 per cent that made the stock the hottest performer in the market.

title: Meany Urges Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) George Meany, president of the American Federation of abor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that a $100 billion bill to provide health insurance for everyone would cost no more than was being spent to buy health care for only some people. Mr. ivleany endorsed a national liealth security bill that would provide universal coverage without excluding any services of requiring individuals to make additional payments. It would be financed out of payroll taxes hatched by general Government revenues.

title: UDALL, HERE, GIVES AN URBAN PROGRAM
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, an aspirant for the Democratic nomination for President, said yesterday that if elected he would seek full employment, a Federal takeovr of welfare, national health insurance and the rebuilding of cities.

title: GARDEN OFFERS CONVENTION PLAN

title: Lisbon Leaders Debate Ways to Increase Authority
description: LISBON, Nov. 6  Military and civilian leaders met in an unusual joint session today to discuss ways to enhance their authority. At the same time, leftist demonstrators fought with the police outside the Information Ministry.

title: Snow Knight Gets No. 5 Post at Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 6Guarding against any further lastminute defections, a field of nine horses representing six countries will break from the starting gate in Saturday's 24th running of the $150,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel Race Course.

description: Leigh Hoadley, an embryologist who pioneered investigations into the growth of body structures in developing embryos, died yesterday in tambridge, Mass. He was 80 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)  A committee representing reporters covering Congress charged Friday that press arrangements for the 1976 Democratic National Convention in New York would hamper news coverage of the convention by wire services and daily newspapers.

description: ROME, Nov. 7 (UPI)Fiorello II, the top Italianbred show jumping horse of the 1974 season and twice an Olympic Mount is dead. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) The Federal Power Commission ordered the Gulf Oil Corporation today explain why its deliveries of natural gas to a key customer, the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, were falling a fourth behind promised volumes. The commission also ordered Texas Eastern to explain why it had not pressed Gulf to deliver the full volume.

title: Art: Sentimental Style of Weber
description: It must have been a very sad day in the life of Max Weber when, on Dec. 21, 1908, he left Paris to return to New York. He was 27 years old. For three momentous years, in a period when Paris was a undisputed art capital of the Western world, he had been a busy and productive participant in its avantgarde endeavers. He showed his work in the historic salons of those years. He helped to organize a famous class with Henri Matisse, and he formed a fast friendship with Henri Rousseau. He traveled to the great museum of Spain, Belgium and the Netherlands, and he saw the work of the new generation of masters of the School of Paris. Most important of all, he produced the first paintings of his own artistic maturity  paintings decisively shaped by the Cezannean ideals of that halcyon period.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A safety procedure instituted on the Long Island Rail Road produced delays from 15 minutes to a halfhour, exasperating hundreds of commuters. The procedure requires conductors to walk out onto the station platform after closing the rear doors of the train to make certain that passengers are safely inside. Conductors then reboard the train and close the front doors after making sure they, too, are clear of passengers.

description: Three construction workers were injured yesterday, one of them cr%ically, when they fell two stories in the collax,2 of flooring and building materials in the interior of a sixstory building under renovation on the East Side.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee voted today to cut $2.2 billion from the Ford Administration's requests for the food stamp program on the ground that there was a decrease in participation brought about partly by tighter enforcement of eligibility.

title: Save the Movement
description: Political analysts are probably right in attributing the defeat of the equal rights dmendments in New York and New Jersey in large measure to the campaign of distortion waged against them by their opponents. The totally unsubstantiated forecasts of effects ranging from the abolition of women's rest rooms to dire financial consequences may well have persuaded many women that it was safer to accept known evils than to risk unknown pitfalls.
