title: Lynne Evelyn Eichler Will Be Bride in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George W. gichler of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynne Evelyn Eichler to Gorden G. Netschke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon W. Netschke of Euclid, Ohio.

title: JOE BUSHKIN'S JAZZ MARKED BY FINESSE
description: Joe Bushkin, the jazz pianist who was last heard in New York six years ago at the Plaza Hotel, insists that he has not touched a keyboard since then except to play at his children's parties. On a visit here from his California home while his daughter rides in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, Mr. Bushkin has moved into Michael's pub, where his professed absence from the piano seems to have done nothing to dilute his and finesse.

title: Ann O'Grady Married to F J. Graver 3d
description: Ann Grace O'Grady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick O'Grady of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Fred John Graver 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Graver Jr. of Paths Park, III.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: I t has been said that great ballet partnerships are, like marriages, made in heaven, and indeed there may be some truth here Occasionally, they can even seem like affairs, and I was conscious of this the other week at the Norman Treigle memorial  performance at the State Theater, when for the first and and possibly last time, Cynthia Gregory, of American Ballet Theater, was partnered by Peter Martins, of New York City Ballet. One felt they should have been dancing Romeo and Juliet at least, but in fact they settled for Balanchine's Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux.

title: Ballet: Miss van Hamel as Raymonda
description: One of the, delights of Rudolf Nureyev's Raymonda is the opportunities it offers to American Ballet Theater's pleiad of dance stars. Friday night at the Uris Theater it was the turn of Martine van Hamel to dance Raymonda. She had appeared in the ballet during the summer at the New York State Theater, but on this occasion she was partnered by Charles Ward, making his debut as the hero, Jean de Brienne, and a most interesting newcomer to the company, Vladimir Gelvan, who, like his compatriot Mikhail Baryshnikov, comes from Riga in Latvia.

title: Ty Cobb's agic: When He Was on Base, Baseball Was Different
description: Ty Cobb added a new dimensionto baseball. Before his time, the baserunner was the natural prey of the team in the field. He was a hunted creature with nine men trying to collar him. In this sense he was on the defensive. It was his responsibility not to get caught.

title: Shotgun Separation
description: President.Ford and Vice President Rockefeller:the unelected Administration, have had a public political separation and will be divorced next year when Mr.. Fordif he is nominatedheads the Republican ticket. Mr. Rockefeller, with the President's obvious encouragement, announced last week he didn't want to be a vice presidential candidate.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in the Voting Roundup last week that Dr. Frank S. Rowland, a chemist at the University of California, opposed a ban on aerosols propelled by flurocarbons. He favors such a ban.

description: TRENTON  The state's Economic Development Authority has begun a campaign aimed at attracting New York brokerage houses to New Jersey and thus enable them to escape a recently imposed 25 perxwnt increase in stocktransfer and bondsale taxes.

title: COMMUNIST GAINS  IN ITALY UPSET U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and other top Administration officials are expressing growing concern over the Communist political gains in Italy and have been sending repeated signals to the dominant Christian Democratic Party to revitalize itself and keep the Communists from joining the national Government.

title: Strutting their stuff in a tent
description: Back when all circuses lived close to the mud, the term mud show was used for those that traveled by truck, right down in it, and not by train. It wasn't especially complimentary, because the performers on mud show were not likely to be very good. Now, however, when the railroad circuses and many of the truck shows, too, perform indoors, a mud show is really a wild and wonderfui thinga circus that still struts its stuff in a tent on the uncertain ground underneath the sky in little cities

title: DR. BELA GYORKY
description: Dr. Bela Gyorky, an internist, who had been on the staffs of Bellevue and Lenox Hill hospitals, died Friday at Lenox Hill. He was 86 years old and lived at 1060 Park Avenue.

description: In Summary

description: In order for this to be, as one of the blurbgivers on the jacket suggests, the most important book on the subject of divorce in years, it would have to take in a territory much more extensive and complex than this little vehicle is capable of traversing. The issues of money (of supporting two households on funds that were previously inadequate to support one, for example), of raising children and of negotiating custody and visiting

title: 71st in Row Ties U.S. Mark
description: HILLSDALE, Mich., Nov. 8 (UPI)Hudson High School got touchdowns from Dan Salamin, Greg Gutierrez and Mark Luma last night and tied the national high school record with its 71st consecutive victory, a 246 success against neighboring Hillsdale. The Tigers, who represent town of only 2,500 persons, finished off Coach Tom Saylor's seventh unbeaten, untied season in a row and probably put Hudson into the playoffs next week. Jefferson City, Mo., won 71 games in a row between 1958 and 1966. Hudson's most recent defeat came in the opening game of the 1968 season.

title: Georgia Upsets Florida On 80Yard. Play, 10 to 7
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP)  Richard Appleby, a tight end, combined with Gene Washington on an 80yard touchdown pass with 3 minutes 12 sec,o,nds remaining as Georgia upset 11thranked Florida, 107, today and damaged the Gators hopes of a. Southeastern Conference championship.

title: Community Theaters Rise
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  All the world may not be a stage, but do not tell that to the 2,500 players who are involved in Long Island's community theaters.

title: Thanksgiving Dinners in the Colonial Style
description: A proper Colonial setting can only enhance the pleasure of Thanksgiving dinner. For people who do not plan to gather around a family table (an ever increasing number, according to Fred Sampson of the New York State Restaurant Association) Long Island offers a number of historic inns in houses built 200 to 300 years ago.

description: ART

title: People/Business
description: New Jersey is nationally recognized for its vast petroleum refining facilities, but many of the products they produce would never get to gasoline stations, industrial installations or homes throughout the nation without a device manufactured by a relatively unknown concern in Dayton, in Middlesex County.

title: Orr Returns But Canucks Beat Bruins
description: VANCOUVER, Nov. 8 (AP)  The Vancouver Canucks, led by Ron Sedlbauer's three goals, upstaged the return of Bobby Orr and the Bruins debut of Brad Park and Jean RateIle by beating Boston, 42, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Nebraska Defeats Kan. St.
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 8 (AP)Nebraska scored a quick touchdown eon Vince Ferragamo's 8yard pass to Tony Davis today and defeated Kansas State, 120. It was the ninth victory for the undefeated cornhuskers.

description: Nan Smith Burgess and William Edward Keegan Jr., were married yesterday afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham Manor, N. Y., by the Rev. David Hoag.

title: VOTE FRAUD STUDY IN SAN FRANCISCO,
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8The sun seems to have gone behind a cloud for city employees here, with some under investigation on vote fraud allegations and all suffering from voter rejection in an election this week.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHI  The small  town politician gripped the visiting American's arm, speaking urgently: The world must know that Mrs. Gandhi has made this country a huge prison, and taken away our freedom.

title: Charlotte Bergen Conducts Here
description: It is just about 10 years since Charlotte Bergen presented the first of her free concerts here in New York, and the decade has seen her progress from occasional events in thurches to annual ones in Town Hall to the present regular seasons of three Saturdayafternoon concerts in Carnegie Hall. Miss Bergen pays off the costs herself, and the hall is not large enough to hold all those who would like to get in.

title: REFUGEE ADOPTION STILL UNRESOLVED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8Seven months after Operation Babylift brought 2,000 Vietnamese orphans to the United States, questions about whether many of them can be legally adopted remain unresolved.

title: CHESS
description: MOSCOW  The King's Gambit went out of favor long ago, yet there are still those who are intrigued by its oldfashioned swashbuckling thrust and counterthrust. As early as the Paul MorphyAdolf Andersson match in Paris in 1858, not one King's Gambit was to be seen. Both Morphy and Andersson loved the gambit, but they saved it for the informal games they played after the serious business of the match was done.

title: Flushing Upset by Stuyvesant
description: Flushing, which had already clinched its Public Schools Athletic League Division B section II title, was upset yesterday by Stuyvesant, 206, at Memorial Field in Flushing.

title: Avril Millon Barton Married To Thomas Andrew Moore
description: Avril Milian Barton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Heisler Barton, was married here yesterday to Thomas Andrew Moore. The bridegroom is a son of Prof. Leo B. Moore of the Sloan School of. Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Mrs. Moore of Lexington, Mass., and Crystal Lake, N. H..

title: Bangladesh: Since Independence, Just Failure
description: NEW DELHI  At a highlevel White House meeting nearly four years ago, Ambassador U. Alexis Johnson, trying to explain to his colleagues what a grim future faced Bangladesh, described the new nation as an international basket case.

title: Connally Sees Confusion in G,O. P. Aiding His Drive for Nomination
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7John B. Connally, amid a monthlong tour of the Republican Party's dinner circuit, is now convinced that the party's power bases are so fractured that boldness can win him a foothold in the maneuvering toward the Presidential nomination next year.

title: Woman TV Reporter Dismissed For Day Off on Wornen's Strike
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Nov. 8Sara Golinveaux, 30yearold reporter for WTVT, Channel 13, the CBS affiliate in Tampa, was discharged from her job after she refused to work on women's strike day on Oct. 29.

title: New Car Engine Is Making Its Debut
description: A new engine that could have a dramatic impact on United States Auto Club championship racing is scheduled to make its debut today in the USAC season runner in almost every event he entered this season.

title: ABC on Its Way Out of the Cellar
description: Amid the welter of statistics about audiences, programs, stations and networks emerging since the start two months ago of the 197576 television season, one fact stands out: American Broadcasting Companies has come alive.

title: Suit Calls for Dissolution of Burlington Sewerage Authority
description: MOUNT HOLLYA Superior Court suit has been filed by the Burlington County Municipal Utilities Authority, which is seeking dissolution of the Northern Burlington County Regional Sewerage Authority.

title: A. C. McCarthy Plans to Marry Mary Donahue
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Peter Donahue of New York and Dowdstown House, Maynooth, County Kildare, Ireland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary. Ellen Donahue, to Anthony Charles McCarthy. He is a son of Mrs. James Russell McCarthy of Bracklyn, County Westmeath, Ireland; and the late Captain McCarthy of the British Army, retired.

title: Notes: A Year for Cyclists
description: To the list of notable events to be commemorated next year, add this: The bicycle was introduced to the United States at the Centennial Exposition in Philadelphia in 1876. century later, America's 90 million bicycle owners are being enticed by a bulging saddlebag full of Bicentennial tours and events that should get their spokes whirling from border to border and sea to shining sea.

title: Panama, and Then Some
description: WASHINGTONDuring the latest United Nations': General Assembly, seven LatinAmerican delegates., rose to, speak on behalf of Panama and its claim to the Panama Canal Zone, two of them Presidents^. and another a Prime Minister.

title: Reagan Seeks a Quick Setback for Ford
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8Ronald Reagan, moving unhesitantly toward an open challenge to Gerald R. Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination, will mount a campaign aimed at quickly undercutting the psychological advantage that an incumbent. President brings to any political contest.

title: Literary Scholars Take a Look Back At U.S. in 1700's
description: Top literary scholars drew parallels here yesterday between New Yorkers today and during the Revolution, emphasizing that an understanding of the 18century mind was necessary if Americans today are to appreciate their east.

title: BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Unnoticed in last weekend's Potomac massacre, wherein many of the Ford Administration's leading lights had their wings clipped in full public view, George Washington.the father of his countryalso suffered loss of face, more perhaps than anyone. He lost when the Treasury decided to reissue the twodollar bill, on which appears the visage of Thomas Jefferson.

title: Two Americans of a brilliant generation
description: Here are two leading American writers of a brilliant generation. Both have had the experience of being somewhat neglected by critics in their later years, but their work survives. One of them is represented by last novelor contemporary chronicle, as he preferred to call itthat was finished shortly before his death in 1970, but was not chiseled into final shape. The other, still writing, is analyzed at length in a book that was started as a critical biography, but that ended as a rather intrusive psychograph.

title: The Politics of the Panama Postponement
description: QUITO, EcuadorUnited States policy in all Latin America will be Irrevocably mortgaged if there is no agreement with Panama to abrogate the existing treaty acknowledging U. S. rights to administer and defend the canal and occupy a zone alongside it and if this new agreement is not arranged within the shortterm future.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: One of the advantages of the amateur photographer is the wide range of special effects he can achieve through the use of mechanical or chemical means.

title: Artists Seeking Still Life Find. It in Bucks County
description: UPPER BLACK EDDY, Pa.New York Cityis alive and well in Bucks County. To many of the transplanted artists who have left Nevi, York to pursue their Various muses here the sing towns that frialtenti the countryside around here fo fer them and their families the best of both worlds.

title: Art of Photography In Fashion Shown
description: HEMPSTEADThe photographs have independent existences. Each is a statement in its own right. Each is an entity unto itself.

title: Fortitude of Dutch Citizen Held Captive 36 Days W ins Admiration of the Irish
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, Nov. 8Dr. Tiede Herrema flew from Dublin to the Netherlands today, taking with him the admiration of what seemed to be all the Irish people. In shops and bars, many conversations dwelt on his bravery and stamina.

title: Lyn S. Horton John L. Newell Wed in Capital
description: Evlyn Spencer Horton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Horton of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday afternoon in Washington to John Lyndon Newell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Newell of Charlotte, N. C.

title: Sands Point In Dispute Over Police In Village
description: SANDS POINTThis picturesque, affluent village overlooking Long Island Sound has no sidewalks, onstreet parking or street lights.

title: The Dead Father
description: The music, you suddenly realize, has stopped. You cannot remember when it happened. All you can hear now is what sounds like comic efforts to articulate the silence. No one will play a tune any more. Nor will anyone tell a proper story. We must be satisfied with episodes, anecdotes, jokes, games_ For we have learned that there is no beginning and no end; if everything is middle, now can one identify an action? The strenuous efforts of Hemingway and Faulkner, of Bellow and Mailer have not saved the old liturgy from revision. But what has taken its place? What are these thumpings in the night followed by laughter, or by lengthy discourses on the strucof everything?

title: FILM VIEW
description: f the members of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences were really adventurous they would consider voting an Emmy to The Sunshine Boys as the best television film made for theaters this year. I'm overstating the case to make a point. The Sunshine Boys, which I like, is the sort of movie that makes you grin almost continuously, laugh out loud on a number of occasions, and then, at the end, leaves you wondering if that's all there is. What have we been laughing at? A couple of quarrelsome old men trading oneliners. That's all. If the movie were immediately followed by a station break and Johnny Carson, one might be so distracted that the quality of the earlier entertainment would not be questioned. Itwasfunwhileitlastedandwhat'sonnext?

State Representative Elaine Gordon, Democrat of Miami, said yesterday that another lobbying effort for the proposal would he futile in the present maledominated Legislature.

description: EL QUNEITRA, Syria, Nov. 6Tension is running high in the Syriancontrolled part of the Golan Heights despite the waning of the fighting in nearby Lebanon and the consequent fading of fears that Israel and Syria might somehow become involved.

description: SCOTCH PLAINSA 250pound bronze bell that hangs above the main entrance to St. Bartholomew the Apostle Church here symbolizes the people renewal taking place within the Roman Catholic parish.

title: A starstudded life
description: Don't be discouraged by the foolish title of this book. Miss Palmer seems to have known everybody interesting during 60 years of a life spent on the stage in Berlin, Paris, London and New York, in films in Hollywood and Munich, and painting in Portofino and Switzerland. She tells her story episodically, modestly and honestly, with enough details of daily life to allow a full picture of herself to emerge. She shows great skill in presenting small portraits of the people who have passed through her lifeNoel Coward George Bernard Shaw, Fritz Lang, Garbo, the Windsors,

title: Rabbi Asserts American Jews Will Spurn OneIssue Candidate
description: DALLAS, Nov. 8The head of American Reform Judaism's congregational body said here today that American Jews would not vote for any Presidential candidate on their appeals to one issue alone, such as their stands on Israel, or Soviet and Syrian Jews.

description: Mark Lewis and Tim Johnson provided the fireworks as Red Bank Regional boosted the longest winning streak in Nev.. Jersey to 24 games yesterday with a 330 victory over Shore Regional.

description: TRENTONNow that the Dethocrats are assured of continued majorities in both houses of the Legislature, party leaders are beginning to maneuver for the various leadership changes that will take effect before the new session begins in January.

title: TV VIEW
description: he commercial networks haven't fallen upon hard times, exactly. ABC, CBS and NBC will doubtlessly still be comfortably in the black come fiscal year's end. But the standard operating script has taken some curious detours. In the crucial dollarandcents competitionior audience ratings, CBS, longtime leader, slipped briefly into third place, a surprise development that assured the cancellation of Beacon Hill. NBC had a sensational sevengame World Series to shove it to the top, but that baseball event comes around only once a year 'The new series have been displaying an astonishing inability to attract audiences. And perhaps most significantly, a recent Nielsen report reveals a 6 percent drop in total household viewing. If the public ever actually rebels against mediocre programming, the tired game of lowest common denominator is over.

title: Plan Urged on Use Of Delaware Basin
description: Planning options for the Delaware River Basin, a 290milelong tract from the Catskill Mountains to the Delaware Bay, are rapidly diminishing, a Government study has warned.

title: Odds Against Isabel
description: With a dramatic rejection of demands that she resign the Presidency, coupled with her decision to grant Argentine workers a 20 percent wage increase, Isabel Martinez de Pern appears to have shored up her position temporarily. But a combination of raging inflation, financial scandals and unabated terrorism leaves her political survival and that of the splintered Peronist movement very much in doubt.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Aaron Copland, as old as the century but in much better shape, celebrates a birthday this week, which makes this a reasonable time to celebrate Aaron Copland. At 75, he is not our oldest active composer, and we still are in no position to predict with conviction that he will,be considered by later generations to have been one of our best. But the signs are promising: the precociously early start, the voluminous output, the wide variety of works, the respect of colleagues, andnot leastthe enduring popularity of many pieces with the general public. The man who composed both the spiky, atonal Piano Variations and the lyrical Appalachian Spring would seem,to.have made a contribution to musical culture that should.last a while. By one rule of thumb, at any rate, Copland long ago became immortal: in music, quoth Brahms with tongue halfway through his cheek, any work that lasts 30 must be considered immortal.

title: Guatemala Urged to Mobilize
description: QUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 8 (Reuters)  Rightwing politicians today urged the Guatemalan Government to mobilize the country's reservists to support its claim to Belize.

title: Paperbacks
description: AMERICAN POPULAR SONG, by Alec Wilder. (Oxford, $6.95.) An account of the kind of tunes we whistled during the century's first half, with serious but never solemn consideration of their form as well as their composers: the author is opinionated, his enthusiasm infectious.

title: Jazz Notes: Dave Brubeck s Quartet Regroups
description: When the members of the Dave Brubeck Quartet, which broke up eight years ago, come together in February to start a fourweek reunion tour, it may be, according to Paul Desmond, the alto saxophonist in the group, the most serious competition for Mount Rushmore in a long time.

title: Palestinians Made F.A.O. Observers; U.S., Israel Protest
description: ROME, Nov. 8 (AP)With only the United States and Israel voicing objections, the Palestine Liberation Organization was given observer status today at the Food and Agriculture Organization's governing conference.

title: A playwright's invention named Papp
description: Even as he talks, the most powerful and singleminded man in the American theater is changing his mind, and tactics, and schedule.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Not long ago, a New York woman I know awoke one morning and discovered her eyebrows were out. I don't mean they had stepped out for a drink before breakfast. Even in New York, eyebrows aren't doing that sort of thing yet.

title: The Outdoors Is a Classroom
description: FRANKLIN LAKESThe outdoors is becoming a special classroom for grammarschool pupils under a pioneering naturestudy project sponsored by the New Jersey Audubon Society.

title: N. R. Burke Weds Claire Gardiner
description: Claire Juliette Geszty Gardiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Pennington Gardiner of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday morning to Nicholas Randolph Burke, son of Mrs. J. Murray Mitchell of Washington. and J. Randolph Burke of Gladwyne, Pa.

description: Police investigations of terrorist bombings attributed to a Puerto Rican nationalist groupF.A.L.N., the Fuerzas Armadas de Liberacion Nacionalhave been hampered by restrictions on counterintelligence, according to testimony just released by the Senate Internal Security Subcommittec

title: Governor's Veto on Schools Is Upset by Daley Forces
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 8A crucial round in a political power struggle between Illinois's two leading Democrats has been narrowly won by Mayor Richard J. Daley, who succeeded in overriding Gov. Daniel Walker veto of $81 million in state spending for schools.

title: NIXONTAXADVISER HAS RESTED CASE
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 8Ralph G. Newman, a literary appraiser accused of lying and helping President Nixon claim an illegal $450,000 tax deduction, has rested his case without calling any witnesses or taking the stand himself.

description: One way of summing up Robert de Gaetano's New York debut recital at Tully Hall on Wednesday night is to say that tie was ultrasuccessful in ultrapiabistic music.

title: NEWS BLACKOUT ON TV IS ALLEGED
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 7The Federal Communications Commission has begun hearings here into allegations that the owner of a television station in this state capital blacked opt local politicians and suppressed news items in order to further his own interests.

title: A half century as a bookman
description: William Targ has been one of New York's more able and industrious book editors for the past 30 years, and this scattershot memoir of his half century as a bookman (including 13 years as a bookseller and shoestring publisher in Chicago) is brought out by the same firm he first went to work for as an office boy in 1925. There is a pleasing symmetry in this arrangement, and one would prefer to join this plainly goodwilled man of letters in celebration of his long survival in the literary wars. Mr. Targ, alas, has committed here an act of protracted selfindulgence that one suspects he would severely reprimand in the work of any author he

title: Ford and Reagan Backers Play New Hampshire Numbers Game
description: CONCORD, N. H., Nov. 7Tide numbers game has already begun in New Hampshire, more than three months before the Presidential primary on Feb. 24.

title: VOTE FRAUD STUDY IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8The sun seems to have gone behind a cloud for city employees here, with some under investigation on vote fraud allegations and all suffering from voter rejection in an election this week.

title: Legislative Plarii Is Not Dead Yeti
description: MINEOLANassau County Democrats, who suffered a substantial defeat in last week's elections, including rejection of a county legislature that they had promoted, are considering further court action to either have the present weightedvoting system declared unconstitutional or to have the courts order the seating of the legislators who were elected.

title: East Orange Mall Sought
description: EAST ORANGECity officials are counting on a projected $5million mall to restore Central Avenue to its status as one of North Jersey's most prosperous shopping streets.

title: In Respite, Lebanese Shop and Await More War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 8Thousands of Beirut residents were emerging from hiding in homes and cellars today for a look at the destruction in their city in the recent weeks of street warfare between Christians and Moslems.

title: Stanford Beats U.S.C. On Late Kick by 1310
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP)Mike Langford kicked a 37yard, field goal with five seconds to play today and Stanford upset ninthranked Southern California, 1310, in a Pacific8 Conference game.

description: Some years ago, a sudden and drastic rise in the level of the Great Salt Lake in Utah threatened to inundate a salt extraction plant nearby. The company, at considerable cost. had the plant sandbagged and dikes built, saving the operation.

title: Young Whooping Cranes Fly Southward With Foster Parents
description: SOCORRO, N.M., Nov. 8The arrival of the first whooping crane hatched by foster parents has raised the hopes of Fish and Wildlife officials that their experimental eggtransfer plan would succeed in eventually providing North America with two separate populations of the endangered species.

title: Chicago Hospital Strikers Under Pressure to End Longest Walkout by Doctors
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 8Strikers at Cook County hospital are under increasing pressure to end the nation's longest walkout by doctors.

description: ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)  Diplomatic relations between Ghana and Guinea. broken off, when former President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana was ousted in 1966 were fully restored yesterday.

title: U.S.Amateur Boxing: An Uphill Fight To Find Enough Money to Keep Going
description: Not even Muhammad Ali can stand up to the challenge of 385,000 Russians. And if this sounds like an absurd mismatch, it does indicate the, present plight of amateur boxing in America.

title: Computer Federalism
description: The plan to put the Federal Bureau of Investigation criminal information computer center at the service of local law enforcement agencies has now gone to the White House for approval. The basic question for the President to ask about this plan is: Who needs it?

title: Cranach to Daumier to Nast
description: Historically, political cartoons developed out of caricatures, which originated around the 16th century. During the Reformation, Lucas Cranach, inspired by Martin Luther, caricatured the Pope. The 16thcentury painter Annibale Carracci is credited with having chosen the term caricatura (the Italian verb caricare means, among other things, to exaggerate) for comic drawings he enjoyed making. The paintersculptor Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini, who was born in 1598 and caricatured famous people of his day, is said to have introduced the word into France when he went there in 1665, during the of

title: Notre Dame Subdues Ga. Tech
description: SOUTH 13END, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP) Ross Browner and Jeff Weston led Notre Dame's defense today as the Irish bottled up Georgia Tech, 243, in an intersectional football game.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: Man is by nature acquisitive. That's a truism that every businessman can verify each time he examines his company's shrinkage figures.

title: What's Doing in MEXICO CITY
description: NUMERO UNOLast year, for the first time, Mexico outdrew Britain (1,012,828 to 859,882) as the No. 1 air destination of Americans traveling abroad and an additional 2,600,000 Americans arrived by automobile, bus, train and ship. The record flow is continuing this year, and Mexico City is playing host to hundreds of thousands of inflationplagued Americans put off by high prices in European capitals. Firsttime American visitors, breathing the rarefied air and downing exotic drinks, might begin to feel so young they'll mistake the capital for another Shangrila. But a word of warning: Don't try to keep up with the Mexicans (who are accustomed to the high altitude); they seem to be staying awake nights, crowding discotheques and playing sophisticate to a degree never before matched in the Land of Mariana. In their new role as Numero Uno, its as if they're hoping maana will never come.

title: Business Bribery Close to Home
description: The attention of the American business community has been riveted lately on disclosures of bribery or kickbacks abroad by such giant American corporations as the Gulf Oil Corporation, the United Brands Company and the Ndrthrop Corporation. The Justice Department was urged recently to form a new division on corporate crime in an effort to curtail such illegal or immoral corporate activities. However, there's a bribery problem right here at home that is largely overlooked. It is extremely widespread, costly, and has grown enormously in the past 15 years. It is grafttaking by purchasing executives.

title: Such a Strange Lady
description: Such a Strange Lady is about the sort of woman more readily found in England than here. Dorothy L. Sayers was eccentric; didn't fit. She was Oxfordeducated, an outspoken feminist, noisy, brash, frumpy and brilliant. Critics tried to pigeonhole her, but she escaped. First, she wrote mystery novels. Lord Peter Wimsey,, her bestknown creation, is an 18thcentury Whig character adrift in the modern world solving mysteries. No Philip Marlowe or Inspector

title: EUROPEWIDE VOTE IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 8The idea seemed as simple as it was attractive. On the first Sunday of May 1978 approximately 150 million voters In the nine European Common Market countries would elect 355 representatives to the European Parliament

description: A spokesman for the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said that sodium nitrate was not permitted in any wines in this country, either domestic or imported. At the same time, he acknowledged that the bureau had neither the facilities nor the manpower check all wine coming into this country from abroad.

title: Cesar Chavez
description: The zealot must make many personal sacrifices in his absolute commitment to a cause. One of the continuing prices Cesar Chavez must pay for his commitment to the cause of the American farm worker is the public perversion of his character and leadership. To his enemiesled by corporate growers in Californiahe is a rabblerousing devil. To his followersand there are tens of thousands of them throughout the nationhe is a gentle saint, a purifying leader in the often brutal realm of the farm

title: Bulgaria: Development Model
description: SOFIA, BulgariaBulgaria, staunch defender of the Soviet version of the Communist faith and developing country on the threshold of developed status, appears to be making a bid to become the howto model for poorer nations around the world seeking economic transformation.

title: ART VIEW
description: The revival of realism In painting is no longer an isolated or eccentric phenomenon on the contemporary art scene. It has cast off the defensive air that still surrounded it only a few years ago, and nowadays looms es movement of considerable energy and ambition.

title: Miss Illoway Plans Marriage in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Illoway of Bryn Clovis Farm, Paoli, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Illoway. to Karl R. Schoettle Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schoettle of Haverford, Pa. A wedding next April is planned.

title: Riding Out the Storm at Channel 13 With Jay Iselin
description: Channel 13 (WNET) is in a state of turmoil. Memos are flying around the offices of New York City's public televisidn station. Employees are wondering if and when they're going to be fired The staff is meeting with management; management is meeting with the board of trustees; the executive committee of the board is meeting.

title: A Russian tells us how to treat Russia
description: Andrei Sakharov has two great achievements to his credit: as a nuclear physicist he made an important contribution to Russia's development of the hydrogen bomb, and today he is the most eminent and active spokesman for dissidents in the Soviet Union. As Solzhenitsyn proclaims the freedom of the individual in the name of a Christian Russia so Sakharov proclaims that freedom in the name of universal moral norms of a secular nature. And for this he has just received the Nobel Prize for Peace. This book answers the legitimate questionwhat is the connection between unrelenting criticism of the policies of the Soviet Union and the promotion peace?

title: For Some Reason, Psychology Is Popular
description: A combination of traditional and untraditional reasons has made psychology a college campus favorite.

title: A man for all Victorian seasons
description: Of all the eminent Victorians few were more eminent, none more Victorian than the Rev. Charles Kingsley, chaplain to the QueenEmpress and Canon of Westminster Abbey: Kingsley the original Muscular Christian, the author of The WaterBabies, his immensely influential parable for children, the Sanitation Reformer, the man who wrote For men must work and women must weep

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8(Reuters)  The authorities have begun a campaign to prepare the people for reunification of the longdivided country.

title: Timor Group Favors Talks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 8 (UPI)The Democratic Union of Timor, one of the three rival independence movements engaged in a civil war in Portuguese Timor. today accepted an invitation from the Lisbon Government to hold discussion on the peaceful decolonization of the territory.

title: If You Go
description: . to Panama and the San Blas islands from New York, you can make hotel reservations through any travel agent, or apply to the Congressa, as I did. There are Cuna men, particularly those who work at Fort Amador, who speak English, and who will serve as your interpreter for about $5 day. Otherwise, you can go with a group from one of several Panama City hotels, which provide their translators.

title: Learning to Live The Colonial Life
description: THE American Revolution wasn't just soldiers running around in uniforms. What was it like to be an average guya farmer, a workerwith this cataclysmic war going on but he still has to bring in the hay? What was it like for the ordinary family 200 years ago?

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThere was irony in President Ford's remarks about the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. The President said that maybein retrospectit was a mistake for the Federal Government to have bailed out Lockheed but that in any case there was a fair distinction between bailing out Lockheed by guaranteeing its loans and bailing out New York City.

title: For Montclair, Change Comes Slowly
description: MONTCLAIR  Three decades ago, Montclair was regarded as another of New Jersey's bedroom communities, with most of its homeowners commuting to jobs in

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  Leaders of both major political parties, attempting to assess the outcome of last week's election, were in general agreement that the results were a victory for conservatives and that public opposition to new government spending would dominate legislative proceedings in the upcoming session.

title: Encounter: A Synagogue in Damascus
description: IT Is very dark in Damascus at A.M.dark and deserted. I was waiting in the lobby of our hotel last August along with another Congressman, Joseph Early, of Massachusetts. He had volunteered to join me on a visit to a synagogueand I had accepted. Even though we would be escorted by a guide sent by the Syrian Foreign Ministry, even though I was sure there was no danger, one's irrational fears can reign at that hour, particularly when alone in an unfriendly country.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Nov. 8(AP)The United States holds most of the cards in the Middle East peace stakes., President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today at the end of his first official Western tour.

title: NoHo Residents Resist Loft Rezoning
description: A number of residents of the NoHo areamany of whom apparently live illegally in loft, buildings of the old rnanufacturing districtappear to be cool, if, not hostile, toward a Planning Commission proposal to rezone the area to permit the legal conversion of some lofts into apartments.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: News of The Realtor Trade
description: The Prudential Insurance Company has foreclosed a 26story office building at Lexington Avenue and East 40th Street. The building's owners are the 360 Lexington Avenue Corporation, of which Melvin Senville is a principal, and the 125 East 40th Street Corporation.

title: PARTHENON DANCERS. SEEN AT FELT FORUM
description: To preserve a folkdance tradition and present these dances in a, theatrical setting has been a growing concern in variety of nations. Kaiti Frangedaki has been a leader of the movement in Greece, and Friday evening he presented the Parthenon Dancers of Greece at the Felt Foruni.

title: 5 Die in Spanish Crash
description: LAZA, Spain, Nov. 8(Reuters)  Five persons died and several were injured when an express train ran off the rails near this northwestern Spanish town early today, officials said.

title: Financiers Here Shy Off From Aiding Ford
description: President Ford's promise to veto Federal legislation that would aid New York City appears to have cost some support among New York businessmen, financial executives And professionals who have helped bankroll the Republican Party in the east.

title: Susan Ann Hillman To Be Wed Jan. 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. G. Hillman of Lake Forest, Ill., and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Hillman, to Robert Pennell Griffiths, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Findley Griffiths of Hinsdale, Ill., and Naples.

title: Action Against Unification Churrch Called Difficult
description: WASHINGTONThe New Jersey Congressman who is leading an inquiry into the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church says it may be difficult for Congress to take any action against the controversial movement.

title: Getting To Know The Cuna Indians
description: ISTOOD alone  at the entrance to the bare wooden structure, gazing over the sturdy backs of 25 Cuna Indians and toward the front of the Congressa, where three chiefs swung in hammocks, sucking on long clay pipes. I shifted nervously. I had a favor to ask, but I could not understand a word.

title: Love letter to himself, poisonpen letter to the world
description: One night during the midfifties, when Walter Winchell must have been already at the nether end of his power, I happened to catch a glimpse of  him leaving a limousine near the Stork Club. Posting himself 10 or 15 yards west of the Club, he squinted into the far distance and took quick, tiny steps which never carried him beyond one sequined cement square in the sidewalk. While he paced he seemed to be making, so far as I could tell from across the street, motions of greeting or dismissal. He continued

title: The impossible Dream: A Cat's View of Cope
description: FOR a black American, Copenhagen is the impossible dream: a Western World city in which a member of a racial minority is respected as a human being. For a black jazz musician like me, Cope has something extra: It's a place where a jazzman is appreciated as an artist, even treated like a celebrity sometimesand where, just maybe, he can eke out a living playing his music.

title: CANADA DISRUPTED BY POSTAL STRIKE
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 8The national postal strike, which has caused economic disruption and personal inconvenience throughout Canada, entered its 19th day today with no indication when negotiations would be resumed between the striking union and the Government.

title: CAVIL RIGHTS UNITS LOSING SUPPORT
description: Observers believe that the recession and shifting national priorities that have led the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to the brink of fiscal disaster are also hastening the steadily declining broadbased support for civil rights efforts generally.

title: The cartoon killers thrive again
description: WASHINGTON. Benjamin Franklin, in addition to everything else, was the first political cartoonist in America. His drawing (at right) of a snake divided into eight parts, published in Philadelphia in 1754, is the oldest American political cartoon on record. A cartoon, of course, is a drawing (or series of drawings) that symbolizes, satirizes or caricatures some subject or action or person. When the subject or action is political, or the person is a politician, the cartoon is a political cartoon. Franklin's drawing wasn't much, but his subject was as political as treason. It was an exhortation for a united front against Britain: the snake's head symbolized New England, the seven parts of the tail the other American colonies, and the caption read: Join, Die.

title: Can Rock Ever Learn To Dance Again?
description: Shame, shame, shame/ Shame on you/If you can't dance, too, wails the refrain of last spring's hit record by Shirley (and Company). It was a taunt from black discodance singers to white rockandrollers because the latter had for years neglected to provide rhythms to which audiences could strut their stuff. Black musicians played and sang danceable music, and now with the disco craze at its height and the urge to dance stronger than ever, white rock musicians have been caught flatfooted.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The idea of using real people in mystery novels is not new. Indeed, it was only a few weeks ago that this column followed no less than Humphrey Bogart going down the wire with Andrew Bergman's private eye in Hollywood and Levine. But no writer, certainly within recent memory, has carried matters to the extent that Joe Gores has in HAIVINTEIT (Putnam's. $7.95).

title: If Reagan Is Candidate, He'll Drop Radio Show

Over the past 60 years many have tried, but few have succeeded. Something always goes wrong no matter what approach a director takes, whether filming an actual stage production or a cast of dubbedover actors in a naturalistic setting. The results almost invariably turn out to he faintly ludicrous as the two media obstinately

title: Eugenio Montale: Ascending
description: Eugenio Montale, just given the Nobel Prize, deserves it. His poems are difficult to enter at first, not because of his sound, which is magnificent and open to everyone, but because of his intense relation to objects. There are enthusiasts who love objects. When they meet one, they feel their psychic energy flow into it. When they meet a dog they exclaim: Oh what a wonderful dog! They love their own energy in the dog. Neruda like that in his Odes; Martinson, who got the Nobel Prize last year, is like that sometimes. Montale is not that sort.

title: Tarrytown's Sunnyside and Lyndhurst: Fulfilled Fantasies

Y., have one thing in common: they are fulfilled fantasies. Washington Irving, New York's first writercelebrity, author of The Alhambra and The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, wanted a quiet country home for his writing, while financier Jay Gould, another New Yorker of the 19th century, found a showcase for his kidglove, diamondbreastpin kind of gaudiness.

title: Those Personnel Changes Seen from Peking, Moscow

The leaders of the Communist world are likely to conclude that the policy of detente with the Soviet Union has won out over the position of the hardliners.

After finishing last in the Class C races held by the Roton Point (Cann.) Sailing Association, Patrick Beatty, Splice's builder and skipper, went home to Johannesburg to modify his design. Splice, the hybrid that combines aeronautical knd marine design concepts, was sold to

In it the Angolans turn to God and ask: Tell us Lord, why have you blessed us so? Other countries have deserts and we have lush lands. Where others are poor, we have diamonds and oil and coffee. Why have you singled us out?

For one thing, it has been a competitive sport for only a short portion of its total history, and competition always breeds new ideas, techniques, and, in this case, materials and equipment.

title: Next Weekend in France, Each Chief of State Will Have a Topic
description: WASHINGTONEconomic policy has become too serious a matter to be left to finance ministers or treasury secretaries alone. That is why next weekend, President Ford will lock himself away in a French chateau with the heads of government of the other five leading industrial nations to discuss the grave economic difficulties confronting the world. Besides his host, the French President, Mr. Ford will confer with the German Chancellor and the Prime Ministers of Britain, Italy and Japan.

title: Layoffs by City Threaten Jobs in. Private Industries
description: More than 15,000 jobs in private industry will disappear as a direct result of city budget reductions already imposed, according to projections by knowledgeable economists.

title: BRIDGE
description: In one respect American bridge organizers are less hospitable to foreign visitors than their European counterparts. If an Italian, or any other foreigner, comes to the United States he is barred from competing in the three most important national events: the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the Spingold Knockout Teams, and the Reisinger Teams. The rationalization is that these events are steppingstones to the selection of the American world championship team, but the same result could be achieved with equal effectiveness and less discourtesy by ruling that a team containing a foreign player could not have any qualifying nights for international playoff matches.

The hijackers are demanding a ransom for their release.

title: Food
description: Although there is no disputing the vastly increased sophistication of this nation's palate during the past two score years, it is remarkable to what extent Americans limit their indulgence in pasta to spaghetti, lasagna and macaroni. There are dozens of interesting pastas with myriad shapes, each designed to please the palate with an esthetic difference. One of the finest pasta chefs in Manhattan is Alfredo Viazzi, proprietor of two excellent restaurantsthe Trattoria da Alfredo, 90 Bank Street, and Tavola Calda da Alfredo, 285 Bleecker Street. A short while ago we invited Alfredo into our kitchen to turn his fine Italian hand in preparation of sauces for different pastas. The pastas include orecchiette, or little ears, with tomato anchovy and olive sauce; fettucelle, with tomatoes, tuna and capers; and green tagliarini, with chicken livers, tomato and prosciutto.

title: BOB WEIR'S KINGFISH OFFERS BLUES ROCK
description: The urge toward a solo career, is common in rock music, where group life is not noted for longevity. Bob Weir, a guitarist, and singer, who appeared at the Beacon Theater on Friday, is a former member of the Grateful Dead, the San Francisco group that had such impactin both lifestyle and musicon the West Coast rock scene when it first emerned.

title: The Old Red MarxillacShe Ain't What She Used to Be
description: LONDON  The same threeword sentence has been uttered to me twice in the past year by men who are unacquainted with each other but who both came to world fame as Marxists or Communists. The sentence was simply: Marxism is dead. And both men, it turned out, meant the same thing by it.

title: Benjamin Raskob, Bank Officer, Marries Elizabeth J. Dougherty

I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and with the General Motors Corporation, were married yesterday afternoon in St. Joseph!s Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del. Msgr. Henri I. Foltz, assisted by Msgr. Wilson Kaiperformed the ceremony.

title: J R
description: One of the hundred or so characters in this novel, a failed teacher and aspiring lecher named Vo gel, is working on a process to convert noise pollution into frozen shards, which when collected and dumped into the sea will defrost out of hearing and out of harm. Environmentalists, naturally, are interested; but the promotional literature on Frigicom stresses its applicability to the arts. Whole concerts, operas, books read aloud will be frozen and preserved; in particular, Frigicom will make widely available longer works of fiction now dismissed as classics and remaining largely unread due to the effort involved in reading and turning more hundred pages.

title: LISBON PREPARES TO FREE ANGOLA

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov: 8Harvard would have given its kingdom and probably even the Yard for an experienced quarterback today as Princetonr.with the most experienced signalcaller in the Ivy League, scored a 2420 upset, dropping the Crimson from the league lead.

Kiefer of Old Saybrook. The Rev. Eugene A. Solega performed the ceremony.

title: Is Uncle Sam Crowding Out Other Borrowers?
description: WASHINGTONNine months after Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon first warned that the current heavy deficit financing could crowd out private borrowers from the credit markets, push interest rates up sharply and possibly abort the economic recovery, none of these dire consequences has come to pass. And a number financial analysts question whether Mr. Simon's foreboding will be realized even next year, when the recovery is in full swing.

title: New Airport Service

The oneway fare to or from Kennedy is $5 and to or from  La Guardia is $4, including baggage.

title: VANDERBILT CAMP BOUGHT FOR STATE
description: The luxurious camp buildings of the Vanderbilt? on Sagamore Lake in the Adirondacks have been purchased by a non profit organization and will be preserved for use by the public, the state's Department of Environmental Conservation has announced.

title: ...And Lettuce In the Basement
description: We had a little sleet last December, and to take my mind off the gloomy weather,. I planted some lettuce down in our cellar. On New Year's Day, I picked a small but delicious fresh garden salad. The harvest continued several times every week until April.

title: Foes Aim at Defeat Of Federal E.R.A.
description: TRENTONElated by victory at the polls last week, leaders of the campaign that helped to defeat the state's Equal Rights Amendment have begun a drive to repeal New Jersey's endorsement of the Federal Equal Rights wide spectrum of proposed Amendment and to attack a political legislation they regard as liberal.

title: Prehistoric Art Is an Endangered Species
description: In 1879, a young Spanish girl, accompanying her archeologist father, discovered bison, boars, horses and deer roaming the ceiling of a cave In Altamira. The animals, many of them long extinct, were painted in blacks, red and ochres; unseen for perhaps 20,000 years, they stood, walked or crouched on the ceiling, their positions often dictated by the contours of the rock. It the first indication of the existence of prehistoric art, and the paintings were immediately dismissed as fakes, incompatible with the idea of early humans as brutes without real language, much less art. Their importance has, of course, since been recognized by art historians and anthropologists.

title: Franco, Under Sedation, Is Stable After Surgery
description: MADRID, Nov. 8Generalissimo Francisco Franco appeared today to be fighting off the effects of his second major operation in five days but was still troubled by uremia and needed a kidney dialysis machine to. hold down the level of urea in his blood.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Nome Improvement. Column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters published here ask questions similar to those posed by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here, but who will, nevertheless, find their answers printed below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: Georgetown's String Cut by Hofstra, 4016
description: HEMPSTEAD. L.I. Nov. 8 Hofstra crushed previously undefeated Georgetown, 4016, today in the Flying Dutchmen's annual Homecoming Day game. The Dutchmen struck in the first period on a 1yard run by Tom Freeley, a quarterback, who had an excellent day, completing nine passes in 16 attempts for 161 yards and three touchdowns.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE LABOR DEPARTMENT reported that wholesale prices, seasonally adjusted, rose by 1.8 percent in October, the largest monthly increase this year. Increases for new cars, lumber and textile products were significant... First National City Bank reduced its prime rate to 7% percent from 734 percent, the third decline in the past two weeks. Other banks are expected to follow... Capital spending in 1976 will total $123.45 billion, according to McGrawHill's latest survey. Expenditures are expected to climb 9 percent over the 1975 level.

title: Banking: Good money on bad loans
description: Only artful lenders could have created those artful borrowers, from New York to Sri Lanka. Yet our banks are sound even though their debtors aren't.

title: Food News
description: SCOTCH PLAINS  Like the walls of Jericho, the food prices at the All Fresh Thrift Store on Route 22 keep atumbling down.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Manyof my earliest and most persistent architectural memories are of the Beaux Arts.in New York, but I was unaware of it, like Moliere's bourgeois gentilhomme who didn't know he was speaking prose. When did become aware of it, I found out I wasn' t supposed to like it. Alas, it was too late. Those buildings were as much a part of my life as my family, and I could neither dismiss nor neutralize my feelings toward them, which were intimately involved in the process of growing up.

title: Tax Unreform
description: In a depressing show of the power of tax lobbyists and of the susceptibility of some Congressmen, the House Ways and Means Committee has transformed the socalled Tax Reform Act of 1975 into what Representative Mikva of Illinois properly calls the Tax Relaxation Act of 1975.

title: Meehan Brothers Batted 333 in Election
description: EDGEWATER  Sirens wailed and bells clanged here last week, as voters specifically Republicans and the town's firemen, celebrated the reelection of a member of the politically prominent Meehan family.

title: Indian Summer Helps Farms To Recoup Some Crop Losses
description: TRENTON  A prolonged spell of Indian summer weather has helped New Jersey farmers, whose crops were damaged by hail, floods and scorching heat earlier in the year, to recoup some of their losses.

title: LIFE FOR BENGALIS RETURNS TO NORMAL
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov. 8 (AP)Government offices, businesses and shops reopened today as Bangladesh began returning to normal after a seesaw power struggle that brought two government changes in week.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: Saturday, Nov. 8. 65th and final day. Weather cloudy for two races, clear thereafter; track sloppy.

title: New Rochelle Police Inquiry Is Asked
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y. Nov. 8A lawyer has been chosen to conduct an unofficial investigation of allegations that the police have mistreated demonstrators supporting the strike of service and maintenance workers employed by a New Rochelle nursing home.

title: Philadelphia Paper Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP)  Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and two of the city's daily newspapersThe Inquirer and The Daily Newsapproved a tentative contract today, averting a threatened strike. A Guild spokesman said the proposed pact covering 875 reporters, editors and advertising employes would be present.ed to the membership for a ratification vote early next week. The Philadelphia Bulletin, the city's other major daily newspaper, reported the pact provides for pay increases ranging from $14 to $33 a week and Increased contributions by the company to the pension fund.

title: The Men Who Are Not Running for President
description: DALLAS, Nov. 8The more you look at the men who are now running for President, the more you have to wonder about the men who are not running.

title: Cynthia Binkerd Wed
description: Cynthia Binkerd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Binkerd of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to James L. Selikoff, son of Dr. S. J. Selikoff of Montgomery, Ala. The Rev. Charles McGowan performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church of America in Atlanta.

title: HANOISOVIET TIE WORRIES PEKING
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 3 The recent visit by Hanoi's top leader to Moscow, in which the North Vietnamese and the Russianssigned two aid agreements and a political declaration upholding Soviet views, appears likelys to strain still further the alreagy shaky ties between China. and North Vietnam.

title: Plants Are Sold To Raise Funds
description: SPRINGFIELD  The greening of New Jersey won some help yesterday with the opening of a threeday plant and decorating show at Temple Sha'arey Shalom here.

title: Schlesinger Given Office Space At International Studies School
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger will move into an office at the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies here after farewell ceremnoy at the Pentagon on Monday.

title: Letters to The Editor

title: Irvington Is Upset By Bloomfield, 277
description: Bloomfield ended Irvington's dream of the first perfect season in its history yesterday with a 277 upset.

title: Streak Maintained By Passaic Valley
description: Passaic Valley remained New Jersey's only unbeaten, untied and unscored upon schoolboy football team yesterday with a 19.0 victory over Garfield, its seventh.

title: Trend Is Not. Destiny
description: In 1575400 years agoithe French scholar Louis Le Roy published a learned book in which he voiced despair over the upheavals caused by the social and technological innovations of his time, what we now call the Renaissance. MI is pellmell, confounded, nothing goes as it should. We, also, feel that our times are out of joint; we even have reason to believe that our descendants will be worse off than we are.

title: 5 Words (Sort of) to Cairo
description: The delayed takeoff for Cairo at eightthirty In the morning displeased Harriman's traveling companion, General de Gaulle. Hardly an easy companion at the best of times, de Gaulle. seemed particularly unbending that morning.

title: Prince Thou Art Suffers A CareerEnding Injury
description: Prince Thou Art, the Darby Dan Farm colt who won this year's Florida Derby but then disappointed in the Triple Crown series, suffered a careerending injury yesterday when he broke down during a halfmile workout at Belmont Park.

title: Spanish, Long Restricted, Are Hoping for a New Era
description: MADRID, Nov. 9A meeting is prohibited, a priest fined, a publication seized or suspended, a movie or play banned. Spaniards have been living with such controls for more than 35 years, and the gradual shift of leadership from Generalissimo Francisco Franco to Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon has brought a promise and an expectation of change.

title: Pilot Says He Gave Man Carrying Gun Push to His Death;
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov, 9, (AP)A passenger who re;  portedly pulled a pistol on the: !pilot of a small private plane he had chartered yesterday was! pushed to his death, the pilot! said, when a door flew open as they were struggling.

title: The Amateurs Are All Upstairs
description: Philip 0. Krumm, president of the United States Olympic Committee; Walter Byers, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association; Willi Daume, who ran the 1972 Olympics in Munich; Billie Jean King, feminist who plays tennis, and a man who claims to be Howard Cosell are due to appear befol'e the President's Commission on Olympic Sports today and tomorrow to say what, in their judgment, is good or bad about the United States Olympic Committee. Mr. Krumm will say what

title: Economic Summit
description: President Ford will be traveling to Europe late this week to attend an economic summit conference at the Chateau de Rambouillet, near Paris, with the leaders France, West Germany, Britain, Italy and Japan. The meeting has been billed as more of a seminar than negotiation.

title: At 200th Year, Marines Face Uncertain Future In More Intricate World
description: The Marine Corps, celebrating its 200th anniversary today, has a great past, a troubled present and an uncertain future.

title: NEW C.I.A. REPORT HAS NO MORE PLOTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9Senator Frank Church said today that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence that is coming out in two weeks would contain some new information on the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency but no new disclosures of agency plans or attempts to assassinate foreign leaders. The committee will close its investigation in February.

title: 15 Busiest Subway Stations Show Big Decline in Riders
description: Fifteen of Manhattan's 65 busieet subway stations have lost more than onethird of their passengers over the last decade, according to a New York Times analysis of the latest Transit Authority ridership figures. Twelve other Manhattan stations have had ridership declines of more than 25 percent.

title: Bronx Gigl, 6, Stabbed; Her Father Is Charged
description: A 44yearold Bronx man who was admitted to Jacobi! Hospital last night suffering from an apparent overdose of pills, was charged with the attempted murder of his 6yearold daughter, who also was admitted to the hospital with multiple stab wounds.

title: 15 Bustest Subway Stations Show Big Decline in Riders
description: Fifteen of Manhattan's 65 busiest subway stations have lost more than onethird of their passengers over the last decade, according to a New York Times analysis of the latest Transit Authority ridership figures. Twelve other Manhattan stations have had ridership declines of more than 25 percent.

title: Life in Beirut Is Calm but Tense AS Factions Maintain CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 9This warnervous capital remained relatively calm today despite widespread public fears and rumors that fighting between Christian Phalangists and Moslem leftists would erupt again over the weekend.

description: FOOTBALL

title: Pope Bids Italians Withhold Support From Communists
description: ROME, Nov. 9Pope Paul VI warned today against support by Roman Catholics of the Communist Party in one of his clearest statements so far on the subject.

title: Giants Lose, 2113; Randy Johnson Stars
description: Randy Johnson, banished from New York by coach Bill Arnsparger last year because he was headed for the World Football League, returned to visit yesterday, but he didn't act like an appreciative guest. Then, too, Arnsparger didn't exactly play the gracious host.

title: Train Carrying Gas Derails And Explodes in Vermont
description: FAIRLEE, Vt., Nov. 9 (UPI) A train carrying liquid propane gas derailed, burned and exploded tonight near this New Hampshire border community, causing evacuation of the, town and lighting up the sky 20 miles away.

title: Volkswagen Rapidly Recovering
description: BONNSpurred by surging car sales in Western Europe, Volkswagen is making a surprisingly fast recovery from the cxisis that rocked the company last year.

title: UltrahighVoltage Lines Studied as Possible Peril
description: Ultrahigh voltage power lines that have been proliferat ng over the eastern United States are looming as a new nvironmental battlegrounda source or electrical emissions suspected by some experts of being potentially harmful to humans and animals.

description: Bishop Asks Prayers in Quinlan Case; Judge's Decision Is to Be Made Today

title: 7,000 Honor de Gaulle
description: COLOMBEY  LES  DEUXEGUSES, France, Nov. 9 (Reuters) Several hundred Gaullists, including former Prime Minister Jacques ChabanDelmas, attended ceremonies here today marking the fifth anniversary of the death of Charles de Gaulle. Seven thousand flocked into this tiny village in eastern France where General de Gaulle lived and died.

title: DRUGGISTS WARN ON MEDICAID FEES
description: A group representing nearly! 1,400 pharmacist  owners of drugstores her voted yester day to give the state until next Sunday to guarantee pay iment of more than $5 million lin pastdue city Medicaid pay ments. The group says it will refuse to fill new Medicaid preIscriptions if payment is not [made.

title: Tanzania Cabinet Shuffle
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 9 (Reuters)President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania announced a new government tonight, listing 10 new appointments in a 26member Cabinet and creating two new ministries. An economics expert, Ibrabbn Kaduma, was appointed Foreign Minister.

title: City Corrals Ranchers in Bid for Aid
description: Three South Dakota cattle raisers, who rode into town at sunset Saturday, predicted over bagels and lox yesterday morning that a default by New York City would cause major financial nroblems back at the ranch.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Commuter operations on the Hudson line of the Penn Central railroad disrupted over the weekend by a freight train derailment, were expected to be back to normal for today's rush hour. On Saturday, 12 cars of an 88car freight train left the tracks near the Ludlow station. There were no injuries.

title: BORYS ROSEN
description: Borys (Bernard) Rosen, who retired recently as president of Precision Graphics, Inc., of Farmingdale, L. I., makers of printed electronic circuits, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 14027 69th Road in Kew Gardens Hills. Oueens.

title: WILBUR H. CRAMBLET OF BETHANY COLLEGE
description: BETHANY, W. Va., Nov. 9 (UPI)  Dr. Wilbur H. Cramblet, president of Bethany College from 1934 to 1952, when he became president of the Christian Board of Publication, the national publishing house of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), died today in a hospital in Wheeling.

title: Wilkins Says AntiJewish Terror Dismays Blacks
description: Roy Wilkins said yesterday that American blacks were appalled at the scattergun terror loosed at Jews, particularly those in Israel, and at the Soviet Union's treatment of Jews.

title: Personal Finance
description: Can you turn a vacation home into a tax deduction?

title: Jeffs Gain P.S.A.L. Playoffs
description: Jefferson, the defending city champion, made the Public Schools Athletic League football playoffs yesterday but barely.

title: Reporter's No On City Fiscal Crisis
description: With mounted policemen's horses tied up to park railings, trash piling up in plastic bags and gray barricades blocking off demonstrators from the surrounding park, the exterior of City Hall these days has a besieged air almost a modernday equivalent of Mont St. Michel during the Middle Ages.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Curran Asks Drive on WhiteCollar Crime
description: More investigations of whitecollar crimes and stronger laws to disbar crooked lawyers were strongly advocated yesterday by Paul J. Curran in a report on his tenure as the United States Attorney here.

title: WOMAN IN MACHINE, SUBJECT OF SUIT, DIES
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (UPI)Judith Ann Debro, in a coma since Oct. 16 and the subject of a court battle to have her lifesupporting machines dislconnected, died today at St. Anthony's Medical Center.

title: Man Hurt in Fight With Housing Police Dies in a Hospital
description: An East Harlem man who was injured in a street scuffle! with Housing Authority police1 men died Saturday in Metropolitan Hospital.

title: Corn and Carter
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, IowaI honestly believe I'm going to be your next President, says former Georgia Governor Jimmy Carter.

title: Flyers Defeat Penguins In a Brawling Game, 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (UPI)With Bobby Clarke scoring his 13th goal, a season high in the National Hockey League, the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6.4, tonight in a game marked by a brawl that stopped action for 19 minutes.

title: Moscow Protester Held
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 9 (UPI)The mother of a Soviet Jew serving a 10year sentence for trying to hijack a plane to flee the Soviet Union staged a second silent demonstration in central Moscow today and was taken away by the police five minutes later. Gesya Pinson Stood outside the Lenin Library with a sign that read: freedom for my son, give us visas to Israel.

title: Music: The American Symphony Opens With Two Premieres
description: The American Symphony Orchestra began its 197576 season yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall with the kind of program that could serve as a model for any ensemble that wishes to keep its franchise as a useful member of our artistic society. The concert, conducted by the orchestra's music director, Kazuyoshi Akivama, used standard pieces as bookendsBerlioz's Benvenuto Cellini Overture first and Beethoven's Eroica Symphony last  and thp space between was filled most interestingly by two premieres, one world, the other New York.

title: A Top Adviser to Britain's Conservative Leader Says the Nation Is Sliding Into Socialist Slumdom
description: LONDON, Nov. 4  Sir Keith Joseph, who will inevitably play a major role in the government if the Conservatives gain power, says that Britain is slipping into socialist slumdom.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Review
description: Considered in a television vacuum, tonight's Hallmark Hall of. Fame presentation? on NBC from 8 to 10, is re, markably appealing. Eric is the story of a young man's valiant but losing battle against leukemia. Filmed on location in Seattle, the production features a beautifully modulated performance by John Savage in the title role.

title: Times and Guild Intensify Talks In Bid to Avert Strike Tomorrow
description: The Newspaper Guild and The New York Times began intensified negotiations yesterday in an effort to reach agreement on a contract and avert a strike threatened for 7 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Knicks Are Defeated, 11596
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 9In probably their worst performance of a season that, alas, is young yet, the New York Knicks lost to the Portland Trail Blazers today, 11596.

title: Belgium to Give Early Pensions To Open Way for Jobless Youth
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 9  The Belgian Government, facing an unemployment problem, has drawn up a plan to give early pensions to 40,000 older workers so that young people can take their jobs.

title: Stores in Belfast Learn to Deal With Fear
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  John McBride Ltd., haberdasher on Fountain Street here, started in business in March 1966. Six months later, the political war that the Northern Irish call the situation led to the troubles.

title: Massachusetts Raises Taxes Sharply Under Pressure of Banks
description: BOSTON, Nov. 9  Massachusetts immediate fiscal crisis wrought by nervous bankers appeared eased this weekend as Gov. Michael S. Dukakis ended a 10month struggle with the state Legislature by signing a $3 billion budget with sharp tax increases and cutbacks in social programs.

title: How to Pay for It
description: A regional tax to sustain the arterial system of this area would have more than the great virtue of making up transportation deficits. It would allow that very reduction in fares and improvement of service that is the only promise of revitalization.

title: Government's Rally In Lisbon Disrupted By TearGas Attatk
description: LISBON, Nov. 9A mass demonstration in support of the Portuguese Government dissolved in panic tonight as teargas bombs were thrown and shots were fired in the air.

title: ARTHUR M. WALDMAN
description: Arthur M. Waldman, a member of the law firm of Waldman & Schaum in Mineola, L.L, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 58 Thorne Place, Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 57 years old.

title: At 200th Year, Marines Face Uncertain Future In More Intricate World
description: The Marine Corps, celebrating its 200th anniversary today,, has a great past, a troubled present and an uncertain future.

title: FEINER CONVICTED IN FELONIES HERE
description: New York City courts convict a lower proportion of felony defendants than do courts elsewhere in the state, but they send more of those found guilty to prison, a state analysis reported yesterday.

title: Bomb Damages First National Branch on Irving P1.
description: A bomb described by the police as containing highgrade explosive detonated at 2:05 A.M. yesterday at a branch of the First National City Bank at 10 Irving Place, at East 15th Street.

title: Sense of Pride and Patriotism Stands Out in Corps
description: From the halls of Montezuma to the shores of Tripoli, Guantanamo Bay, Manila Bay, St. Nazaire, Guadalcanal, Tarawa, Guam, Iwo Jima. Inchon and the beaches of Da Nang, the United States Marines for the last 200 years have fought, died and inspired the nation.
