description: DETROIT, Nov. 13Newcar sales for the first 10 days of November were up 45 percent over the depressed level of the same period last year.

title: Two Fresh and Funny Films on Indonesia and Cuba
description: Two men meet at a party. The big one puts out his hand and booms: "I'm J. Peter Throgmorton. That's me." The small, sallow one puts out his hand and mumbles: "I'm Lycurgus Threep. That isn't me."Michael Rubbo is a Canadian who makes Threeplike documentaries. His theme, as he goes from place to place, is the impossibility of getting at very much reality in any of them.Most documentaries proclaim, stridently or politely: "This is it," or at least, "This is part of it." In his two funny fresh and mostly admirable films on Indonesia and Cuba, Mr. Rubbo's message is: "This isn't it."The films are being shown by Film Forum at the Vandam Theater through Sunday and, again. Thursday through Nov. 23 at 8 P.M.Mr. Rubbo photographs and asks questions and then asks himself what significance or truth or relevance can possibly be contained in what he has filmed or asked. He and his crew set down their camera in a jammed slum in Jakarta or a mental hospital near Havana. They interrupt life, slide off the realities and leave their footprints all around.But most documentaries carefully conceal their footprints. Mr. Rubbo photographs his.In the film on Indonesia "Wet Earth and Warm People," for example, where Mr. Rubbo is trying to encompass the vast, horrendous population-poverty cycle, we see him visibly lost on a swarming street, wondering what possible question or approach could even begin to make a dent.Husky, copper-bearded, direct, he has that self-awareness so rare in both journalists and film makers. He knows his simple presence is enough to scare off the tenuous clues he is seeking."My cameraman looks like a small colonialist," he muses, standing beside a Landrover from which his crew is unloading equipment. "I look like one of the Dutch soldiers who used to be here."He tries: he puts up a line of inquiry. For example he learns that the Jakarta authorities are trying to get rid of the swarms of pedicabs, their place presumably to be taken by taxis. This seems monstrous to him: the one available assetmillions of unemployed legsto be replaced by expensive and polluting gasoline engines.He goes about interviewing a pedicab driver, the Mayor, the Chief of Police; trying to ask why. The answers are vague, bland and polite. Gradually his question fades; so does his own certainty that it is a question to be asked.So he lets his camera roam. There is a splendid sequence showing him projecting a film in a village: in the tropical, bug-ridden night the villagers stare big-eyed at a demonstration of how to build an igloo.Even more surreal is the running relationship of good will and incomprehension between Mr. Rubbo and Indonesia's chief of police. Toward the end he shows the police chief and a few friends, decked out in bright-colored pareus, crooning "The Way You Look at Me" on national television."How much it's calculated is hard to say, but I do know he's trying to change the image of the police," Mr. Rubbo comments soberly. He doesn't mock the incongruousness of the scene. He wonders at it, and at his own wonderment. He doesn't spare his own foolishness, and out of it he has constructed a movie that has a beginning of wisdom."Waiting for Fidel," is stronger and tighter but basically it takes the same approach. It is about Cuba, in a way, but it is also about the difficulty in seeing Cuba for what it may be. Again, Mr. Rubbo holds his camera no higher than his own head; it is a perplexed, ambiguous head.What he is filming, in fact, is a traveling argument. His trip to Cuba is taken in the company of two antagonists. One is Joseph Smallwood, a former Premier of Nova Scotia, a lifelong Socialist with a bubbling enthusiasm for the new Cuba. The other is Geoffrey Stirling, a self-made millionaire who is financing the trip and who wields a fierce suspicion of what he is seeing.It is part holiday, part adventure, part inquiry, and it starts with a naive burst of enthusiasm. They have been promised an interview with Fidel Castro. And almost from the first shots it is clear to any journalist who has been promised the same thing that they are in the category of the middling honored visitor: They will get endless hospitality and no interview.While they wait, they take strenuous guided tours around the island. They muse and argue about what they have seen: The fascination is in how little two shrewd and experienced men like Mr. Smallwood and Mr. Stirling really do see.Mr. Rubbo likes the Cuban revolution, but he does not anchor the film to his liking. Perplexity is his instrument for measuring the world, and he never lets go of it.There are disadvantages in the method: a certain blandness, a sameness. If Mr. Rubbo gets around to doing Lapland or Borneo, they may end up more alike than different. He will be standing before the camera in seeming disarray, saying: "This is Lapland (or Borneo). But it isn't."But these disadvantages should not mask his accomplishment. Most documentaries are speeches to the audience or stories told to the audience. His come close to being a dialogue.

title: Ford's Reappraisal of Stand on City Aid Said to Reflect Views of His Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13President Ford's reappraisal of Federal aid to New York City reflects the views of most of his top economic advisers, most of whom now favor shortterm loan guarantees for the city, Administration sources said today.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The Depariment of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $18.3 billion, up 11 percent from the yearearlier $1.2 billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.7 billion, up 13 percent from the yearearlier $10.3 billion.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1975

title: In Yonkers, a Question of Fiscal Leadership
description: YONKERS, Nov. 13 Yonkers, which faces default tomorrow unless the State Legislature provides a solution, has been without firm fiscal leadership for much of the last two years. This, in the view of many who News watched the state's Analysis fourthlargest city move from crisis to crisis, is the major reason for its problem, but there are others, in their view. They say that blame should be attached to the city's increasing use of the same questionable fiscal techniques that helped create New York City's problems.

title: People in Sports
description: After resisting its blandishments for two years, Chris Evert has agreed to join World Team Tennis. The topranked woman tennis player in the world, who won the United States Open in September, signed a twoyear contract with the Phoenix Racquets for an undisclosed salary, but one that the team president, Jim Walker, said made her the highestpaid player in W.T.T.

title: People and Business
description: Carla A. Hills, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, yesterday gave the lagging housing industry some favorable news. She told the National Association of Realtors at its convention in San Francisco that more existing homes were sold in September than in any month in 15 years.

title: OneYear Bills Sold By the U.S. Treasury
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 13The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 6.010 percent.

title: About the Jets
description: There are all sorts of experiments going on in the defensive backfield. The new man, Jerry Davis, has been working out at the right cornerback slot, normally Roscoe Word's territory. Davis has been around only a few days and may not start on Sunday, though. Burgess Owens, returning from an injury, also is working out at corner. He is normally the strong safety.  John Riggins leads the league's fullbacks in total yardage, based on receptions well as rushing.  Bob Gresham may be the halfback on Sunday if Emerson Boozer's sinus ailment doesn't improve and Carl Garrett's hip remains sore.

title: Banks Reported to Favor Moratorium on City's Notes
description: New York City's largest banks were reported last night to be moving toward acceptance of Governor Cary's plan for a moratorium on the payment by New York City of principal on its notes.

title: Coffee Negotiators Propose a Return Of Export Quotas
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP)Negotiators drafting a new world, coffee pact agreed in'principle today on a compromise solution that would reintroduce export quotas if coffee prices plummet conference sources said.

title: More Trouble in Coal
description: Establishing democratic rule in the United Mine Workers after a halfcentury of ironfisted autocracy proving a bumpy process for the reform leadership elected by the nation's coal miners three years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: The introduction to a text published Thursday in The New York Times stated incorrectly that the document, a United States draft resolution on amnesty for political prisoners, had been introduced in the United Nations General Assembly. Actually, the resolution was introduced in the Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee.

description: Morning

title: Canada Cooker Inquiry Set
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (UPI)Canada announced today the start of an antidumping investigation into imports of steam cookers from the United States. The Federal agency said if the investigation turned up evidence of dumping, which occurs when goods are sold it Canada at less than what they would cost in the country of origin, the matter would be referred to a tribunal for a decision on material injury to Canadian production of steam cookers.

title: Notes on People
description: In Rome. Yelena Sakharov decried as a challenge to the world the Soviet Government's explanation that her husband Andrei Sakharov, ould not be permitted to go to Onle Norway, to accept his Nobel Peace Prize because of his knowledge of Soviet nuclear secrets. The physicist, she said, had many contacts with foreign scientists journalists and touristsIf he had wanted to tell state secrets, he could do it in Moscow.

description: The proscribed becomes the permitted; the permitted becomes the prescribed; and the prescribed becomes a great bore.

title: STATE BILLS AVERT YONKERS DEFAULT; H.F.A. ALSO SAVED
description: ALBANY, Nov. 14The City of Yonkers and the New York State Housing Finance Agency both narrowly avoided default today as the Legislature passed a complex, temporary financing plan for Yonkers and State Controller Arthur Levitt used State Treasury funds to buy $80 million of the H.F.A.'s maturing notes.

title: Judith Hahn Is Wed To Robert L. Brenner
description: Judith Silberberg Hahn of Woodbridge, Conn., widow of Harold H. Hahn Jr., was married yesterday morning to Robert Lewis Brenner of Southington, Conn. Rabbi Bruce Cohen performed the ceremony in his study at Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn.

title: 13 NOW Leaders Form A Dissident Network
description: Thirteen present and former leaders of the National Organization for Women have formed a group to broaden the appeal of the women's movement.

title: Art: Recent Tapies Work Keeps Old Spirit
description: One of the more persistent reputations in contemporary European art is that of An toni Tapies, whose recent work is on view through Dec. 13 at both branches of the Martha Jackson Gallery (32 East 69th Street and 521 West 57th Street at 10th Avenue).

title: PAUL P. JULEY
description: Paul P. Juley, art photograper, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 330 West 58th Street.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEEKS CONTEMPT ORDER AGAINST KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The House Select Committee Ion Intelligence, its members angered by their inability to obtain classified information for their investigation, voted overwhelmingly today to hold Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in contempt of Congress.

title: EDWARD A. CONDON
description: Edward A. Condon, a pressman with The New York Times for the last 16 years, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home at 1687 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 52 years old.

title: Robbers Torture Man to Death On the West Side, Son Reports
description: An 80yearold man was found dead in his small penthouse on the Upper West Side yesterday and a son with whom he lived told the police that the two had been bound, blindfolded, beaten and tortured for two days by a pair of thugs who robbed them of $4,200.

title: Frazier Has Tendonitis
description: Walt Frazier, who complained of pains similar shin splints following his career low of 6 points against the Phoenix Suns on Tuesday night, was examined yesterday by the New York Knicks team physician, Dr. Jeffrey Minkoff, and found to have a mild case of tendonitis in the back of both knees.

title: Money

description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Nov. 14 (UPI)An allmale jury found seven members of a snakehandling faith guilty today of disrupting a church service with the reptiles. The defendants, who will be sentenced next Tuesday, had admitted during hteir trial in Bartow Superior Court that into the Calvary Holiness Church and caused a commolion.

title: Carl Lobell Weds Katherine S. Carr
description: Katherine Swenson Carr and Carl David Lobell, both of New York, were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Anna May Nielsen of the Unity Center in Bronxville performed the ceremony at the Colony Club.

description: TRENTON, Nov. 14 (UPI)The final plan of the United States Railway Association to implement the ConRail system is a patchwork analysis of distorted figures that evaporate upon close examination, a state official said today.

description: YONKERS, Nov. 14Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, alone in City Hall tonight except for an aide, expressed profound relief a few minutes after being notified from Albany that his city had avoided default.

title: Edwin Ripin, 45, Musicologist, Old Instruments Expert, Dead
description: Edwin M. Ripin, an expert on old musical instruments, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home at 61 Greenway South in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 45 years old.

title: Grambling, Norfolk Play Here
description: Although thousands of fans in New York and around the country will be interested in the outcome and details of today's football game between Grambling and Norfolk State at Shea Stadium, the general reaction when somebody mentions Grambling is Who've they got this year that's a pro prospect?

title: At Engle School, Difference Is Style
description: SPARTAThe toddlers enrolled in the Engle School, a private institution in this rapidly growing rural community, are experiencing the type of early education once reserved exclusively for the rich.

title: Dearness Office Denies Cavanagh Resignation
description: Mayor Beame's office denied yesterday rumors that First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh had resigned. But one City Hall official, referring to the possibility of resignation, described the situation as fluid.

title: COLEMAN PERFORMS SONGS HE CREATED
description: Cy Coleman, the composer and pianist, appeared Thursday in the Men of Music series at Hunter College, a format that leans toward composers and lyricists not generally seen singing and playing in the limelight and unreeling their musical bographies.

title: BANKS HERE BACK NOTE MORATORIUM
description: Some of New York City's largest banksincluding Chase Manhattan and First National Citysaid yesterday they supported. Governor Carey's plan for a moratorium on the payment by New York of principal on city notes, and for a restructuring, of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

title: Islanders On a Losing Path in West
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14As far as New York teams are concerned, all of California is Death Valley this November, and the Islanders, the latest victims, headed for Vancouver today seeking prompt restoration after last night's 43 loss to the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Jenkins Victor At Horse Show
description: TORONTO, Nov. 14 (AP) Rodney Jenkins of the United States continued his domination of the North American fall jumping circuit with a victory in today's opening event for international equestrian teams at the Royal Winter Fair horse show. The show continues through Nov. 22.

title: BUTZ WARNS F.A.O. ABOUT U.S. SUPPORT
description: ROME, Nov. 14 (UPI)Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today that Congressional support for international agencies was eroding because some countries were using them to settle political scores.

title: PRESS STRIKE ISSUE RESOLVED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP)  A labor dispute that stopped publication of London's national daily newspapers was eased today when the Daily Express withdrew dismissal notices for 96 engineers.

title: Grain and Soybeans Hold Steady Price; Wheat Up 4 Cents
description: Prices of grains and soybeans held steady yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Holdeta of long positions like to liquidate before a weekend, and their selling just about offset purchases by those holding short positions.

title: COURT UPHOLDS U.S. ON MEAT GRADING
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (UPI)A Federal appeals court approved today the right of the United States Agriculture Department to implement new nationwide meat grading standards for the American consumer, livestock feeders and meat related industries.

title: Baseball Owners Yield on Talks
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14 (AP)Major league baseball club owners agreed today to allow arbitration to proceed in the cases of Andy Messersmith of the Los Angeles Dodgers and Dave McNally of the Montreal Expos, who are seeking to become free agents.

title: Pitt Not Home at Home
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 (AP) The University of Pittsburgh said today the National Collegiate Athletic Association had denied its appeal for hometeam status in its Nov. 22 football game here with Penn State. That means Pitt and Penn State can field only 48 players each for the nationally televised game at Three Rivers Stadium. The game was originally scheduled for Pitt Stadium. but was moved to Three Rivers because it has lights to accommodate the late afternoon telecast.

title: Banks Increase Use Of Discount Houses
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the First National City Bank, each of which manages one of the world's biggest investment portfolios are turning increasingly these days to discount stockbrokers to buy and sell small amounts of stock.

title: ... If Default Comes
description: Despite these shortcomings, New Yorkers are compelled to accept the Carey plan as a last desperate bid to avert the far greater disaster toward which the city is being swept as a result of the Ford Administration's vindictive myopia. The local dimensions of that disaster were spelled out in some graphic detail yesterday by Deputy Mayor Kenneth Axelson who warned that we will literally have to shut down the city if assistance is not forthcoming by Dec. 1.

title: SHOP TALK
description: If you ask a number of craftsmen to produce an effective hanging of very small size (no more than 10 inches) in a medium that usually is expressed on rather grand scale, what happens?

description: To the Editor:

title: Susan's Girl Choice Today
description: Susan's Girl, approaching the end of a brilliant career, is favored in today's $50,000added Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct, one of the few top filly and mare stakes she has failed to win. At the Fred W. Hooper's 6yearold mare Race was made the Tracks early 75 choice yesterday when she was entered under top weight of 126 pounds against nine rivals.

title: Director Resigns Commodity Agency
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 14 (AP) The executive director of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has resigned to take an executive position with an exchange that has four potential conflictofinterest cases pending before the agency.

title: GROWTH IN MONEY STIRS CONFUSION
description: The sharpest oneweek increase in the nation's money supply in at least 16 years aroused surprise and confusion among economists and money market analysts yesterday over the current attitude of the Federal Reserve Board on monetary policy.

title: Island or Suburb?
description: Significant help is now on the way to preserve the unique scenic, ecological, and historic qualities Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard. Senator Kennedy, working closely with Senator Brooke, Representative Studds and local officials, recently introduced an amended version of the bill he first offered in 1972 to establish a National Trust to protect these fragile islands.

title: Facing 1.4 Million Deficit, 1 Hofstra Cuts 111 Off Staff
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 14 Faced with an unexpected deficit of nearly S1.4 million this year, the president of Hofstra University, Robert L. Payton, notified 111 of its 600 administrative workers that they were being dismissed as of next Friday. previously would have accepted and that the high school standing of the average incoming freshman had risen from the top 34 percqnt of his class to the top 26 percent.

title: Film System Patented
description: A system for transferring widescreen motion pictures to tape for television broadcasting was among the ideas patented this week. Page 37.

title: F.T.C, STRENGTHENS RIGHTS OF BUYERS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Under a new Government rule announced today, consumers who purchase on credit will receive new protection against merchants who sell shoddy goods or services.

title: Newspaper Guild and The News To Resume Negotiations Today,
description: Negotiators for The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild are scheduled to resume negotiations today in a new effort to resolve their differences and avert a strike threatened for 8 A. M. Monday.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN BLANKCHECK PLOT
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UPI) Richard Keats, the accused mastermind of a plot to bilk the Los Angeles city treasury out of millions of dollars in a stolencheck scheme, was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: DefaultAnticipation Notes Bow at Follies
description: The 1975 version of the Financial Follies, an annual musical parody about events in business, finance and the economy, was presented last night in the form of a town meeting.

title: House Votes to End Panel In Defense Favors inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The House voted today to abolish a Congressional committee that recently emerged from relative inactivity to announce that it would investigate allegations that defense contractors were improperly entertaining Pentagon officials.

title: WESTCHESTER ASKS RISE IN SALES TAX
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14County Executive Alfred B. DelBello said today that he was planning to ask the county's Board of Legislators to raise sales taxes in Westchester County next year to at least 7 percent, or by two percentage points, in many towns and villages.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: MIDWEST

title: Algeria in OilSale Dispute With Big French Company
description: PARIS, Nov. 14France's biggest oil company has been informed that Algeria will not sell it any more oil after the end of the year. The step followed a breakdown in negotiations for a new charter for a joint company.

title: Scores on WOXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station,

title: In Memoriam
description: EDWARDSLouts F. Beautiful memories stilt remain a precious possession.

title: Luanda Is Shattered but Joyful
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 12 There is no water, the electricity flickers, meat is unobtainable and beer is running low, yet the mood here is almost joyous. Spontane ous motorized parades in honor of independence erupt all during the day and night, with drivers picking up pedestrians and carting them on overloaded trucks, with horns blaring in rhythm.

title: Dave Anderson
description: When a baseball argument ends, the umpire should never revive it. The umpire called it the way he saw it, period. When the dispute ends, play ball. But four weeks after his controversial World Series call, Larry Barnett has stirred a new debate by holding Tony Kubek and Curt Gowdy personally responsible for the threats on my life and the lives of my wife and daughter. At least 95 percent of the mail I have received has mentioned the television announcers and their views. I think they were unfair to

title: Rail Traffic Down 7.7%
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 15.9 billion tonmiles, 7.7 percent below a year aao.

title: Soviet Boxers Fall to U.S., 64
description: The United States, inferior in experience and ability and a decided underdog before the competition, scored a smashing victory over the Soviet Union's best amateur boxers in an allheavyweight card at Madison Square Garden last night. The United States won the 10bout program, 6 to 4.

title: G.A.O. FINDS LAXITY ON STUDENT LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP)  Lending institutions are using a Federal program to dun the Government for money they have lent, instead of trying vigorously to collect it themselves, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: XEROX CUTS RENTAL FOR SOME COPIERS
description: The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday rental price reductions on four copier products, effective Jan. 1. Rental of the Xerox 3100 and 3100 large discount copiers wilt be reduced about 0.5 percent. The 4000 will be cut about 21/2 percent and the 4500 will be reduced about 4 percent, base on an average for all customers.

title: Gaining Funds but Losing Its Function Is Choice Given Mount Vernon Church
description: Members of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Mount Vernon, N. Y., most of whom drive up from the Bronx every Sunday morning, are afraid that they will have to give up the soul of their colonial church in order to save its structure.

title: Dual Purpose Funds

title: ROCKEFELLER MOVES TO AVERT A SPLIT
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14 Vice President Rockefeller today moved to avoid the possibility of a split in the New York State Repubilcan Party, warning that attempts to sway the state's Republicans from their official uncommitted status would be resisted vigorously by all of us.

Services will be held at GultermonMusicant.Kreitzmon rarner Passaic and Park Sts., Hackensack, N.I., on Sunday, November 16th at 1:30 P.M.

title: G.O.P. in Congress Assails Oil Accord

title: Cyanamid Unit to Expand
description: WAYNE, N. J., Nov. 14 (UPI) The American Cyanamid Company said today its Dutch subsidiary will build a 15 million acrylamide monomer unit at its Botlek manufatcuring complex at Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The plant, to be in operation in 1978, will replace the existing sulfate process with a catalytic hydrolysis process unit.

title: The Julepizing of America
description: A Presidential campaign approaches and no candidateno, not oneincludes racial justice among the points in his platform, especially not if it to be achieved at any higher cost.

title: 12 Injured on BMT When a Passenger Pulls Stop Cord
description: Twelve persons were injured, none seriously, when a southbound BMT subway train stopped abruptly because a passenger pulled the emergency cord as the train was leaving the 34th Street station at Herald Square at 5:23 P.M. yesterday.

title: A Plan to Conceal Thefts Laid to 2 Grain Executives
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A witness has told Federal investigators that the top two executives of the Bunge Corporation once discussed, at a meeting with junior com pany officials in a New Orleans suburb, a budget item allegedly used to cover income from systematic thefts of grain.

title: FRANCO UNDERGOES A THIRD OPERATION
description: MADRID, Nov. 14 Generalissirno Francisco Franco today, underwent his third operation in less than two weeks after the sutures of the second one burst open.

title: STUDY FINDS POOR UNAIDED IN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A Justice Department study reported today that there had been only token compliance with the landmark Supreme Court ruling in 1972 that required the appointment of a lawyer to represent any indigent defendant who faced a possible jail term.

title: Governor Begins the Bargaining for Higher
description: ALBANY, Nov. 14Governor Carey today opened the bargaining for higher taxes with the Legislature by describing a $1.7 billion shortage in the state budget over the next 17 months that, he said, required tax increases on income, sates, banks, corporations, liquor and cigarettes.

title: Woman Hurt Badly By Subway Train; Man Is Accused
description: A 23yearold Bronx woman was critically insured last night when u man allegedly pushed her in front of a subway train as it pulled, into the West Fourth Street station in Greenwich Village, the police reported.

title: Teacher Sues to Bar Investment in M.A.C.
description: A retired teacher sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to restrain the Teachers Retirement Board from purchasing any securities of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Art: Lyric Vein in Frankenthaler Paintings
description: The paintings of Helen Frankenthaler occupy a distinctive place in the recent history of American abstract painting. Their roots are in the abstract expressionism of Jackson Pollock and Mark Rothko, yet their achievement belongs to the more hedonistic esthetic of colorfield abstraction, in the development of which Miss Frankenthaler played a key role. Unlike other colorfield abstractionists, however, she has never been tempted to sacrifice the freeform lyric immediacy inherent in the nature of liquefied color to straight  edge, geometrical structures. The effect of her large canvases is rather like that of a watercolorist working from nature. We feel ourselves in the presence of imaginary landscapes landscapes distilled into a chromatic essence.

title: TAXI COMMISSION LAYS OFF 2 AIDES,
description: Two deputy commissioners in the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission were laid off yesterday. They were Joseph Cerbone, first deputy commissioner, and Stanley Katz, deputy commissioner for legal affairs.

title: The U.S. Airlift Has Growing Strategic Importance
description: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill.The strategic situation of the United States has developed to a point at which the capabilities of the Military Airlift Command are an increasingly important element in the fulfillment of commitments to Europe and the Middle East.

title: Troubled Past Haunts Summit Scene
description: PARIS, Nov. 14  The choice of the Chateau de Rambouillet as the site of the economic summit meeting proves that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the host, is not superstitious. In its 600 years the chateau has frequently been the scene of trouble or tragedy.

title: Senate Backs Nomination Of Eckerd as Head of G.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The Senate approved today President Ford's nomination of Jack Eckerd, a drug store millionaire in Florida, to head the General Services Administration, the Government's housekeeping agency.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1975

title: Ford Flies to Paris
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Nov. 15President Ford returned to Washington late last night, changed planes at An drews Air Force Base and left almost immediately for an economic summit meeting in Paris.

title: Use of Scrip Is Planned if City Defaults
description: If the city were forced to. default next month, municipal employees and welfare recipients would receive part of their biweekly stipends in scrip, public schools would close indefinitely well before the Christmas holiday, all public construction would be halted and only the most essential servicespolice, fire, garbage collection and nondeferable hospital carewould be maintained.

title: Dumping Permit Extended
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had granted the Du Pont Company a oneyear extension to dump chemical wastes into the ocean at its Edgemoore, Del., plant.. Daniel Snyder, regional administrator, said the permit, which expires Nov. 13, 1976, allows Du Pont to dispose of 115 million gallons of wastes at a site 45 miles southwest of the mouth of the jalaware Bay.

title: Major Angola Group Said to Lose Port
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 14 (Reuters)An armored column led by white mercenaries has captured the port of Novo Dedondo from forces of the Sovietbacked Popular Movement for tyle Liberation of Angola, inforrffed sources said today.

title: Manila Decree Draws Church Protest
description: MANILA, Nov. 14A decree requiring church organizations to obtain Government. approval before assisting in labor causes and banning foreign missionaries from tradeunion 4ctimity was strongly protested today by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila and 3,000 priests and nuns.

title: Starburst Over Mesopotamia Linked to Rise of Science
description: Sometime before the dawn of human civilization Mesopotamia, perhaps about 10,000 years ago, a great star suddenly burst into dazzling brilliance in the southern sky.

title: Lisbon Capitulates To Labor Demands
description: LISBON, Nov. 14The Portuguese Government capitulated today to the demands of angry construction workers who held the Prime Minister hostage for 36 hours.

title: Brandt and Schmidt Are Acclaimed in Party Votes
description: MANNHEIM, West Germany, Nov. 14In an unusual demonstration of solidarity, the left and right wings of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party united today to give him a resounding vote of confidence in the last regular convention before elections next October.

title: Business Briefs
description: Atlantic Richfield Leaves Group

title: Mild Asks New Spirit
description: PARIS, Nov. 14Prime Minister Takeo Mild of Japan called here today for a new spirit of creative international cooperation, the spirit of Ram. bouillet, as he termed it.

title: DEBT MORATORIUM OF 3 YEARS IN CITY PASSED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY. Saturday, Nov. 15  The Legislature, officially finding that New York City's fiscal condition has dramatically worsened and that basic city services would be threatened by the disastrous consequences of default, voted early this morning to impose a moratorium of up to three years on the repayment Of $1.6 billion in city notes falling due between and next June 30th.

title: WideScreen Film Put on Tape Undistorted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Motion pictures prepared for wide screens in theaters can be transferred directly to magnetic tape for television broadcasts without distorting them Patents to fit the much smaller viewing of the window of the Week home television set. The system, called Transcan, was patented this week by K. Blair Benson for the Goldmark Communications Corporation, Stamford, Conn., of which he is vice president. More than 10,000 transfers have already been made by the method disclosed in patent 3,919,474.

title: At School, Instead of Money, Students
description: WASHINGTON, Conn.Middleaged fathers, whose normal exercise is walking from their cars to their desks, gamefully turned into aerialists on unsteady ladders to paint the Gibson dormitory of the Gunnery school last weekend.

title: GERALD P. O'BRIEN
description: Gerald P. O'Brien, a vice president of the United States Fire Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Crum & Forster, died yesterday of cancer in Morristown, N. J. He was 43 years old and lived in Convent Station, N. J.

title: U.S. Indochina Talks
description: Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger told a House committee that the United States was ready to open talks with the Communist nations of Indochina on normalizing relations. Page 9.

title: I. W. LEVER DIES; SHAKESPEAREAN, 62
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 14 (Reuters)Prof. J. W. Lever, Shakespearean scholar, author and playwright, died near here on Tuesday at the age of 62.

title: Employees of Grant Bitter: No Severance
description: Raymond A. Smith, a 31yearold father five children, bleakly considers the end of promising career after the loss of his job as store manager for the W. T. Grant Company.

title: Hypocrisy in Action
description: Item: in 1948 Andrei Gromyko, now the Soviet Foreign Minister, bitterly condemned the Middle Eastern Arab states for sending their troops into Palestine and carrying out military operations aimed at the suppression the [Jewish] National Liberation Movement in Palestine.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was asked the other night in Pittsburgh how much influence should be wielded by the President's national security adviser the position Mr. Kissinger held until 11 days ago.

title: RAYMOND J. CASEY
description: Raymond J. Casey, retired district manager of the John Hancock Life Insurance Company for Westchester, died Thursday in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Father Tortured to Death By Robbers, Son Reports
description: An 80yearold man was found dead in his small penthouse on the Upper West Side yesterday and a son with whom he lived told the police that the two had been bound, blindfolded, beaten and tortured for two days by a pair of thugs who robbed them of $4,200.

title: Morocco and Mauritania In Sahara Pact With Spain
description: MADRID, Nov. 14 Spain agreed today to abandon Spanish Sahara by the end of February and to share its administration there until then with Morocco and Mauritania.

title: Quarterly RateShift Idea For Utilities Stirs Debate
description: A new concept in regulation that guarantees an electric utility a certain level of income through frequent rate adjustments is being considered by regulators in several states as a means of enhancing the attractiveness of utilities to investors.

title: Morocco and Mauritania In Sahara Pact With Spain
description: MADRID, Nov. 14  Spain agreed today to abandon Spanish Sahara by the end of February and to share its administration there until then with Morocco and Mauritania.

title: Tryout For Hargett Canceled by Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 14 (AP)  The New York Jets said today that their reserve quarterback, J. J. Jones, had recovered from a pulled muscle in his rib cage and that they have decided against signing Edd Hargett to replace him.

title: U.S. Gives Thais $940,000
description: BANGKOK. Nov, 14 (Reuters) The United States has given Thailand $940,000 for improving rural living conidtions. It is the first grant for a project expected to involve contributions of $4 million from the United States and $1.5 million from the Thai Government over the next four years.

description: ROME, Nov. 14 (UPI)Luigi Chiarini, a film critic who was director of the Venice Film Festival from 1963 to 1968, died yesterday. Mr. Chiarini, a professor of film history at the University of Urbino, was 75 years old.

title: Major City Ballet Debuts
description: George Balanchine, everyone knows, is in the direct line of descent from the 19thcentury FrenchRussian choreographer Marius Petipa. Occasionally, however, he can go FrenchDanish on us.

description: NEWARK, Nov. 14A program to celebrate International Women's Year is scheduled for Dec. 3 through Dec. 6 in various parts of New Jersey, according to Constance Woodruff, head of the New Jersey Advisory Commission on the Status of Women.

description: ALBANY, Nov. 14Following is the text of the legislative findings and statement of purpose of the proposed legislation pertaining to a moratorium on the payment of New York City securities:

description: The use of scrip dates to the Second Continental Congress, which authorized the use of paper currency to finance the Revolution. Since then, about 500 different types of scrip have been issued by the Federal Government, states, cities, counties, boroughs and school districts in times of fiscal stringency.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) Contract talks between negotiators for four railroad shop craft unions representing 70,000 employees and the nation's railroads will resume tomorrow. The talks, under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, will he held at downtown Washington hotel.

title: Nursing Care Failure
description: The Moreland Act Commission on Nursing Homes was right on target when it called its report on the regulation of nursing care The Paper Tigers. Until recently, the nursing home story in this state, at least, could be pictured as the deposit of a great deal of money on a stump surrounded thickly by two classes of people: those who wanted some of the money and those shuffling official papers who were charged with controlling the program. Unfortunately, very little of all of that activity was necessarily related to the quality of care received by patients in nursing homes.

title: Fromme Jury Hears Ford Tape; Testimony First by a President
description: SACRAMENTO. Calif., Nov. 14President Ford, in a video[tape deposition shown today at the trial of Lynette Alice Fromme, testified that he had, no recollection of hearing a gun click when Miss Fromme allegedly thrust a 45caliber Colt at him here last Sept. 5.

title: Dow Index Rises by 2.44; City and Fed Are Factors
description: The stock market began with a small decline yesterday and ended with a small advance, but its moves in both directions I were only minor as investors apparently stepped back to asjsess the outlook for New York forand, to a lesser extent, for Federal Reserve policy.

title: Colonels Get Caldwell Jones
description: LOUISVILLE: Ky., Nov. 14 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels acquired today 6foot11inch Caldwell Jones, an American Basketball Association allstar who had been a member of the San Diego Sails. The San Diego franchise folded earlier this week.

title: Miss Stacy Ties For Lead on 74
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 14 (UPI)Hollis Stacy of Savannah, Ga., the last player on the course, dropped 20foot birdie putt on the final hole today for a 74 that tied Sandra Post for the firstround lead in the $50.000 Lady Jacksonville oven colt tournament.

title: The True, the Most Consuming Death
description: MACHU PICCHU, PeruWhen Pablo Neruda, the great Chilean poetdiplomat, came to this famous, ancient city of the Incas he was reminded of irresistible death and impressed by the power of the true, the most consuming death.

title: Arabs Hope AntiZionism Vote Will Lead to Vast Reappraisals
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14The Arab League voiced the hope today that debate in Western societies on the Zionist question (raised by the resolution approved by the General Assembly on Monday) would encourage rethinking of many premises and the abandonment of many myths.

title: Kissinger Says U.S. Is Prepared for Indochina Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Sentary of State Henry A. KIssinger told a House committee today that the United Stales was now ready to open discussions with the Communist states of Indochina on normalizing relations.

description: MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (AP)The death of the poet Olga Berggolts, known for her verses about the wartime siege of Leningrad, was reported today by the Soviet press. The date of death was not given. She was 65 years old.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvanians
description: The relationship between the Pennsylvania Ballet and the Brookyn Academy of Music is a gratifying one. Twice a year the company comes to New York and gives four performances at the Academy's Opera House and it is hoped that next year the number of performances will be increased. It offers this very important American company a home from home and a New York showcase. And, of course, New Yorkers are enabled to keep up with a company that many of us like to think of as a sort of permanent troupe.

Lukas Foss, principal conductor of both orchestras, was on the Podium.

description: Volume Declines SlightlyOTC Finishes Lower

description: NEWARK, Nov. 14Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson has charged that the Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum company, discriminates against fueloil customers in innercity areas.

title: Feb. 17 Trial Date Set in Theft At Hughes Coast Headquarters
description: LOS ANGELES  Superior Judge Earl Riley today set Feb. 17 as the trial date for Donald R. Woolbright in the 1974 burglary of Howard R. Hughes's headquarters here.

description: THE WAR OF ATONEMENT. By Chaim Herzog.300 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $10.

title: Wilson and 2,000 Attend Cardinal Heenan Requiem
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) More than 2,000 persons attended a requiem mass at Westminster Cathedral today for John Cardinal Heenan, leader of four million Roman Catholics in England and Wales. He died a week ago at the age of 70.

title: HYLAND BACKS BILL ON JURY EXEMPTION
description: TRENTON, (UPI)The State attorney General's office ruled oday that it would not be a violation of the Constitution to allow people 70 years or older to exempt themselves from serving on juries.

title: Niederhoffer Turns Pro to Aid Game
description: Victor Niederhoffer has turned pro. A few years ago, this news might not have raised an eyebrow outside the small, esoteric world of squash racquets, but things have changed. When the fourtime national champion and acknowledged No. amateur squash racquets player in the world announced his decision this week at the age of 31, the thousands of alsorans emitted sighs of relief.

title: Grandfather Marx's Strange Rhinoceros
description: Hitler must have had a good laugh down in Hell this week when the United Nations General Assembly formally endorsed antiSemitism by a large majority. After thirty years in odious repute, the old dictator's theory of what made the world go wrong has finally been declared the collective wisdom of the higherminded nations of the planet.

Haydn; Naila Waltz, Delibes; Nocturne, Grieg; Moto Perpetuo, Paganini; 66:55, WNYCFM. Gaude Maria Virgo, Ockeghem; Madrigals, Motets and Instrumental Music, Pomponio Nenna.

title: Dodd Criticizes State Education Chief For Backing Teachers
description: TRENTON, Nov. 14Dr. Fred G. Burke, commissioner of the State Department of Education was criticized today by Frank J. Dodd, the Senate Democratic leader for supporting the right of public school teachers to strike.

title: Connors Defeats Nastase in 3 Sets
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP)Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., outlasted his doubles partner, Ilie Nastase of Rumania, 63, 46, 61, tonight in a spectacular semifinal match of the Dewar Cup tennis tournament before 6,000 fans in the Royal Albert Hall.

title: Former Israeli Executive Convicted of Tax Evasion
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 14 (AP)The former manager of the Israeli Government oil company has been convicted of incometax evasion and currency fraud, court officials said today.

title: ART GAINES
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (AP)Arthur P. Gaines, former major league baseball scout and founder of the Art Gaines baseball camp in Hunnewell, Mo., died yesterday at his St. Louis county home. He was 57 years old.

title: Energy Studied at ABomb Birthplace
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M.At first, it looks like just another clean suburban town. Ranch houses, schools, tennis courts and shopping centers dot the landscape. A new county office building sits atop the flat mesa high, in the mountains of northern New Mexico that local people still refer to as The Hill. Everything seems in order.

title: A New Satellite Launching Is Set for Further Studies on Ozone
description: A maneuverable satellite is scheduled to be launched next Wednesday for a succession of dips into the atmosphere to help scientists determine whether a variety of human activities are depleting the earth's protective ozone layer.

title: First Sellout in 50 Years Gives Brown a Happening
description: Brown University opened its football arena 50 years ago and called it simply Brown Stadium. During the halfcentury since then, no crowd was ever large enough to determine how many persons would fit into the rather small stadium The answer will finally be known today when Brown and Harvard meet before the stadium's first capacity crowd.

title: 7 Doctors Receive 10Day Jail Terms In Chicago Strike
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 14Seven doctors who led a strike of residents and internes at Cook County Hospital were found guilty today of contempt of court and sentenced to 10day jail terms.

title: HOUSE UNIT SEEKS CONTEMPT ORDER AGAINST KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The House Select Committee on Intelligence, its members angered by their inability to obtain classified information for their investigation, voted overwhelmingly today to hold Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger in contempt of Congress.

title: Doubt Is Cast on Payoff Charge Against Bailey in JaiAlai Case
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 14 A daylong series of witnesses before the State Gaming Commission here today cast doubt on charges that the late John M. Bailey had accepted $235,000 to help a jai alai promoter secure a state license.

title: WESTCHESTER ASKS RISE IN SALES TAX
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14County Executive Alfred B. DelBello said today that he was planning to ask the county's hoard of Legislators to raise sales taxes in Westchester County next year to at least 7 percent, or by two percentage points, in many towns and villaees.

title: PRESIDENT TO ACT ON COURT QUICKLY
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 14President Ford said here today that he would move quickly to nominate the best qualified lawyer or jurist he could find to fill the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Associate Justice William O. Douglas.

title: Lebanese Leader Forbids Use Of Army to Enforce CeaseFire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 14Prime Minister Rashid Karami rejected today a proposal that the Lebanese Army be used to suppress violence that is disrupting the current fire in civil strife here.

title: Screen: 'Other Side of the Mountain'
description: Just a little more than 20 years ago Jill Kinmont, a 20-year-old California girl, was a sure bet for the United States Olympic ski team. Then, in the course of a trial competition in Utah, Jill took a fall, breaking her neck and becoming paralyzed from the chest down."The Other Side of the Mountain," which opened yesterday at the Columbia 2 and other theaters, is the story of Miss Kinmont's fight to survive as a paraplegic and to find new purpose in her life. According to the film, Jill Kinmont's life really looked very much like a film in which one counts not the years but the lap dissolves, in which every important moment is underscored by a heavenly choir consisting of one voice (Olivia Newton-John's) that, on cue, intones depressing bits of lahrymose philosophy.The life came first, but the movie seems to have less interest in Miss Kinmont than in the devices of romantic fiction that reduce particularity of feeling to a sure-fire formula designed to elicit sentimental responses. If you go to see "The Other Side of the Mountain," load up on handkerchiefs and leave your wits at home. Should you have even half a one with you, you'll be ahead of David Seltzer's screenplay at almost any plastic point.I suspect that Larry Peerce, the director, knew exactly what he was doing in constructing this film the way he did. The audience it's aimed at likes to know in advance each new heartbreak, no matter how clumsily the hints are heaved at them. Such foreknowledge is reassuring and very much a part of the pleasure of weeper movies.Knowing the kind of movie he wanted to make, Mr. Peerce has worked with a singleminded purpose to achieve it. He has an extremely pretty, efficient young actress named Marilyn Hassett to play Jill, and he has Beau Bridges to play the daredevil of a fellowskier, motorcyclist, sky diverwho loves Jill through thick and thin. In a film like this, Mr. Bridges's appearance is the sort of certificate of honor the audience looks for.There are some beautiful ski scenes and some terrifying scenes in the hospital. The movie also contains a couple of moments of genuine feelingall set in a Los Angeles center for the rehabilitation of the handicappedthat raise the over-all tone. Mostly, though, the inspiration one detects in "The Other Side of the Mountain" is the inspiration to make the kind of prefabricated romantic movie that every few years turns the American public into a bunch of blubbering idiots.

title: SAYS STATE BUT ACT FIRST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14President Ford said today that he would make no commitment of financial aid for New York City until the State Legislature enacted a fiscal plan proposed by Governor Carey.

title: Quebec Bails Out Montreal Games
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 14The Quebec Provincial Government announced today that it would take over from Montreal the financing and construction of the $600 million, 72,000seat main stadium for the 1976 Olympic Games.

title: 76ers Top Celtics
description: BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers capitalized on the departure of Boston's center, Dave Cowens, who left with a back ailment at the start of the second half, and rolled to a 119109 victory over the Celtics tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

description: The Ford Administration continued to play a cruel and dangerous game of chicken with state and city officials yesterday as the clock relentlessly ticked on toward a municipal disaster that even some of the President's closest advisers now admit could have grave national and international repercussions.
