title: A GoalLine Stand Against Student Despair
description: Most students in Yale College feel or say they feel a relentless, pervasive tension about work, called by common consent academic pressure. Let us disregard the fact that something like this has always been felt by serious students; that graduates and professional students and faculty feel it, too; that it would be hard to educate yourself without feeling some of the pressure.

title: GABEL PHILLIPS, NEWSMAN DEAD
description: Cabeil Phillips, for 26 years a Washington correspondent of The New York Times and the author of three books on recent American history, died yesterday in Memorial Medical Center, Savannah, Ga. His age was 70. He had made his home since his retirement in 1971, in Hilton Head. S.C.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HARKING BACK Two estimable theater figures who began their careers in Germany are represented on the local scene. Kurt Weill's oneact opera Der Jasager (The Yes Man), is being presented tonight at 8 o'clock at St. Luke's Chapel, 487 Hudsim Street (at Grove). Composea In 1930 as a school opera and based on a Japanese Nohstyle play. the work examines the social dynamics of a small group of pupils and their teacher during a perilous journey across the mountains. The work appeared three years after the Three Penny Opera thunderbolt by young Weill and Bertoldt Brecht, and five years before the composer emigrated to the United

title: Music: Ever Astonishing
description: Whenever Alicia de Larrocha sits down at a piano you must be prepared to be. astonished. The tiny Spanish woman simply plays the instrument miraculously well, and her performance of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night left one tun of admiration for its quicksilver fluency and its unforced classical eloauence.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Hunter Needs a Clear Mind
description: FOURTH MUSQUACOOK LAKE, Me.The north wind was a torrent in the tall spruces as I worked my way up a hardwood ridge on the southeast shore of Clear Lake.

title: A Plan to Conceal Thefts Laid to 2 Grain Executives
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14A witness has told Federal investigators that the top two executives of the Bunge Corporation once discussed, at a meeting with junior com pany officials in a New Or leans suburb, a budget item allegedly used to cover income from systematic thefts of grain.

title: NOTE MORATORIUM HELD NO DEFAULT
description: ALBANY, Nov. 14Governor Carey's office today sought to dispel the notion that a moratorium on the city's debts would he tantamount to the default that city and state officials have been struggling for months to avoid.

title: Court Jails 12 New Haven Teachers For Disregarding Order to End Strike
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 14 Twelve New Haven teacher union leaders were sent to jail today for failing to obey a court order that they end their fiveday strike.

title: SENATE WON'T END PICKETING DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14Supporters of a bill to extend construction workers rights to picket failed by two votes today to end a Senate filibuster when three Senators who are believed to favor the bill were out of town for the vote.

title: MARINUS J. TOPP
description: Marinus J. Topp, a former vice president and senior loan officer of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, died Thursday at his home in Wyckoff. N.J.

title: ELLIOTT ZEITLIN
description: Elliott Zeitlin, a teacher and principal in city schools for more than 40 years who retired in 1971 as principal of Junior High School 67 in Littlir Neck, Queens, died yesterday at his home at 6917 182d Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 68 years old.

title: Israel Yields a Sinai Oilfield To U.N. for Transfer to Egypt
description: SUDR, Siani Peninsula, Nov. 14 (UPI)Israel pulled out its last soldiers from this dusty town on the Gulf of Suez today and turned over the Sudr oilfield and a slice of desert around it to the United Nations for return to Egyptian control.

title: Geographic Special on Body Used Some Animals
description: A feature story release by the National Geographic Society, describing how organs inside the human body were filmed for the recent PBS special The Incredible Machine revealed that animals were used as standins for humans in a few of the sequences.

title: Antiques: Lure of Kilims
description: Kilims, those folkart weavings that orientalrug artisans have produced, reportedly for centuries, primarily for their own, use, have over the last decade attracted an enthusiastic, graphicsoriented audience whose ranks are steadily growing.

title: A.B.A. Will Discuss Possible Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The special American Bar Association committee that is investigating President Ford's possible nominees as a successor to Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas will meet here Sunday morning to discuss its preliminary findings.

title: Club Pros Tourney Different
description: PINE MOUNTAIN, Ga., Nov. 14Two contestants in the clubpro championship of the Professional Golfers Association are penalized two strokes each for using their cart to scout the second shot on a par5 hole. Another player is wearing a woolen ski mask, the kind used by terrorists and bank robbers. A dozen or so women are caddying for their husbands. There are no spectators.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Friday. Nov. 14. 1975

title: People and Business
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, a former member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Board, said yesterday that the recent easing of the Fed's monetary policy has hampered rather than facilitated economic recovery.

title: Increase in Power Is Stressed At ItalianAmerican Conference
description: They were a diverse group, from matrons in furs and silkribboned hats to somberlooking Jesuit priests, college professors in velveteen suits and youths in sweatshirts and combat jackets. But when they gathered yesterday at Queens College, some of them wearing badges proclaiming I'm proud to be Italian. 300 Italian Americans agreed on one thing they want more political muscle, everywhere from the local ward to the White House.

title: Study in Congress Puts Gas Shortage At 4% This Winter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) A new Congressional study says this winter's naturalgas shortage will not be as severe as forecast by the Federal Power Commission. But it says residential customers may be threatened with gas cutbacks next winter.

title: Plan to Develop the Economy Is Urged
description: TRENTON, Nov. 14 (AP)The State Economic Policy Council today urged adoption by New Jersey of a state economic development plan to head off future money crises in government and coordinate economic growth in the state.

title: Senate Wrangle Over Missiles Stalls Decision on Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A wrangle over continued operation of the nation's only antiballistic missile system delayed the Senate today in final action on the $112.6 billion defense appropriation bill.

title: Saharan Referendum
description: Spain and Morocco, dangerously close to an armed clash over the Spanish Sahara a week ago, have apparently reached with Mauritania a threeparty agreement that would provide for a selfdetermination referendum under United Nations supervision for the territory's 75,000 inhabitants. The crucial question is whether Algeria, long the advocate of a referendum but opposed the transfer of the Sahara to Morocco and Mauritania and not a participant in the negotiations, will go along with the settlement.

title: Gulf Said to Have Given Personal Funds to Scott; Senator Issues a Denial
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican leader, was said to have received $5,000 each spring and fall for several years from the Gulf Oil Corporation, according to a sworn statement by a Pittsburgh lawyer in a firm representing the oil company. The statement Was made by Thomas R. Wright of the Pittsburgh firm of Reed. Smith, Shaw & McClay in a deposition taken for a suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Claude C. Wild Jr., former Washington representative for Gulf Oil. The suit is in connection with the company's alleged $10.3 million slush fund used for payments to United States politicians and officials.

title: Ford Firm on U.S. Stand for Weekend Talks in France
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14President Ford is going to the economic summit conference in France this weekend determined to keep his freemarket policies for American economic recovery separate from the plans of nations whose recovery is far more dependent on trade, according to Administration officials.

title: Starburst Over Mesopotamia Linked to Rise of Science
description: Sometime before the dawn of human civilization Mesopotamia, perhaps about 10,000 years ago, a great star suddenly burst into dazzling brilliance in the southern sky.

title: Other College Football Games Today
description: Home teams are listed first.

title: POTTERY NUMBERS Nov. 14, 1975
description: J. Daily90758

title: Carolyn Sims Married To Richard W. Baron
description: Carolyn Sims, who will become administrative editor of Pocket Books next month, was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard W. Baron, director of publishing at the Subsistence Press. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Amex Announces a Profit, Against YearEarlier Loss
description: The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday that it earned $56,000 in the third quarter of 1975, in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $602,000. Revenues in the latest quarter rose to $6.4 million from $4.7 million.

title: London Bombings: Now the Richer Targets
description: LONDON, Nov. 14The terrorists of the Irish Republican Army are choosing more fashionable targets these days.

title: Inflation in Britain Slows To Annual Rate of 25.9%
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) New figures today showed) that Britain's annual inflation rate has fallen to its lowest level of six months in the secand monthly decline after a year of continuous rises. However, Britain's inflation remains the worst among the leading nonCommunist industrial nations.

title: Carey Is Enjoined From Implementing His Disclosure Rule
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 14 (UPI)Justice Frank Kronenberg of I the State Supreme Court today issued a temporary injunction preventing Governor Carey from dismissing state workers earning more than $30,000 who did not comply with his finanIcialdisclosure order.

title: State Acting to Curb Surgery
description: TRENTONActing on reputs that unnecessary operations are being performed on Blue Shield patients, James J. Sheeran, the state's Commissioner of Insurance. has established a program to reduce the incidence of elective surgery.

title: How Jobs Could Fight Inflation
description: One of the most widely accepted economic propositions of our time, endorsed by Keynesian liberals as well as conservatives, is that the achievement of full employment will inevitably bring price inflation. The socalled Phillips curve even calibrates the connectionthe lower the rate of unemployment, the higher the rate of inflation, and vice versa.

title: After Decades Of Repression, Democracy Is Still the Wish
description: MADRIDAmong a group of 12 Madrid University students gathered to talk politics, six declared themselves Communists, five Socialists and one CatholicSocialist. Only one opposed bourgeois democracy and said that civic freedoms would have to be limited come the revolution the bourgeoisie couldn't get power back.

title: A new Model T to the rescue
description: DETROIT. It was not long ago that the small automobile was the butt of a great many jokes, not only among American motorists but within the American automobile industry. There was the one about the rich Texan who bought a Cadillac and took two Volkswagens in change, and the one about the truck driver who asked the owner of stalled small car: What's the matter, sonny? Lost the windup key? and many another. But in recent years, Toyota, Datsun, Volkswagen and other foreign makers of small cars have taken over 18 to 20 percent of the domestic market, and to Detroit's automobile manufacturers, small cars are no longer a laughing matter.

title: Ideas &
description: South America: Much Is Still Unexplored

title: Theresa McBride To Marry June 26
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. McBride of South Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Theresa Frances McBride, to Christopher Michael Levy, son of Milton L. Levy of New York and the late Mrs. Levy.

title: The Ballet: A Restaging
description: Like Heraclites, George Balanchine believes you cannot bathe in the same river twice (no two performances can he exactly alike), but sometimes he also throws the hathwater out and keeps the baby.

title: P.U.C. Aids a Solar Project
description: CHESTER  An engineer who is building a home here that will be heated largely by solar energy has won an appeal for help from the state's Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

title: Steps to Sustain Franco Stir Doubts
description: MADRID, Nov. I5A special routine has become part of the daily life of virtually every public figure in Madrid. It involves at, least one visit to La Paz Hospital, on the northern edge of the capital, where Generalissimo Franco continues to battle for life after more than a month of illness.

title: Waiting in Line
description: The first story of the seven in this collection concerns a giant hermit crab intent upon the destruction of the Southern California coastline. It wears an Orange Julius stand on its back but will soon require larger shelter. Elves, a whole kingdom of them figure in another.

title: New Dorp and Jefferson Reach Final
description: Jefferson, the defender, will meet New Dorp Saturday for the Public Schools Athletic League championship. The Jeffs beat Far Rockaway, 228, yesterday and New Dorp downed Clinton, 1916, in semifinal games

title: Literary Prospects
description: The poetry division of Washington's Library of Congress, under Stanley Kunitz's enthusiastic, youthful (he is 70) and imaginative leadership, called together recently a select group of poets, fiction writers, editors of poetry in trade houses, university and small presses, and editors of literary magazines to agonize over the parlous state of poetry publishing in the United States. No esthetics were discussed, not a word was spoken about what Dylan Thomas once called the color of saying. Instead the two days were spent uncovering the vipers of technology, recession, the nonreading and nonbuying publics and the hard economic facts of publishing poetry (and short stories and first novels, which were thrown in now and then).

title: DR. WILLIAM OWEN, CLASSICS PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Owen, who joined the Brooklyn College faculty in 1969, also taught classics and comparative literature at the

title: Mayor Evers Accuses the Engineer Corps of Bias
description: JACKSON. Miss.. Nov. 15Mayor Charles Evers of Fayette has charged that the United States Corps of Engineers is practicing gross discrimination against blacks in employment at the Vicksburg Waterways Experiment Station. He also contends that officers are sending their children to private segregated acadamies using Government transportation.

title: City Is Sponsoring An Unusual Mixer
description: An unusual social event that will blend jazz music and poetry reading with belly dancing and a variety show is planned for next Saturday night at the Brooklyn War Memorial Recreation Center at Cadman Plaza.

title: Outstanding Books of the Year
description: The titles on this list were selected by the children's editor. Quoted comments are from the Book Review.

title: New Lure for Shoppe
description: LAKE GROVE A growing number of Long Island's shopping centers, which have established themselves as focal point in the .life of suburban communities, are putting greater emphasis on promotional displays in an effort to attract more business.

title: Watermelons still have seeds, cacti still have spines
description: Luther Burbank was an authentic American genius: a bit of humbug, some overblown promotion and a lot of hard, fruitful work1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration to use Edison's famous definition.

title: West German Coal Stockpiles Mounting in Ruhr and Saar Basins Because of Slump in Steel Industry
description: BONN, Nov. 15Two years after the severe shortages and high prices of the energy crisis. West Germany has on its hands a surplus of cheap oil and a 13.5 millionton pile of excess coal that threaten to become a political problem.

title: Laurence Gershman to Marry Jacqueline M. Ward in January
description: Jacqueline Marie Ward, a fashion model known as Jacqueline, and Laurence Andrew Gershman, president of the Richiar Realty Corporation, plan to be married in January.

title: A Company Says Cookers May Cause Food Spoilage
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) National Presto Industries, Inc., has told the Government that some of its crockerytype slow cookers may have defective thermostats that could cause food to spoil when conked at too low a temperature.

title: Susan Taylor Wed To J. A. Martin Jr.
description: Susan Randolph Taylor, a reporter with The Tampa Tribune in Florida, was married yesterday afternoon to James Addison Martin Jr., an Investigator for the Florida State Comptroller in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: MORE BEEF CATTLE IN FATTENING LOTS
description: GRAND JUNCTION. Iowa, Nov. 15With a record corn crop already in the elevators and a bumper supply of beef coming off the ranches, cattle feeders this week were increasing the numbers of animals In their fattening lots for the first time in two years.

title: Amsterdam Called Center of Heroin Traffic
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 10  Amsterdam has replaced Marseilles as the center of the heroin traffic in Europe, according to senior officials and Western narcotics experts.

title: State Seeking Energy Research Center
description: TRENTON  Through the efforts _ of Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman of the state's Department of Labor and Indust!), the Byrne administration has begun a drive aimed at persuading the Federal Government to establish a national energy research and development center in New Jersey.

title: Criminals At Large
description: For a combination of adventure, mystery and straight action, DEAD RUN by Jack Foxx (BobbsMerrill, $6.95) will be hard to beat. Some two years ago, Foxx came out with The Jade Figurine, a novel set in the Orient. It was his first novel and a very good one. In Dead Run Foxx has retained his basic locale and his central character. The locale is Malaysia in general and Kuala Lumpur in particular. The central character is Dan Connell, a bush pilot now grounded, with a past that will not bear close investigation.

title: Snanish Aide in Algiers
description: ALGIERS, Nov. 15 (Reuters) A Spanish envoy arrived here today to explain Spain's plan to hand over the Spanish Sahara to a provisional MoroccanMauritanian administration early next year.

title: Novels and stories
description: Prophecy Dragoncourt, an American widow of immense wealth, lives in London surrounded by poets, pretenders to poetry, and con artists who drain off her money in exchange for their ambience. The idea that genius mly lurk in their midst keeps her going and paying. Orlando Kitson is a pretender whose talent lies entirely in cadging money and sympathy. He is violent, cheap, and ambitious, and although Prophecy sees through him she still sees only him. He is one of many parasites, but a mas

title: Notes: Cleaning Up The world's Mountains
description: AREALLIFE version of the Abominable Snowman of the Himalayas seems to be roaming the highlands of the world in the guise of Mr. Average Mountain Climoer, but unlike the Snowman, who leaves only his footprints behind, this new monster deposits an abominable mess of litter.

title: Presidential Spending Power
description: Testifying in 1973 before the Senate Appropriations Committee, Elliot Richardson, then Secretary of Defense, told his auditors that even if Congress denied the Pentagon its modest $500million appropriation for continued Cambodian bombing, We will consider that we have the authority to do it anyway. We can find the money to do it anyway... We could invoke section 3732 authority. What on earth, even a Senator might wonder, was section 3732 authority?

title: Hillsborough Edges Roselle Park, 147
description: Undefeated Hillsborough defeated Roselle Park, 147, at Hillsborough for its eighth victory.

title: AN AIRLINE IS SUED ON RELIGIOUS BIAS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15A class action suit charging religious discrimination has been filed against World Airways, Inc., the largest charter airline in the world, on the ground that the company has threatened employees with suspension, and even dismissal, if they refuse on religious principles to take a special assignment in Saudi Arabia.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: What the City Manager of Eugene, Ore., today calls a long saga began in 1964 when the Eugene Sand and Gravel Company erected a 51foothigh concrete cross on city property atop Skinner Butte. A group of 10 residents sued in 1966 to force its removal on the ground that the cross was a religious symbol. The gravel company and the City of Eugene argued that the cross was art.

title: Black and white in Catholic eyes
description: In Boston recently, Catholic mothers have said their rosaries in the streets to protest busing, rather like the flower children of 1967 protesting war. In Rosedale, Queens, some Catholic hoodlums have twice bombed the home of a brave black man from Trinidad, a despicable method favored by the New World Liberation Front. Protests, demonstrations, riots and civil disobedience continue in the 70'sbut not at the same places as in the 60's. They are likely to get worse.

title: Jacobsen Loses Bid For Trial Site Shift; Case Opens Jan. 12
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., Nov. 15Jake Jacobsen, a former milk lobbyist, must go on trial Jan. 12 on state charges of theft that are virtually the same as the Federal charges the Justice Department. dropped in return for his testimony against John B. Connally, former Governor of Texas. Mr. Connally, in a trial in Washington, was acquitted of bribery

title: Brooklyn and Queens Projects Felled by Budget Ax
description: A halfbuilt school in the Rosedale section of Queens. the planned Flushing bus terminal and two Brooklyn waterfront installations calculated to provide thousands of :jobs are among the mu nicipal construction projects threatened with abandonment :n the city's budget crisis.

title: Best Sellers
description: Mass marked paperbacks are add on newstands, in supermarkets and parker stores, as well as bookstores. TAIs analysts based on mares from representative wholesalers and and= with more Man 9.000 outlets is As Milted Mates.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: It's Philadelphia's Turn

title: Brookhaven Bus Is Given a Stay
description: A commuter bus Service ce operated by 120 Port Jefferson residents was given conditional approval to continue operating into Manhattan last week by the city's Board of Estimate.

title: Natalie Eldredge Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morrison Coates Huston of than, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Huston's daughter, Natalie Eldredge, to Robert Greig Crichton, son of Mrs. Kempton Boyce Jenkins of Washington and the late Robert Andrew Crichton.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17
description: Morning

title: Feminism Scores Again; Willpower
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) The Labor Department, sensitive to criticism from women's actvist groups, has changed the name of the Manpower Administration to delete any reference to gender.

title: Luanda Regim'e Ousts Reuters For ShootingIncident Report
description: LUANDA, Angola, Nov. 15 (Reuters)The Government of the proclaimed People's Republic of Angola ordered the Reuters news agency today to suspend its activities here and told the agency's two correspondents to leave the country immediately.

title: Liberal Arts Yielding to Career Studies
description: An increasing number of American students appear to be shying sway from the traditional staple of their academic dietthe liberal artsand moving toward programs that teach practical, careeroriented skills.

title: The Women of Watergate,
description: If there were such a thing as a liberated approach to being the wife of a Watergate defendant, it's difficult to imagine what it would be. The

title: Anne Hope van Schaack Plans Wedding to David Hopkins 3d
description: Henry Colford Schaack of New York and Mrs. Schaack of Southport, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anne Hope Schaack, to David Luke Hopkins 3d, son pf Mr. and Mrs. Hopkins Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y. and Northeast Harbor, Me. The wedding is .planned for next month.

title: Inside
description: This is one very fine book. It teaches, not preaches, seeing with the inner eye, andby extension  imagination and empathy. Warm, colloquial, factual, it leads the mind from the concept of sight to that of insight. It does so by revealing the various aspects of common things, by looking at them from different angles, by probing them in crosssection.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Haute Cuisine Cooking Taught in a Rural Gourmet Shop
description: MOUNTAINVILLE  Businessmen, career women, housewives, young mothers, grandmothers and a teenage girl are among the students enrolled in a haute cuisine cooking school in this rural Hunterdon County hamlet.

title: Dorsett of Pitt: 303 Yards
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 Notre Dame's hopes for a berth in a college football bowl game went up in a blaze of offensive statistcs by Tony Dorsett of Pittsburgh today as the brilliant Panther running back almost personally pinned a 3420 setback on the Irish before a capacity crowd of 56,480 at Pitt Stadium.

title: Large people in small pieces
description: These two books resemble each other strongly. Both are collections of fugitive pieces rescued from magazines and newspapers and brought together in new volumes as a stay against oblivion. But what works well for Stanley Kunitz does not work at all for Colman McCarthy.

title: Kenneth Murdock of Harvard Is Dead
description: Kenneth Ballard Murdock, who had been the Francis Lee Higgiason Professor of English Literature at Harvard University, died yesterday at the Newton (Mass.) Convalescent Center. He was 80 years old.

title: Farmingdale Crowned Again
description: Farmingdale scored in the final 16 seconds for an 80 defeat of Oceanside yesterday and repeated as Nassau Conference I champion. Port Washington (III) and West Hempstead (IV) joined the Dalers in clinching titles.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A threeweek postponement in a reduction of the schedule of hours, as well as the pairing of 38 branches of the Brooklyn Public Library was announced. The change was originally set for tomorrow but Kenneth F. Duchac, the library system's director, said it would not go into effect until Dec. 8.

title: State Conservationists Are Putting Nature on the Man
description: That solitary figure trudging slowly over the countryside with a compass and a notebook this winter may be member of a Conservation Advisory Council, mapping the land.

title: Carl Rakosi's art and self
description: Carl Rakosi is a veteran (very much alive at 72) of the lonely, earliest years of the new poetry. He was born a Hungarian Jew in Berlin and followed his divorced father, a watchmaker and jeweler, to the United States in 1910 after six years with his grandparents in Hungary. No soon

title: Muskie Seems to Be in Danger Of Losing Seat in 1976 Contest
description: PORTLAND, Me.What happened to Albert Gore of Tennessee and Ralph W. Yarborough of Texas in 1970 could happen to Edmund S, Muskie of Maine in 1976. Despite his seniority, his national reputation and his expertise in the ways of the Senate, the craggyfaced Down East Democrat seems in jeopardy of losing his spat.

title: JOHNNY RIVERS SINGS RHYTHM AND BLUES
description: Johnny Rivers, who is at the Other End through tonight, is a Los Angelesbased singer with a considerable diverse, not to say confused, past. Having had some hits (both originals and covers) in the 1960's, he then explored all facets of the music business, with hi bestknown accomplishment being the launching of the Fifth Dimension.

title: Williams Retains Title, Def eating Amherst, 256
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 15In the snowdusted hills of the Berkshires just off the Mohawk Trail a purple cow covorts on a soggy football field. The big colleges have Spartans, Indians, bulldogs or tigers as mascots, said a former sports editor of the Williams College Paper. You're really on a different level here.

title: Millay in Greenwich Village
description: Here is a subject worth writing about: the young Edna Millay living and writing in what, if we ever had a Bloomsbury in this country, was itthe Village in the twenties, a literal hotbed of political, artistic and sexual radicalism. Anne Cheney

title: Cavanagh Will Quit Dec. 31 As Beame's First Deputy
description: First Deputy Mayor James A. Cavanagh, who had been widely criticized for his handling of the city's fiscal affairs, has resigned, effective Dec. 31.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP)Sandra Haynie shot a oneunderpar 71 today and opened up a fourshot lead over Hollis Stacy after two rounds of the $50,000 Lady Jacksonville open golf tournament.

title: Martin Carey: Ships, Real Estate and Discount Gas
description: During the last few months, a new string of independent service stations has been making its presence felt in in the populous Long Island suburbs of New York.

title: Cardiac
description: The Washington Redskins and St. Louis Cardinals, tied for first place in the Eastern Division of the National Conference, clash today at St. Louis in pro football's No.

title: Army Loses Eighth Straight; Georgia Tech Tops Navy, 1413
description: NASHVILLE, Nov. 15 (AP) Brenard Wilson of Vanderbilt interceupted a pass at his 20yard line with 3 minutes, 36 seconds left and returned it 38 yards, helping the Commodores to a 2314 victory over Army in football today.

title: WorkStudy: Cash and Credits
description: Asking me what I think of cooperative education is like asking Billy Graham what he thinks of God, Roy L. Wooldridge said not long ago. I think it's wonderful and tremendous for just about every reason.

title: The Drac
description: The dragon has always been one of the most popular of imaginary beasts, inspiring a particularly agreeable sort of terror. Children today scare each other with stories of the baby lizards and alligators flushed down drains who now flourish, grown to monstrous size and shape, in the sewers of New York, London, Rome, etc. (The Chicago ones, according to a former student of mine, have become phosphorescent and can see in the dark.)

title: H. E. W. Plans New Way to Alert Public to CancerCausing Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPS) The Government, concern:2d with figures showing that. 25 percent of Americans will get some form of cancer during their lifetimes, is studying new way to alert the public quickly when suspicions arise about possible cancercausing agents.

title: Priests, Nuns Get Therapy
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE Tensions caused by pressureridden living in the 1970's and by changes and less rigid lifestyles in their religious communities since the Second Vatican Council have caused many conflicts for priests and nuns, according to Sister Mary Jane Brustman, execu five director of the twoyearold Consultation Service for Religious Personnel of the Diocese of Rockville Centre.

title: COLUMBIA WEIGHS ITS FISCAL FUTURE
description: Plagued by financial problems, Columbia University has plunged into an intensive examination of its structure and operations in a search for ways to restructure the university to make it more financially secure.

title: The Region
description: Once Again Mr. Nadjari Is Criticized

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1975

title: BACKTALK
description: Because Channel 13 has the responsibility for achieving the full potential of public television in our communityand we are almost wholly dependent on our viewers! support (as partners, in effect)we feel obliged to correct certain of the major misapprehensions caused by Judith Hennessee's article. The article impugns Channel 13's board its management and its nroRramminr.

title: LISBON IS TENSE AMID COUP RUMORS
description: LISBON, Ncw. 15The Portuguese braced themselves today for an imminent showdown between supporters of Prime Minister Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo's Government and their Communistled opponents.

title: County Weighing Tax Plan For Stores
description: MINEOLAA local law to prevent supermarkets from charging customers sales taxes on items that are not taxable was proposed to the Nassau County Board of Supervisors by a consumer group last week.

title: Panaceas Come and Go, but Teachers Endure
description: Teachers know all about panaceas. Accountability was the most recent remedy for the ills of American schools. After some obligatory grumbling and retooling, teachers made their peace with it. They even began to see how mutual accountability might be advantageous and have been saying the word out loud to principals, superintendents and school boards. This interesting notion has useful possibilities. But teachers may not be able to develop them, for newer panacea is upon them. Productivity has surfaced.

title: CALIFORNIA PLAN ON SEACOAST NEAR
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13A pioneering experiment in state land use regulation is nearing a critical phase in California. It involves a massive program for controlling all future development in a zone five miles wide along the state's entire 1,100mile coastline.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE FORD ADMINISTRATION AND CONGRESS have agreed on a longterm national policy that will regulate the price of domestic crude oil and put a lid on petroleum prices for at least the next two years. The oil industry predicts that the legislation will reduce domestic oil exploration ... Crude oil imports last week, at 4.58 million barrels a day, rose from 4.47 million barrels the week before. Petroleum product Imports, at 1.79 million barrels daily, were up from 1.70 million barrels Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabian Oil Minister, said that he expected crude oil prices, frozen until next June, to remain at current levels until the end of 1976.

title: Garment Workers Will Request Substantial
description: Sol C. Chaikin, the new president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, told employers in the dress industry last week that the union would be seeking substantial wage increases in current negotiations and would also seek to lay the groundwork for more nearly uniform agreements in the entire outerwear industry.

title: Up a Jersey Creek Without a Paddle
description: MY upraised paddle glints in the sun, my birchbark canoe flashes past moose and water moccasin. I am the bravest of the braves leading my Iroquois war party silently through the wilderness bent on looting and pillaging some frontier settlement. And a little rape wouldn't hurt.

title: City Fiscal Crisis Perils Big Brothers
description: An effort to solve many of the fiscal problems of Big Brothers Inc of New York City and also to help meet city needshas been snagged at least temporarily by the city's (fiscal uncertainties.

title: BIGGER RE FLOW IS AIM OF PROJECT
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 15 (Reuters)  The dream of 19thcentury engineers to increase the lifegiving waters of the Nile is to become a reality with a multimilliondollar fouryear effort to dry out one of the world's largest swamps. Work is to start next year on a 180mile canal bypassing the vast Sudd, a swamp in the southern Sudan to funnel water to the parched north and into Egypt.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Farewell to the Rangers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Strong Quake in Mexico

title: ExSS Officer Said to Will Funds to Israeli Charities
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, Nov. 15, (Reuters)  A Nazi SS officer who fled to South America at the end of World War Il has left everything in his will to Israeli charity organizations, according to natusnanor here.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: Plumbing repairs make it necessary to refinish the drywall around the tubshower enclosure in my old house. I don't want to get involved with putting up tile and wonder whether I can use paint or paper to waterproof the walls around the tub?A.L., Galena, W.

title: TV VIEW
description: Children's Shows Still a Case Of Neglect

title: An Emphasis on Respect for Ethnic Roots
description: You always heard in school that if you had any problems you should go and talk to the teacher, said Elban Otero, a young Puerto Rican. But in came this guy in his penny loafers, and you knew you couldn't relate. I had no one to talk to about my problem. They just didn't understand me.

title: Art of L.I. Collectors Is Displayed
description: GREENVALELong Island has been known for some time as a center for artists and in recent years it has become an increasingly important center for collectors.

title: Exploring Bonaire From Top to Bottom
description: IREST in an airy niche under a jagged coral boulder. Once alive at the bottom of the sea, this mammoth anthozoan looms 40 feet above the white sand beach. The bluest of waters turns to white foam as it mounts balconies of limestone and splashes in hundred cascades to fashion a calm tidal pool at my feet.

title: Rye Farewell and Streak Spoiled by Harrison, 70
description: John Nugent made his final coaching appearance before the hometown Rye fans yesterday wanting to go out a winner. Harrison and Coach Art Troilo had nther plans.

title: Houghton Soccer Victor
description: HOUGHTON, N.Y., Nov. 15 (UPI)The Houghton College soccer team beat Western Connecticut State College, 10, today in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Area 7 championship. Houghton advanced to the national tournament beginning Nov. 26 at Raleigh, N.C.

title: The Rambouillet Spirit
description: History's first economic summit of the free world's three principal industrial powersthe United States, Japan and the main Common Market countries, Britain, West Germany, France and Italyis more political than economic in purpose. The objective of President Ford's weekend encounter with his allies near Paris is not merely discussion of the West's nastiest depression since World War II. The hope is to initiate a continuing system of what Secretary Kissinger last week called cooperative decisions by the countries that control twothirds or more of the world's production, trade and monetary reserves.

title: JOAN LEE FAUST
description: Last call for bulb planting. Bulbs must make good root growth before soil freezes Continue tree and shrub planting. . . . Remove tree leaves from lawn. Grass is damaged by a winter leaf blanket.

title: Rebecca A. Livengood Plans Marriage
description: Rebecca Anne Livengood of Cambridge, Mass., and Walter Ferrier Rogers 3d of Syracuse plan to marry Jan. 17 in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, N. J. Their engagement has been announced by the Rev. Hugh Livengood and Mrs. Livengood of Westfield, parents of the future bride.

title: The Report by Reuters
description: A Reuters dispatch from Lisbon last Tuesday, as printed in The New York Times, said that a gunman in Luanda had fired on a car that he presumed was carrying President Agostimho Neto. The Reuters dis. patch attributed the report to the Portuguese Government press agency.

title: At Brown, Still 2 Communities
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.One of the good things about Brown University, thought when I arrived here, was the way it handled race. It cultivated the image of a place where blacks and whites dealt with each other as individuals rather than as stereotyped ghettodwellers or honky hypocrites. To be sure, no one here told me things were perfect. But three years ago I would not have believed the truththat while race relations are good during orientation week, they quickly deteriorate by Thanksgiving.

description: Peer deprivation

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  As the economic summit conference one that boasts the heads of government of the principal industrial countriesconvenes near Paris this weekend, one fact well known to experts but seldom realized by the public at large is deep in the consciousness of the six leaders.

title: Caso Seeking Rise Of 1% in Sales Tax
description: MINEOLA  A proposed budget of $823.3million for Nassau County calls for property tax increases reduction in some services. elimination of some projects, a wage freeze and an increase of I percent in the county sales tax, putting it on par with the city's S per fax..

title: Bicentennial Plates Offered in Bergen

title: Zionism Resolution Assailed
description: WASHINGTONMembers of Congress from New Jersey reacted with outrage last week to the United Nations vote equating Zionism with racism. Many said that the United States should reassess its affiliation with the world organization, and a few questioned whether the country should continue its financial support.

title: They Need Listeners
description: MOSCOWIn one of the two cramped rooms that make up Andrei Sakharov's Moscow apartment, there stands wooden bookcase with glass doors. Taped inside the glass are jumbles of family snapshots, and among them hangs small piece of white paper on which Mr. Sakharov has written two columns of numbers, radio frequencies. Over one column appear the words Voice of America, over the, other, BBC.

title: American Is Upset By C. W. Post. 210

Three interceptions and four fumble recoveries bottled up the Yellow Jackets, who ran only six plays in Post's territory.

title: Curtain Going UpBehind Bars
description: Hey Chuck, you're late! You shoulda took a heliocopter, man! The cry comes from a group of shadowed faces behind a barred window on the third floor of the Bordentown, New Jersey, Youth Correctional Institution.

description: Nyack, which has been playing without its regular coaching staff for most of the season because of a teachers strike, knocked Clarkstown South out of the Rockland County Public Schools Athletic League title picture yesterday with a 22S victory:

title: Suit Fights Removal of Refugees From a Church Adoption A gency
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15World Vision, an evangelical Protestant relief organization, filed suit in a Federal court in Los Angeles on Tuesday in an effort to overturn a decision by a Superior Court judge that removed Cambodian children brought to the United States during Operation Babylift last April from the control of a sectarian adoption agency.

title: CITYAID BILL GAINS AS CAREY CONFERS INITH HOUSE AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The chairman of the House Banking Committee, the House Republican leader and Governor Carey agreed today on compromise on loanguarantee legislation for New York City: that they believe will enable the bill to gain Republican support and greatly enhance its chance of passage.

title: The Truck Cartel
description: Most cartels have only a few members. The trucking industry in this country is that rare exception, a cartel with 15,000 members, most of them small. But they have a giant allythe United States Government.

title: ACCORD ON SAHARA SAID TO BYPASS U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15The United Nations was bypassed and Algeria outmaneuvered by, the accord reached by Spain, Morocco and Mauritania on Spanish Sahara, diplomats here said today.

title: What's Doing Around TAMPA
description: OVERVIEW  The TampaSt. PetersburgClearwater triangle, with a population of almost 1.5 million, is second only to Miami as Florida's leading metropolitan area. Tampa is the region's manufacturing, business and government center; St. Petersburg, Clearwater and smaller communities in between are primarily resorts. The Tampa area has none of the hankytonk gaudiness of Daytona Beach or the nightclub garishness of Miami Beach. The winter season begins around Dec. 15 and peaks in February and March; this month and early December are good times for lower rates. Daytime temperatures through December are usually in the 60's, and the waters of the Gulf of Mexico and Tampa Bay are good for swimming, although local residents are likely to find them chilly.

title: Unbeaten Texas A. &
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 15 (AP)Texas A. and M.'s defensive combination of Lester Hayes and Mark Jackson set up two touchdowns over a span 88 seconds in the third quarter today and rallied the thirdranked Aggies to a 3314 Southwest Conference football victory over Rice.

title: City Trees Fight for Survival
description: The trees in our cities and suburbs are in trouble. We need them to make urban life more bearable, but our civilization produces an environment that is detrimental to tree growth.

title: After Justice Douglas
description: President Ford has signified his intention to move as quickly as possible to fill the gap left by the retirement of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas. According to his counsel, the President recognizes the importance of swiftly restoring the Court to its full operating strength, a condition which Justice Douglas tried gallantly, but in vain, to maintain.

title: The Signs
description: By midNovember, according to country lore, it should be clear what kind of weather can be expected In the winter ahead.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The history of opera is full of problem children, works of noble intent, often by composers of genius, that ultimately fail to fulfill the goals they set out to achieve. Weber's Euryanthe, composed in 182223 immediately after the composer's highly successful Der Freischtltz, is one of these flawed masterpieces. Cursed with an impossible libretto, it is nonetheless an opera that historians and musicians agree stands as a landmark in the levelopment of romantic 19thcentury music drama.

title: City Studies OutofState Roots of Relief Families

He asked how rare it was. We replied on Nov. 2 that it was extremely rare and that perhaps T. H. was pulling our leg. We noted that outdoor trees do not bear until six years old. T. H., a sophomore student at Greenwich High School, replied that he was not pulling our leg. A plant enthusiast and active in the Plant

title: Group Travel for the Venturesome, e.g., Patagonia at $1,175Plus
description: As the beaten track grows more heavily beaten adventurous travelers increasingly yearn for wild frontiers where visitors are too rare to be cynically exploited and Hilton is merely an Englishman's name. Of course, there's always the problem of longdistance arrangements. How does one hire Himalayan sherpas, rent dugout canoes or find reliable camel driversmuch less arrange air drops, entry permits or emergency supplies?

title: Rx for the Bond Market
description: TRENTONThe current efforts to avoid default by New York City are of critical importance to urban areas throughout the nation. Federal action is clearly warranted. But New York's financial woes are merely one victim's symptoms of a developing national malady in the municipal bond market.

description: WASHINGTONDon't expect any major new domestic or foreign policy developments out of here in the next twelve months. Until the future leadership of the United States, the Soviet Union, and China is much clearer than it is now, the big three will be in a holding pattern.

description: WASHINGTONOne hundred men have served on the United States Supreme Court. Most have had legal talent and some have been brilliant beyond compare, but almost never has legal talent alone decided an appointment. Often, legal talent has been the least of it.

title: No Murder, But a Dash of Deja Vu
description: AS far back as 1961, its demise was considered certain. The old Orient Express, wrote one columnist, from which Alfred Hitchcock's lady vanished, scene of a score of movies and plays, is finished, dead, killed by the Iron Curtain... Yet today, in the dawn of dtente, the Express lives as the main direct longdistance train between Eastern and Western Europe. Its future is bright, and its present is pleasantas L discovered recently when I boarded the King of Trains, Train of Kings in Vienna for an overnight trio to Paris.

title: MODERN SYRIA
description: Since its independence from Prance in 1946, Syria went through periods of chronic instability, political isolation, and economic mismanagement which had grievous consequences on the future of the country for more than two decades. Yet, the progress achieved over the last five years has been more than a surprise for observers interested in the Middle East.

title: CrossCountry Races: Marathons for the Masses

We were crossing a rolling section of the Brattleboro Country Club in southern Vermont, she in one set of tracks, iii another alongside. Ahead of us, strung out over a halfmile of snowy fairway and disappearing into hilly woods beyond, were perhaps 250 other Skiers, looking like a scene of the Russian Army in Dr. Zhivago. Behind us, in varying attitudes of pursuit and lengthening degrees of distance, were

title: U.S. Coal Supply Runneth Over
description: A 1969 Geological Survey report, updated in 1972, estimated that the United States had more than 3,000 billion tons of untouched coal resources, an amount which, if demands were to remain fairly constant, would last hundreds and hundreds of years.

description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Nov. 15 (UPI)The Nevada Supreme Court yesterday upheld a section of the state's capital punishment law that mandates the death penalty for a persons convicted of killing more than one person in a common plan or scheme.

description: MADRID, Nov. 15 (AP)The Government legalized wider use of regional languages in Spain today, returning to about onethird of the nation's population a cultural heritage that had been banned for 36 years.

They can play as well as Washington, St. Louis and Dallas, and those three are three of the best teams in the National Football League.

title: Elis Post 2413 Victory Over Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 It started out as a sweep to the left with Don Gesecki, Yale's reliable halfback, taking a pitch out from Stone Phillips, the quarterback, on second down at the Elis 3yard line. But Gesecki stopped and threw a wobbly pass 33yards downfield to Gary Fencik, who caught the ball and ran away from the two covering Princeton backs, Ed Sheridan and Tom Palmer, for a 97yard touchdown play.

description: FREMONT, Ohio, Nov. 15 (UPI)  An offduty and unarmed Ohio highway patrolman was stabbed to death late yesterday by a man who followed the officer and his family home from visiting friends. James Bradley Turpin, 20 years old, Was charged with murder in the death of Patrolman Michael D. Fulton, 27.

title: Textile Giants Slugging It Out in Pantyhose
description: BURLINGTON, N. C.For two of the nation's leading manufacturers of pantyhose, the Christmas season this year translates into highly visible campaigns intended to convince women that the need for wearing panties is no more.

title: Jerz
description: WOODCLIFF LAKEThe Garden State is where Thomas Alva Edison invented the light bulb and where Hans Brinker, the classic children's book, was written by Mary Mapes Dodge. The silent movie serial, The Perils of Pauline, was filmed in Bergen County, and the tomato, long believed to be a poisonous growth, was first eaten by a Jerseyan, a brave act that made the tomato one of New Jersey's most profitable crops.

title: Litigation Would Continue for Years and Years
description: The Franklin National Bank crashed one year ago. The trustee appointed by the Bankruptcy Court to handle its affairs has two sets of lawyers, for general advice and litigation. There are also firms representing various classes oreditors and stockholders and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. When all the lawyers get together, one says, we just about fill the courtrooman incredibly mob. In a year, the lawyers fees have exceeded $1 million.

title: Margaret Drabble's En
description: Margaret Drabble is one of the best English novelists writing today. While her books are about contemporary English lifespecifically that of intellectual Londonersher style is closer to George Eliot's than to Virginia Woolf's. She is a traditional novelist in the best sense; she confidently takes the reader into a densely imagined, realistic social world. Individualitythe small quirks and gestures that make ordinary people unique and interestingfascinates her; the characters in her novels are alive, sharp and welldefined, honed by an uncompromising, talented hand.

title: Canucks Stave Off LastMinute Bid
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 15 When it was all over, Coach Al Arbour figured he had spotted someone who had performed even worse than his New York Islanders tonight as they dropped a 43 decision to the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Democrats Split On Senate Post
description: TRENTONThe State Senate, torn by leadership rivalries within the Democratic majority and faced with at least two fiscal crises, reconvenes here tomorrow.

description: William E. Doulin, the Republican Party chairman of Orange County, was convicted of perjury yesterday for denying that he had used his influence to obtain a suspended sentence for a defendant in criminalassault case.

title: Movement Education,
description: TENAFLY, N.J.Make yourselves as small as possible, Sandra Wilbur told 20 kindergarten children. The children found spots on the gymnasium floor. Some assumed a fetal position. Others knelt and ducked their heads. A few sprawled loosely on the floor. One little boy ran around aimlessly. Miss Wilbur watched carefully, praising a few, criticizing nobody. This was no ordinary physical education class, because the children were stretching their minds as well as their bodiesand having fun at it.

title: Gloria A. Pinza, A. P. Geoghegan To Be Married
description: Gloria Adele Pinza, a third year student at the Harvard Law School and datighter of the late Ezio Pinza, the Metropolitan Opera basso, plans to be married to Andrew Phelps Geoghegan, a Portland, Me., lawyer.

title: Waldheim Is Expected In Mideast This Week
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 15Secretary General Kurt Waldheim is expected to leave for the Middle East next week to seek formal consent by Syria and Israel to extend their agreement on military disengagement in the Golan Heights, United Nations sources said today.

title: Ski Notes: Amid Hopes for a Boom Season, the Show Blows In

Skiing flourished during last winter's economic storm, and there's cause for optimism about the season just starting. The show will begin its fourday stint in Manhattan on Thursday.

title: The Animal Doctor
description: The Animal Doctor is subtitled A Novel of the Future, which is slightly deceptive, suggesting a sort of Star Trek with Orwellian characters. Though the story is supposed to be set in Sweden in 198889, the society's paternalism, the machinery for bureaucratic bullying of the individual, the condescension to women and old people, sound chillingly close to contemporary life. title: Elephant Hunting In Uganda And Ivory Sales Are Banned
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) Elephant hunting has been banned in Uganda and poachers may be executed by firing squads in the futuer, according to the Uganda radio.

description: TRENTONCommon Cause, the publicinterest lobby, reports that an overwhelming majority of the Assemblymen elected this month have committed themselves to end conflicts of interest or any legislative or Congressional redistricting plan that includes gerrymandering for partisan advantage.

title: Letters To Horseface
description: Letters to Horseface carries an initial shockat least, to a student of Mortirt's letters. One rapidly leafs through these pages, not paying much attention. Ah, yes, Mozart's letters to his sister while he was a boy on tour. Then one actually starts reading these letters, and they are not by Mozart at all.

title: Music: Copland Jubilee a Fine Salute
description: Aaron Copland reached the age of 75 on Friday, and to celebrate the anniversary the Juilliard Orchestra played an allCopland concert at Tully Hall. A capacity audience that included a number of distinguished composers, per formers and representatives of the theater and ballet worlds heard a program that offered Statements for Orchestra, the Symphony No. 3 and Dance Panels.

title: The World
description: Governor General Sir John Kerr, invoking powers of the British Crown's viceroy unused in Australia's 75 years as a federation, last week dismissed the Labor Government of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, even though the Laborites have a majority In the lower house of Parliament. The result is a constitutional embroglio that could lead to deep changes in the way Australia is governed.

title: Rome Parliament Member Is Kidnapped in Sardinia

title: How to Patch Up Your Home And. Wardrobe
description: Patchwork originated in the early days of this country when even the simplest of necessities had either to be hand made at home, or ordered from the store in town at what then seemed exorbitant prices. As a result, women learned to extend the life of every available piece of fabric. Wornout or outgrown garments were cut up and the pieces then stitched together to form pillows, blankets, stuffed animals, pot holders, and many other useful and attractive articles. in the process, homemakers who originally stitched because they had to found that they could be surprisingly expressive in the objects they created by using thread, needle and scraps of fabric.

title: A Gallery of Ghosts and Ghouls
description: A recent look at some reprints of old horror comicsthe ones stamped out in the 1950's by the Comics Codeimpressed me with the formal, strict morality of even the most gruesome examples of this kind of fantasy. There was, for in seance, an allegory about selfdestruction, concerning a ghoul and a vampire in love with each other; and there was a political lesson about civic corruption thwarted by righteous corpses. It therefore seems unlikely that (as some people are suggesting) Dracula and giant ants merely escalate one's need for thrills, leading to literature and movies of senseless violence.

title: Opera: Berliners Stage Lohengrin
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15The Government that runs this city (and, if some political commentators are to be believed, may soon be running New York as well) has helped West Berlin through some trying days in the past. So the grateful Berliners have sent to Washington what might be called a cultural CARE package, in the form of a 16performance visit by the Deutsche Oper, West Germany's leading company, the trip being made possible by a halfmilliondollar subsidy by the Berlin and Bonn Governments. (The company can afford it; its annual subsidy from both sources totals $17 million.) The Berlin Opera's visit, one of a series in response to a worldwide invitation by the White House for foreign governments to take part in our Bicentennial, got away to a rather lame start last night with a performance of Lohengrin, in the muchdebated staging by the composer's grandson, Wieland Wagner. Wieland whose often stark, often dark, symbolladen productions revitalized the Bayreuth Festival after World War H, was to have staged this Lohengrin at the Metropolitan Opera in 1966, but he died at the age of 49 about two months before the opening. His conception was carried through by an associate, but nobody can be sure that the production now proclaimed as Wieland Wagner's Lohengrin is actually one he would have recognized. The Washington staging, at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, looks somewhat different from the 1966 version. The first scene of Act II, which at the Met was played out by Ortrud and Telramund in the shadow of a towering turret, has a curved wall that gives one the impression the principals are arguing at the bottom of a cistern.

The Puritans sought for understanding by running from one hourlong sermon to another. But for our generation, science, coupled with technology, became the god through which we would find the road to economic and intellectual salvation.

title: Nononsense chic

The onebedroom apartment, rimmed by a terrace, is a study in minimal decorating. The 16by20foot living room and adjoining dining alcove, the 12by18foot bedroom and compact kitchen hold only the basic furnishings needed for comfortable living. Miss Peretti, who spends only six months of the year in New York (the remainder is spent restoring a farmhouse outside Barcelona), hates hotel rooms and keeps the space as a convenient diedterre.

title: New York: Taking The Right Tour Bus
description: THERE is a dreamlike quality to Manhattan's Bleecker Street at 6 A.M. on a winter Sunday. The street lights are still on, narrow necks crooked over cobblestones; the sky is turning from charcoal to gray. The night people have disappeared, the day people are sleeping in, the street people have somewhere found shelter from the cold. It is as if the dreamer, skis on shoulder, boots in hand, had been plucked from a mountain peak and set down gently in a New York as serene and quiet as the snow.

title: Grimm's Women
description: Not long ago, a young woman whom I know slightly caught me up in the street and said breathlessly, Tell me something. How can I learn to be woman? I was surprised, for it seemed to me that the mere fact of having been born on the side of Yin was sufficient. A woman was what you inevitably, and willingly, became, as the seed becomes the flower. She had had. I knew, several lovers. Surely from these experiences, satisfying or otherwise, she could have learned something that would help her to define her aim. I cast about in my mind for some instructive book, and my good angel tapped me on the shoulder. Read Grimm's Fairy Tales, I said, and left her, openmouthed and incredulous, standing on the corner.

title: You Got to Have a Boss
description: When last seen, George Foreman boxed five opponents and battered them all. But somehow he was the loser. Once the world heavyweight champion, he had tried to be a comedian in carnival atmosphere last April, his only appearance since Muhammad Ali dethroned and embarrassed him. But his performance that day in Toronto was more pathetic than huSports morous. Spectators and of TV viewers laughed at him, not with him. He no Times had nobody but himself to blame. He had nobody in his corner, nobody to guide him, nobody to provide the command he needed. By the loneliness of their profession once the bell rings, boxers are people who need people. George Fore man understands that now. When next seen, he will have Gil Clancy in his corner. Watch out, world.

With Lionel Pary harpsichordist she prayed sonatas _ by Blauvet and Fisch, 4nd with Nlarc Neikrug, pianist, Prokofiev's Sonata in D and Mr. Neikrug's Preludes. The program also included Debussy's Svrinx and Varcce's Densit}, 21.5. both for unaccurn panied flute. Miss Siebert's reputation as a flutist of more than ordinary lattainments was sustained by, authoritative performances. Thz strength and eveness of her. Itone were impressive, the ease with which she could inflect and color that tone were admirable and her responsiveness to stylistic differences made her interpretations consistently. rewarding. 1 The Neikrug Preludes do not exploit all of the flute's versatility, but they do show how subtle it can be in suggesting the lights and shadows of predominantly melancholy moods. The set of pieces might seem stronger if it were shortened a bit, perhaps at the beginning. In any case, this gently modern music made an agreeable addition to the program. ALLEN HUGHES

title: How to Make A Castro Movie Without Castro

But now, at !east, the outsiders obsession with Cuba has been captured on film. Waiting for Fidel. which will play at the Film Forum in its new home at 15 Vandam Street in SoHo for two long weekends this month (Nov. 1316 and 2023), is a highly inventive and at times excruciatingly funny documentary about selfdeception and the limitations of curiosity.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Is the day of the hero done, then? And was the great man, to say nothing of the sixshootiri sex goddess, always something of a cheat? There is a tantalizing line in Jesse and the Bandit Queen, now being given an excellent experimental production at the Public, that volunteers to speak for the frontier of a hundred years ago: This country's fear is not for its heroes, but of them. Suddenly you do remember that the giants of American fable, the ones that have survived in balladry and most often been resung, have been killers, good or bad. And, as you turn uptown to the Golden, where Kennedy's Children is performing an autopsy on the 1960's, the line lingers in your memory, ambiguously but nagging. For the 60's began by killing the heroes it had somebody must have been afraid of Kennedy and Kingand then went on to create a new album of instant superstars, most of them dead of overdoses before the decade could go away. Disillusion twice: with the old and with the new.

In the muster room, they noticed a group of young women who had been picked up by a Prostitution Control Unit sweep on a section of Eighth Avenue that has become known to police as the Minnesota Strip. title: Loss of Aid From State Forcing Cut In Bus Runs
description: MAYWOODMore than 100 bus lines in the state will curtail or reduce their service at the end of the month because of an expected $11 million deficit b funds available for subsidies.

title: Key Elements Of The Syrian Economy
description: On the 9th of October 1973, a Syrian military communique announced that Israeli warplanes bombed some of the industrial and civil targets in the area of Horns, in central Syria. The raids marked the beginning of the biggest operation against industrial installations witnessed in the Middle East.

title: Nets Top Spurs, 112109, After a Marriage at Half
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex.. Nov. 15 (AP)Julius Erving and a quartet of New York guards let the Nets to a 112109 American Basketball Association victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article last Sunday about shoplifting and employee theft, the overall percentage of loss was stated incorrectly. It should have said that the total loss in retail business operations last year was over $2 billion, or 2.5 percent of total sales.

title: France the Logis may
description: THE jampacked road out of Normandy Beachwhere we had just attended the 30th commemoration of the DDay landingresembled rushhour on the Long Island Expressway. By the time we arrived at our inn, the Auberge du Pont de Brie, the kitchen staff had left, but the family running the inn had stayed up to make sure we had a hot meal. Our dinner that night: fresh Iangoustine (prawns), steak broiled over a fire, freshly picked vegetable salad and a dessert of apple tart heaped with rich Norman cream.

title: Photographs of Early American Tools Are Shown
description: WATER MILLThe trades of the cooper, chandler, blacksmith and cordwainer long ago vanished from the American scene. But the tools of those trades have managed to survive and are the subject of an unusual photographic exhibit shown at the Old Water Mill Museum and soon to appear at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Rabbi Ezra Bick to Wed Etta Zablocki
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris Zablocki of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Etta Pauline Zablocki, to Rabbi Ezra Aaron Bick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bick of Forest Hills. Queens.

title: Barred by Taiwan, ExP.O.W. Is Here With Assumed Name
description: One of 10 former Chinese Nationalists who left China last April after 25 years in prison, , frustrated in his efforts to go to Taiwan, is now living in New York under an assumed name and is pressing the Nationalist Government in Taipei for back pay assertedly owed to him over the last quarter century.

title: Harvard Routs Brown by 4526 To Share Ivy Lead With Yale
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov 15  Harvard, the oldest university around, kept old traditions alive in the Ivy League today by beating Brown, 4526. This put an end to Brown's chances to win the Ivy League football championship outright for the first time since the formal inception of the league in 1956. It also established The Game between Harvard and Yale next week as The Game

title: Notes for an environmentalimpact statement
description: July 12: Mathilda was quite unpleasant about the Wheel today. She found the drawings painted on the wall near the fire when she came to make breakfast, for I had been at them almost until dawn. It has become my habit to labor over the infinite detail of the drawings during the quiet hours of the night. You may amuse yourself with this nonsense, she said, but I have real work to do. Of course, she splashed the cooking water on the wall as she did every morning, and now I must begin again.

Irish Eccentrics

title: State Farm to Raise Rates For Auto Insurance Dec.
description: The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, the nation's largest automobile insurance company and a major underwriter in this state, is raising its rates Dec. 1 by an average of 14 percent.

title: BRIDGE
description: Golfers are well accustomed to the alcoholic comfort of the 19th hole, but consider the feelings of the football fan who sees his team operating with 12 men, or the nightmare sensations of a bowler who finds himself facing 11 pins. A chess expert who counted 33 pieces on his board would begin to wonder whether he needed psychiatric help, but a 53card deck is not unknown the bridgetable.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY SUN AND WEATHER
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 15 For well over 100 years there has been speculation that the sun's magnetic fields exert subtle influence on the earth's weather. Now, scientists in California and Colorado report they are getting proof to support the speculation.

title: Schoolhouse Is Posing A Problem
description: FLORHAM PARKIn 1865, when Florham Park's Little Red Schoolhouse was built, the area was a bucolic farming community. The local children trudged miles to the oneroom school, whose teacher was paid in farm produce.

title: Unfair, sexist, going brokewhat else is wrong?; Social Security
description: Individual Social Security taxes have increased as much as 300 percent in the last decade, and half of all taxpayers now pay more in Social Security than in income taxes; however, benefit payments still seem inadequate for millions of retired persons. Social Security accounts for a third of all Federal tax revenues, yet this year Social Security expenditures will exceed

title: Police Fighting Crime With Airplanes
description: The introduction of high altitude detection equipment has allowed the aviation unit of the City Police Department  a seven helicopter flight group operating out of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklynto increase its anticrime assistance to ground units without cutting back cn regular air patrol duties.

title: CALIFORNIA PLAN ON SEACOAST NEAR
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13A pioneering experiment in state land use regulation is nearing a critical phase in California. It involves a massive program for controlling all future development in a zone five miles wide along the state's entire 1,100mile coastline.

title: Millville Planning A Pedestrian Mall
description: MILLVILLEThis city, famous the world over for its glass products plans to convert the heart of its main business street into a pedestrian mall.

title: INVESTING
description: For the past year, investors owning New York City bonds have faced a unrelenting stream of bad news that pushed the value of their securities lower and lower. In the secondary market, meanwhile, yield's on New York City bonds rose higher and higher.

title: HAYS DRAFTS CURB ON ELECTION UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15Representative Wayne L. Hays has quietly drafted a plan to restrict the independence of the Federal Election Commission, one that would, in effect, give him a veto over all the agency's proposed reform regulations.

title: The Talk in Lisbon Is of Coups, Left and Right
description: LISBONThere recently have been so many rumors of impending coups in Lisbon that even the bar waiters in the better hotels have stopped passing them on. If all tie reported plots had been carried out, the Government Would have changed every 20 minutes for the last two weeks.

title: Helen Hilary Martin Engaged To Richard Spalding, Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Augustus Martin Jr. of Hillsborough, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Hilary Martin, to Richard Coxe Spalding of New York.

title: Return to Howard: The Turbulent 60's Seem Long Ago
description: I had left Howard University, the nation's largest black university, eight years ago, a graduate in its centennial year. When I returned recently, the campus, settled on a rise under one of Washington's brilliant Indian summer skies seemed smaller.

title: Deaths of 10 Philadelphia Aged Tied to Drug Test
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP)Ten elderly patients at private Philadelphia nursing home died in 1964 and 1965 while they were being used as subjects in a drug experiment, The Philadelphia Bulletin reported today.

title: Royal Glint Scores; All The More Wins
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP)Royal Glint, the favorite, owned by Dan Lasater of Dayton, 0., scored a 314length victory in the 40th running of the $114,480 Hawthorne Gold Cup today at Hawthorne.

title: Recital Is Given By Peter Pears And Osian Ellis
description: Peter Pears and Osian Ellis, two distingiushed Britons who had already appeared in a program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center this season, had Friday evening to themselves at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The tenor and harpist collaborated for the most part, but Mr. Ellis had two solos, John Parry's Harp Sonata in D and Faur's Impromptu.

title: Rockefeller Finds Advantage in LameDuck Status
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 15Vice President Rockefeller seems to find being a lame duck something of an advantage to a politician who has never stopped running for the Presidency.

title: Columbia Subdues Penn Eleven, 2825
description: Behind the brilliant running of Doug Jackson, who rushed for a record 194 yards on 33 carries and scored three touchdowns, Columbia beat Penn In an Ivy League game, 2825, yesterday at Baker Field. The victory was Columbia's second of the season and second in the league and left the Lions alone in sixth Mace.

title: Rutgers Tops Boston U. For 5th Straight, 41 to
description: BOSTON. Nov. 15 (AP)Curt Edwards ran for 151 yards and scored two touchdowns as Rutgers trounced Boston University, 413, today for their fifth football victory in a row.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The gnomes are busy in and around New York again. Gnomes, in the modern definition, are creatures specializing in acts of perverse illogic or malevolent nonsense that result in situations of consummate absurdity in which the rest of us are trapped. They are particularly active in official circles. Gnomes, for example, had the dandy idea a few years ago of widening Fifth Avenue by cutting back the park side in order to speed traffic; when the outcry started they crawled right back under their manhole covers. Really professional gnomes would have gotten the job done when no one was looking; they usually deal in the sneaky fait accomp

title: Susan Rubin Fiancee Of Mitchell Koeppel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Rubin of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter. Susan Yvette Rubin, to Mitchell P. Koeppel, on of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Koeppel of Hollywood. Fla. A February wedding is planned.

title: Are All the Giants Dead?
description: Mary Norton is much admired for her fourbook series on The Borrowers the pencilsized little people who live in the bowels of Firbank Hall and borrow whatever they need from the big people up top. It a charming and ingenious fantasy, combination of Tom Thumb and Upstairs, Downstairs, and was recently recycled into a charmless televislon program by people with pencilsized imaginations.

title: Cynthia Rabin Is Fiancee of J. N. Tanner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Rabin of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Patrice Rabin, to Jonathan Nelson Tanner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester J. Tanner of New York and Easton, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: All the Families in the Order of Cetacea
description: It is one of the most wretched of all ecological ironies that now, just when man is beginning to appreciate the wonder of whales, several kinds of whales are on the brink of extinctionbecause it has taken man so long to awaken to that wonder.

title: Russian Fairy Tales
description: The Russian fairy tales that Aleksandr Afanasyev collected and published between 1855 and 1864, which Norbert Guterman translated masterfully into English in the 1940's, and which Pantheon has reissued with illustrations by Alexander Alexeieff and a commentary by Roman Jakobson, contain hundreds of Russian folktales. Afanasyev was for the Russian folktale what the Brothers Grimm for the German folktale. For hundreds of years tales were told in the Russian villages and hamlets but it, never occurred to any Russian to write them down and collect them. Only material related to religion was recorded and published. A number of Russian folktales came out in English translation about 200 years before any Russian edition of this genre appeared. There is now a large literature of and about Russian folktales, but Afanasyev's is still considered the classic collection.

title: Dibbs Beats Connors in Tennis Final
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP)Jimmy Connors's 1975 slump continued today when he lost in the final of a tennis tournament for the fifth time this year, bowing to another American, Eddie Dibbs, 16, 61, 75, for the Dewar Cup championship.
