description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Instead of sending her two small sons to a local school two blocks from their home North Stamford, Patricia Purnell, who is white, puts them on a bus every morning for a 40minute ride to a predominantly black and Hispanic school near this city's aging center.

title: DOCTORS LOSE PLEA OVER MONITORING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14The Association of American Physicians and Surgeons lost today its bid to block a nationwide system of review that will monitor the treatment that hospitals and doctors give to Medicare and Medicaid patients.

title: Red Sox Get Jenkins In Trade
description: BOSTON. Nov. 17 (AP)The Boston Red Sox confirmed tonight that the team has obtained Ferguson Jenkins, the seventime 20gamewinning pitcher, from the Texas Rangers.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Ford Is Increasing 4thQuarter Output To Meet Demand
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 (U131)The Ford Motor Company said today that it was increasing fourthquarter production by 12,200 units to meet. strengthening demand for 1976 model cars and trucks.

title: Bengals Defeat Bills, 3324
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 17 (AP) Ken Anderson, overcoming O. J. Simpson's 197 yards rushing, riddled Buffalo's pass defense for 441 yards and two touchdowns tonight in leading the Cincinnati Bengals to a 3324 victory over the Bills.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EASY DOES IT The sprightly keyboard music of George Parker is one attraction at Lucifer, (7555987), a restaurant at 338 East 49th Street (midway between First and Second Avenues). Another is the decor of the bar area. a blend of elegant chandeliers and rococo framed mirrors with a plain wooden floor for reassurance. There is an effusive nattily clad hostmanager named Reed Sterling, who peals out solos and cues in group singing around the piano, where you can also perch and sip. A quieter listening post beyond the bar (a glass of white wine was $1.50) is the small corner banquette looking into the dining section.

title: SPECTER SEEKS SEAT OF SENATOR SCOTT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17Arlen Specter, a former District Attorney here, today became the second announced candidate for the Republican nomination to the United States Senate seat now held by Senator Hugh Scott, the minority leader.

title: Changing Lebanon
description: Agreement to discuss constitutional changes may sound like the most paltry of concessions among feuding factions; but in the acutely sensitized air of Lebanon today it is a noteworthy shift away from incipient civil war.

title: Mamaroneck and Many Other Suburbs Ponder Issue of Dwindling Enrollment
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Nov. 17The issue dividing this quiet community on Long Island. Sound begins with a statistic: six years ago. school enrollment reached a record 6,400 students. Five years from now it will have fallen to 5,200.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Up at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 Yields rose on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: SLOCUM CHAPIN, 62, RAN TRAVEL AGENCY
description: Slocum (Buz) Chapin, who retired in 1965 as a vice president of the American Broadcasting Companies to establish, with his wife, Jane, Adventures Unlimited, a worldwide travel agency based at Abercrombie & Fitch Company, died Saturday in Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 500 East 77th Street.

title: For Economic Health
description: PARIS, Nov. 17The leaders of six of the nonCommunist world's richest countries rang the expected note of optimism as they went home today after

title: Ballet: Alert Hispanico
description: Alvin Ailey, Talley Beatty and Donald McKayle in alphabetical or any other order constitute a strong choreographic team. The point has not been lost on the alert Ballet Hispanico, which presented works of all three Sunday evening at Hunter College in a concert that demonstrated the company's continuing growth and accomplishment during the last five years.

title: A NEW HEMORRHAGE SUFFERED BY FRANCO
description: MADRID, Tuesday, Nov. 18 (Reuters)Generalissimo Francisco Franco suffered a large intestinal hemorrhage early today, an announcement from his household said. The announcement added that at the moment the bleeding was being controlled.

title: INQUIRY SPURNED BY MRS. PERON
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17President Isabel Martinez de Peron today rejected an inquiry into corruption in her administration by the Argentine Congress.

title: Bobick Makes Garden Ring Debut Dec.12
description: Duane Bobick, an unbeaten heavyweight managed by Joe Frazier, will make his Madison Square Garden debut Dec. 12 in a 10round fight against Randy Neumann.

title: Warning Sounded On Protectionism
description: The international economic system is threatened by increasing protectionist pressures from industrialized countries and the developing world's demands for a new international economic order, bankers and government officials attending the 62d annual convention of the National Foreign Trade Council were warned yesterday.

title: Television
description: 8:00 P.M. New York WashingtonConnection (5)

title: Westchester Budget To Increase 24.6%
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17Westchester County's 1976 budget is expected to rise by 24.6 percent, to $382.8 million, with most of the increase caused by higher welfare costs, the product of a changing population and inflation.

title: Lonely and Tainted by Divorce, Catholics Unite to Win Respect
description: BOSTONCarolyn Riley is a small, 35yearold typist who has brown hair and Irish blue eyes that really do seem to smile. But when asked what she was doing at the fourth National Conference for Divorced and Separated Catholics here, her eyes welled with tears.

title: How Bowl Games Are Shaping Up
description: Tangerine Bowl, Orlando, Fla., Dec. 20Miami, Ohio, vs. team to be named.

title: Bankrupt Kassuba Asks Court to Back A New Realty Plan
description: Walter J. Kassuba, a Florida) builder whose bankruptcy in 1973 was then the second largest on record, has filed a plan in Federal Court in Illinois to get back in the real estate business.

title: OPEC Aid to Poor Nations Is Reported Near
description: VIENNA, Nov. 17 (AP)The world's major oilexporting nations neared agreement late today to set up a $5 billion aid and development fund to help poor countries hurt by the quadrupling of oil prices, Iranian officials said.

title: Jets Play Down Sideline Fight, But Winner's Future in Doubt
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 17 The Jets lockerroom philosopher and defensive captain, Jamie Rivers, thought the whole problem really was this simple:

title: FORD CONSIDERS THREEYEAR PLAN FOR HELPING CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17President Ford is leaning toward a program of shortterm Federal assistance to New York City that would include $2.5 billion in loan guarantees for a threeyear period, White House sources said today.

title: 2 Policemen Told to Pay $102,400 to Beaten Man
description: Two policemen who beat up a man they were arresting were ordered by a jury in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to pay $98,000 in compensatory damages and $4,400 in punitive damages to their victim. Two other policemen, who accompanied them, but did not strike the victim, were ordered to pay $300 each in puitive damages.

title: Grandness and Gags in Berliners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17Everything fell into place last night for the Deutsche Oper Berlin, which has open having its ups and downs at the Kennedy Center in its first visit to this country. The opera this time was Mozart's Cosi fan tutte, one of the supreme tests of any company's ensemble precision. All the pieces clicked together like the tumblers of a cracked safe, thanks primarily to the expertise of the 80yearold Karl Bohm, whose magisterial presence in the pi:, gave the performance unfailing rhythmic vitality and theatrical timing.

title: LIBERALS
description: The Presidential candidate who is endorsed by the New Democratic Coalition will isolate the others from liberal support, Senator Birch Bayh said yesterday at a news conference organized by his lacol supporters here att he Drake Hotel.

title: F.B.I. Reports Crime Took 20,000 Lives Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. (AP) Criminals struck 19 times every minute to claim 20,000 lives and $2.6 billion in loot as crime in the United States rose 18 percent last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

title: Of Steinbeck and Letters and Wrath
description: I don't know whether or not I told you, wrote John Steinbeck to Elizabeth Otis, his friend and literary agent, a year before his death, but the last time was in Washington and staying at the White House I had a long and early breakfast with the President and I told him what I thought we were doing wrong and made suggestions for correcting our errors, all based on winning this war. He listened carefully, asked a few questions and asked me to stay over and meet his men at noon. Then I saw McNamara, Rusk, Humphrey and several others and went over the ground again. They listened and made no comment but McNamara asked me to write it down. I couldn't, so I made a tape of it, which he took to Vietnam on his last trip. Recently he telephoned to say that he had put my suggestions before the field menthat they had accepted some of them and rejected others. It seems to me that the rejected ones were the most important.

title: COLEMAN REPORT CALLED MISUSED
description: Two students of public school desegregation have charged in an article in an educational journal that the landmark Coleman Report was deliberately distorted by government officials to make it appear to favor desegregation more than the data warranted.

title: FORD CONSIDERS THREEYEAR PLAN FOR HELPING CITY
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 17 President Ford is leaning toward a program of shortterm Federal assistance to New York City that would include $2.5 billion in loan guarantees for a threeyear period, White House sources said today.

title: Carey's StateBudget Plan Accepted By Anderson, but They Differ on Gap
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, tonight accepted Governor Carey's approach for solving the state's budget troubles in one 17month agreement.

title: ANDREW MULRAIN, SANITATION CHIEF
description: Andrew W. Mulrain, Sanitation Commissioner from 1949 to 1957 who won rather grudging public approval for his innovative and effective administration, died Sunday in Springfield, Mo. He was 75 years old and lived in Sarcoxie, Mo., and Fort Salonga, L. I., and formerly in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Justices Disagree on Law Test For Unconstitutional Vagueness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17A bitter disagreement in writing erupted today among the Supreme Court's Justices over the test that should be applied in deciding whether a law is so vague that it is unconstitutional.

title: Rockefeller Scored by Levitt on U.D.C.
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt testified yesterday that former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. the banking community, bond raters and the Urban Development Corporation nad failed to inform the public of the riskiness of the corporation's bonds.

title: French and Italian Reds Concur on Aims
description: ROME, Nov. 17 The two largest Communist parties in Western Europe, the Italian and the French, greed in an unusual joint statement today that the way to power was through the democratic systems of their countries.

title: F.B.I. to Leto Rosenbergs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today that it would Make available about 30,000 pages of documents on the investigation of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg to the couple's sons.

title: 12 New Haven Teachers Are Jailed Again
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 17After a weekend out of jail. 12 leaders of the New Haven Teachers Federation were fined and locked up again today for refusing to call off a weekold strike.

title: Bottle Bill Gets Signatures
description: NEWTON, Mass., Nov. (AP)Backers of a bill that would ban nonreturnable beverage containers say they have collected 40,000 signatures in an effort to bring the measure before the Massachusetts legislature. Norman Stein, an associate with the Massachusetts Public Interest Research Group, said 56,000 signatures must he collected by Dec. 3 to put the petition before the lawmakers.

title: Du Pont Trims Payout For Year End by 50c
description: Directors of E. 1. du Pont de Nemours and Company declared yesterday a yearend dividend of $1 a share, payable Dec. 13 to holders of common shares of record Nov. 25. Last year, the yearend dividend was $1.50 a a share. Total dividends this year will be $4.25 a share compared with $5.50 paid in 1974.

title: Chess
description: Ten years ago Grandmasters William Lombardy and Pal Benko shared first prize in the United States Open in an Juan, P.R. This year they repeated the feat in Lincoln, Neb.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Nov. 17, 1975

title: Baskets That Are Objets d'Art
description: When Diane Love opened her Madison Avenue shop four years ago elegant fabric flowers were her stock trade. They're still there in the offcolors the designer prefers to prime reds and yellows, but the emphasis has shifted to other things, such as the antique Japanese baskets that are her pride and joy.

title: 3 COMPANIES SELL BREAD TO SCHOOL
description: The Board of Education moved quickly yesterday to find other bakery companies to supply bread to the city's public schools in the wake of the weekend closing of the board's largest bread supplier, Silvercup Bakers, Inc.

title: DelBello Proposes 24.6% Rise In Westchester County Budget
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17Westchester County's 1976 budget is expected to rise by 24.6 percent, to $382.8 million, with most of the increase, caused by higher welfare costs, the product of a changing population and inflation.

title: TESTING FOR FOG: Five detectors near Interchange 16W on the turnpike in East Rutherford. The turnpike authority is conducting an experimental
Squires Generate Optimism
description: Dave DeBusschere, commissioner of the American Basketball Association, was optimistic last night that the Virginia Squires would solve their monetary problems and remain in operation.

title: MISS HEARST WINS A DELAY TO JAN. 26
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 A new trial date of Jan. 26 was set today for Patricia Hearst on the charges of armed bank robbery and use of gun to commit a felony.assassinate President Ford, that, the court of appeals acted. But Miss Moore's trial judge refused today to change her trial date of Dec. 15, while Miss Hearst, who had not appealed, won a 32day delay.

title: Antifreeze Glut Takes Chill Out of Prices
description: Motorists who were reminded by last weekend's cold weather that it might be time for new antifreeze will find an ample supply at dealers at as much as $2 a gallon less than last year's price, which was inflated by shortages.

title: DACCA REPORTED IN A TENSE STATE
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 17Nearly two weeks after the latest change in the Government of Bangladesh, the situation there remains tense and unstable, according to reports reaching India.

title: Jersey High Court to Act On Quinlan Family Appeal
description: MORRISTOWN. N.J. Nov. 17 The parents of Karen Anne Quinlan today filed an appeal of the court decision that denied their request to turn off the respirator that is sustaining the life of their comatose daughter.

title: Report Criticizes Soviet On Its Political Prisoners
description: Amnesty International, the human rights group, estimates in a report made public here that there are at least 10,000 political and religious prisoners in the Soviet Union.

title: Wings
description: An assault charge was brought yesterday against Doug Barkley, the Detroit Red Wings coach, in the wake of an alleged attack against a hockey, writer. The attack followed the DetroitRangers game Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, which the Wings lost, 30.

title: LOTTERY REVISIONS EXPECTED NEXT YEAR
description: A revision of the state's suspended lottery probably will not be completed until early next year, a source in Goyernor Carey's office said yesterday.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
description: Nov. 18, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 3 P.M.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Employee's Discharge Sparks Dispute

title: School Tax: Can Reform Aid Quality?
description: The national movement to equalize the spending power of wealthy and poor school districts is causing growing concern, and talk of organized political resistance, among suburban school officials. In general, their position, is that school  finance reform is desirable but that it should be brought about through a leveling up of disadvantaged schools rather than through a Robin Hood approach that would shift assets from the rich to the poor.

title: Garlock Is Sought By Colt Industries
description: Colt Industries Inc. is offering to purchase for about $76.8 million all the outstanding common stock of Garlock Inc., but the offer, which was said to have come as a complete surprise, is being opposed by Garlock, it was disclosed last night. In an ad scheduled for today's papers, Colt, a producer of steel, scales and engines, with headquarters in New York City, said it would pay $32 per share for the shares of Garlock, headquartered in Rochester and a producer of mechanical packing devices. There are 2.4 million shares of Garlock outstanding and they closed yesterday on the New

title: Text of Statement After 6Nation Economic Parley
description: RAMBOUILLET, France, Nov. 17 [AP]Following is the text of the statement issued at the end of the meeting here of the leaders of the six principal nonCommunist industrialized nations:

title: 6 NATIONS PLEDGE ECONOMIC STEPS TO END THE SLUMP
description: RAMBOUILLET, France, Nov. 17Leaders of the United States, Japan and four Western European industrial powers pledged today to work closely together to assure the recovery of their economies and put inem on a course of growth that is steady and lasting.

title: PERJURY INQUIRY FOCUSES ON HELMS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI)The Justice Department is investigating whether Richand M. Helms, the former head of the Central Intelligence Agency, perjured himself before Congressional committees investigating the agency's activities, department sources said today.

title: Waste and Patient Abuse Laid to State Drug Facility
description: The State Commission of Investigation yesterday charged some of the state's residential facilities for drug addicts with abuse of patients, extravagant costs, unqualified supervision and nonexistent or minimal rehabilitation programs.

title: School Tax: Can Reform Aid Quality?
description: The national movement to equalize the spending power of wealthy and poor school districts is causing growing concern, and talk of organized political resistance, among suburban school officials. News In general, their Analysis position is that school  finance reform is desirable but that it should be brought about through a leveling up of disadvantaged schools rather than through a Robin Hood approach that would shift assets from the rich to the poor.

title: Leone Warns of $891 Million Deficit
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17State Treasurer Richard C. Leone warned the State Senate today that New Jersey faced an impending deficit of $891 million ?? next year's state budget.

title: Construction Stringencies to Last 3 Years, Aides Say:
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17Even if New York City is rescued by Washington from its credit crisis next month, state and city officials said today, it will still not be able to ease up on the stringencies imposed in its construction program for the next three years at least.

title: GREEKS DEBATING CAMPUS REFORMS
description: ATHENS, Nov. 17As students returned to classes, Greek universities weer embroiled in a debate this month over reform of this country's antiquated system of higher education.

title: REVOLT REPORTED ON CITY TAX RISES
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17The Democratic majority in the Assembly, to the consternation of the leadership and the Governor's office, apparently balked today at the prospect of imposing $200 million in new taxes on New York City, one of President Ford's prerequisites for approving Federal loan guarantees for the city.

title: R. C. Sherrill, Playwright, Dies; `Journey's End
description: LONDON, (AP)R. C. Sher!riff. who wrote the play Journey's End about World 1War I, died on Thursday. He was 79 years old.

title: Archdiocese Assails Jesus Jeans
description: They're exploiting Christ, religion, Christianity and women, all in one fell swoop, a spokesman for the New York Archdiocese said yesterday, objecting to the advertising campaign that is being used to market a line of slacks called Jesus Jeans.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH OF L.I. GIRL RULED A HOMICIDE
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 17The Nassau County Medical Examiner ruled today that the d of Maryjane Dahl, a I6year1 old terminally ill Long Island girl, was a homicide com mitted by someone who disconnected her lifesustaining respirator at Nassau Hospital on Nov. 2.

title: Carey's StateBudget Plan Accepted By Anders on, but They Differ on Gap
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17The Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, tonight accepted Governor Carey's approach for solving the state's budget troubles in one 17month agree! ment.

title: Notes on People
description: Looking at a jetliner designed by Alexander Calder as a sort of flying flag, Betty Ford said yesterday that it was an attractive, biggerthanlife reminder of the Bicentennial. Known for primarycolor paintings as well as for his sculptures, mobiles and stabiles, the 77yearold artist was also present at Washington's Dulles International Airport to show off the red and blue wavelike designs on the white background of a Boeing 727. Braniff International commissioned him to design and supervise the painting of the plane for $100,000.

title: Students Help Author Test a Musical
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Nov. 17Dale Wasserman, author of Man of La Mancha was in Connecticut last week testing his new musical, Western Star, with an unlikely cast: A group of college students.

title: REVOLT REPORTED ON CITY TAX RISES
description: ALBANY, Nov. 17the Democratic majority in the Assembly, to the consternation of the leadership and the Governor's office, apparently balked today at the prospect of imposing $200 million in new taxes on New York City, one of President Ford's prerequisites for approving Federal loan guarantees for the city.

title: The Theater: Toe Jam
description: A mother sacrifices herself and stifles her present so that her two daughters can have a future. The younger daughter is funky and permissive. The other, Xenith, is a dreamer, lost in an imaginary world; she playacts her life. She is Cleopatra standing on a kitchen table. Her passport for liberation is a handsome photographer whom the mother regards with total scorn.

title: DR. WINIFRED FRIEDMAN
description: Doctor Winifred Friedman, an assistant professor of art history at Wellesley College, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, where her, husband, Dr. Edward W. Freedman, is a surgeon. She was 52 years old and lived in Newton, Mass.

title: DEATH OF L.I. GIRL RULED A HOMICIDE
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 17The Nassau County Medical Examiner ruled today that the death of Maryjane Dahl, a 16yearold terminally ill Long Island girl, was a homicide committed by someone who disconnected her lifesustaining respirator at Nassau Hospital on Nov. 2.

title: DOCTORSLOSEPLEA OVER MONITORING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Association of American Physiclans and Surgeons lost today its bid to block a nationwide system of review that will monitor the treatment that hospitals and doctors give to Medicare and Medicaid patients.

title: Stiffer Terms Ordered In Violent Street Crimes
description: TRENTON, Nov. 17Citing occasional excessive leniency on the part of some judges, Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the Slate Supreme Court issued a series of guidelines today as part of an effort to make prosecutors and the courts get tougher with defendants accused of violent street crimes.

title: Scott Would Keep 10c Stamp
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican leader, called today for passage of legislation to keep the cost of mailing a letter to 10 cents an ounce for individuals. The United States Postal Service has announced it intends to raise the rate to 13 cents on Dec. 28.

title: Penn State. Sugar Bowl Bid Provokes Coaches in Big 8
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant, the stronghanded and persuasive. football coach at the University of Alabama, got just what he wanted yesterday a Sugar Bowl match between his Alabama team and Penn State.

title: ELECTIONS PREPARED FOR UNITED VIETNAM
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 17 (AP)General elections, a national assembly and a constitu tion are being planned in Saigon for a unified Vietnam, the Saigon radio said today.

title: HANDICAPPED TELL OF FACING ABUSES
description: Handicapped persons testifying yesterday at a legislative hearing here told of long delays in repairs to their equipment, shoddy but expensive devices and red tape in the processing of insurance claims.

title: Ruling Explained On Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17The manner in which the controversial St. Louis touchdown pass play was decided in the CardinalsRedskins game here on Sunday amounted to

title: MEXICO CHANGING ON U.S. PRISONERS
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17The State Department recently submitted to Congress a qualified but generally positive report to the effect that the Mexican lawenforcement authorities were beginning to give better treatment to Americans arrested on charges of transporting narcotics.

title: Advertising
description: A 30second spoof travelogue that shows the adventuresome, pithhelmeted hero captured by spearcarrying natives and freed by their king is the latest creative contribution of Martin Landey, Arlow Advertising to Fortunoff, the source.

title: Miners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) The United Mine Workers Union named a veteran coal miner today to be its representative on the newly created Arbitration Review Board. He is Robert Benedict, a former District 12 executive board member in Illinois.

title: BEAME ASKS PEOPLE TO HELP THEIR CITI
description: Painting a grim picture of the city's future under the best of uncertain plans to ease the shock of budget cutbacks, Mayor Beame used a major address last night to renew his appeal for emergency assistance.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Hunter's Guide to Cooking Waterfowl
description: Now that the waterfowl hunting seasons are well under way throughout the nation, tens of thousands of housewives once again are staring at the carcasses of ducks and geese and wondering how in the world to make them taste better than they did last year.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WEST SIDE FIRE ROUTS 100 TENANTS: Firemen inspecting the scene of a threealarm blaze in a row of apartment buildings on Amsterdam Avenue between 91st and 92d Streets.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Jobless Pay in Pregnancy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not refuse unemployment benefits to women during their last three months of pregnancy and the six weeks following delivery simply because the states presume that all such women are unable to work.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prospective jurors in the JoAnne Brown murder trial were being questioned in the judge's chambers prior questioning in open court, in a procedure described as unusual by the defense attorney, Robert Rivers, who had made the request. Mrs. Brown a 32yearold divorced mother of three children is accused of seconddegree murder in the Sept. 29 shouting death of Burr C. Hollister, State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived in Uniondale, L.I. The trial is betore Judge Bernard Tomson in Nassau County Court.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company announced that Lufthansa German Airlines had purchased its eighth Boeing 747, valued at about $35 million.

title: InnerCity School Becomes Magnet
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Instead of sending her two small sons to a local school two blocks from their home North Stamford, Patricia Purnell, who is white, puts them on a bus every morning for a 40minute ride to a predominantly black and Hispanic school near this city's aging center.

title: ExSenator From Utah Denies He Knew of Gulf's Envelope
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 17 (AP)  Former Utah Senator Wallace Bennett said today he had no knowledge of an envelope allegedly given one of his staff members 13 years ago by a lobbyist for the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Delivering Justice
description: According to a 1972 Supreme Court decision, the Sixth Amendment requires that indigent defendants facing jail terms be provided with counsel. Yet, three years after the decision, that right is an empty one for many defendants, according to a recent study conducted for the Justice Department's Law Enforcement Assistance Administration.

title: A Time To Look Ahead
description: After the bloody suppression of the Attica revolt on Sept. 13, 1971, when 29 inmates and ten of their hostages were killed by New York State Police gunfire, authorities discovered the bodies of three other inmates in Cell Block D. Medical examiners for the New York State Special Commission on Attica reported that the three men had died of multiple stab wounds.

title: Summit Substance
description: In the postwar Marshall Plan days, it used to be said that when the United States catches cold, Europe gets pneumonia. Today, that dependence runs in both directions. The interdependence of the three major industrial economies of the worldthe United States, West Europe's ninenation Common Market and Japan, controlling twothirds or more of the free world's production, trade and monetary reservesdemands closer policy coordination in the future than has been seen in the past.

title: French and Italian Reds Concur on Aims
description: ROME, Nov. 17 The two largest Communist parties in Western Europe, the Italian and the French, agreed in an unusual joint statement today that the way to power was through the democratic systems of their countries,

title: GAC Reports Debentures Of Subskliary In Default
description: MIAMI, Nov. 17 (Reuters) The GACS Corporation said today less than 80 percent of the holders of its GAC Properties Credit Inc. subsidiary's 12 percent debentures due November 15, 1975, accepted it exchange offer and accorrdingly the debentues were in default.

title: James Tanham, ExOfficia Of Texas Company, Dead
description: James Tanham, a former vice president for industrial and public relations of the Texas Company, died Sunday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Boyfriend Arrested in Murder Of an Honor Student at Adelphi
description: A 22yearold Long Island man who was apparently a former boyfriend, of a 22yearold Adolphi College honor student was arrested yesterday in connection with her murder.

title: Cleaver Returning After 7Year Exile
description: PARIS, Nov. 17Eldridge Cleaver, a former leader of the Black Panther Party and a fugitivefrom American justice, will give himself up tomorrow in New York when he returns to his home country after seven years of exile.

title: Steel Output Is Up From a Week Ago, But Behind 1974's
description: The nation's steel producers increased their output somewhat in the week ended Nov. 15, but not enough to erase a 1.6 percent decline reported in the week ended Nov. 8, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

title: Samplings at Chain of Submarine Volcanoes Indicate Rift in Atlantic
description: Sampling of several sites in a chain of more than 30 submarine volcanoes that extends from off Cape Cod into the midAtlantic has indicated that they probably have formed along an extended rift in the sea floor.

title: SUSPECTS DISAPPEAR IN MISSING BOY CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 17 (UPI) A man and a woman scheduled to take lie detector tests in the disappearance of the woman's 5yearold son have disappeared, the police said today.

title: Giant Offense Is on Defensive
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 17The Giants aren't throwing punches at one anotherthe way they've been going, if they did, they'd probably missbut the defense, which has been playing decently, is growing tired of waiting for the offense.

title: Novel About Arab Youth Wins Goncourt Prize
description: PARIS, Nov. 17France's top literary prize today was awarded to a mystery man, Emile Ajar, for a novel, La Vie Devant Soi (Life Before You).

title: Soviet's Advanced MIG25 Is Reported in Syria
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17The Soviet Union was reported today to have agreed to send squadron of highflying MIG25 reconnaissance planes to Syria.

title: Texts of Letters to and From Douglas
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 17Following is the text of a letter to William O. Douglas regarding his retirement from the Supreme Court and a letter from Mr. Douglas in return. The letter to Mr. Douglas was written by the eight remaining Justices and was read at court today by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

title: Rheingold to Cut Back at Plant in Orange
description: NEWARK, Nov. 17Executives of the financially troubled Rheingold Breweries of Brooklyn notified tradeunion leaders here today of plans to cut back the operations of the company's 800employee plant in Orange beginning the week of Dec. 15.

title: Concert
description: It's easy to distrust matineeidol conductors, especially when they are conducting in this country. Their sculptured profiles; their tailored evening dress; their carefully choreographed movements; their trendily shagged or shaped hairdosall extraneous to the musical process, no doubt, and fit only to flatter the fantasies of highsociety board members.

title: U.S.CHILEAN TIES CALLED STRAINED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 Administration officials say that United States relations with Chile have deteriorated in recent weeks, mainly because of disputes over humanrights issues.

title: Dollar Value Falls And Gold Declines In Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 18 (UPI)The dollar, after some profit taking following yesterday's sharp upturn, settled at lower levels in quiet trading on most European money markets today. The price of gold fell sharply.

title: Marchers Here Protest Antipoverty Project Cuts
description: Several thousand demonstrators protested slashes in the city's antipoverty programs yesterday by blocking traffic at major intersections and by holding marches and rallies throughout the city.

title: Senate Intelligence Panel Told of F.B.I Attempt to Discredit Dr. King in 1964
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent a note and a tape recording to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in late 1964 that the black leader came to believe was an effort to drive him to suicide, according to testimony and documents presented today to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

title: 800 Students of Truth
description: The late Mme. H. P. Blavatsky, forefinger to chin, full face framed in kinky hair, gazed with intelligent eyes from a bulletin board in a hotel reception area here this weekend as her followers from all over the world mingled to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Theosophical Society, which she helped to found.

title: Suspension of Teacher In Bavside Recomended
description: A trial examiner has recommended the suspension of a Queens clementa teacher who allege Changed a student against a concrete wall and pulled hair from another students scalp an attempt to keep order, a school official said last night. pla order. st night ina

title: CAREY AIDE NAMED TO PLANNING POST
description: Mayor Beame yesterday named Victor Marrero, a 34yearold first assistant counsel to Governor Carey, to replace John E. Zuccotti as chairman of the City Planning Commission.

title: Radioactive Packages Missing From Hospital
description: Two small packages of radioactive material that are extremely dangerous if swallowed or handled, according to the city's Health Department, are missing and presumed to have been stolen from the Queens Hospital Center, 8268 164th Street, Jamaica.

title: EULA W. WESTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Eula W. Weston, former chairman of the Maine State Racing Commission, died yesterday at Circle Terrace Hospital in Alexandria, Va. She was 81 years old and lived with her daughter, Emily W. Leommartson, in Alexandria.

title: SENATE APPROVES DEFENSE SPENDING OF $90.7 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Senate approved a $90.7 billion defense appropriations bill today after rejecting a proposed additional cut of $564 million to drop the total to the level approved by the House.

title: Hartford's First Gentleman A Happy No. 2 in Connecticut
description: HARTFORDDr. Thomas Andrew Grasso has been many things in his 60 years. He has run a movie house, a lumber business and a machine shop. He taught and became a high school principal in East Hartford. He is a painter of some merit. But he has never been a Governor and, until Ella T. Grasso's inauguration in Connecticut last January, he was never a Governor's husband. He is the only one in the country.

title: MATINEES AT DE LYS ENDING 20YEAR RUN
description: The annual Matinee Theater Series at the Theater de Lys, 121 Christopher Street, is being dissolved by Its founder and artistic director, Lucille Lortel.

title: New Haven Strike Spreads as Judge Jails 77 Teachers
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 18Protesting the jailing this afternoon of 77 striking teachers, municipal labor unions representing 1,000 nonacademic employees of the Board of Education here voted tonight to join the teacher? strike that started Nov 10.

title: Henry A. Thouron Dies at 63; ExHead of Hercules Powder
description: Henry A. Thouron, retired president and board chairman of Hercules Inc., died Monday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 63 years old and lived in West Chester. Pa.

title: SENATE APPROVES DEFENSE SPENDING OF $90.7 BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Senate approved a $90.7 billion defense appropriations bill today after rejecting a proposed additional cut of $564 million to drop the total to the level approved by the House.

title: Advertising
description: We think we're adding some gaiety and sparkle to American life. And we're also helping ourselves get a hearing with opinion leaders for what we have to say.

title: Moscow's Mayor Thinks Default Is for Capitalists
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18The Mayor of Moscow is glad he is not the Mayor of New York.

title: Bishops
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18Roman Catholic teachers and priests were called upon today to avoid any presentation that might tend to disparage Jews or Judaism.

title: AMIN SAID TO GET PEKING INVITATION
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) President Idi Amin has accepted an invitation from Mao Tsetung to visit China, the Uganda radio reported today.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Steps Up Arms Shipment to Luanda
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters)The State Department said today that it had received reports indicating that the Soviet Union was stepping up the supply of weapons to the Luanda Goverment in Angola.

title: DR. JOHN JANNEY, 82, AN EPIDEMIOLOGIST
description: Dr. John H. Janney, for many years a member of the Rockefeller Foundation medical field staff in Rumania, Spain, Portugal and Chile died Thursday in Catonsville, Md. From his retirement in 1959 to 1974, he had been an epidemiologist with the Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. He was 82 years old.

title: REPUBLICANS TERM FORD SYMPATHETIC TO SOME CITY HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.President Ford told the New York Republican Congressional delegation today that if the Legislature took action on Governor Carey's fiscal plan, he would, in their words, look with sympathy toward shortterm Federal assistance for New York City.

title: BLACK G.O.P. SEEKS CONGRESS SEATS
description: A group of prominent black Republicans is starting a fundraising drive to support the Congressional campaigns of black Republicans in some heavily nonwhite districts.

title: West Side Synagogue to Be Revitalized
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 18  An experiment to revitalize a congregation on Manhattan's Upper West Side will be undertaken by the United Synagogue of America, the lay arm of American Conservative Judaism.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Tuesday, Nov. 18. Eighth day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Portuguese President Presses Effort to End Crisis
description: LISBON, Nov. 18President Francisco da Costa Gomes met today with political and military leaders to try to find a solution to the worsening political situation.

title: ALL VIETNAM TO USE HANOI VOTING SETUP
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Nov. 18 (Agence FrancePresse) The electoral system in South Vietnam will be set up like North Vietnam's for the election of a constituent assembly for the whole of Vietnam.

title: News Summary and Index
description: A bomb thrown from a passing car into Walton's, a fashionable restaurant in London, killed at least two persons. Scotland Yard and the Home Office assume it was the work of the Irish Republican Army or a breakaway group. As in a London restaurant bombing last. Wednesday, no warning was given before the blast. [Page 1, Col. 4.]

title: A Book and a Display Laud Trumbull, a PatriotArtist
description: More than many a more gifted painter, John Trumbull has been fundamental to American selfawareness. To stand in the Capitol Rotunda in Washington and see his Surrender of General Burgoyne, his Declaration of Independence. his Surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown and his Resignation of General Washington is an archetypal American experience.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: For the Food Buff
description: Madame Maigret's Recipes, presented by Robert J. Courtine (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95).

title: Cleaver Seized on Return Here After 7Year Exile
description: Eldridge Cleaver, a former leader of the Black Panther Party, returned from Paris last night after seven years of selfimposed exile and was immediately arrested.

title: ROBOT AIRCRAFT GAINING WAR ROLE
description: A rapid development by the United States of robot aircraft for electronic espionage and ground attack and as missile decoys and target markers has added a new dimension to war.

title: West Accused by Soviet On Helsinki Security Text
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (UPI)The Soviet Union accused western nations today for the second day of not heeding the European security agreement.

title: The Toledo Way
description: WASHINGTONI suppose that how a Midwesterner regards New York City's plight is largely a matter of perception and a reflection of his background.

title: BODY TEMPERATURE OF FRANCO LOWERED
description: MADRID, Nov. 18Generalissimo Francisco Franco's body temperature was lowered today to 91.4 degrees in an effort to halt further internal hemorrhaging. Normal temperature is 98.6 degrees.

title: Irish Deny Discord
description: ??ch Dan Devine and his Notre Dame players branded as a lie a published report that the Fighting Irish voted not to play in the Cotton Bowl because the players were upset with Devine's leadership, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: ILLINOIS PLANT SET TO CONVERT COAL
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 18 (UPI) The first large demonstration plant for converting coal to cleanburning oil and gas will I be built near New Athens, III., and be financed jointly by the Federal Government and private industry.

title: SALT II at Risk
description: Soviet rejection out of hand of the latest American strategic arms limitation (SALT II) proposals appears rule out the agreement and the visit to Washington that Leonid Brezhnev wanted before the quinquennial Congress of the Soviet Communist Party next February throws into serious risk completion of the November 1974 Vladivostok nuclear arms accord and, with it, the future of dtente.

title: TREEAIMING TRAIT OF PLANTS FOUND
description: Walking through the tropical forest in Costa Rica, a Florida socologist who ordinarily studies insects noticed that vine seedlings on the forest floor were always pointed toward a nearby tree. The snakelike vines converged like the spokes of a wheel with the tree as the hub, as if they knew precisely where the tree was.

title: Senate Votes Curb On a Filibuster Used To Bar Picketing Bill
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 18 (AP)The Senate voted today to curb a filibuster against a bill sought by construction unions to allow more widespread; picketing in labor disputes.

title: New International Rates Set by Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI)  The Postal Service announced today that international mail rates will be increased on Jan. 3, except for mail to Canada and Mexico.

title: Jersey's High Court Bans Garbage From Out of State
description: TRENTON, Nov. 18Yonkers and Philadelphia, along with several Long Island communities, including Glen Cove, were banned by the State Supreme Court here from dumping any more of their garbage in New Jersey.

title: G.M. IS PLANNING OUTPUT INCREASE Stronger Car Sales Cited4 Car Models and 2 Light Trucks Are Affected
description: DETROIT, Nov. 18The General Motors Corporation announced today that because of stronger car sales it was planning to increase the production of four cars and two light trucks early next year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Gibson Loses on Residency Law

title: Thank You, Jerry Hoffberger
description: Bill Veeck had invested more than a year of his life in an effort to buy the Baltimore Orioles when Jerry Hoffberger, the owner, told him abruptly last June that the deal was off. This means, Veeck said the next day, the loss of a friend, the loss of a ball club, the loss a year and a lot of dollarsand for me at the age of 61, the loss of innocence.

title: 36 Colleges in Metropolitan Area Propose Free Admission of Students Now in City University
description: Thirtysix private colleges and universities in the metropolitan area, seeking to help themselves while helping others, have devised a plan that calls for admitting more than 23,000 City University undergraduate and graduate students to their own underused classrooms.

title: ALBANY IS VISITED BY JIMMY CARTER
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18Come on in and meet Jimmy Carter, the girl said to a man getting out of a cab at an Albany motel.

title: Reagan's Theatrical Politics
description: Ronald Reagan's bid for the Presidency really should be tossed to the movie critics. In theatrical terms, win of lose, it is the best script the old trouper ever had, but in political terms, even if he knocked off the President, he would divide his party, and almost certainly assure the victory of the blackhat Democrats.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation were under pressure yesterdays for the third consecutive session as institutions continued to unload positions in the stock of the company, the nation's second largest maker of electrical equipment and leader in nuclear power.

title: West German Parents, and Children, Assail Withering of School Programs
description: HANOVER. West Germany Michael Sobbek, a collegebound student in the Humboldt School here, has not had Icourse in art or music since eighth grade. For two years in a row he has had only one semester of history. On Wednesday afternoons school simply closesall for lack of teachers and money to pay them.

title: Computer System in Oregon Offers Career Counseling
description: GRESHAM, Ore.Using a typewriter terminal, a computer asked Rodney Brock more than two dozen questions about his scholastic aptitudes, personal attributes and desires. The 17yearold high school senior in this Portland suburb recalled recently that one of the questions was, How much can you lift over 100 pounds?

title: ADM. JAMES FIFE, SUBMARINE CHIEF

The heads of state came together because of shared beliefs and shared responsibilities. Their success will strengthen, indeed is essential to, democratic societies everywhere

Just one segment of this virgin tract contains six trees, each of which is the largest of its species in the United States, including a cypress that sprouted before the beginning of the Renaissance.

title: Film: Finnish 'Earth Is a Sinful Song'
description: Judging by the readily available evidence, films from Finland arrive here without about the same frequency as kind words from Moscow or Peking. So it is an occasion of more than ordinary note to record not only the arrival of such a film, but also the arrival of a good one."The Earth Is a Sinful Song" is the somewhat misleadingly lyrical title of this film, which opens today at the Eighth Street Playhouse. It is based on a novel set in Finnish Lapland in 1947-48 and concerns itself, in unusually intimate detail, with the lives of the inhabitants of a small, rustic community, and with particular emphasis on one familyan old man, his unhappy son, haggard daughter-in-law and teen-age granddaughter.One is tempted to call these lives harsh and brutal. But that would be an urban judgment, passed upon people who exist so close to nature that the appearance of an automobile about midway through the film jars a viewer. No, these lives are simply different, stripped almost bare of what we like to call the amenities of civilization. They have no luxuries. Hardship is omnipresent. Death comes among them frequently, taking people and animals. Pleasures are simplean outdoor dance (where a drifter is killed); drink; religion; the sauna; and sex, indulged in and depicted with a minimum of fuss.The seasons pass. Lives change. People grow up, grow older, die, are killed, are born. The cycle is ancient and eternal; the landscape is literal paradise and figurative hell. Rauni Mollberg, who wrote, produced and directed this film, which was shown at the festivals in Cannes, London, Edinburgh, Berlin and Locarno, gives us stark lives and an impression of witnessing a documentary.Eventsa fatal calving, a reindeer roundup, an initiation into sex, a community religious service, even a partytend to be joyless and devoid of sentiment. Mr. Mollberg seems to save his comment on life for the camerawork by Kari Sohlberg and Hannu Peltomaa. And what they seem to be saying, without incongruity, in scene after scene that dazzles the eye with the glory of nature or caresses the faces of strangers in a way that makes the heart care, is that the human animal is profoundly beautiful.

Dr. Rosen faces up to five years prison and a $10,000 fine for the Federal crime.
