title: Cosmetics Trade Views IngredientLabeling With Accentance but Some Growls
description: Next year  probably there will be ingredient labeling on cosmetic products. The Food and Drug Administration has already published the final regulations, and the cosmetics industry has almost, if not quite, accepted the idea.

title: Forced Retirement at 70 For a Teacher Is Upheld
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) Saying that a mandatory retirement policy was not unconstitutiona, a State Supreme Court justice has upheld the forced retirement of a 70yearold Brewster school teacher.

title: Wynn Bullock, Photographer Of Nature Scenes, Dies at 73
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI)Wynn Bullock, a noted nature photographer, died Sunday at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: Heart of the City
description: Next Tuesday's New York rally will be held, not surprisingly, in Times Square, still symbolically the city's heart. Theater marquees will proclaim for the day New York Is United instead of advertising the habits nvrnnhptc and other characters

title: Fennel: A Legend In Aromas(Cont'd)
description: MARCELLA HAZAN'S 4. BREADED & FRIED FENNEL

title: Public TV Said to Overlook
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18A study of the treatment of women by publicly owned radio and television stations has found pervasive underrepresentation of women, both in employment and in program content.

title: People in Sports
description: Jesse Owens, hero of the 1936 Olympics, was in town yesterday (in the Log Cabin on the roof of Abercrombie & Fitch) to accept another $10,000 check from the Canadian Olympic coin program on behalf of the United States Olympic Committee. Before and after the official presentation, which brought to $260, 000 the amount the United

title: City's Bond Tax Short Of Estimate, Says Panel
description: The Mayor's Temporary Commission on City Finames reported yesterday that the city's bondtransfer tax would yield far less than originally estimated and that the tax threatened New York's dominance in bond trading.

title: Haze Lifts for a Bright Lunar Eclipse
description: Right on schedule but hidden at first behind a layer of haze, yesterday's lunar eclipse turned into a thing of serene beauty as the glowing, coppery moon rose above the horizon for the finale.

title: TV: Indians in Afterschool,
description: If the image pinches, try another size. Two of today's new television offerings are exercises in image fitting. One, legitimate but only moderately effective, is an ABC Afterschool Special called The Shaman's Last Raid. The other, questionable but completely ineffective, is Rickles, an hour with Don Rickles in Las Vegas on CBS at 10 P.M.

title: In Beirut, Both Talks and Sniping Go On
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, Nov. 18Sniping and other shooting incidents erupted throughout today in several quarters of Beirut, but in some neighborhoods a bustling commercial life continued.

title: PAINE, WEBBER SUED; STAFF RAID ALLEGED
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 18 (UPI) Asserting that there had been a wholesale raid on the staff of its Fresno, Calif., office, Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a Los Angelesbased brokerage house, filed a $5 million lawsuit today against one of Wall Street's largest concerns.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PROF. HARVEY SACKS
description: Prof. Harvey Sacks, a sociologist and anthropologist died, Friday in California after an automobile accident. He was 40 years old and lived in Rose Canyon, Calif.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Department of Commerce rejected yesterday the International Business Machines Corporation's application to supply a computerized reservation system to Intourist, the travel agency of the Soviet Union. The system was valued at $11 million.

title: Moscow Perceives Western Divisions At Economic Talks
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (Reuters) The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the Western economic conference in Rambouillet, France, had solved nothing and was merely an attempt to create a united front against the rawmaterial suppliers of the third world.

title: STEFANO CUSUMANO, ARTIST AND TEACHER
description: Stefano Cusumano, a painter and for 19 years an art teaches at Cooper Union died yesterday in Eureka, Calif. He was 63 years old.

title: Proposed Stadium For Bears Blocked
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Nov. 18 (AP)By a 53 vote, the village board has denied a specialuse zoning, permit to Madison Square Garden Corporation to build a 76,000seat stadium next to Arlington Park race track for use by the Chicago Bears football team.

title: Miligarchy After Oligarchy
description: LIMA, PeruPeruvians like to say that the military government which has ruled this country since the 1968 coup is not a dictadura but a dictablanda. Dictadura is the Spanish word for dictatorship but Jura means hard, blanda means soft. Hence the nun.

title: Jerry Walsh of Arthritis Fund, Who Fought False Cures, Dead
description: Jerry J. Walsh a victim of severe arthritis for 35 years who barnstormed around the country in a crusade against arthritic quackery, died yesterday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 9720 57th Avenue in Corona. Queens.

title: Earnings Advance at May and Federated
description: The profit upswing reported by retail merchandising chains in the third fiscal quarter was further emphasized yesterday with earnings increases of 46.2 percent reported by Federated Department Stores Inc. and 41.2 percent by the May Department Stores Company.

title: British Send Unarmed Boats To Guard Fishing Off Iceland
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Britain ordered four unarmed patrol boats into Icelandic waters today to help British trawlers after the rupture of negotiations on fishing limits.

title: Colt May Borrow To Partly Finance Offer for Garlock
description: Lott Industries otter yesterday to purchase all the 2.4 million shares of Garlock Inc. of Rochester indicated that Colt would finance the $81 million purchase out of its own general funds. Colt is offering $32 a share, Merger and contemplates News other expenses. Colt, in its balance sheet of Dec. 31, 1974, listed cash and new securities of $64.2 million and total assets of $777.1 million.

title: LIVINGSTON SPLIT OVER A NEW NAME
description: PISCATAWAY, N. J., Nov 18The Livingston College community here appears equaffly divided over the proposal to rename the school Paul Robeson College in honor ct; the singer and actor, who is a 1919 alumnus of Rutgers University. A vote on the matter will be taken by the college faculty chamber tomorrow.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: RHAPSODY IN TWO It's easy to see why the first of this season's Composers Showcase series, starting tonight at 6:45 P.M. at the Whitney Museum of American Art (945 Madison Avenue at 75th Street), will be repeated at 9:30 P.M. The George GershwinCole Porter evening has some rarely presented music and a cast that includes Mabel Mercer, Peter

title: U.S. Urged to Guarantee. Freedom of All Writers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18A panel of writers and publishers told a Senate subcommittee today that the United States had an obligation to guarantee the freedom of authors everywhere to issue their work without peril of suppression, harassment, torture or death.

title: Brian Friel's Here I Come!
description: Philadelphia, Here Come! is not a homecoming, but a homeleaving play. Gar O'Donnell's destination is America, which offers him challenge and opportunityor so he convinces himself. But his place of birth, his natural habitat, Is Ireland. He can't take Ireland with him. Therefore, the night before his departure he packs his suitcase with memories, images and impressions, all of which, he knows, will make him miserable.

title: Lack of Cash to Pay Municipal Employees Next Week Imperils City's LongRange Plans
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18Even as they looked to Washington for longterm assistance, New York City and state officials acknowledged today that they still did not have the cash to pay municipal employees and contractors next week.

title: Auditing I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service, though extraordinarily powerful, depends to a very large degree for its effectiveness on the faith of the American people that while the tax structure may not be entirely fair, the tax laws are administered professionally and impartially. That faith has been taking a severe battering lately.

title: Notes on People
description: Robert Moses, the 87yearold former official celebrated as The Power Broker in a recent bestseller but whose only public office now is as consultant to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, invited the United Nations out of New York yesterday and nominated Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate, as ideally fitted to represent us in making such an arrangement.

title: G.E. Fails to Stop State Inquiry Into Its Role in the Arab Boycott
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18The General Electric Company failed in Federal Court here today to stop a State Assembly investigation of the possibility of its participation in the Arab economic boycott of Israel.

title: Driver Sues To Upset Tracks
description: William (Buddy) Gilmour one of three harness drivers locked out by New York tracks for the last seven weeks, took his case to court yesterday. In a bid for reinstatement, GilAt the mour filed suit in United States District trict Court, ManTracks hattan, for a preliminary injunction against Roosevelt Raceway, Yonkers Raceway and the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: MCM Sets 4% Dividend
description: Directors of MetroGoldwynMayer Inc. declared yesterday a 4 percent dividend on the common stock, payable Dec. 23 to shareholders of record Nov. 28. The action is in line with its present dividend policy of paying an amount equivalent on an annual basis to about 75 percent of the company's neb income. Shareholders have received three 25cent quarterly dividends, the last on Nov. 10. They followed a 2for1 stock split and a special dividend of $2.50 paid last March 25. No dividends were paid from 1970 until 1974 when 70 cents was distributed.

title: About Education
description: New evidence was presented this week that the ability of American schoolchildren to handle the three R's, is deteriorating.

title: Kissinger Meets Waldheim, Says U.S. Will Propose Mideast Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States would soon propose the convening of multilateral talks on peace in the Middle East.

title: Jobs and Price Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) Petitions bearing 174,816 signatures calling for jobs for the unemployed and a rollback of prices were presented to several Congressmen by the National Coalition to Fight Inflation and Unemployment.

title: WINE TALK
description: In 1969, Ely Callaway, then president of Burlington Industries here, put himself into the wine business by planting a vineyard near Temecula, Calif., at a time when many people were doing the same thing. The difference in Mr. Callaway's case was that Temecula is near San Diego, more than 600 miles from what is usually considered California's premium wine country.

title: Bridge: Julius Rosenblum Is Named Man of the Year by Writers
description: The title of Bridge Man of the Year has been awarded, by an overwhelming vote of bridge writers throughout the world, to Julius Rosenblum, president of the World Bridge Federation.

title: Rockwell Is Scored On Its NASA Acts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (Reuters)The Rockwell International Corporation, a leading space and defense contractor, improperly entertained employees of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Senator William Proxmire charged today.

title: About Education
description: New evidence was presented this week that the ability of American schoolchildren to handle the three R's, is deteriorating.

title: Democrats Set Convention Seating Plan
description: The Democratic National Committee took the first steps toward transforming New York into their convention city yesterday by drawing lots for conventionfloor seating and hotel accommodations and by haggling over the transportation; the city will provide the delegates.

title: U.N. RESOLUTIONS ON KOREA CLASH
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18The General Assembly adopted two conflicting resolutions on Korea today and victory was promptly claimed by North Korea on the one hand and South Korea on the other.

title: On the Emperor
description: NEW HAVEN During the Pacific war, Americans considered all Japanese malignant, especially Hirohito. Today, thirty years after the war, Japanese by and large seem benigneven the same Emperor.

title: Jersey's High Court Bans Garbage Dumping From Out of State
description: TRENTON, Nov. 16Yonkers and Philadelphia, along with several Long Island communities, including Glen Cove, were banned by the State Supreme Court here from dumping any more of their garbage in New Jersey.

title: Marathon of Nureyev and Fonteyn
description: The two most famous dancers in the worldthey are not even named on the front of the playbill, which shows a certain classare back together and back in New York. Last night they opened a twoweek, completely soldout seasona particularly taxing seasonat the Uris Theater. They are, incidentally, for anyone still in the dark, Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev.

title: BOND PRICES OFF; SALE POSTPONED TripleA Asian Bank Issue Is DelayedPhiladelphia Offering Gets No Bids
description: Price declines hit the Government and corporate bond markets yesterday, reflecting in part the heavy inventories recently accumulated by dealers. Underscoring the unsettled atmosphere, a $75 million note offering for the Asian Development Bank was postponed. Underwriters said that this postponement  the first such action taken for tripleA rated offering in some timewas due to market conditions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Nov. 19, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. to consider scientific work on peace research: restitution of art works: cooperation with the Organization of African Unity, and at 3 P.M. the question of Cyprus.

title: Narcolepsy Group Calls for a Campaign on Sleeping Disorder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18Bill Baird is a narcoleptic. That means he is sleepy all the time. He often loses all muscle control and thus collapses when he laughs or experiences strong emotions. He falls asleep in the middle of important conversations. He needs to take stimulants to drive a car.

title: OPEC Members Will Lend $5 Billion to Poor Lands
description: VIENNA, Nov. 18 (Reuters)The members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Counties tonight established a special aid project intended to make $5 billion available for Third World development needs in the next five years.

title: Elections Panel to Allow Companies to Raise Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18The Federal Election Corn mission cleared the way today for corporations to invest millions of dollars in contributions from their stockholders and employees in the politicalcampaigns of of candidates regarded. friendly to business.

title: NEW UTILITY FEE BARRED BY STATE
description: A controversial proposal by 12 utilities in the state to place a monthly surcharge on customers bills to raise funds for financing exploration for natural gas was rejected yesterday by the New York State Public Service Commission.

title: A Younger Brother Of City Councilman Is Found Murdered
description: A younger brother of City Councilman Samuel D. Wright was found shot to death late Monday night on a Brooklyn street, the second brother of the Councilman to die by gunfire in two years.

title: Yale, Harvard Will Celebrate 100 Years in Typical Fashion
description: Last week the name Yale was not mentioned in Cambridge, Mass. Harvard's players and coaches had another university football team on their mindsBrown. That re suit is now in the record book. Harvard's 4526 rout of Brown virtually eliminated the Bruins from the Ivy League title.

title: New Brunswick's Council Endorses StudentFiremen
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 18 The New Brunswick City Council voted 4 to 1 last night in favor of a controversial plan to use 16 Rutgers University students as city firemen as part of a plan to cut the city budget.

title: To Show You're Divorced
description: It's just a little ring of hammered gold, but it tells something about the wearer: that he or she is divorced. Peter Lindeman, who designed the prototype for his own use, calls it a separation band, however. The name divorce band resulted in too much static, he said. When the jeweler meets a woman for the first time his glance invariably strays to her hand. I see you're divorced, too, is an easy opening gambit and dispenses with a lot of tedious preliminaries, he believes.

title: Brookhaven's Zoning Law Attacked as Exclusionary
description: PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 18Charging that exclusionary zoning practices by suburban communities aggravated New York City's fiscal problems, Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan joined a coalition of housing and civilrights groups today in instituting a lawsuit against the Town of Brookhaven.

title: Knicks Down Blazers, 10192; Islanders Bow, 31, to Sabres
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Nov. 18  The Buffalo Sabres, showcasing a new and more defensive style, continued their old habit of beating the New York Islanders tonight, this time by a score of 31. In their four seasons, covering 16 games, the Islanders have never beaten Buffalo.

title: P.E.N. Congress Demands A Halt to Curbs on Writers
description: VIENNA, Nov. 18 (AP)The 40th International P.E.N. Congress called today for freedom of movement for writers and an end to persecution of authors who speak up for human rights.

title: Nigerians Oppose Abortion
description: LAGOS, Nigeria (Reuters)Nigeria's National Council of Women's Societies has joined the Roman Catholic Church to oppose a proposal by the federal Government to legalize abortion. In a statement the council president said legalized abortion would have a bad effect on society and encourage moral laxity.

title: A Desert Vision Takes on Shape As Builder Seeks New Society
description: ARCOSANTI COMMUNITY, Ariz.The desert is a traditional breeding ground of visions. Simple mirages or the ecstasies of holy men, they take ethereal shape in the heat and cruelty of the sunblasted earth. Arcosanti Community is, a palpable vision, rising dustily from a balsaltic mass overlooking the Agua Fria River about 70 miles north of Phoenix.

title: CARRIER INCREASING COOLINGUNIT PRICES
description: The Carrier Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising prices up to 7 percent on its airconditioning and refrigeration products.

title: Belmondo Is Sleuth in 'Night Caller'
description: Producers use Jean-Paul Belmondo like a security blanket, and they use him so often he is beginning to resemble one: the nub worn down, the creases gone limp.Through some odd work with the trans-Atlantic scissors, the Franco-Italian production "Night Caller" by Henri Verneuil seems to be two completely different movies, neither of them up to much.The overworked Mr. Belmondo is in both of them, and he even plays the same character in both, which saves changing suits. His name is Inspector Le Tellier, and he carries his great nose and jaw structure into battle against criminals and madmen, his misty eyes and bent smile one contemplative pace behind.The main movie is about a deranged man with an artificial eyeball who calls women up and subsequently kills them. Inspector Le Tellier goes to work, but all of a suddenamid screaming women, sinister black leather gloves and oppositely rolling eyeballshe detours to catch a long-sought bank robber.The 15-minute chase has Le Tellier chasing the robber by car through rush-hour Paris and then boarding the new blue-tiled express Mtro line. In a final shoot-out the Inspector plugs the robber in a crowded subway car, dumping him for good measure into the path of an oncoming train.This has absolutely no relation to the madman story. Perhaps it is an advertisement for the new high-speed Paris subways. On the old kind it wouldn't make much sense to have a lot of split-second dashing in and out since the doors open and close with dreamy slowness.Back to the madman. There is this man who decides that women with free-ranging sex lives should be punished. He picks several. They all live in nicely furnished apartments where the phone rings loudly. The madman calls, threatens, and comes around two or three days later to strangle.Le Tellier gets within striking distance of the killer once or twice. There is a long ledge-and-chimney-pot chase that ends inconclusively.Finally, the madman throws a hand grenade into a porno-film theater and is off to hold the star hostage in her apartment. All the top Paris police authorities ask Le Tellier what is to be done. He has the answer. A helicopter lowers him outside the actress's window: he smashes the window and beats the madman to a pulp.That is the end of the two movies. That is two movies out of the way for the priceand the lengthof one.

title: Bayh Backed in Massachusetts By State's Lieutenant Governor
description: I BOSTON, Nov. 19Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana began this week to accelerate the pace of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and today won the endorsement of Lieut. Gov. Thomas P. O'Neill 3d of Massachusetts.

title: WOMAN REPORTED ON NEW COURT LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19United States District Judge Cornelia Kennedy is on a second list of about eight lawyers and judges whom the Ford Administration has asked the American Bar Association to investigate as possible successors to Supreme Court Justice William 0. Douglas, wellplaced sources said today.

title: Chase Buys $85.5 Million of NoIncome Property
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, which recently reported a 52 percent decline in its thirdquarter earnings, purchased last month $85.8 million worth of property that was earning its owners no income at the time of the sale, according to reports filed with the Securities Exchange Commission.

title: F.B.I. Aide Terms Effort To Vilify Dr. King Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that there was no statutory basis or justification for some 25 separate incidents of bureau (harassment of the Rev. Dr. MarLuther King Jr. during sixyear campaign to discredit the civil rights leader.

title: New Haven Schools Shut as Unions Call For General Strike
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19Public schools in New Haven were ordered closed this afternoon in the face of a general strike that was threatened as a protest against the jailing of 90 teachers and union lead ers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Generalissimo Francisco Franco died after 36 years of dictatorial rule over Spain. He was 82 years old. The death of the Chief of State, who led rightist military forces to victory in the Spanish Civil War that ended in 1939, came at the La Paz Hospital on the northern edge of Madrid. He had been rushed there on Nov. 7 from the Pardo Palace. [Page 1, Column 23.]

title: A Correction
description: In an editorial published yesterday, the date of the New York rally was erroneously given as next Tuesday. The correct date is Monday.

title: Purolator Records Sought
description: Purolator Inc. said yesterday it had been subpoenaed by the Atlanta office of the antitrust division of the Justice Department to produce information on armored car and air freight services..

title: AntiAmericanism in Mexico Is Deep but Not Blatant
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13Every Mexican has two attitudes toward the United States. One is by heritage, one by his own experience.

title: Jets Dismiss Coach
description: The New York Jets football team, which has lost six straight games, dismissed Charley Winner as head coach yesterday. Ken Shipp, an assistant, was named interim coach. Page 55.

title: Corporations Release Reports Covering Their Sales and Earnings
COLBY ASKS PANEL TO DROP 12 NAMES FROM PLOT REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, appealed today to a Senate committee not to make public the names of 12 individuals, some of them agency officials, who were allegedly involved in C.I.A. plots against the lives of foreign heads of state.

title: BRITAIN PLEDGES SCOTS AND WELSH SOME HOME RULE
description: LONDON, Nov. 19Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Party Government formally announced today its intention to provide Scotland and Wales with some form of home rulea move that would represent the most profound constitutional change in the United Kingdom in many years.

title: Amin Getting Away With Biting Soviet Hand That Feeds Him
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 19 President Idi Amin of Uganda appears once again to have gotten away with biting the hand that feeds him, this time challenging the Soviet Union, his major source of military aid.

title: Changing Faces Of Local Teams
description: Since the first of the year, the following changes have been made in the leadership of New York teams:

title: A Pollution Emergency Curtails Steel Output in Pittsburgh Area
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19  As many as 30 industrial plants in the Pittsburgh area were forced, to curtail operations today as a weather inversion caused air pollution levels to soar to the highest levels since the establishment of Allegheny County's monitoring system.

title: Bull Ties Up Traffic
description: FARIBAULT, Minn., Nov. 19 (UPI)A Holstein bull brought traffic to a standstill at a busy intersection today and challenged cars and police officers to a duel before he was corrailed. Traffic was at a standstill for 20 minutes before six police officers and a crowd of daredevil helpers corralled the beast in a snow fence.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court in Trenton ruled that a criminal defendant who asked for a lawyer and then made a voluntary confession without his attorney present could not appeal to have the confession excluded.

title: Northrop to Split Stock
description: Directors of the Northrop Corporation declared yesterday a 3for2 split of the common stock. The board also increased the quarterly dividend to 45 cents a share from 40 cents. Both dividends will be payable Dec: 20 to stockholders of record Dec. 1. The company said the cash dividend would not be paid on the split shares.

title: Israeli Reconnaisance Jets Fly Over Beirut, Stir Fear of Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19Two Israeli reconnaissance jets flew over Beirut shortly before noon today, drawing fire from Lebanese antiaircraft gunners and from Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Democrats Vie, Openly and Otherwise, for Right to Challenge Buckley
description: With the final returns from the last election still being counted, New York politicians are looking forward the nest, andas is customaryDemocrats project the deepest disarray.

title: Grain and Soybeans End Mostly Lower; Gold Futures Rise
description: Grain and soybean futures closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after dropping sharply the day before following predictions of record crops this year.

title: French to Join Bicentennial
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 19 (AP) The French Navy, which helped the American colonists defeat the British 200 years ago, has agreed to take part in Bicentennial celebration in this seaport City next year. Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, said this week that French officials had informed him that a warship would be sent to Newport next summer.

title: Retailers Mixed on Cigarette Price Rise
description: Cigarette prices may rise as much as 5 cents a pack in the next few days as vendors begin passing on increases in manufacturers prices of 6 to 9 percent.

title: BOND PRICES OPEN WEAKER BUT GAIN
description: The credit markets reacted skittishly yesterday to the dual problem of heavy dealer inventories and prospects of weighty financings in the near future. Corporate bonds and Treasury issues opened sustantially weaker but improved later in the session. I'd say the market is somewhat demoralized, one underwriter ventured. At this point, it needs some good news possibly a favorable sign from the Federal Reserve.

title: Personal Income Up 1% in October, Slowing Its Climb
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) The personal income of Americans increased by $12.7 billion, or 1 percent, in October, the smallest rise in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Neighborhood's Tree Goes Off to the Big City
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 19Rockefeller Center came and bought Jean Wolfe's tree today.

title: CORPS OF ENGINEERS SUED ON SEA DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The National Wildlife Federation sued today to curb the ocean dumping of dredged material by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.

title: JAPANESE LEADER IN SELFCRITICISM
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19Prime Miaster Taken Miki today openly admitted that his handling of his nation's political, diplomatic, economic, and military affairs had been inadequate.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: READY FOR INSPECTION A program of 21 movies from East Germany starts today at the Museum of Modern Art. The selections were made from 600 films produced in the German Democratic Republic since the end of World War H. Only three works in the sixweek program have been shown previously in the United States. Commenting on the output of a country that subsidizes its film production, a museum official pointed out that while many of the German imports were socialized and traditional in style, the program nevertheless provided some insight into a cinema shaped by the force of political ideology.

title: CHESTER LAWTON, 78, OCEANCABLE EXPERT
description: Chester S. Lawton, an oceancable engineer and executive of the Western Union Telegraph Company for more thar 40 years, died Monday in the Ridgewood Nursing. Home it Ridgewood, N. J. He was 78 years old and lived in Ridge, wood for 50 years.

title: Senate Eases Restrictions On Construction Picketing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Senate passed tonight by a vote of 52 to 45 a long disputed bill greatly broadening the authority of building trades unions to picket at construction sites.

title: Chess
description: Arthur Bisguier is accident prone. His colleagues also drop games to much lower opponents from time to time, but none falter as colorfully or as frequently as the Rock Hill, N. Y., grandmaster.

title: Convention of Conservative Jews Urges More Religious Education
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 19The United Synagogue of America today mandated that its Conservative congregations in this country and Canada make available a minimum number of hours of instruction for Jewish students.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Justice Harry B. Frank of State Supreme Court issued an order yesterday temporarily barring the dismissal confidential court: attendants to 45 justices in Manhattan and the Bronx:. His ruling upheld the justices contention that the elimination of attendants would result in increased delay in litigation because such services as recordkeeping. security, reception, stenography and answering telephones would be curtailed.

title: Two Banks Allowed To Form Branches Throughout State
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19The Federal Reserve Board approved today a set of organizational changes involving the Marine Midland Bank and the Bank of New York that will enable them to start statewide (branching at the beginning of next year as allowed by New York State law.

title: Chairman Reports U.D.C. Is Doing Well
description: The Urban Development Corporation, which defaulted last February on a loan and on $100 million in bondanticipation notes, is alive and doing well today, according to its chairman, Richard Ravitch.

title: A Pollution Emergency Curtails Steel Output in Pittsburgh Area
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19  As many as 30 industrial plants in the Pittsburgh area were forced to curtail operations today as weather inversion caused air pollution levels to soar to the highest levels since the establishment of Allegheny County's monitoring system.

title: Mr. Church's CoverUp
description: WASHINGON. Nov. 19On Oct. 10, 1963, the thenAttorney General of the United States put his personal signature on a document that launched and legitimatized one of the most horrendous abuses of Federal police power in this century.

title: Triple Default
description: President Ford is continuing to play a cynically cruel and reckless game with the City of New York. But the city slides into default while awaiting the Federal assist that the President still refuses to endorse, the blame cannot be laid solely on the doorstep of the White House.

title: Hawks Win in Overtime From Warriors by 10498
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (AP)John Drew scored 6 of his gamehigh 27 points in overtime tonight to lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 104=98 National Basketball Association victory over the Golden State Warriors.

title: JOBLESS FIGURE IS CALLED WRONG
description: The executive director of the National Urban League, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., said last night that the real unemployment figure for the United States was double the more than eight million given by Government statistics.

title: Amtrak Turbotrain And Truck Collide; 39 Hurt in Illinois
description: ELWOOD, Ill., Nov. 19 (AP)Four cars of a highspeed Amtrak turbotrain derailed today when it collided with a sixwheeled truck, injuring 39 persons.

title: Cortland Democrats Open CareyforPresident Drive
description: While Governor Carey was in the midst of state and city fiscal crises, a CareyforPresident boomlet took shape yesterday in Cortland County as the Democratic organization there endorsed his candidacy.

title: ERNEST H. BAKER
description: Ernest H. Baker, an artist best known for the covers he did for Time magazine, died Monday at Norton, Mass. He was 86 years old.

title: The Cost of Disunity
description: A critical group inside Portugal's armed forces has analyzed with great clarity the terrible dangers of civil war arising from the bitter political and ideological divisions in the military establishment. As the report suggests, disunity within the command structures and the blatant identification of officers with leftist political parties have enabled the Communists and their allies repeatedly to humiliate the moderate Government Prime Minister Pinheiro de Azevedo in recent weeks.

title: That $4,000 Dinner for Two:
description: With the glut of problem news items, it was inevitable, perhaps, that a note of levity was thought to be introduced with the account of the $4,000 dinner at Chez Denis in Paris that was attended by Craig Claiborne and friend and considered to be a newsworthy morsel, to be digested with relish by Your readers

title: PRESIDENT AWAITS CITYSTATE MOVE BEFORE GIVING AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19President Ford said today that he would not now support. Federal financial aid to prevent a New York City default, but would reconsider his position next week if the city and state took further concrete actions.

title: NADJARI SUBJECT OF COURT MEETING
description: A closed meeting ordered by Justice John M. Murtagh of State Supreme Court was held yesterday in an attempt to deline more precisely the jurisdiction of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: Fiscal Panel Acts to Bolster Pensions, Calling for an End to Use of Gimmick
description: The state's Emergency Financial Control Board took three steps yesterday toward bolstering the soundness of the city's five pension systems at a time when the systems are being viewed as a source of heavy borrowing for the city.

title: Girl Skater, 14, Finds U.S. Haven for Her Aspirations
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Nov. 19The winner of first place today in NoviceLadies, Group B, comes from a small family who defected two years ago from Rumania. She wants to enter the High School of Music and Art, go on to college and become a professional figure skater aspirations sharply defined for a girl who is just 14 years old and in this country, only one year.

title: Musselman Sees Squires Top Nets
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 19Bill Musselman, hired, in the afternoon as the Virginia Squires head coach, watched his new team defeat the New York Nets, 110100, tonight before 7,192 fans, the largest home crowd of the season for the American Basketball Association franchise.

title: Ford Stand on City Depresses Stocks
description: The stock market declined fairly sharply yesterday in disappointment over President Ford's decision to continue withholding his support for financial aid to New York City until the Legislature in Albany acts on the city crisis.

title: Minority Group to Press Carey For Posts on New Fiscal Units
description: The Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus is scheduled to meet with Governor Carey today and intends to press for minority representaAlan on the two state agencies monitoring the city's budget, the Emergency Financial Control Board and the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Lombardozzi Is Indicted With 6 on Perjury Counts
description: An investigation involving elaborate electronic bugging and highly dangerous undercover work led to perjury indictments yesterday against Carmine Lombardozzi, identified as a major figure in organized crime and six other persons.

title: F.E.A. OIL RULING STIRRING DEBATE
description: The decision by the Federal Energy Administration last Monday to award Edward M. Carey's New England Petroleum Corporation entitlements worth $2.8 million for its residual fuel imports has stirred further controversy in the oil industry.

title: REV. VINCENT BENNETT
description: The Rev. Vincent. Leroy Benretl, who from 1942 to 1945 was associate rector of the. Episcopal Church of the Ascension at Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, died Tuesday at his home in Manchester, Vt. He was 84 years old.

title: Lord Henribee, $3, Wins Third Straight
description: W. H. (Billy) Turner, the former steeplechase rider turned trainer, yesterday continued to ave over the notential of 2yearold Lord Henribee as he watched Mil ton Ritzenberg's At the talented colt win Race the $43.150 Rockaway at AgueTracks duct it xkasn't t n e convincing 27, length margin that the ored Lord Henribee boasted over Christiana's Dance Spell at the finish of the six furlong contest but the Coles over  all performance that delighted the lanky conditioner.

title: OilDistillate Items Show Output Drop As Purchases Slip
description: Production of distillate petroleum products, primarily home heating oil, fell last week, apparently because of lagging purchases by dealers who expected price declines.

title: Wings Tie Bruins, 33, On Late Redmond Goal
description: DETROIT, Nov, 19 (UPI)Mickey Redmond scored with 10 seconds to play tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 33 National Hockey League tie with the  Boston Bruins. Mike Korney set up the goal, which came with the Wings goalie, Ed Giacomin, out of goal in favor of an extra attacker.

title: L.I.R.R. WILL TEST NEW TYPE OF DOOR
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 19A test of 20 Long Island Rail Road cars with doors redesigned to prevent passengers from being trapped will be conducted throughout the winter, the state's Select Legislative Committee on Transportation was told today.

title: Academy of Poets Gives 1975 Award To Robert Hayden
description: Robert Hayden, author of six books of poetry and professor of English at the University of Michigan, has been elected the 1975 Fellow of the Academy of American Poets. The award carries a stipend of $10,000 and was announced by Mrs. Hugh Bullock, president of the acaemy. The three most recent winners were Leonie Adams, W. S. Merwin and W. D. Snodgrass.

title: Night and Day, Shoulders Are Visible Again
description: Bare shoulders are back.

title: Conservative Madeirans Are Cool to the Revolutionary Politics of Mainland. Portugal
description: FUNCHAL, Madeira, Nov. 14 While construction workers were surrounding the Government Palace in Lisbon and demanding higher pay, those on this Portuguese island stayed on the job.

title: For Children, A Funny Frankenstein
description: You shake your head, cluck your tongue, and laugh in spite of yourself during a performance of Frankenstein by the Off Center Theater.

title: Elan of Garde Republicaine
description: The Garde Republicaine of Paris is a military band, 70 members strong, that was founded in 1848 but had made only three visits to this country before Tuesday night's concert at Carnegie Hall. It played a little military music and, of course, the quasimartial anthems of France and the United States. But the bulk of the program and by far the best part was given over to works for what is often called the symphonic band.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SEOUL IS REVISING ITS POLICY ON U. N.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 15The Government of South Korea, in a major foreign policy reversal, has all but written off the United Nations as guarantor of the mation's security

title: Liquor Labeling Plan
description: The Food and Drug Administration said it would soon order the alcoholic beverage industry to list on labels the ingredients in all domestic and imported beer, wine and liquor. The Treasury Department recently rejected such a plan. Page 29.

title: Senate Approves 3 Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (Reuters)  The Senate today confirmed the rrominations of James W. Spain as Ambassador to Tanzania, Walter L. Cutler as Ambassador to Zaire and Nathaniel Davis, now Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. as Ambassador to Switzerland.

title: Text of Ford's Statement
description: I am gratified that the leaders of New York appear to have accepted primary responsibility for solving the financial problems of the city and are proceeding in the direction of a longterm solution in accordance with the State Constitution and laws. I am impressed with the seriousness of their intentions, as described by Governor Carey in his letter to Secretary Simon, and await further concrete actions by the state and the other parties concerned.

title: Paroled Mugger Is Seized in Robbery of 2 Women
description: A 21yearold paroled mugger who in 1972 kept a diary listing 30 victims, the weapon used and the amount of money taken was arrested again yesIterday in the Bronx and charged with, robbing two elderly women of 45 cents while menacing them with a heavy steel chain, the police reported.

title: Franco Is Dead in Madrid at 82
description: MADRID, Thursday, Nov. 20  Generalissimo Francisco Franco died early today after 36 years of dictatorial rule over Spain. He was 82 years old.

title: CopperProducing Lands Vote to Retain Cutbacks
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 19 (AP)Copperexporting nations, setting their sights on raising export prices, approved today a continuation of 15 percent production cutbacks and voted to consider setting up a buffer stock to combat inflation in the metal.

title: KISSINGER UNVEILS PLAN ON SINAI UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the 200 American civilians to be assigned to monitor the recent Sinai agreement between Egypt and Israel would be under contract to a private American company that would be supervised by the State Department.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In talking about why Charley Winner was discharged yesterday as the New York Jets head coach, Phil Iselin, said:

title: Refusal of Sakharov Visa Publicly Disclosed in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (UPI)The Soviet Union informed its citizens today of its weekold decision not to grant an exit visa to Andrei D. Sakharov to receive his Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Enter Reagan
description: Contrary to the popular stereotype, it is not unusual for incumbent Presidents to be challenged within their own party for renomination. Not only did Senator Eugene J. McCarthy oppose President Johnson in 1968 and Senator Estes Kefauver oppose President Truman in 1952 but Vice President John Nance Garner fought the thirdterm bid of President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940. The most spectacular battle ever waged against an incumbent was former President Theodore Roosevelt's effort to block President William Howard Taft, his former friend and protg, in 1912, a struggle that split the G.O.P. and had consequences that have lasted to the present.

title: EMPLOYEES CURBED IN FRESNO SWITCH
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) Employees who switched suddenly from one stockbrokerage firm here to another have been barred temporarily from using any accounts from their previous emolovment.

title: Court Suspends Rate Rise For News Service Phone
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A, Federal court has temporarity suspended higher private, line telephone rates due to go into effect today. The nation's four major newswire agencies have said the new rates would cost them $5million more al ye.

title: Listing of Prices for Contracts in Futures of Commodities
Music: A First for Sonata by Luening
description: Otto Luening, prolific composer, tireless champion of American music, innovator in electronic music, teacher of thousands at various schools (he became professor emeritus at Columbia University in 1968), turned 75 last June 15. His birthday has not been celebrated publicly with any fanfare, and modest notice was taken of it Tuesday night in the Hear America First program at the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Mr. Luening's Sonata for Piano in Memorism Ferruccio Busoni was given its first concert performance, as the centerpiece of the evening. Afterward, Oliver Daniel, a vice president of Broadcast Music Inc., presented the composer with a silver tray, a gift from his students.

title: People in Sports
description: It was a great honor to become a member of a United States team. The speaker was 6foot2inch, 231pound Floyd (Jumbo) Cummings, who was one of two American heavyweight boxers to score a victory over the Soviet Union amateurs in Cincinnati Tuesday night. The Russian team won, seven bouts to two.

title: ANTIPOVERTY FUNDS RESTORED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)  The house voted 244 to 172 today to restore 80 percent Federal funding for community antipoverty programs, rather than allow the Federal share to decrease under legislation passed last year.

title: Market Place
description: In the sobering days since the gogo years of the late 1960's, individual investors have experienced difficulty merely breaking even in the stock market.

title: Times Is Warned Of a Possible Strike By Photoengravers
description: The Photoengravers Union warned yesterday of a possible strike against The New York Times at 5 P.M. today if it did not agree to continue a contract clause giving the union jurisdiction for platbmaking for offset presses.

title: People and Business
description: Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon said yesterday that he has no present plans for another auction of part of the Treasury's gold, but he said the Treasury would continue to sell gold as necessary to meet domestic demand and therefore reduce gold imports.

title: Drug Center Chief Doubts Sex Abuse Is Widespread
description: The director of the state narcotics rehabilitation center for women in Ray Brook, N. Y., said here yesterday that while he was aware of some allegations of sexual abuse of female residents by male employees at the facility, he doubted that it was as widespread as witnesses had testified.

title: Gilmour Gets Writ
description: At the request of William (Buddy) Gilmour. a Federal iudge ordered New York's harness tracks yesterday show cause why they should not he enjoined trom conunuing their ban against the 43yearold driver.

description: Bella Abzug is upstate, speaking softly. Ramsey Clark is getting out the scuffed Hush Puppies. Robert Abrams working very hard and very publicly for, he says, a Presidential candidate. Bess Mverson is ... cov.

title: Out of the Crucible of Civil War, Franco's Iron Hand Forged a Modern Spain
description: One of the most durable, canny and empirical of modern dictators, Francisco Paulino Hermenegildo Teodulo Franco y Bahamonde became master of Spain as a result of a military con spiracy, a dash of luck, timely help from foreign corporations, the influence of the Roman Catholic hierarch and crucial armed assistance from Hitler and Mussolini.

title: Words And Deeds
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19On Nov. 12 the chief American delegate to the U.N., Daniel Patrick Moynihan, introduced a resolution urging the release of political prisoners around the world. Speaking for the idea, Mr. Moynihan denounced the selective morality of the United Nations in matters of human rights.

title: STATE REDESIGNS SCHOOLAID PLAN
description: TRENTON, Nov. 19Sensing mounting public discontent over proposed plans to redistribute state school aid in an effort to insure that local school districts are providing a thorough and efficient education for all public school students, the State Board of Education is preparing a new set of much less ambitious regulations.

title: DEMOCRATS KILL ANTIBUSING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19House Democrats turned back today an effort to force an antibusing amendment to the Constitution out of the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Rticsian Five Wins, 9992
description: WINSTONSALEM N. C., Nov. 19 (UPI)Mihail Korkia scored 17 points tonight to lead the Soviet Union to a 9992 victory over the Wake Forest quintet in double overtime.

title: TV: Notorious Woman
description: Public television's Notorious Woman. which began last Sunday at 9 P.M. and will run for six more Sundays, is a British Broadcasting Corporation version of the life of George Sand (150476). Originally named Amandine Aurore Lucile Dupin, George Sand achieved fame and notoriety as a prolific writer of novels and plays, and as a friend or lover or both to many of the more famous of her French contemporaries.

title: Woodlynne Rebuffs Church a 2d Time On Zoning Request
description: WOODLYNNE. Nov. 18The Rev. John H. Brent was rebuffed tonight in a second effort to get a zoning grant that borough officials say he needs to move his congregation to a vacant church here.

title: E.P.A. AIDE WARNS OF TOXIC LEAKAGE
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19A chemist for the Environmental Protection Agency estimated today that at leas 10 million pounds of the toxic chemicals known as polychlorinated biphenals are lost into the environment each year through vaporization, leaks and spills.

title: WOMAN INDICTED IN MEDICAID THEFT
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Nov. 19A Suffolk Counuty grand jury; today indicted Dolores Esposito, former owner of the Sayvile Nursing Home, on charges that she fraudulently claimed; nearly 5125,000 in Medicaid expenses.

description: ALBANY, Nov. 19President Ford's latest comment on the fiscal crisis, with its more conciliatory, if still ambiguous tone, triggered a series of political postures today as varied as the terrain that stretches from tilt state house here to the White House For upstate Re publicans, there was concernexpressed by the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson  about any intertwining of the state's fiscal problem, and its taxation issue with the city's fiscal crisis.

description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously upheld a ruling that a New York City police officer convicted on drug charges two years ago had not received a fair trial and should be tried again.

description: Dolores, one of the most beautiful Ziegfeld Girls of more than half a century ago, died in Paris on Nov. 7. She was 83 years old.

Several hundred yards away, the skeletons of two halffinished large coal silos stood out against the rolling, mustardcolored grass lands.

title: A Longer Landfill Life Forecast., In Ban on OutofState Garbage

description: LONDON, Nov. 19Britain' major literary prize, the Booker Award, was given today to Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, the Germanborn novelist who has spent more than 25 years in India.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Sout h Africa, Nov. 19 (Reuters)Twelve miners were killed and, four injured in an underground methane gas explosion at the Kloof gold mine, near Johannesburg, a mine spokesman said today.

title: Italy's Inflation Rate Drops
description: ROME, Nov. 19 (Reuters), Italy's annual inflation rate dropped below 12 percent in October even though prices rose faster in that month than over the summer, the National Statistics Institute has announced. The rate for the 12 months ending in October was 11.8 percent. The annual rate has been dropping steadily since it reached 25.1 percent last January.

description: Dr. Victor L. Butterfield, president emeritus of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., died there yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Middletown.

description: CAMDEN, Nov. 19Judge Mitchell H. Cohen of Federal District Court refused today to dismiss charges that the Governor of Puerto Rico and two of his top labor offic'als conspired with New Jersey to deny Puerto Rican farmworkers ade.uate housing on Jersey farms.

description: The Food and Drug Administration said it would soon order the alcoholic beverage industry to list on labels the ingredients in all domestic and imported beer, wine and liquor. The Treasury Department recently rejected such a plan. Page 29.

description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 19Former Gov. Roger D. Brani[gin, one of the Hoosier State's most popular Governors and widely noted for his wit, died today at a hospital here. He was 73 years old.

title: Card Sale to Aid City Parks
description: Holiday cards depicting a winter scene in Central Park by the American painter William J. Glackens will be sold to raise funds to aid in restoring the city's parks. The City Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration will sell the cards for 20 cents each at the Arsenal, at Fifth Avenue; and 64th Street, Room 103. Checks can be made out to the Park Recreation Fund, and they are taxdeductible.

title: Media Credited in HeartAttack Drive
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 19Two experimental mass media campaigns in two small California towns have been extremely effective in persuading people to stop smoking, to eat more wisely and to exercise more, thus reducing their overall risks for having heart attacks, it was reported here today.

title: Idle Dice Triumphs at Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 19Idle Dice became the first horse in the international division to win two events at the Royal Winter Fair show when he captured the faultandout test tonight.

title: Giscard's First 500 Days: Quiet and Gradual Change
description: PARIS, Nov. 19President Valery Giscard d'Estaing emerged from the sixpower economic meeting he convoked as a new kind of French leader, diminishing arguments with the United States and emphasizing the need for Western unity.

title: Nicholson, the Free Spirit of 'Cuckoo'
description: People like Randle Patrick McMurphy are foregone conclusions. You gather together at random any 12 men, and one of them will eventually surface as the group's Randle Patrick McMurphy, the organizer, the spokesman, the leading hell-raiser and free spirit, the man who accepts nothing at face value and who likes to shake up the system, sometimes just because it's there. The quality of Randle Patrick McMurphy depends entirely on the intensity of his opposition.Before the start of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," Milos Forman's film version of Ken Kesey's 1962 novel, Randle Patrick McMurphy (Jack Nicholson) was strictly small potatoes, his life distinguished by nothing except carelessness.One assumes him to have been a quick-witted but none-too-bright fellow whose vanity, drinking, whoring and short temper have earned him a minor police record consisting mostly of assault - and - battery complaints, concluding with a conviction for statutory rape. The girl, who said she was 19, was only 15.When we first meet Randle, he has served two months of his six-month sentence and has managed to get himself transferred to the state mental hospital for psychiatric observation, figuring that life in the loony bin would be easier than on the prison farm. It's the beginning of the end for Randle, but the ferocity of the system imposes on him a kind of crazy grandeur."One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," which opened yesterday at the Sutton and Paramount Theaters, is a comedy that can't quite support its tragic conclusion, which is too schematic to be honestly moving, but it is acted with such a sense of life that one responds to its demonstration of humanity if not to its programmed metaphors.Once in the bin, Randle becomes the self-proclaimed champion of the rights of the other ward patients, his adversary being Nurse Ratched, a severe, once-pretty woman of uncertain age who can be sympathetic and understanding only in ways that reinforce her authority. Nurse Ratched represents the System that all Randles must buck.As played by Louise Fletcher and defined in the screenplay by Lawrence Hauben and Bo Goldman, the film's Nurse Ratched is a much more interesting, more ambiguous character than in Mr. Kesey's novel, though what we take to be her fleeting impulses of genuine concern only make the film's ending that much more unbelievable."One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is at its best when Mr. Forman is exercising his talents as a director of exuberant comedy that challenges preconceived notions of good taste. It's not too far from the mark to describe Randle as a sort of Mister Roberts who finds himself serving aboard the U.S.S Madhouse. It's to Mr. Forman's credit that the other patients in the ward, though suffering from all sorts of psychoses, are never patronized as freaks but are immediately identifiable as variations on ourselves, should we ever go over the edge of what's called sanity.Mr. Nicholson slips into the role of Randle with such easy grace that it's difficult to remember him in any other film. It's a flamboyant performance but not so overbearing that it obscures his fellow actors, all of whom are very good and a few of whom are close to brilliant, including William Redfield (as an egghead patient who talks grave nonsense), Will Sampson (as a deaf-mute Indian) and Brad Dourif (as a young man with a fatal mother complex).There are some unsettling things about "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest." I suspect that we are meant to make connections between Randle's confrontation with the oppressive Nurse Ratched and the political turmoil in this country in the 1960's. The connection doesn't work. All it does is conveniently distract us from questioning the accuracy of the film's picture of life in a mental institution where shock treatments are dispensed like aspirins and lobotomies are prescribed as if the mind's frontal lobes were troublesome wisdom teeth.Even granting the artist his license, America is much too big and various to be satisfactorily reduced to the dimensions of one mental ward in a movie like this.

title: In Memorian
description: LIPSCHITZCella. Dearest mother, left u twenty tour rears Ago toddy. Your wise words, your love and devotion will never be forgotten You alve forever In our hearts. Children MABEL end HERMAN.

title: Adoption Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 19 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today to permit single persons 25 years of age or older to adopt foreign orphans. Under present immigration law only married couples may adopt them and bring them into this country..

title: Tax Charges Dismissed
description: Incometax charges against George Gamaldi, a former vice, president of Hills Supermarkets, were dismissed in Federal Court here by Judge Henry F. Werker. After the prosecution presented its evidence in the. threeday trial, the judge dismissed the case as too vague and unspecific. The tax indictment of Mr. Gamaldi grew out of alleged kickbacks in the meat industry here.

title: Scouts Turn Back Rangers Here, 64
description: The Mr. Nice Guys of the National Hockey Leilgue did it again last night. Facing one of the league's weak sistersthe Kansas City Scouts the Rangers danced around the Madison Square Garden ice like big brothers until their 2  year  old visitors waltzed off with a 64 victory.

title: Bond Prices Inch Up
description: The credit markets reacted skittishly yesterday to the dual problem of heavy dealer inventories and prospects of weighty financings soon. Corporate bonds and Treasury issues opened weaker but improved later in the day. Page 60.

title: Suffolk Democrats Elect New Presiding Legislator
description: HOLBROOK, L. I., Nov. 19Suffolk County Democrats today elected Floyd S. Linton, a 30yearold former school teacher, as the next presiding officer of the County Legislature, which they now control for the first time in this traditionally Republican area.

title: After Long, Cautious Dickering, Madrid Completes Some Reform
description: MADRID, Nov. 19A limited reform program started by Prime Minister Carlos Arias Navarro almost two years ago has been completed.

title: MARINE MIDLAND EXPECTS DEFICIT
description: Marine Midland Banks Inc., the nation's 12thlargest banking organization, disclosed plans yesterday to write ofi $25 million In bad loans and said it would report a loss for the fourth quarter of this year.

title: AID BILL IS VOTED FOR HANDICAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to legislation to make free appropriate public education available within five years to all the nation's handicapped persons from ages 3 to 21.

title: BERNSTEIN BOWS OUT OF FIDELIO
description: Leonard Bernstein, who had been scheduled to conduct a series of performances of Beethoven's Pidelio at the Metropolitan Opera beginning Jan. 2, has withdrawn from the assignment.

title: F.B.I. Aide Terms Effort To Vilify Dr. King Illegal,
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19A top official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that there was no statutory basis or justification for some 25 separate incidents of bureau harassment of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. during sixyear campaign to discredit the civil rights leader.

title: Books of The Times
description: In Trinidad, where V. S. Naipaul was horn, there is, or used to he, a bird called the nocturnal poormeone whose cry was said to he so pathetic that it brought gooseflesh to those who heard it. Progress has probably frightened away the nocturnal poormeone, or rendered it extinct, but now, in Guerrillas, Mr. Naipaul has come to take its place. His cry, I'm sure, will bring gooseflesh to his listeners, too, and with scarcely more reason.

title: MAN SEIZED HERE IN FIVE BOMBINGS

title: ... on Money Stability

At Rambouillet, the United States rightly stressed the cardinal importance of achieving underlying economic and financial stability among nations as the precondition for stable exchange rates. And France acknowledged that exchangerate flexibility is needed today to cushion the continuing shocks of a still disordered international economy.

Arcosanti Community is a palpable vision, rising dustily from a balsaltic mass overlooking the Agua Fria River about 70 miles

description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 19 (AP)Jaya Prakash Narayan, the ailing 74yearold opposition leader released from jail last week, said from his hospital bed today, We really haven't broken away from the slavery of the British time here, and that he planned to resume active opposition to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Looking at Spain
description: WESTPORT, Conn.There is a tendency among some commentators to regard the Spanish Civil War as struggle between fascism and democracy. In fact, the socalled Republican Government was eventually controlled from Moscow. Moscow then, as now, was demonstrably not interested either in freedom or democracy. Republic is a handsome word that covers a multitude of sins, since the leftists in Spain steadfastly disregarded public opinion and election results, just as the Communists are doing in Portugal.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Senate passed tonight by vote of 52 to 45 a long disputed bill greatly broadening the authority of building trades unions to picket at construction sites.

description: RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 19 (AP)Morocco's 250,000 invaders of the Spanish Sahara were ordered to break camp today and return home following the Spanish Parliament's action opening the way for transfer of the territory to Morocco and Mauritania.

title: Stage: A Curio of 1800's
description: Concentrated essence of baboons, as one chaarcter interjects. The York Players have actually exhumed Tom Tyler's Our American Cousin from the musty theatrical trunk. This is the play of course whose performance on the night of April 14, 1865, was terminated by John Wilkes Booth, who in addition to being a Presidential assassin may have been an erstwhile drama critic.

title: ELECTIONS CHIEF OPPOSED TO CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19Thomas B. Curtis, chairman of the Federal Election Commission, called on House leaders today to oppose pending legislation that he said would convert the commission from an independent agency into a toady of Congress.

title: The Screen:'Human Factor,' Story of Bloody Vengeance
description: Vigilante justice, one of the oldest movie staples, is given improbable and gory treatment in "The Human Factor," which opened yesterday at local theaters. The idea of an intellectual's taking the law into his own hands is no newer than, say, last year's "Death Wish." But "The Human Factor," despite technological trappings, political innuendo and colorful Italian locales, evolves as a manipulated affair that is no more convincing than its lackluster direction, pedestrian performances and jerry-built script.A modicum of tension is initially generated when George Kennedy, playing an American computer expert with NATO forces in Naples, discovers that the wanton slaughter of his wife and three children is the work of terrorists who, it is dimly indicated, will continue killing expatriate Americans at random if "political prisoners" aren't freed.If our shocked hero deserves sympathy, it is diluted when, aided by a good deal of somewhat unbelievable computer sleuthing, he is able not only to unearth the gangsters but also to mow them down singly or en masse in bloodbath style. The gang members, led by Frank Avianca, who is also the film's producer, are a blatantly callous lot who stack the emotional cards in favor of Mr. Kennedy.His drive for vengeance may be conceivable, but it's not entirely logical. Despite the pleas of John Mills, as his NATO scientific sidekick, to let the police do the dirty work, the highly intellectual Mr. Kennedy emerges in effect as a violent man who, under stress, doesn't seem to be much better than the murderers he systematically seeks out and destroys.His characterization of a man racked by grief and hate is generally restrained and occasionally touching. But Mr. Mills as well as Raf Vallone, as the police inspector; Rita Tushingham, as Mr. Kennedy's colleague; Barry Sullivan, as an American Embassy official, and Arthur Franz, as the NATO general, are serious but perfunctory in largely surface stints.In this case, "The Human Factor" is no more persuasive than its contrived and bloody melodrama.

title: Bridge
description: The biggest bridge game ever played, the charity game of the American Contract Bridge League, will take place next Tuesday evening at 506 sites. Most of the games are in the continental United States, but there will also be games in Alaska, Puerto Rico, Canada, Mexico, Germany, Hong Kong, Cuba, Indonesa, the Bahamas, Greece, Australia, Singapore, the Philippines. Iran, Korea, Japan and the Marshall Islands.

title: West Berlin Mayor Looks To Soviet Power Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin said today that his city which is in the middle of East Germany, had yet to notice any benefits from the EastWest security conference concluded in Helsinki last summer.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An investigation involving elaborate electronic bugging and highly dangerous undercover work led to perjury indictments in Brooklyn against Carmine Lombardozzi, a major figure in organized crime and six other persons. The indictments involved denials of conversations about millions of dollars in loansharking operations and arsonforinsurance schemes fraud.

Playing it safe, however, the Juilliard American Opera Center, which presented Rusalka last night, says that it is believed these performances mark the American premiere. (Repeats are scheduled tonight, tomorrow and Sunday.)
