description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: SABINE MAY SELL URANIUM HOLDING
description: The Sabine Royalty Corporation of Dallas, an independent oil company, said yesterday that it was considering an offer from an unidentified public util4y to buy Sabine's interest in

title: National Review: 20; William Buckley: 50
description: Theodore H. White was there, perhaps to take notes for an epitaph on The Settling for a President, 1976. So was Daniel P. Moynihan, our permanent representative at the United Nations. And able company to most of the Camelot courtiers. Many of them, in fact, concluded that a man of his evident intelligence and charm couldn't possibly take his own politics seriously; he must have been mining some main chance they hadn't intuited. Opportunists tend to generalize from limited experience.

title: Devine Supported By Irish Players
description: MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP)Notre Dame's 48man traveling football squad gave a vote of confidence tonight Coach Dan Devine on the eve of its game with the University of Miami in the Orange Bowl,

title: CHURCH EXPECTS SENATE SUPPORT OF C.I.A. CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Senator Frank Church said today that he believed the Senate would pass before Easter legislation providing for strong Congressional oversight of the intelligence agencies.

title: One Labor Bill
description: With all the problems of inflation and unemployment confronting the country, it is a measure of distorted priorities that Congress has seen fit this year to push through a longdisputed bill making it easy for building trades unions to shut down an entire construction site when any single union has a dispute with even one subcontractor.

title: The Oil Problem: An Alternative Approach
description: The tension and conflict surrounding the recent rise in Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prices is a reminder that the world oil problem remains unsolved. If the worldwide recession continues it will lend impetus to the idea that aggressive Western intervention in OPEC affairs, including possible military action, is necessary to prevent a prolonged depression. This should not be surprising, since the alternatives of war or depression, or both, have been the most common responses of our economic and political system to its economic crises.

title: List of Proposed Taxes
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21Following is a description of the tax proposals the Legislature was due to take up tonight.

title: Bridge:
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon with thousands of players from all parts of North America, plus a handful from other continents, competing for five major national titles and a score of minor ones.

title: Housing Muddle
description: As if an inordinate share of the suffering from inflation and recession were not enough, America's illhoused poor also have to put up with a housing policy that being administered as if sleepwalkers were at the controls.

title: HARRY B. COEN
description: DETROIT, Nov. 21 (UPI) Harry B. Coen, former General Motors vice president foT employee relations, died yesterday at a nursing home in Bloomfield Hills. He was 87 years old.

title: 2 More H.E.W. Aides Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Two more top welfare administrators in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare brave submitted their ivignations. The resignations of John A. Svahn and John C. Young in H.E.W.'s Social and Rehabilitation Service represent almost the last of the Nixon Administration carryovers in the Department.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Teacher of Year Named

title: Device on Aircraft Gauges Collision Risk
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21George B. Litchford, an inventor of aviation safety, equipment, has received the latest in a series of patents on his midair collision avoid ante system, as Patents well as a $527,000 contract from of the the Federal AviaWeek tion Administration to produce experimental models. Patent 3,921,172 was granted Mr. Litchford this week for a method by which an aircraft may determine the bearing of another by intercepted radar signals.

title: Anna Murray McDonnell, 81; Philanthropist, Fund Raiser
description: Anna Murray McDonnell philanthropist and fund raiser, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. She was 81 years old and lived at 580 Park Avenue and in Southampton, L. I. Mrs. McDonnell was a former president and longtime member of the board of St. Vincent Hospital, for which she led fund drives for modernization and construction of its Alfred E. Smith Memorial Building. She also led fund campaigns for Bellevue Hospital, the New York Foundling Hospi

title: Political Placement Test
description: A bum approaches you on the street and asks for 25 cents for a cup of coffee. Your response tells whether you are a conservative, a moderate, leftwing Republican, a Wallaceite, a populist, a rightwing Democrat or a liberal. Check your philosophy.

title: Military Rulers in Lisbon Chide Cabinet, Oust Area Commander
description: LISBON, Nov. 21Portugal's Imilitary leadership censured Prime Minister Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo's Cabinet today for suspending its activities and called on the ministers to go back to work until an agreement can be reached on a new political formula.

title: Art: Puvis de Chavannes in Another Light
description: TORONTOIn the famous Salon d'Automne that was held in Paris in 1904faimous, among other reasons. for the great influence it was to wield on the younger painters of the School of Parisfive artists were given the honor of having special rooms devoted to their work. PoOr of these artistsCezanne, Redon, ToulouseLau ;tree and Renoirare now permanently established among the classics of modern painting. The fifth, PierreCecile PIMS de Chavannes 4182498), though widely admired in his day, is no longer even a name to anyone but a small circle of specialists. He has all but disappeared from recent histories of modern art, and in the Museums if his paintings are not completely relegated to the storerooms, they are now unlikely to be found among the acknowledged masterworks of the modern move

title: For Christmas, Dolls That Grow and Dolls That Don't
description: People Christmas shopping for dolls this year will find such standbys as Raggedy Ann and Andy, such contemporary favorites as Barbie, and something else that seems to have become an institution: higher prices.

title: Murderous Diplomacy
description: The massive, bipartisan report by the Senate's special committee on the Central Intelligence Agency's covert plots against foreign leaders removes all doubt that this arm of the United States Government was involved activities which are inexcusable by any standards international morality and diplomatic expediencyand which must be eliminated from all future intelligence operations.

title: Nuclear Nations Said to Agree To Restrict Uses by Importers
description: LONDON, Nov. 21The seven countries that manufacture and export most of the world's nuclear technology were said today to have general agreement on ways to prevent importing countries from using the technology to make nuclear weapons.

title: Gurney Faces Retrial on Jan. 5 On Two Slush Fund Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) Former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, who served on the Senate Watergate Committee, will be retried Jan. 5 on charges of conspiring to create a $233,000 political slush fund and making (false declarations to a grand jury, the Justice Department said today.

title: MISSILE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP)  The Defense Department and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration denied today that any missiles had been fired in an area where an Eastern Airlines pilot reported seeing two missiles pass his plane two days ago.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF; OTC PRICES RISE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued lower in light trading yesterday but those in the overthecounter market finished slightly higher.. Uncertainty over the effects of efforts being taken to solve New York City's financial problems hung over both markets.

title: SENATORS TO STUDY LAB WORKER'S DEATH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) A Senate subcommittee announced today that it would investigate the death of Karen Silkwood, who was killed in an auto wreck last year after questioning safety conditions at a plutonium plant in Okla

title: Surinam, to Be Independent Nov. 25. Adopts a Charter
description: PARAMARIBO. Surinam, Nov. 21 (AP)The Surinam Parliament has unanimously adopted a Constitution to take effect Tuesday when the country receives independence from the Netherlands.

title: Rockefeller in Madrid For Franco's Funeral
description: MADRID, Saturday, Nov. 22 (Reuters)Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller arrived here today to attend Generalissimo Francisco Franco's state funeral tomorrow and the installation of the king, Juan Carlos de Boroon.

title: ST. JOHN'S LAW MARKS 50 YEARS
description: Back in the early days of St. John's University's Law School in 1925, the founding dean, George W. Matheson, squeezed into a tiny elevator every night at 50 Court Street in Brooklyn to ride up to the school's makeshift classrooms with his law students.

title: ORDERS REBOUND IN DURABLE GOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Government reported today that business orders for durable, goods rebounded in October, providing evidence that industry was providing the economy with the spending lift that analysts say is necessary to sustain the recovery.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: CLEVELAND QUARTET FAVORS BEETHOVEN
description: ;Beethoven and the Cleveland Quartet go well together, so it was not surprising that at Tully Hall on Thursday night the ensemble was beginning its third Beethoven Quartet cycle here in three years.

title: Dr. Samuel Patterson Dies at 91 Writer and Professor at Hunter
description: Dr. Samuel White Patterson, writer of biographies and, since 1952, professor emeritus of education at Hunter College, died Thursday at the Valley Nursing Home in Westwood, N. J. He was 91 years old and lived in Paramus. N. J.

title: TATIANA KOYEN
description: Tatiana Koyen, a fashion consultant who was a chief buyer for Elizabeth Arden's fashion salons in the late 1960's, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, following cerebral hemorrhage. She was 50 years old and lived at 219 East 69th Street.

title: ORGAN DONATIONS BACKED IN SURVEY
description: A survey of public attitudes on human organ and tissue donations indicates that most persons favor donation of their kidneys, eyes, hearts and other organs for medical transplantation or scientific research after death, the National Kidney Foundation said here yesterday.

title: LaidOff Surgeon Faces a Different
description: Dr. Joseph T. Rowbottom 3d says that he may have to go back to collecting garbage.

title: Foe of Gas Deregulation Cites Study on Production
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, a prominent Democratic opponent of deregulation of natural gas prices, made public today a study that argues that producers have an economic incentive to withhold gas from the market in hopes that prices will rise.

title: U.S. Riders Win Jigsaw At Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 21Buddy Brown and Bob Ridland today gave the United States Equestrian Team its seventh victory in 11 international jumping classes at the Royal Winter Fair horse show by capturing the Jigsaw Stakes.

title: GARVICE D. KINCAID
description: FORT KNOX, Ky., Nov. 21 (AP)Garvice D. Kincaid, Lexington financier, died today at Fort Knox. He was 63 years fold.

title: 2 Arrested in Torture Murder Of Man, 80, in His Apartment
description: Two men were arrested last night in the murder a week ago yesterday of 80yearold John Wildmann in his apartment on the Upper West Side.

title: Indoor Ski Trail Gets A Workout at Coliseum
description: An indoor 400foot ski touring layout from Norway was the most popular exhibit yesterday in the second of four days at, the annual New York Coliseum ski Show.

title: Met Opera Presents a New Production of Figaro
description: The Metropolitan Opera has needed a new production of Le Nozze di Figaro. The great Mozart opera was not very well served by the Metropolitan the last time around. So a new production was unveiled Thursday night. For this the company went to Guenther Rennert, whose Nozze di Figaro is one of the adornments of the National Theater in Munich. Mr. Rennert directed, and sets and costumes were provided

title: Park Ave. Burglars Get Jewelry Valued at 1.8 Million by Owners,
description: Burglars forced their way; into the Park Avenue duplex apartment of Thomas L. Kempner, the investment banker,, yesterday afternoon and escaped with personal jewelry valued by the victims at $1.8 million, the police said.

title: Israelis Keep Guns at Hand After Golan Heights Raid
description: RAMAT MAGSHIMIM, IsraeliOccupied Golan Heights, Nov. 21The students at the Golan Yeshiva sat down to their candlelit Sabbath meal as usual here tonight, but beneath their chairs most of them had submachine guns.

title: Pollsters Assay Issuesfor Democrats
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov 21More than 1,500 Democrats, mostly liberal activists from the North and West, gathered here today for a Democratic issues convention that they hope will lay the basis for the party's platform next year.

title: Big Board in Black
description: Profits of the New York Stock Exchange totaled $628,000 in the third quarter of 1975 in contrast to a yearearlier loss of $41,000, James J. Needham, chairman, reported yesterday. Revenues rose to $20.2 million from $17.5 million.

title: Antiques: Spirit of 1876
description: WHITE PLAINS  Two years ago, nobody would look at this Liberty Bell glass, Marie Schaumann observed the other morning in her morning in her booth at the Eastern States Antiques Fair here.

title: The Dance
description: A standing ovation closed the second program of Lhamo, the visiting Tibetan folk opera and dance troupe, at the Hunter College Assembly Hall on Thursday night, and the applause was completely deserved.

title: EDWARD S. DAVIS
description: Edward S. Davis, a founder and former president of the commercial printing concern of DavisDelaneyArrow Inc., died Thursday at his home at 200 East 66th. He was 82 years old.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: I1975. by Triancb. Publicationt, Ina. (The Daily Raring Form)

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's New York Times about United States banks loans in South Korea incorrectly reported the amount of the outstanding loans held by the Fidelity Bank of Pennsylvania. Fidelity's loans to South Korean institutions total $43 million, or 2.2 percent of the bank's loans outstanding.

title: Josephine Paglieri, 94, Dies; A Founder of Restaurant
description: Josephine Oliengo Paglieri, who helped her husband, Paulo, her sister and brotherinlaw start the old Enrico & Paglieri Restaurant in Greenwich Village, died Thursday night at her apartment at 64 West 11th Street, where the restaurant had been operated for more than 60 years. She was 94 years old.

title: Artfully 65 Choice At AqueductToday
description: Lucien Laurin, the trainer who became nationally prominent two years ago when he saddled the great Secretariat to repeated victories, was seen at Belmont Park

title: Art: In Show of New Noland Paintings, Consistency Takes Unexpected Forms
description: People have been hoping for years that Kenneth Noland would quietly shut up shop and go away instead of upholding with a peculiar constancy a view of painting that is narrow and inconvenient, but does nonetheless yield results that are quite unlike anyone else's.

title: MONTANA RULING WON BY UTILITIES
description: HELENA, Mont., Nov. 21In a case with implications for the nation's energy development program, a consortium of electric utility companies overcame today a major hurdle that has delayed construction of two huge coal fired generating plants in the southeast Montana town of Colstrip.

title: Big Ten, Big Eight and Ivy To Decide Championships
description: Coach Woody Hayes has been known to get a bit excited before, during and after the Ohio State teams engage Michigan. But his fans claim good old Woody really a swell guy.

title: Authorized Taxes Resisted by Council For Last 4 Years
description: Since 1972, the City Council, has had authorization to pass a series of nuisance taxes that would raise an estimated total of $146 million a year, but for political reasons and the contention that the imposts were onerous, it has refused to pass the necessary legislation.

title: Medicaid Cuts and Effects on the Pook
description: An emergency drive to reduce New York State's $3billionayear Medicaid budget has spread confusion and concern about its effect on health services to the indigent. An ex ample is the report from the office of News Governor Carey Analysis last weekend that he would propose to the special session of the Legislature a switch from costplus to a flat rate of payment to nursing homes.

title: Witness Hazy on What Miss Fromme Said About Gun
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 21A Sacramento college student who had told the police that he had heard Lynette Alice Fromme yell It isn't loaded anyway after she allegedly Pointed a gun at President Ford testified today that he could no longer remember whether she had said that or not.

title: City Is Foreclosing On Village
description: The Beame administration, foreclosed the mortgage yesterday on a controversial $25 milHon project, West Village Houses, and said it planned to rent the 420apartment complex at a loss to the city of an estimated $12 million.

title: MONDAY DATE SET FOR NOTE SWAP
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation decided yesteiday to schedule the gigantic swap' of $1.6 billion in outstanding city notes for longterm M.A,C. bonds this coming Monday.

title: Stoneham Has Surgery
description: STANFORD, Calif., Nov. 21 (UPI)Horace C. Stoneham, president of the San Francisco Giants, successfully underwent surgery today at the Stanford Medical Center to correct an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Stoneham's condition, described as a swelling of the main artery leading from the heart to the abdomen, was discovered during a physical examination last week at Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

title: India Delegation to Moscow
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 21 (Reuter)An Indian delegation led by the Secretary to the Ministry for external affairs, Kenai Singh, will discuss international developments with Soviet Foreign Ministry officials in Moscow next week, it has been announced here. The delegation will leave for Moscow tomoram for the talks, which, are exmeted to last until next Friday.

title: U.S. Golfers Lead Japanese by One
description: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 21 (AP)Al Geiberger set a course record of 65 today and led the United States to a onestroke lead over Japan, 551552, in the first round of the fifth annual match between American and Japanese golfers, at the par72 Ibaraki Kokusai Golf Club course.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Friday, Nov. 21, 1975

title: State Prosecutors Weigh Impact Of Ruling on Zicarelli's Appeal
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21New Jersey law enforcement officials expressed doubt today that the reversal of a bribery conviction of a reputed Mafia leader would jeopardize many convictions obtained against other alleged mobsters.

title: Tight Arm Sends Kilmer to Showers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Billy Kilmer, the Washington Redskins quarterback, quit practice early today because his injured shoulder tightened up, but he still may start Sunday's game here against the Oakland Raiders.

title: That Should Be Two
description: A particularly ironic aspect of this exercise in bipartisan Congressional surrender to union political influence is that it has been hitched to a companion measure that admirably serves the interests of the public well as those of management and labor. This measure would create statutory machinery designed to bring much greater stability to construction wage settlements. The mass unemployment now prevalent in the building trades and the impossibility of building homes or apartments in many areas at prices that middleincome families can afford without massive public subsidy are symptoms of the need for such reform.

title: Student Killed in Istanbul As Left, Right Clash Anew
description: ISTANBUL Turkey, Nov, 21 Reuters)Leftist and Rightist ollege students fought each other with guns and clubs again today. The police said one student died.

title: DELAY IS FEARED ON CONRAIL START
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Final Congressional action to implement the massive reorganization of the bankrupt Northeast railroads appears put off until next year, arousing official concern that the scheduled March 1 opening of Conrail, the new Federally subsidized railroad corporation, may be jeopardized.

title: Final Countdown for a Coup d'Etat
description: BUENOS AIRESAt this moment it seems inevitable that the Argentine armed forces will stage a military coup d'etat, probably within a few weeks, in order to oust the feckless, incompetent Government of Mrs. Isabel Martinez de Peron, the late President's widow. The countdown has started.

title: $200 MILLON RISE IN TAXES FOR CITY STALLS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21The expected passage of a $200 million tax package for New York City became stalled shortly before midnight and the Legislature recessed until 10 A.M. tomorrow morning.

title: U.S, DROPS EFFORT IN U.N.ON AMNESTY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21The United States today withdrew its proposed resolution calling for amnesty for all political prisoners, protesting that amendments put forward by Communist and thirdworld countries would have made it 'a travesty.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Indonesia Fights to Save Oil Agency
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 21Pertamina, Indonesia's state oil company, is virtually bankrupt. Government and private industry officials now believe that only massive infusions of private capital and a complete restructuring of all contracts with foreign oil companies can save it.

title: FRANK J. DILLON
description: Frank J. Dillon, a partner in the law firm of Dillon & O'Brien here and a specialist in trust and estate law, died Thursday at his home, 14 Sutton Place South. He was 73 years old.

title: A Celebration of Public Education
description: Grotwing Up in America seems a distinctive history of American public education: if for no other reason than that the authors petspective is so buoyant and congratulatory. Precisely because the Hechingers are knowledgeable and intelligent writershe is a former education editor of The New York Times and is now a member of The Times editorial board; she is columnist for The Wall Street Journal and a historianthe perspective appears so unusual today.

title: U.S. DROPS EFFORT IN U.N. ON AMNESTY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21The United States today withdrew its proposed resolution calling for amnesty for all political prisoners, protesting that amendments put forward by Communist and thirdworld countries would have made it a travesty.

title: Dance: An Impish Touch
description: James Cunningham is a child of the theater who revels in its traditions but brings a contemporary impishness to their use. Conversation becomes transformed into mutual monologues of misunderstanding, and music festoons the ear more than accompanies the dance.

title: Jewel Theft Reported
description: Burglars entered an investment banker's Park Avenue apartment yesterday and escaped with personal jewelry that its owners said was worth $1.8 million, the police reported. Page 33.

title: Jones Key in 128 116 Game
description: UNIONDALE, L.1., Nov. 21 On the New York Nets, Rich Jones's nickname is House in deference to his size and tonight at the Nassau Coliseum he used his bulk and an occasional elbow to power his team to a 128.116 American Basketball Association victory over the Denver Nuggets.

title: Rockefeller Warns Republicans On Appeal to Narrow Minority
description: WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 21Vice President Rockefeller, in his first speech since Ronald Reagan announced he would try to win the Republican Presidential nomination from President Ford, warned Republican. governors here today that no, major American party can long endure by directing its appeal to a narrow minority.

title: Asia Not Free of Smallpox Yet 9 Cases Found in Bangladesh.
description: Smallpox workers in Bangladesh have discovered new cases of the viral disease, forcing the World Health Organization and the Bangladesh Government to retract a Nov. 13 announcement that smallpox Sad been wiped out in. Asia.

title: COAST SUITS OPPOSE OIL AND GAS LEASING
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The state of California and a coalition of 11 cities and three counties in southern California filed similar suits in the Federal District Court here today (asking that the Department of Interior be enjoined from proiceeding with a sale of oil and gas leases off the southern California coast scheduled for Dec. 11.

title: Sallie Goldstein Wed to Edwin Stern 3d
description: Sallie Goldstein, an equity trader at the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, was married here yesterday afternoon to Edwin H. Stern 3d, a partner of Lasker, Stone & Stern, stockbrokers. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the home of Mts. Stanley Goldfarb of New York, the bridegroom's niother.

title: TREATY WEIGHED AT COFFEE TALKS
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (UPI)International coffee negotiators finally got down to drafting a treaty today after sharp prodding from the United States.

title: City Council Balking on Proposed Taxes
description: A minor revolt against the proposed $200 million tax package developed late yesterday evening among City Coungil members, causing a recall from Albany of Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedman and ad ministration experts to answer questions described as vital.

title: People in Sports
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it was dropping Curt Gowdy from its major league baseball telecasts. Carl Lindemann made this brief announcement for the network:

title: Bomb Hurts 2 in Osaka
description: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 21 (Reuters)Two persons were hurt tonight by a bomb explosion that shattered the windows of a 13story office building of Mitsui, a leading trading company.

title: DALEY DEFEATED IN POLITICAL FIGHT
description: SPRINGFIELD, III., Nov. 21Chicago Mayor Richard J. Daley, in his most bitter political fight yet with Gov. Daniel Walker, failed today to persuade the Illinois Senate to restore $116.7 million in state aid to education vetoed by the Goverritir.

title: Race Unit to Check Auto Winners
description: PARIS, Nov. 21 (AP)Winning world championship Grand Prix race cars will undergo spot anticheating checks next season. Common in other classes of racing, the investigation of engine size, overall weight and body dimensions will be new to Formula One, the pinnacle Europeanstyle road racing.

title: ANNIE PRIMM
description: Annie Delphine Evans Primm, a music and elementaryschool teacher in the Mamaroneck (N. Y.) public school system, died Wednesday of cancer at the New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital Center. She was 45 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: EXLEGISLATOR HELD IN HIS WIFE'S DEATH
description: Bernard L. Avcollie, a 43yearold lawyer and former Connecticut state legislator, was indicted yesterday on charge of murdering his wife. Wanda, whose body was found in the family swimming pool in Naugatuck last Oct. 30, the local police said.

title: Coach in Westchester Accused of Larceny
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 Thomas A. Comenzo, the club football coach at Westchester Community College, was arraigned today in Greenburgh Town Court on charges of padding and forghig disability insurance claims to help his team.

title: CAREY TO REQUEST A SINGLE PRIMARY
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21Goveror Carey today agreed to put before the special legislative session a proposal calling for single political primary next year in late May or early June.

title: Rozelle Heard on Blackouts
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 (UPI)  Commissioner Pete Rozelle acknowledged today that National. Football League teams had not suffered serious financial losses becauset soldout home games were televised locally.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in yesterday's New York Times about United States banks loans in South Korea incorrectly reported the amount of the outstanding loans held by the Fidelity Bank of Pennsylvania. Fidelity's loans to South Korean institutions total $43 million, or 2.2 percent of the bank's loans outstanding.

title: CANADA DISTRIBUTES U.S. PENSION MONEY
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 21With the help of the Canadian Government, the United States Embassy has set up an emergency cietwork to distribute Social Security checks and certain other pension items to some 40,000 Americans who have not received their payments because of the postal strike.

title: CHARLES DIEFENDORF OF MARINE MIDLAND
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 21 (AP)Charles H. Diefendorf, former president and board chairman of the Marine Midland CorIporation, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Unions Pledge General Strike To Back New Haven Teachers
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21A group of labor leaders in the New Haven area resolved unanimously tonight to stage a oneday general strike beginning at noon on Tuesday if 90 striking school teachers and union leaders were not released from jail by then.

title: Buffalo Comptroller Dies
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 21 (AP)City Comptroller George D. O'Connell, chosen by Governor Carey to join the State Tax Commission, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while playing golf.

title: JACOB BERESIN
description: Jacob Beresin, retired president of the ABC Consolidated Corporation, a vendingmachine concern that is now division of the Ogden Corporation, died Nov. 12 at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 84 years old and lived at the BellevueStratford Hotel.

title: INQUIRY CENTERS ON GRAIN STORAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Federal agents are investigating possible frauds against the United States in its grainstorage program as part of their broad inquiry into corruption in the grain industry, according to Government sources.

title: Once Ranking Vietnamese Make Way in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Some highranking South Vietnamese were more than ready for the collapse last April.

title: Knicks
description: AT GARDEN. 8 P.M.

title: SOVIETITALIAN PACT SETS COOPERATION
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (Reuters) Italy and the Soviet Union have pledged to increase political cooperation and concert their efforts for internationa dtente.

title: Moynihan, About to Quit, Agrees to Wait
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21Daniel P. Moynihan, frustrated by what close associates described as insufficient support from the State Department, planned to announce his resignation today as chief American delegate to the United Nations, but was dissuaded at the last moment by the White House.

title: Superman's Creators, Nearly Destitute, In His Spirit
description: Two 61yearold men, nearly destitute and worried about how they will support themselves in their old age,, are invoking the spirit of Superman for help. Joseph Shuster, who sits amidst his threadbare furniture in Queens, and Jerry Siegel, who waits in his cramped apartment in Los Angeles, share the hope that they each will get pensions from the Man of Steel.

title: Unions Pledge General Strike To Back New Haven Teachers
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21A group of labor leaders in the New Haven area resolved unanimously tonight to stage a oneday general strike beginning at noon on Tuesday if 90 striking school teachers and union leaders were not released from jail by then.

title: Etna Erupts at New Spot
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Nov. 21 (UPI)Mt. Etna erupted today with flaming lava flowing from a new opening on the north side of Europe's tallest and most active volcano. Officials said the stream of molten lava, about 55 yards wide, had advanced a mile and a quarter by midday, but did not threaten any houses or farmland.

title: CITY'S SUPPLIERS SLOW DELIVERIES
description: Robert. I. Cohen, the city's Commissioner of Purchase. said yesterday that close to half of the approximately 4,000 suppliers who sold a wide variety of goods to the city had slowed down their deliveries because of the possibility of default.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Montclair State College was ordered to pay nearly $18,000 to a woman who charged she was denied a teaching job because of her sex. The State Civil Rights Division ordered the college to pay Jane L. Price, 28 years old, New York, $17,423 in wages she would have earned she had been employed and $500 for mental pain, suffering and humiliation.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 21North and South Vietnam announced plans today for joint elections in the first half of next year to choose a National Assembly for a reunified country.

title: Two Suggested Dates
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Ambassador to China has said that general elections for a National Assembly for Vietnam are likely to be held either on April 30 or on North Vietnam's independence day, Jan. 6, according to a Japanese report from Peking.

title: Nutritional Problems of Women Discussed by Medical Experts
description: The great number of special nutritional demands made on a woman's body through adolescence, pregnancy and old age, was the subject of a symposium this week addressed by nutritional and medical experts from across the country and Britain.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)Three billion jar lids for home canners will be produced for the next canning season, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Greystone Is Accredited As Decision Is Reversed
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21Reversing an earlier decision, the Joint Commission on the Accreditation of Hospitals today granted a oneyear extentlon of its accreditation to Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, thus preventing the loss of nearly $10 million in Federal Medicaid and Medicare funds tied to accreditation.

title: ANGOLA UNIT SAYS IT HOLDS RUSSIANS
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Nov. 21 (Reuters) An Angolan nationalist movement today reported the capture of 20 Soviet soldiers in the battle for the key Angolan town of Malange earlier this week.

title: Bar on Concorde Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (Reuters),Senator Edward M: Kennedy said today that he would introduce a resolution in the Senate saying that the AngloFrench Concords airliner should not be allowed to land at Boston's Logan Airport. Citing a report that Air France might seek permission to land at Logan if it is barred from New York's Kennedy Airport, Senator Kennedy said more than 100,000 people already lived in an unacceptable noise environment near Logan.

title: $200 MILLION RISE IN TAXES FOR CITY STALLS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21The expected passage of a $200 milHon tax package for New York City became stalled shortly before midnight and the Legislature recessed until 10 A.M. tomorrow morning.

description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday it expected to trade in options of 20 additional New York Stock Exchange stocks by December, raising the number of options in which it trades to 60. The new issues have not yet been selected, the Amex said.

title: DEFENSE AIDE SEEKS DATA ON GRATUITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements is [asking top corporate officials whether their companies hive given gratuities to Pentagon employees, a defense department spokesman said today.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Dodger Begins FreeAgent Bid
description: Andy Messersmith, a pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, began his pitch for freeagent status yesterday in an arbitration case that has much wider application than the one that made Catfish Hunter a free agent last year.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Reports that Rumania had ordered or was about to order 20,000 tons of soybean meal, I that East Germany wanted 60,000 tons and Czechoslovakia needed 20,000 sent soybean meal prices sharply higher yesterday. Soybean meal is widely used as an animal feed.

title: Two Suffolk Outsiders
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 20 The two men have so much in commonincluding a death grip on each other's career. They both identity as outsiders, a custodian's son and an orphan, who pushed themselves into law careers. They were sworn in together as assistant district attorneys, and they traveled to seminars together. And now they could destroy each other.

title: Reagan Expected to Slacken Pace Now
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21Ronald Reagan returned home today after a twoday, 5,000mile blitz in five primary states that are crucial to his strategy to challenge President Ford for the Republican nomination for President next year.

title: Municipalities Balk at Plan for LowIncome Housing
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 (AP)The New Jersey State League of Municipalities balked, today at endorsing a resolution urging municipalities to provide for construction of lowincome housing.

title: Short Interest on Big Board Down by 962,674 Shares
description: The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange dropped 962,674 shares during the month ended Nov. 14 to 23,522,885 shares, it has been announced by the exchange.

title: Marxist Faction Claims Golan Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21A Marxist Palestinian guerrilla group today claimed responsibility for a raid that apparently originated in Syrian territory last night and, according to Israeli accounts, took the lives of three 19yearold soldiers in a settlement on the occupied; Golan Heights. rillas in Lebanon have reportedly been poised for an Israeli retaliatory operation.

title: BLACKMUN BACKS A CURB ON PRESS IN NEBRASKA CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21Supreme Court Justice Harry A. Blackmun, acting on a gag order imposed on the press by a judge in a Nebraska murder case, ruled today that courts may forbid the press to report on confessions, certain other statements and perhaps a defendant's criminal record if the courts consider such orders necessary for a fair trial.

title: 3 Minus 2 Equals One Playoff Spot
description: Three into two won't go. Once a movie title, that phrase now applies to the developments in the PotBoiler Division, sometimes known as the Patrick, with the islanders (without a victory in their last five games), the Rangers (still losing the easy ones) and the Atlanta Flames (good field, no hit) battling the next 4 months for the last two playoff positions.

title: SON, 24, IS GUILTY IN MURDER OF SIX
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 21Ronald DeFeo Jr. has been found guilty of seconddegree murder in the shooting deaths of his mother, father, two brothers and two sisters.

description: MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP)A flight attendants union on strike two and a half months has voted to reject a proposed contract that officials of National Airlines had hoped would allow the carrier to resume service next Monday, union officials said today.

Tonight at the Boston Garden, Cowens and Havlicek played supporting roles to Glenn McDonald as the Knicks lost their eighth straight road game, 110101.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21The New Jersey Senate Democratic Caucus asked the United 1States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit today to dissolve an injunction that bars 28 State Senators from excluding a colleague, Alene S. Ammond, from caucus meetings.

description: BOSTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)Ross Grimsley, a pitcher for the Baltimore Orioles must return to court for still another hearing into charges he purposely heaved a ball into the bleachers at Fenway Park striking a spectator.

description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 21 (AP)Ticky Burden and Willie Wise combined for 62 points tonight as the Virginia Squires pulled away in the third quarter and posted a 10698 American Basketball Association victory over the Utah Stars.

title: 148 HurtasFinnish Trains Hit
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 21 (UPI)An express train and a freight train collided today in Sievi Station, Western Finland, injuring 48 persons. Fourteen persons were hospitalized for observation.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The White House confronted Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign rivalry today by professing to ignore it.

title: Big Realty Trust, Advised by Chase, Achieves a Profit
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate investment trust with $844.7 million in assets, reported yesterday a profit of $769,000 for its fiscal first quarter, ended Aug. 31. In the yearearlier period the trust had a $142,000 loss.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POET ENTERS GUILTY PLEA
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 21 (Reuters)  Breyten Breytenbach, a 36yearold Afrikaans poet who opposes apartheid, stunned a packed courtroom today by pleading guilty to charges under South Africa's Terrorism Act.

title: Notes on People
description: The acting director of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, Henry S. Dogin, will join the state Division of Criminal Justice Services as deputy commissioner in charge of planning, Governor Carey's office confinned yesterday. A spokesman said his salary was not known.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Government Printing Office, which is printing for the public 20,000 copies of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that they would sell for $3.25 each.

title: Ballet: Simple and Dense
description: There was a certain air of celebration at the New York State Theater on Thursday night. This was probably because the New York City Ballet Guild was sponsoring a welcomehome party for its company, but it was just pos sibly because George Balanchine's amazing Le Tombeau de Couperin was having its first New York performance apart from its special debut at last summer's Ravel Festival. When seen in the ordinary circumstances of the repertory rather than the heightened atmosphere of a festival, the sheer simplicity and genius of the ballet become all the more evident. Mr. Balanchine is continually and, almost continuously, surprising.

description: TRENTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)State Education Commissioner Fred G. Burke, accused of advocating teachers strikes, insisted today that he favored limited strikes under the right condiitons, but not necessarily in New Jersey at this time with its problems.

title: Gunnar Gunnarsson, 86, Dies; A Leading Novelist of Iceland
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 21 (UPI)Gunnar Gunnarsson, one of Iceland's bestknown authors, died here today at the age of 86. Mr. Gunnarsson won European acclaim through a number of novels he wrote in Danish and lived in Denmark for many years before moving back to his native Iceland in 1939. Among his best known works are The Church on the Hill, Blackbird and The Family Borg.

description: FORT DIX, Nov. 21 (UPI)K. Vietnam veteran charged with selling leaves to Army recruits was ordered today to stand trial on the charges Dec. 16.

title: Tomato Growers Sue 26 Canners, Alleging Monopoly
description: FRESNO, Calif., Nov. 21 (UPI) A classaction suit has been filed in United States district court here against 26 tomato canners and processor alleging they had conspired to keep tomato growers from joining a growers association and had established a monopoly in the industry.

title: CLEAVER FEARFUL OF JAIL TRANSFER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21Eldridge Cleaver, the onetime Black Panther leader who has since been expelled from the party, has asked to remain in Federal custody because he fears for his safety in a Califorada state prison.

title: Rosenberg Son Charges a File CoverUp
description: Michael Meeropol, a son of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, who were executed as atomic spies in 1953, charged here yesterday that Federal agencies were laundering the Rosenberg files in a continuing coverup of the fraud and frameup in our parents cases.

title: Reason Triumphs
description: In tabling a resolution that calls for a Constitutional amendment to prohibit busing for purposes of school desegregation, the Democratic caucus of the House Representatives has in effect killed the measure. The decisive vote of 172 to 96 provides incontestable proof that such an amendment would, fortunately, have no chance of gaining the approval of the twothirds of the members of Congress needed for submission to the states or ratification.

title: October Purchases High
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) Mutual fund investors cashed in their shares faster than they purchased new ones in October for the sixth month in a row despite a level of purchases that was the second highest in history.

title: Interior Aide Urges Curbs on Use of PCB Chemical
description: CHICAGO Nov. 21Assistant Secretary of the Interior Nathaniel P. Reed said today that the Federal Government must impose a ban on the use of potentially harmful group of chetnicals except in certain electrical equipment.

title: Injury to Mets
description: Mike Vail, last season's rookie sensation of the New York Mets, learned yesterday that the knee that has been bothering him for two months is nothing more than mild sprain. Vail, an outfielder who tied a National League rookie record by hitting in 23 straight games, hurt his left knee at Philadelphia during the last weekend of the season. He had since been playing winter ball with Lara Venezuela, and when the knee continued to bother him, he flew to New York and was examined by the Mets physician, Dr. James Parkes.

title: Zionism and Peace
description: WASHINGTONThe painful point about the United Nations resolution equating Zionism and racism is that it had an element of truth. This is implicitly acknowledged by the counterattacks. These rely on two implicitly inconsistent propositions: that it's lie, and that anyway most of the resolution's sponsors are hypocrites and themselves practice one form of discrimination or another, whether racist, nationalist, religious, class or tribal. Only the second, the fallback position, is wholly true.

title: Cowpokes Still Ride The Trail in Arizona

The riders are inside, crowded up to the bar, a jukebox blasting out cowboy songs about lonesome women and fasttalking men.

title: Parent and Child: The new old way of delivering babies
description: joke that theirs is the second oldest profession, and most of the world's babies are still delivered by midwives. In the United States, however, in the early part of this century, the medical establishment forced midwives  who were then largely oldfashioned, untrained granniesout of the childbirth business. Maternal and infant mortality was appallingly high in those days. As recently as World War I (according to the National Center for Health Statistics), more than 700 out of every 100,000 women died in childbirth, and 96 out of every 1,000 babies died before the age of 1. As the developing specialty of obstetrics attacked this problem, women were persuaded to have their babies in hospitals, and to be delivered by physicians. Today it is rare for a woman to die in childbirth, and infant mortality down to 16.5 per 1,000 live births. And today there are only a handful of granny midwives left, still legally delivering babies, mostly in rural areas the South and Southwest.

title: A huge, angelic, failed effort
description: F or 20 years or more Charles Olson has been a cult figure in American literature, the prophet of the Black Mountain poets, even to their second, third, and successive indistinguishable generationg. It is a fact. To my mind it is also a misfortune, both for the mani.e., for his posthumous reputationand for literature itself. We know what happens to cult figures: when the bubble bursts it bursts completely and they go down into academic oblivion. I hope this won't happen with Olson, but I fear it may.

title: A Patch of Sand, A Jug of Cacti And the Sun

title: New &
description: When Field Marshal Sir John Durham decides, at 80, to write his memoirs, he insists on veracity, the truth, all of it, all the time. This compulsion for veracity gets Sir John right into the Tower of London, as a violator of the Official Secrets Act. The very rumor of Durham's revelations agitates Whitehall, the White House and the Mafia, one of whose members was killed by the Field Marshal's wartime strategy. In the private sector there are those who try to blackmail the old soldier, and a couple who attempt to murder him.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Bicentennial. Although publishers are escalating their production of Bicentennial titles, so far only the Bicentennial Series of historical novels by John Jakes have made any best seller list. Now the. Trade Paperbacks list has its first entry, Bicentennial Almanac, edited by Calvin D. Linton. Dr. Linton, a professor of history at George Washington University, provides an overview of each year from 1776 to the present, followed by capsule entries describing important or minor events throughout the year on appropriate dates. The book is also available in hardcover at $14.95, is copiously illustrated and is thick (512 pages). Orders are currently running at the rate of 30,000 copies a month for both editions, with heavy sales in elementary and high schools, at book fairs sponsored by local jobbers. The publisher, Thomas Nelson, a venerable religiousbook firm based in Nashville, Tenn., also publishes about 50 secular titles a year, according to sales manager James Keaton.

title: HOSPITALS PAYING CHAPLAINS $14,500

title: RITAN FOR PRESIDENT
description: Everett has a hell of a lot to do with Henry Jackson, says S. Sterling Munro Jr., the Senator's administrative assistant. That's his roots, and he's a roots man.' Everett. Wash., a grimy little mill town of 50,000 on Puget Sound north of Seattle, is the unprepossessing end product of a failed dream. James J. Hill and John D. Rockefeller were going to make it the timber capital of the Northwest, but their ambitions perished one day in 1916 when the local constabulary opened fire on a boatload of radical unionists, killing dozens of them. title: Experts Doubt View That Atorn Blast Could End All Life
description: A suggestion in the current Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists that a nuclear explosion in the atmosphere or deep in the sea or in the earth might set off a cataclysmic chain reaction has been termed total and utter absolute nonsense by a leading authority on such reactions. feared, might lead to the fusion of more nitrogen nuclei. Since air consists chiefly of nitrogen, much of the atmosphere, physicists feared, might be converted to silicon, which, when combined with the oxygen of the air, would form silica, primary constituent of sand.

title: Food News

I., Nov. 22  With Ron Atanasio and Tom Lang handling most of the offensive chores, the Adelphi University soccer team today blanked Le Moyne College of Syracuse, 6.0, in the Eastern final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division 2 playoffs. Atanasio, an allAmerican, scored two goals and assisted on another, while Lang had one goal and two assists.

title: Fight on Blackbirds Shifted
description: HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22 (UPI)The state plans to reduce the blackbird population in western. Kentucky with the use of poison pellets, replacing the controversial chemical Tergitol.

description: TEANECK  Athletes at Fainleigh Dickinson University are a versatile lot. In the last few years, the school's hockey team include'd a Roman Catholic priest who was studying at the university, its baseball team has been coached by a personneltraining specialist and its football team by an artist in oils and ceramics.

title: Charities Are Facing Increased Demands for Food, Clothing
description: TRENTONCharitable organizations in New Jersey are facing unprecedented demands for food and clothing as the holiday season approaches, and most of them say they cannot fill the bill.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE CONSUMER PRICE INDEX rose seventenths of 1 percent in October to 164.6 percent of the 1967 base period, the third largest monthly increase this year. Food prices rose by 1.3 percent in the month . . . First National City Bank cut its prime rate A point to 7 percent, reflecting continued weak loan demand and gains in the money supply. Other banks, many of which are still charging 71/2 percent, pre expected to cut their rates. . .. Corporate profits after turas totaling $82.2 billion in the third quarter were 16.9 percent higher than the secondquarter level. The thirdquarter advance was the largest quarterly Increase 23 years.

title: A citizen, diplomat at the center of great events
description: Averell Harriman began his career as a special envoy in 1912 when, as representative of the Yale University rowing team (then a poor competitor against Harvard), he traveled to England to learn the secrets of Oxford's strength on the river. This first venture into international diplomacy lasted only six weeks, and afterwards, Harriman turned his attention in other directions. While still a college senior,

title: One Dead as U.S. Ships Collide in Mediterranean
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22The aircraft carrier John F Kennedy and the guidedmissile cruiser Belknap collided today during flight operations in the Mediterranean Sea. One man was known to have been killed and other casualties were considered likely.

title: ARIEL DANCERS BEST IN SHORTEST PIECE
description: The most moving part of The Ariel Dance Company's concert Friday evening was the shortest. This is only to say that Moshe Ariel's Yemenite Dance solo had more feeling and grace in its few minutes than the rest of the program collectively. Where the other works were kinetically verbose, it was taut and to the point. The program was given at the theater of Riverside Church.

title: Harvard Tops Yale, 107, and Takes Ivy Title; Ohio State Beats Michigan for Big 10 Crown
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22A successful field goal in the last minute of the Yale game gave Harvard the Ivy League championship today as the Crimson beat the Elis, 107. Mike Lynch booted the football through the goal posts from 26 yards away with 33 seconds left as the long shadows fell in Yale Bowl before a crowd of 66,846 that had waited all afternoon for something exciting to happen.

title: AUTOPSY FINDS BOY WAS SLAYING VICTIM
description: The Hudson County Medical Examiner, David Drelich, said yesterday that a 5yearold boy missing from his Jersey City home for more than a week had been murdered, not more than 48 hours after his body was found in a marshy area in Kearny, N.J.

title: People/Business
description: New Jersey's industrial scene can anticipate an influx of foreignowned companies in the next decade, if the findings of a Florham Park concern that specializes in locating new sites for businesses are borne out.

title: City Council Agonizes All Night Before Endorsing Tax Packag
description: After an all night 19hour session, the City Council early yesterday passed a resolution supporting a $205 million tax package that state and city officials said must be levied before the Ford Administration would consider aid to the city.

description: MILDENHALL, EnglandThe radio's clamor died. The control aircraft was unnaturally quiet. Col. Jerry P. Tietgehis code name for the operation was Head Dancer Alpharelaxed and said: They're all down now.

title: Safety Unit Weighs Action on Lighting Of Christmas Trees
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said yesterday that it was studying whether it could revive a Christmas tree light inspection program that has been halted by opposition from the decorative light industry.

title: New Finding on Vacancy Rate Stirs Up Rent Dispute
description: A finding that the citywide rental vacancy rate for apartments is only 2.8 percent in New York has added new element to the longstanding controversy over the city's rentregulation programs.

description: Under a compromise plan offered by the trustees of the Queens Borough Public Library district and acceped by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, no libraries will be closed in Queens as a result of budget cuts.

title: STAMPS
description: SAMUEL A. TOWER

title: Lawyers Undertake Critical SelfAnalysis
description: What makes a good lawyer? For years that question was rarely asked. Now it has been posed, but a satisfactory answer is not obvious.

title: He invented the Bloody Mary and almost propositioned the Queen Mother
description: This is George Jessel's autobiography, and it is a fascinating story of the remarkable life of a poor Jewish kid from Harlem who became one of America's classiest entertainers: a comedian who could get Winston Churchill to laugh at himself at a lunch for Somerset Maugham and move Queen Mother Elizabeth to tears at a Command Performance  and then whisper to her at the party afterwards that if she didn't have a title, he'd make a pass at her.

title: Mississippi Field Goals Top Mississippi St., 137
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 22 (AP)  Steve Lavinghouze booted two field goals today to give MissiSsippi a 137 football victory over Mississippi. State in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: BELGIANS DISPUTE VILLAGE MERGERS
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 22A plan to reduce drastically the number of local governments in Belgium by fusing them into bigger units has caused a major political fight in this country where the citizens strong allegiance to the community has changed little since the Middle Ages.

title: Ants, Indians, And Little Dinosaurs
description: Lately, Shag had been spending his nights in the shrubbery, although earlier in the summer he had found shelter in a house hallway.. He would push the front door open to gain access and wait for someone leaving to help him get back to the streets, but his habit of marking the inside hall had led to his ouster by the building's residents. . . .

title: Pilgrim State Hospital Seeking to Regain Status
description: BRENTWOOD  Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center, which last month became the first psychiatric hospital in the nation to have its Federal funds cut off for losing accreditation, will begin tomorrow a massive reorganization of staff and services,

description: Ken McGovern's extrapoint kick in the second quarter following Brian McShane's 21yard touchdown run helped Bergen Catholic notch a 76 victory over Seton Hall yesterday in Fair Lawn and move into the North Jersey, Parochial A playoff final.

title: All the Strange Hours
description: A scientist with a soul, Loren Eiseley for more than 20 years has been attracting readsrs who yearn to bridge that gulf between the two cultures of science and the rest of life. Without at first being fully conscious of creating his own literary form, he has found his way into what he now calls the concealed essay. In it, personal experiences are allowed gently to bring under observation thoughts of a more ourelv scientific

title: Schlesinger Says Budget for 77 Was Important Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) James R. Schlesinger says he considers President Ford's planned defense budget inadequate and has indicated that Mr. Ford dismissed him as Secretary of Defense, after he objected to the budget.

title: Default Fear A Damper On Market For Houses
description: Instead of buying their first house, Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Marino decided to fix up their small apartment in Rosedale. Oueens.

title: Colorado Turns Back Kansas State by 337
description: BOULDER, Colo., Nov. 22 (AP)Billy Waddy raced 100 yards with the opening kickoff today and Terry Kunz added two more touchdowns, powering Colorado to a 337 rout of Kansas State in tha regularseason finale for both Big Eight football teams.

title: Notes: At JFK Airport, A Very Stubborn Flock
description: Fl FFORTS to prevent a repetition of the recent destruction of 41 DC10 jumbo jet, which burst into flames after a flock of seagulls were sucked into its rightwing engine during takeoff at Kennedy Airport, are likely to center ongarbage. The thousands of tons of solid waste that are dumped daily on landfills in the New York area, including Far Rockaway, Staten Island and the Bronx, provide an irresistible source of food for gulls. According to Richard Plunkett, an official of the National Audubon Society, that food has helped cause a gull population explosion in the vicinity of New York. The gulls now number about 1.5 million in winter, he says; in summer most of them disperse to breeding grounds up and down the East Coast.

title: School Programs Will Teach How to Use and Store Energy
description: NEWARKThe state took its first steps last week to familiarize its schoolage population with New Jersey's energy problems and to enroll it in helping to conserve the use of energy or all kinds.

title: South Africa to Build Big Atom Plant
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 22 (Reuters)South Africa is to build a uranium  enrichment plant that could ultimately make much of the Western world this country's customers.

title: ILLINOIS COUPLE LEAD AT BRIDGE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22New York experts were strongly in contention going into the final session of the national mixed pairs at the American. Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here tonight.

title: Maryland Crushes Virginia by 6224
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 22, (AP)Steve Atkins, a freshman, scored two touchdowns to cap a 27point thirdquarter outburst as Maryland crushed Virginia, 6224 today.

title: Winter Can Wait
description: Whether a spell of mild November weather is Indian Summer or not seems to depend on who is talking. Nobody ever codified the rules governing Indian Summer, but there seems to be general agreement that it consists of a series of warm autumn days with clear skies, calm air distant haze and cool nights.

title: Cavaliers Shade Knicks by 9594
description: A free throw by Jim Chones, the sleepyeyed, 6foot11inch center, with one second remaining provided the Cleveland Cavaliers with a 95.94 victory over the Knicks last night at Madison Sauare Garden.

title: Notre Dame Vanquishes Fumbling Miami by 329
description: MIAMI, Nov. 22 (AP) Ross Browner, a defensive end, set up a touchdown with a fumble recovery at Miami's 3yard line and, gave Notre Dame a safety three minutes later tonight as the Irish scored 16 points in the second periodto beat the Hurricanes. 329.

title: Plan for Fire Island Is Fought by Environmental Groups
description: Friends of the Earth, national environmental orgar nization with more than 3,500 members in New York State, has criticized the National Park Service proposals to develop an eightmile stretch of unspoiled barrier beach in the Fire Island National Seashore as environmentally unsound ... and illegal as well.

title: What's Doing in FRANKFURT
description: HUB CITY  Frankfurt is West Germany's commercial hub, a city of banks and trade fairs, and site of the country's principal stock exchange. At the latest count there were no fewer than 270 banks in Frankfurt, not counting branches, 90 of them foreign. The Rothschilds began here, opening their first bank in 1798 and subsequently branching out to London, Paris, Vienna and Naples. American families occasionally stop in Frankfurt while visiting G.I.'s stationed in Germany, but few tourists seem to include the city in their itineraries. A pity, for Frankfurt could be a jumpingoff place for tours of the more picturesque parts of north and central Germanythe Rhine Valley with its vineyardcovered slopes, historic Mainz (where boats are available for Rhine River cruises) and old Heidelberg. Besides, Frankfurt has its own charms. The Main River with its barges, quayside mansions and gothic churches is a welcome contrast to the grim industrial zones on the periphery of the city. After wartime bombing, which razed most of medieval Frankfurt in 1944, an extraordinary effort has been carried out to restore, even to rebuild from rubble, historic

title: 911 Calls A Success In Nassau
description: MINEOLA  More than threequarters of a million emergency calls have been answered by the Nassau County Police Department through its 911 emergency dialing system since it went into operation 27 months ago, it was noted last week.

title: Design: Some garret
description: One member calls it a utopian conceptionthis club enjoyed for over threequarters of a century by artists, art lovers and, so some say, at least one pair of lovers. Founded in 1898, the National Arts Club on. Gramercy Park at. 20th Street was intended not merely as a place for members to meet but also as a place for them to live and work. The highceilinged rooms with diffused north light were a particularly perfect setup for painters, even though the club embraced members in all the arts. Conceived as an opportunity to provide the cross fertilization and stimulation conspicuously absent in the lonely garret, the club provided a chance for artists and patrons to mingle. The principle, after 77 years, still works.

title: Confessing to it Papa by painting Paul and Peter
description: Professor Leo Steinberg is before all things a rescuer. To the discipline of art history he brings a chivalric intent and, with that, a depth and a density of emotional commitment which are quite exceptional. When we read him we feel ourselves in the company not of one of art history's accountants, but of an ardent and vulnerable nature which is stretching itself to the utmost.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was reported incorrectly last week that the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company had arranged the private placement of 51.75 billion of Trans Alaska Pipeline System bonds. The financing was arranged by Morgan Stanley and Company.

title: Charlie. Buster. Harold and all the other mute and funny men
description: MY admiration for what Walter Kerr has achieved is so unqualified that I'm afraid I can say here only a very few of the things I feel need to be said in celebration of The Silent Clowns. a book about the great and neargreat comic artists

title: Woman of About 50 Found Murdered in Inwood Park
description: The body of a woman about 50 years old with some of her clothes removed and her throat slashed was found yesterday in Inwood Park, at the northern end of Manhattan.

title: NOISE
description: Mary Robinson often spends her lunch hour strolling down Second Avenue in New York, busy thoroughfare characterized by thundering trucks, automobile horns, pneumatic drills, an occasional screaming siren and other sonic byproducts of the urban scene. Recently, after returning to the East Side office where she works, she began to notice a ringing in her ears that lasted 10 or 15 minutes. Her heart beat faster than usual; her stomach tightened; her mouth felt dry, and colleagues in the office had to shout at her to Make themselves heard.

title: Athlete and Death: Easier to Live, Easier to Die
description: When death comes, we should have had time to fulfill the demands of Pythagorus: build a house, plant a tree, sire a son and write a book. That is the conventional wisdom about subject where there is no conventional wisdom. Strike the Pythagorean bargain. The best revenge is to live long and well.

description: In Summary

description: ART

title: Westwood ChildCare Center Is Facing a Squeeze
description: WESTWOOD  Last September, when the Dr. David Goldberg ChildCare Center completed extensive renovation of its building here, Kay Gellert, executive director of the nineyearold nonprofit facility, thought that all of its troubles were over.

title: Brooke Melanie Breckenridge Engaged to R. Edwards Taylor
description: Brooke Melanie Breckenridge, a staff assistant in Washington to Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, and Richard Edwards Taylor, a senior leasing representative with the Rouse Company, Columbia, Md., owner/developer of regional enclosed malls, will be married May 22 in Bristol, Conn.

title: 9 Die in Mexican Gunfight
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 (AP) Two rival leftist groups shot it out at a rally in southern Mexico Friday night, leaving nine persons dead and four wounded, the police reported today. They identified the victims as members of the 23d of September Communist League and the StudentWorkerPeasant Coali tion.

title: Arabian Days
description: Dame Freya Stark is the great chronicler of Arabia and Asia Minor, those troubled, bounteous, dry, flowering lands of impeccable sky and ruined landscapes where time, the world and man's wrecked artifacts lie in the sun like a stricken language, stammering, in spite of the ages, messages of wonder and delight to the traveler. She is the listener who calls forth the land, establishes in the center of it her tremendous spirit, and before long the reader, deep in the excursions of her prose, finds that he is pilgrim as well as she and enters into her world and is blessed.

title: Albany Stalls on Rolling Back City Pension Device
description: ALBANY, Nov. 22 The New York City fiscal package now stalled in the Legislature includes a provision to cut the salaries of city workers more than $300 a year on average by rolling back a fiscal device of the past to face the austerity of the present.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: DONALD HENAHANT

title: Bigger and Faster Fishing Boats With Wider Range Are Dominating. the Scene
description: High  performance hulls with specially designed interiors are beginning to dominate the fishing scene in both salt water and fresh water as more boat builders are recognizing and responding to the demand for additional speed coupled with safety, comfort and fishability.

title: The World
description: The forces in Spain that supported the policies of Generalissimo Francisco Franco until his death last week are expected to try to continue to patch up the old regime. But pressure for fundamental political change seems certain to be exerted on King Juan Carlos, who has become Spain's first monarch in 44 years.

title: Personnel Agencies Entangle Officials in a Bureaucratic Maze
description: At the Manhattan District Attorney's office, there is no law librarian. The office has battled for more than a year to get a librarian, and has all but lost its case in the bureaucratic labyrinth.

title: IN MOSCOW,
description: In early August 1972, Moscow was enveloped for days in a mysterious blue haze. It hung motionless over the city. The big domestic airport at Domodedovo, south of Moscow, had to divert flights because of poor visibility. From our eighthfloor apartment some mornings, we could see no more than 300 yards. Muscovites were coughing terribly, wiping tears from their eyes. Streetcars and automobiles were forced to use headlights. People were alarmed by rumors that fires the fields around Moscow were menacing populated areas. Yet for nearly a week, the press said nothing. Finally, one skimpy backpage article mentioned a peatbog fire near Shatura, about 60 miles east of Moscow. Two days later another newspaper added the obvious fact that smoke had reached Moscow but did not say whether the city was in danger. The smoke seemed too dense and stable to have been blown 60 miles.

title: Frampton, Mason, British Guitarists, Perform at Garden
description: Friday evening was British guitarists night at Madison Square Garden, with Peter Frampton and Dave Mason sharing the billing. Mr. Mason was apparently the headliner by virtue of appearing last and having a backdrop, a desert island scene replete with palm trees, pointing out in a less than subtle manner that his current recording is Split Coconut.

title: How Hollywood's Memory Plays Tricks on Us
description: The nostalgia craze is still with us. With the promise of forthcoming films dealing with the lives of stars (Clark Gable, Carole Lombard, W. C. Fields, John Barrymore, Clara Bow, Rudolph Valentino, Tom Mix, Sarah Bernhardt), to say nothing of Broadway revivals, a nostalgia book club, magazines and TV tributes to Hollywood's legendary past, it appears that we have a fullfledged nostalgia industry in our midst with no layoffS in sight. What can account for

title: Suffern Spoils Title Bid Of StrikePlagued Nyack
description: A Nyack team that played most of the season with a pickup staff of coaches because of a teachers strike missed in its bid for the county championship yesterday by losing to Suffern, 197.

title: The Players True Home Is Where The Game Is
description: Sunday afternoon had faded into Sunday night and almost everywhere in the city it was time to go home. But in the smoky gaming room on West 72d Street, no one seemed to notice.

title: Reagan Campaign Debut: A 2Day TV Event
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Making calculations that are basic to the craft of modem campaign managers, Ronald Reagan's advisers kept a close eye on the deadlines of the telej vision networks when they timing out the sequence and timing of the six stops he would make in his first two days of formal campaigning for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: P.L.O. Role in a U.N. Parley in Canada Again Issue
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 22  The Canadian Government, which last summer postponed a scheduled United Nations conference on crime because of protests against the planned attendance of members of the Palestine Liberation Organization, faces a possible problem over a conerence scheduled for next year.

description: There's nothing more deadly than taking wit, humorThe Comicseriously. Look at Freud; Max Eastman; G. Leg

title: Portrait of the artist as a special kind of hero
description: In 1909, at the age of 27. obscure, impoverished, struggling to gain foothold as a writer, James Joyce heard a rumor that his wife, Nora, had been unfaithful with an old Dublin friend. The rumor left him distraught. In August he wrote to Nora: Is Georgie my son?...Were you fby anyone before you came to me? Joyce was soon reassured that his wife had been faithful, but the incident set loose, or disarranged, his erotic imagination and in a group of letters that autumn he poured out his anxiety. O take me into your soul of souls and then I will become indeed the of race.

title: The Cities of America
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 22The cities of America all have their troubles, but in the midst of all the economic and racial turmoil, it is seldom noticed that there is probably still more civic pride, more striving by private ,individuals and institutions to face our problems and correct our faults in the United States than in the cities of any other nation in the world.

title: Temporary Dumps Urged for Garbage
description: HACKENSACKThe Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders is being urged to set up a system of garbagetransfer stations as way of overcoming the shortage of space for the disposal of solid waste.

title: Suffolk Democrats at Odds With Klein
description: HAUPPAUGE  Suffolk County Democrats moved last week to consolidate their new, majority in the County Legislature, but their actions appeared to set the stage for a confrontation with John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, who is a Republican.

title: Albany, Like New York City, Has CashFlow and BudgtGap Difficulties
description: For months the State of New York, like an anxious parent, has brooded over and sought to nurse its governmental child, the City of New York, back to fiscal health. The attention given the city's finances, however, has tended to obscure the state's own financial problems.

title: Calhoun Captures L.I. Soccer Title
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 22 Ed Eschmann's goal at minute 28 seconds of suddendeath overtime gave Calhoun of Merrick a 32 victory over North Babylon tonight for the Long Island soccer championship at Hofstra Stadium.

title: Love Stories Make The Turntable Go Round
description: Tis love, tis love that makes the world go round, the Duchess informed Aliceand the same driving force is also prepared to do as much to your turntable. Scheherazade could have entertained the Sultan royally for another thousand nights with the amount of recorded material available on the subject of love. It's enough after a while to make the listener echo the villanelle in Joyce's A Portrait of the Artist, I am weary of ardent ways..., Yet the path that never did run smooth leads to some thrilling stops en route.

title: Dance Makes The Musicals Go Round
description: There is a new breed of musicals on Broadway these daysmusicals that are built on a dance impetus instead of conventional plots. In shows such as A Chorus Line, Grease, Chicago, Pippin, The Wiz and Candide, choreography is the lubricant that oils the wheels and maintains the momentum of the productions, some of them like roller coasters designed to thrill you within an inch of your life, and deposit you intact with a smile frozen on your face.

title: Music: Scottish Group
description: The Scottish National Orchestra, coming to the end of its first American tour, appeared in Carnegie Hall Friday night. The ensemble is celebrating its 25th anniversary, but its lineage, through the Scottish OrChestra, goes back to 1891. Based in Glasgbw, it is conducted by Alexander Gibson, a 49yearold Scot, who has been music director for 16 years.

title: Keeping Heads Above Water
description: New York, of course, is currently in a state of fiscal blight, but that's no reason not to think positive say two young men who chose the Big Apple es the place to set up a business.

title: Juan Carlos I
description: With the confirmation of Juan Carlos de Borbon as King Juan Carlos I, Spain has finally moved, officially and symbolically, out of the incredibly drawnout era Francisco Franco. As he was obliged to do, the 37yearold King swore to, uphold the principles and defend the system imposed for 36 years by the Generalissimo who anointed him. But he surely knows, that Franquismo died with its creator, and that the basiC question is: Which way will Spain now go?

title: Extra Point Decisive As Barringer Gains
description: Unbeaten Barringer, which had to fight in court for the right to play, edged Irvington, 76, in a North Jersey, Group 4, playoff game at Newark's Schools Stadium yesterday. Oscar Fernandez's extrapoint kick gave Barringer the victory. It followed a 10

title: Victory Is First in 6 Games
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 22 The Islanders scored their first victory in six games tonight by beating the Kansas City Scouts, 52, but New York is still searching for the confident frame of mind and organized play with which it began the National Hockey League season.
