description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28The United States denounced South African racial practices today and challenged the South African Government to permit a full inquiry by outside investigators.

title: From Brooklyn to Coco Bowl on a Shoestring
description: Two months ago, the players on the finandaily beleagured Brooklyn College football team would have looked away in embarrassment anyone had suggested that they would end their season with a bowl game in Puerto Rico. Tonight, at the Coco Bowl in San Juan, there will be nothing but satisfied grins.

title: Late Kick by Finochio Earns Crown for Farmingdale, 97
description: CARLE PLACE, L.I., Nov. 28 Bob Finochio kicked a 34yard field goal in the final minutes today, giving Farmingdale a 917 victory over Massapequa for the Nassau Conference III championship.

title: Niagara 83, Fairfield 78
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 28 (AP)  Niagara University's Jim Singleton made two free throws with four seconds to go, that sent the game into overtime, then Niagara moved to a quick:: 10point lead and scored 8378 victory over Fairfield: University tonight.

title: False Hopes for C.U.N.Y.
description: The anguish among the faculties of the City University over the institution's disastrous budgetary situation is fully justified. The certainty of new cuts on top of earlier ones poses a serious threat to the university's effectiveness. Regrettably, the response by the Faculty Senate, calling for the state to take over the university's financing and management, is unrealistic and misleading.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times on Thursday incorrectly said that a vote by the Hicksville, L.I., School Board to fine a teacher, Jerome McCarthy, $1,000 for allegedly breaking the jaw of a student, was unanimous. The vote to impose the fine was 4 to 3.

title: Green, 137, Holds Lead By Stroke
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan, Nov. 28 (AP)Hubert Green of Bay Point, Fla., rallied on the incoming nine today with four birdies and retained a onestroke lead after two rounds of the $200,000 Phoenix golf tournament. He shot a 70 for a total of 137.

title: Gannett Will End Funding Of Laser Graphic Systems
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 28 (UPI) The Gannett Company Inc announced today that it would discontinue funding of the Laser Graphic Systems Corporation of Sudbury, Mass., which manufactures and sells laserbased printing plate equipment for the newspaper industry.

title: Jersey Court Lifts a Ban On Raising Transit Fares
description: NEWARK, Nov. 28A move to postpone proposed rail and bus fare increases to go into effect Monday for 700,000 New Jersey commuters succeeded briefly today in the state appellate court, but was overturned a few hours later by State Supreme Court justice.

title: Elizabeth Channing Rodd Married
description: Elizabeth Charming Rodd, who teaches first grade at the Hewitt School here, was martied in Dover, Mass., yesterday to John M. Meyer 3d, manager of the institutional section at J & W Seligman & Company, investment counselors here. The Rev Gary B. Rundle performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Dover Church.

title: City NoteBond Trade Explained
description: The opening day of the massive offer to exchange outstanding city notes for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds was marked by confusion and uncertainty, especially on the part of individual noteholders trying to make up their minds on whether or not to accept the swap.

title: Monsoon Rains in India Improve Economy AntiInflation Steps Are Also Helping to Cheer Outlook
description: BOMBAY, India, Nov. 22After several years of gloom about India's future, international economists and businessmen are now more optimisticor less pessimisticthan they have been in some time.

title: U.S. REJECTS ROLE IN ARABS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) Secretary of Commerce Rogers C. B. Morton announced today that he had ordered his department to stop distributing Arab notices of trade opportunities if they involved boycott requirements against Israel.

title: Maine Woodsmen Embittered
description: CAMP 106, The Allagash, Me.After the union election, the American woodsmen gathered by their pickup trucks in front of the bunkhouses of this logging camp deep in the north woods. Against the night's cold they wore knitted wool watch caps, layers of flannel shirts, heavy boots. They spoke of their defeat in the soft, ScotchIrish accent of people isolated for generations. Damn Canadians, said one.

title: XRay of Entire Body Shows Color TV Image
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28A professor at Georgetown University Medical School here was granted a patent this week for his Xray machine, which can scan the

title: DR. SIDNEY L. SIMON, PHYSICIST, 62, DEAD
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 28Dr. Sidney L. Simon, a former physicist and senior associate consultant with Kensington Management Consultants Inc. of Stamford, Conn., died Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived here at 89 Londonderry Drive.

title: The President's Choice
description: Twentyeight years ago, as a young Chicagoan with a sheaf of references, an unprepossessing manner and a new law degree, John Paul Stevens Man went to Washin the ington to begin News two years of service as law clerk to Associate Justice Wiley B. Rutledge of the United States Supreme Court. Yesterday the former clerk was selected by President Ford to return to the Court, this time as an Asso ciate Justice and the succes

title: FREDERIC MACCABE
description: Frederic Maccabe, who retired in 1961 as president of the American International Marine Agency, an insurance organization here, died Tuesday in Easton, Md., where he lived. His age was 83.

title: Deals by Coast Doctor Studied
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 27 Two grand juries and a half dozen Federal and state agencies have begun investigations, of a Santa Ana surgeon's financial dealings that enabled him last year to become the most lavish spender in California state politics.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Nov. 28, 1975

title: Pilots Escape as Bombers Collide Over Kansas Base
description: OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 28 (AP) Two B57 bombers collided in the air and exploded in flames today while approaching a runway at Offutt Air Force Base, the headquarters of the Strategic Air Command. The pilots parachuted to safety.

title: Industrial Relations Head Named by The Daily News
description: H. J. Kracke, manager of industrial relations for The Daily News, has been named director of industrial relations, effective Dec. 1, W. H. James, president, said yesterday.

title: A. MILD WINTER SEEN FOR MOST OF NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) Nearly all of the United States may have abovenormal or normal temperatures this winter, the National Weather Service said today.

title: Congressional Units Face Knotty CleanAir Issues
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28On returning from the Thanksgiving recess next week, the Senate Public Works Committee and the House Commerce Committee will resume the delicate task of considering bills drafted by their environmental subcommittees to amend the 1970 Clean Air Act.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: MRS. GRASSO SHUNS TAXINCREASE PLAN
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 28Gov. Ella T. Grasso today rejected a union counterproposal that she increase state cigarette and liquor taxes rather than ask 40,000 state employees to work longer hours in an effort to avoid a projected $80 million budget deficit.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Contrary to earlier indications that it won, New York's voters turned down by a narrow margin an amendment to legalize charitable gambling in the state.

title: Radio
description: 6.6:55 A.M., WNYCFM. Gregorian Chants by a Chorus of Monks from the Abbey of Encalcat in France; works by Dufay and Pergolesi.

title: City NoteBond Trade Explained
description: The opening day of the massive offer to exchange outstanding city notes for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds was marked by confusion and uncertainty, especially on the part of individual noteholders trying to make up their minds on whether or not to accept the swap.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO SELL CANADAIR Ottawa Says It Will Acquire AircraftManufacturing Unit for $38 Million
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 28In what was described as a significant step toward a longrange restructuring of the Canadian aerospace industry, the Government announced today that it would purchase Canadair Ltd., the Montreal aircraftmanufacturing subsidiary of the General Dynamics Corporation of St. Louis, for $38 million.

title: F.D.A. Weighs a Cut In the Limit of PCB It Allows in Fish
description: ALBANYAn official with the United States Food and Drug Administration has indicated that his agency is considering lowering the allowable limits of the toxic chemical PCB in fish, in part becausg recent studies indicate PCB is carcinogenic in animals.

description: 1975 by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: U.S. Stays Out of Angola, Kissinger Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger declared today that thee United. States will not intervene militarily in Angola despite its strenuous objections to Soviet involvement in the civil war in that West African country.

title: Senate Reaction d Is Limited by Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28The initial, limited reaction of senators who must vote on confirming President Ford's nomination of Judge John Paul Stevens of Chicago to the Supreme Court ranged from warm bipartisan approval by Illinois's two Senators to a guarded desire on the part of some key members to know more about Judge Stevens. Congress was in recess for the Thanksgiving holiday, and many senators were not available or were unprepared to comment on the nomination.

title: CAREY TO REVISE STATE'S LOTTERY
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced a complete overhaul of the State Lottery, including the dismissal of Jerry Bruno, the Lottery Director, and the entire Lottery Commission staff.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MANILA, Nov. 28 (AP)Benjamin Corona of Mexico averaged more than 205 pins today in taking the lead the quarterfinals of the Bowling World Cup.

title: 200 Madrid Lawyers Deplore King's Amnesty as Too Limited
description: MADRID, Nov. 28  Some 200 members of the Madrid Bar Association today declared their most energetic disagreemerrt with King Juan Carlos's decree granting amnesty to number of political prisoners. The lawyers said that the decree in practical terms excludes from the benefits of the pardon almost all the political prisoners and defendants in Spain.

title: Paul Simon Sings at Fisher Hall With a Band and Dixon Quartet
description: Deployed above and behind, Paul Simon, his band and his Stage set Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hallthe last two of his four performances here are tonight at midnight and to morrow night at 8was a gigantic, crumpled white cloth hanging with the words PAUL SIMON Loves New York City printed neatly on it.

title: JapaneseI.B.M. Fight
description: Japanese computer makers, having broken the dominant hold of the International Business Machines Corporation on their market, are preparing to resist a new I.B.M. threat on Dec. 1 when protective barriers fall. Page 42.

title: FRANK F. TRUSLOW
description: Frank Fosdick Truslow, vice president of the ICM Corporation, coal trading and producing company, died Thursday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Wilton, Conn.

title: Neighbors Protest Plan To Shut Firehouse Here
description: Four elderly women settled into an old sofa drawn up in front of the gleaming red fire truck at Engine Company: 212 yesterday afternoon as res idents of Brooklyn's Greenpoint section vowed to sit in night, and day to keep the city from closing down their firehouse.:

title: Screen: Endless Devil's Cleavage
description: People like us are the tripods that keep up the ceilings of motels, says Ginger Menninger, one of several heroines who lurch from one shattered dream to another in The Devil's Cleavage, George Kuchar's metaphorstuffed, sometimes solemnly funny parody of terrible movies. The film was presented by the Film Forum yesterday at the Vandam Theater, Greenwich Village, where it will be shown this weekend and next.

title: Manes Expected to Endorse Jackson's Bid for the White House and Play a Major Role in His Campaign Here
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens is expected to endorse and play a major role in Senator Henry M. Jackson's Presidential campaign in New York, persons close to Mr. Manes and the Washington Senator's campaign said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NEW SHIP IN TOWN While this is the final weekend for the public to enjoy bay excursions aboard the schooner Pioneer (information: 7669055), the South Street Seaport has a new arrival, the Peking, ready for family dockside visiting. This makes, four historic ships open for daily inspection from noon until 4 P.M. Admission is $2.50 for adults and $1 for students; children under 6 years are admitted free with adult..

title: Russian Clergy at Kenya Talks Deny Persecution by Moscow
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 28Russian churchmen attending the fifth assembly of the World Council of Churches here defended today their country against charges of religious persecution made earlier this week. In separate letters published this morning by the daily newspaper of the Christian Councils of Kenya and Tanzania, the chairman of the foreign affairs department of the Russian Orthodox patriarchate and a group of four Russian Baptists conceded that problems occasionally arose between their churches and the Soviet regime but they denied that systematic repression was carried out.

title: Lafayette Defeats New Utrecht, 60
description: Alvin Morgan scored on an 8yard run and gave Lafayette High School a 60 victory over New Utrecht yesterday.

title: Dessert: Freedom a la Mode
description: HOT SULPHUR SPRINGS, Cob., Nov. 28 (UPI)Four inmates of the Grand County jail had special plans for their Thanksgiving dessert yesterday. After finishing a dinner of turkey, dressing, mashed potatoes and gravy, they jumped their jailer and escaped. All four were later captured.

title: Suspect Held in Bank Theft
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for allegedly conspiring to sell $15 million worth of United States Treasury bills stolen from the Chase Manhattan Bank on Nov. 5, 1973. J. Wallace LaPrade, head of the F.B.I.'s New York office, said the man, Alphonse D'Ambrosio, 51 years old, was arrested at his home on an indictment in connection with the

title: Ursula Dewitz, 60, Owned And Ran the Thalia Theater
description: Ursula Urdang Lewis Dewitz, owner and operator from 1955 to 1973 of the Thalia Theater, 95th Street, near Broadway, died Thursday in Palm Beach, PM., where she lived. She was 60 years old and also lived in Stockbridge, Mass.

description: Morning

title: City Lists Construction Projects Stopped Because of Fiscal Crisis
description: The Beanie administration made public yesterday the full list of 46 city construction projects being suspended because of the fiscal crisis.

title: Carey to Overhaul Lottery And Diimiss Entire Staff
description: Governor Carey yesterday announced a sweeping overhaul of the State Lottery, including the dismissal of Jerry Bruno, the Lottery Director, and the entire Lottery Cornmission staff.

title: Chief of Biggest Indian State Resigns After Party Fight
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 28 (Reuters)The Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh, Hemvati Nandan Bahuguna, resigned today, ending a yearlong struggle for power within the ruling Congress Party in the northern Indian state.

title: 30 Santas, Briefed on Their Duties, Off and Jingling
description: Yes, Virginia, there is a Hyman Rosenblatt.

title: Zaire's First Oil Begins to Flow From Offshore Field
description: MOANDA, Zaire, Nov. 28President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire stood on the deck of the Gulf Oil tanker Solen yesterday and opened a valve that started the flow of Zaire's first oilfield about 10 miles offshore from this town at the mouth of the Congo, now the Zaire River.

title: DOLLAR ADVANCES; STERLING DROPS
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 28 (UPI)The dollar soared to a sevenweek high on Continental money markets today and drove the British pound down to record lows. At one London bank people lined up 10 deep to sell sterling.

title: FORD CHOOSES A CHICAGOAN FOR SUPREME COURT SEAT; NOMINEE IS APPEALS JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28President Ford today named John Paul Stevens, a 55yearold Federal Appeals Court judge from Chicago, to the Supreme Court seat vacated two weeks ago by William O. Douglas.

title: Geoffrey von Kuhn Weds Anne Randolph
description: Anne Winder Randolph, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haughton Fitz Randolph of New Orleans, was married there last evening to Geoffrey Andrew von Kuhn, son of Mr and Mrs. Andrzej von Kuhn of North Salem. N.Y.

title: Grain and Soybean Futures Off; Gold and Silver Decline Sharply
description: Grain and soybeans lost a few cents a bushel at the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade in a session traders described as quiet, preweekend activity. Before a long weekend, especially a holiday weekend such as the Thanksgiving period, many traders like to liquidate their positions and be safely out of the market when foreign news might influence prices.

description: Horses listed in order of cost nonstlions Leiter designates OTR listing FIRST$7,500, cl., 2Y0, 6f.

title: A Witness Warns Senate Panel Of Bicentennial Sabotage Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) A Senate committee has been told that Communistbacked extremists might invade Philadelphia next year to sabotage the city's Bicentennial celebration. A Puerto Rican, identified only as Martinez for security reasons told the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee there is strong evidence Fidel Castro's Government would use all means available to disrupt activities in the city.

title: FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28Prices farmers get for raw agricultural products dropped) 4 percent from Oct. 15 to Nov. 15, the second straight monthly decline, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Assad's Hand Is Firm, And His Ear Attentive
description: DAMASCUS, SyriaThe intense stare of President Hafez alAssad beams from posters in every Syrian town. Traffic stops when he goes for a drive, and the faithful stir as he enters the Great Omayyad Mosque here.

title: Newspaper Editors Assail Blackmun Curb on Press
description: RENO, Nov. 28 (AP)A. United States Supreme Court Justice's limitation on news reporting in a Nebraska case id an unconstitutional prior restraint amounting to censorship, the Associated Press Managing Editors Association said today.

title: Breakfast on Capitol Hill Is a Nebraska institution
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28Good morning, breakfast clubbers. You are attending the oldest breakfast club in the world.

title: TEACHERS DISCUSS HOMOSEXUALITY They Find Similar Problems on Subject in Classrooms
description: Should the vernacular be used in a class on homosexuality?, Should a male homosexual professor teach a course for lesbians? Should a course on homosexuality include discussion of militant feminism?

title: Barbara Frackman Wed
description: Barbara K. Frackman, a widow, and Armand J. Kleinberg, both of New York, were married hare at neon yesterday by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel in his study at Temple EmanuEl. The bride is with the Merchandising Group as a men's wear consultant for du Pont de Nemours & Company. Her husband, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is president of Kleinberg & Son, importer of precious stones.

title: Bailey Loses His Bid to Delay Hearst Trial for Own Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28F. Lee Bailey, Patricia Hearst's chief defense counsel, was rebuffed today in his request for a threeday delay in her trial that would permit him to pursue his business interest in a helicopter company.

title: Rail Freight Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28The Association of American Railroads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Nov. 22 totaled an estimated 15.5 billion ton miles, 1.4 percent above the 1974 week.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Dow Stock Index Up 2.12 As Volume Shows a Drop
description: Stock prices closed with modest advance yesterday in quiet, postThanksgiving trading.

title: JERSEY CITY YOUTH ARRESTED IN DEATH
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 28 (UPI) A youth was arrested today on a charge of concealing a crime in the death bf a young girl whose nude body was found on the ground beneath a window of her apartment house, the police reported.

title: Ford Ponders Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) President Ford is still debating whether to sign a compromise energy bill that would remove price controls on oil by 1979 to stimulate production. It is the closest call on any piece of legislation he's had,, said his press secretary, Ron Nessen.

title: HIGH COURT GETS CALLEY'S APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) William L. Calley Jr. asked the Supreme Court today to overturn his Mylai murder conviction, saying Congress had no more right to withhold testimony for his trial than President Nixon did for the Watergate nrosecutions.

title: Laotian Leftists Demonstrate For End of Vientiane Coalition
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 28 (AP)Seven months after it began its bloodless takeover of Laos, the proCommunist Pathet Lao sent marchers into the streets today to demand an end to the coalition Government of Prime Minister Souvanna Phouma, who Is a neutralist.

title: The Burden Begins for Clean Gene
description: When he was approached about succeeding John Wooden as the U.C.L.A. basketball coach Gene Barlow didn't fast break at the opportunity. I had to think twice about il, he says. I liked the people I was working with at the University of Illinois and I had a longterm contract there. But after sleeping on it, I realized that if I turned down the offer I might never sleep for a year. Gene Bartow has been sleeping well ever since. But tonight his, burden, if not his sleepless nights, begins when the Univer sits of California, Los Angeles, opens its season against Indiana at. St. Louis in a nationally televised game. The burden is obvious. In the 12 seasons before John Wooden retired. U.C.L.A. won 10 national championships. Not that Gene Bartow has been hired to match that record. But he better not tarnish it.

title: Mexicans Lead Zone Net Match
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 28 (AP)Mexico took a 20 bead over Canada in an American Zone qualifying round of the 1976 Davis Cup tennis series today with singles victories by Joaquin LoyoMayo and Marcelo Lara.

title: 4 Jockeys Given Jail Terms for Fix
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 28Four jockeys, one of them a former national champion, were sentenced to six months each in Federal prison today for rigging the outcome of the ninthrace trifecta at Bowie Race Course last Feb. 14.

title: BHUTTO OPPOSITION TELLS HIM TO RESIGN
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 28 (UPI)The major opposition parties have asked Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto to step down and have called on their own politicians to leave their seats in protest against Mr. Bhutto.

title: Art: Construction by de Rivera
description: Three years ago we were given a retrospective exhibition of the sculpture of Jose de Rivera at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Mr. de Rivera was then 67 years old, and the exhibition embraced a period dating to 1930. It was dominated by the openform steel Constructions that the artist had long ago established as the signature of his artslender masses of steel, bent, welded, hammered and polished into graceful arabesques that seem to dissolve into light and space before our very eyes.

title: HOLIDAY SEASON IS FOR FUN: Skaters at Wollman rink in Central Park, which opened with few skaters on Thursday. Yesterday's weather wasobviouslysuperior.
FRANCIS X. BUSCH, TRIM LAWYER, 96
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 28 Francis Xavier Busch, a leading trial lawyer during the first half of the century, died here today at the age of 96. He had lived near here in retirement about 25 years.

title: TRADING OF NOTES FOR M.A.C. BONDS STARTS SLOWLY
description: In moods ranging from resentment to resignation, investors began exchanging their shortterm New York City notes for longterm Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds yesterday in a series of transactions crucial to the success of the program to rescue the city from default.

title: Unification
description: Several prominent scientists attending a conference sponsored by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon said yesterday that the importance of their deliberations outweighed criticisms that they were contributing to the growth of the controversial Unification Church.

title: Jaspers, Redmen In Final
description: A pair of potentially splendid local basketball teams easily eliminated outoftown opposition in the opening round of the first Joe Lapchick Memorial basketball tournament at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens last night and will meet tonight in the final.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENCatherine A., of Bronzy!Ile, N.Y., suddenly,. Jan Nov. 26, wife of John W. Allen, mother of Mrs. Brooks A. Dixon of Riverside, Conn., Timoth F. Allen 2d of Greenwich, Conn., grandmother of Holly Dixon and Joan and Christina Allen, sister of Mrs. Elizabeth A. Putnam of Lawrence, N.Y., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Ackermann. Services at Christ Church, Bronxville, N.Y. at 2 P.M., Saturday, Nov. 29. In lieu of flowers contributions to Christ Church would be appreciated.

title: Wilson Is Set to Act as Britain Feels Effect of Doctors
description: LONDON, Nov. 28Prime Minister Harold Wilson announced today that he would meet Sir Rodney Smith, president of the Royal College of Surgeons, next week to discuss the doctors dispute with the state ospitals over pay and conditions. Sir Rodney expressed grave concern over the dispute's effect on the safety of patients.

title: Swiss Credit Bank Disputes Charges Made by the S.E.C.
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 28 (AP)The Swiss Credit Bank, accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of fraudulent sales of unregistered securities to United States investors, said today it would seek revocation of a United States court order for turning over an estimated $150 million to $200 million in assets to its New York branch office.

title: HOT RADIATOR KILLS INFANT IN TRENTON
description: CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 28 (UPI)A 6monthold girl was reported in fair condition at a hospital here today after she and her twin brother rolled off a bed and were burned by a hot radiator at their apartment in Trenton.

title: Votewise, It's G.O.P. Time Again (Good Old Peking)
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Remember those 1972 election commercials on television? They showed Richard Nixon, the arch Cold Warrior, in Peking, descending the steps of Air Force One to shake hands with Chou Enlai as the StarSpangled Banner proclaimed an end to SinoAmerican enmity.

title: TRADING OF NOTES FOR M.A.C. BONDS STARTS SLOWLY
description: In moods ranging from resentment to resignation, investors began exchanging their shortterm New York City notes for longterm Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds yesterday in a series of transactions crucial to the success of the program to rescue the city from default.

title: Mr. Cleaver's Rights
description: Eldridge Cleaver, the former Black Panther leader who faces prosecution on charges of participating in a shootout that led to the death of a police officer, jumped bail in 1968, spent the intervening years abroad, and recently returned to the United States amid statements that, despite its faults, the American political system is the freest and most democratic in the world. He added that he stood ready to have his case decided within the normal process of the American judicial system. As a result, he has become exceedingly unpopular with many of his radical former associatesso unpopular that he is known to have expressed fears for his life.

title: OFFICIALS ABROAD PAID BY M'DONNELL
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, one of the nation's leading aircraft manufacturers, said yesterday it had paid about $2.5 millionapparently to officials of foreign governments  as fees, commissions and consultant payments between 1970 and mid1975.

title: Elizabeth Charming Rodd Married
description: Elizabeth Charming Rodd, who teaches first grade at the Hewitt Fahcol here, was married in Dover, Mass., yesterday to John M. Meyer 3d, manager of the institutional section a J & W Seligman & Company, investment counselors here. The Rev. Gary B. Rundle performed the Episcopal ceremony In the Dover Church.

title: U.N. Council Is Stalled on Golan Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 28The Security Council, meeting behind closed doors for a total of seven hours today, failed to reach agreement on extension of the mandate for the Golan Heights buffer force between the Syrians and Israelis.

title: Bruins to Play in Rose Bowl
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (AP)John Sciarra passed to Don Pederson for two touchdowns and the University of California, Los Angeles overcame 11 fumbles tonight to limp its way into the Rose Bowl with a hardfought 2522 victory over its perennial rival, Southern California.

title: DUTCH IN ACCORD FOR A U.S. INSURER
description: The Nationale Nederlanden N. V. of Rotterdam announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Midwestern United Life Insurance Company of Fort

title: Books of The Times
description: In a memoir the writer is alone with himself and one imaginary reader. W. Averell Harriman's record of his World War II years is not a real memoir. It is like one of those encounters so frequent with public figures; a private conversation that turns into a levee. A secretary is there; so is a valet, and subordinates wander in and out.

title: Animal Wastes Called a Source of Feed
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 28A group of livestock producers and agricultural scientists gathered here this week to talk about the use of animal wastes as cattle feed to help farmers fight inflated production costs and deflated market prices.

description: LEVINEMurray. Nov. 29, 1973. Much loved, much missed. LILLIAN, ANNE,

title: Amex and Counter Prices Increase in Quiet Trading
description: Prices on the Amex and in the overthecounter market rose yesterday in quiet post holiday trading.

title: Storm Hits Newfoundland
description: CORNER BROOK, Nfld., Nov. 29 (AP) A storm struck wester and central Newfoundland yesterday, accompanied by winds gusting up to 100 miles an hour. The wands disrupted most travel on a 200mile stretch of the TransCanada Highway between Deer Lake and Port aux Basques. A bus was blown off the highway, but there were no passengers aboard.

title: FORD, IN ALASKA, PRAISES PIPELINE AND LINKS TO ASIA
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 29 President Ford, clad in an arctic parka, walked along the trans: Alaska pipeline today and hailed the construction project as a weapon in the struggle to liberate the United State's from unreliable foreign sources of oil.

title: My Life
description: In 1969 Levi Eshkol died in midterm and Golda Meir was nominated Prime Minister of Israel She was at that time an old lady of 71, a former foreign minister living in semiretirement, frequently hospitalized and said to be seriously ailing. She was not the people's choice. Her nomination was designed to please an inert party machine anxious to avoid a possible disruptive fight between Moshe Dayan and Yigallon; it was not a bone to please the general public of whom only 3 per cent favored Mrs. Meir. And yet within months of her confirmation by the Knesset, public approval of Mrs. Meir's leadership bad risen to more than 80 per cent, and, in a remarkable demonstration of the recuperative potency of high office, she seemed healthier and more vigorous than she had been for 20 years, even while she worked up to 15 hours each day.

title: Builders Doubling as Inspectors
description: With New York City making massive cutbacks in its services these lays, it is having to resort more and more to get it done by somebody else alternatives. Inspections of big construction projects are next. Already, in fact, where minor alterations are concerned, the city will accept inspections by an engineer or architect hired by the owner of the property.

description: Governor Carey has decided to entirely reorganize the operations of the nowsuspended New York State Lottery, on the recommendation of an independent management consulting firm.

title: Meeting Backs U.S. Homosexual Rights Measure
description: More than 1,000 people at the third annual conference of the Gay Academic Union here yesterday were urged to support a Federal homosexual civil rights bill to ban discrimination against homosexuals in public accommodations and facilities, housing, education and Federal programs.

title: Europeans In Malaise
description: From a transAtlantic perspective during a visit several leading European cities earlier this month, it became readily clear that the American economy has been flexing its muscles.vigorously again and exhibiting much more vitalityin both absolute terms and in relation other economies of the Western worldthin was obvious closeup at home.

title: Disco Dance Party At Garden Likened To Woodstock Idea
description: It looked like an attempt) to create the Woodstock of the discotheque crowd, and it certainly underlined the fact that disco music and the places themselves are one of the major trends today in popular music. About 14,000 people crowded into Madison Square Garden on Friday to give the promoter Richard Nader's claim of the world's largest discotheque some validity.

title: Decadence
description: One of the sloppier public myths of the American middle class during the 1960's was the one about the counterculture. The myth told us that somehow the young people of those years were unique: a cultural mutation that was breaking the course of Western history. They

title: Power Coop Keeps Rates Low
description: SUSSEXAlthough it has been nearly two years since the energy crisis hit consumer pocketbooks, it was not until last May that the 5,881 subscribers of the electric company here paid a rate increase.

title: CITY LABOR TALKS FACE UNCERTAINTY
description: Wage deferrals, layoffs and the prospect that the city's straitened circumstances will continue indefinitely have cast a shadow of uncertainty over major contract negotiations next year with the publicemployee unions.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today accused China of making hypocritical statements about its solidarity with thirdworld oil exporters while undermining their position by selling its own oil at prices below international levels.

title: U. of North Carolina Is Accused Of Favoring Children of Alumni
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 29 A New York woman has filed suit charging that admissions policies at the University of North Carolina here favor children of alumni.

title: Warning for a King

Cardinal Enrique y Tarancn's words King Juan Carlos I at what in effect was a coronation mass were broadcast to the entire nation.

The near miracle was accomplished in less than 48 hours and at a cost that not even The Greek himself cares to discuss.

title: Ballet: An Ensemble Night
description: The New York City Ballet is a company where the ensemble or soloists, if not all the principals, are expected to dance every night in ballets that give them as much to do as the ballerina.

title: The Twilight of Splendor
description: Henry James, visiting Biltmore, the awesome French chateau Richard Morris Hunt built in North Carolina for George Vanderbilt, called it an affirmation of resources, and went on to say that If large wealth represented some of them, an idea, a fine cluster of ideas, a. will, a purpose, a patience, an intelligence, a store of knowledge, immediately workable things, represented the others. What it thus came to  was that somebody cared enoughand that happily there had been somebody to care.

title: Registration Slated At Felician College
description: LODIFelician College will conduct registration for the spring semester on the evenings of Dec. 9 and 10. Students who are interested in day or evening sessions can enroll on a fulltime or parttime basis for courses or for a degree program.

title: The Best of the EasyCare Trees and Shrubs
description: Is there an ideal tree or shrub? It would have to be shapely and showy, reasonably troublefree, easy to care for, grow. in any kind of soil and need little watering. Some woody plants do qualify on all counts, requiring only a minimum of maintenance. As a bonus, they also offer aesthetic appeal, even to the most discriminating home gardener. Here are a few good species to choose.

description: The word around Washington is: Wow! There's a lot of great stuff in this book. As its title suggests, Myra MacPherson's book, The Power Lovers: An Intimate Look at Politics and Marriage, reveals a great deal of gossip about public and semipublic people.

title: Nassau Introduces Road Safety Plan for Holidays
description: MINEOLAA special effort to curtail highway accidents and fatalities during the holidays has been started by the Nassau County Police Department. It is called Operation AllOut. A holiday anticrime program is also under way.

title: Chappaquiddick camp and Washington wives
description: This book is going to be misunderstood and scoffed at by a lot of people who want to take it too seriously. It's already happening. But actually Malcolm Reybold, a New Yorker who used to be an advertising executive. has put together a nice piece of camp and I'm sure that's what he intended to produce. It's not great camp, but it is charming for the most part, and where it isn't charming it is irritating in a memorable way, as camp litershould be.

title: Toni Kennedy Has Wedding
description: Toni Page Kennedy of Cambridge, Mass., and Erik M. Gelotte of Quincy, Mass., were married yesterday afternoon in Exeter, N. H. The Rev. Richard Siener, an Episcopal priest, peformed the ceremony in the Phillips Church.

title: Best Year So Far
description: NEWTONThis has been our best year so far, Len Soucy remarked with satisfaction. As of Nov. 14, we've banded 646 hawks, and we may top 700 before the season ends. Before this, we never did better than about 430.

title: The Real, Not Metaphorical, Banana Republic Experiences Growing Violence
description: MEXICO CITY  Probably no country in Latin America fits the clich of banana republic better than Honduras: It is tiny and backward, it is ruled by the army, its population is unevenly divided between a few rich and many poor and its economy is in fact, not metaphorically, dominated by two United States banana companies.

title: A Cautionary Tale of Two Men, A Myth and the Fall of a Muse
description: REMEMBER Miriam Hopkins in that wonderful old Lubitsch movie, Design for Living, when she played muse to a painter and a writer? On a visit to Vail, Colo., I saw myself as a MiriamoftheMopes, inspiring two friends to learn the fine arts of skiing. Neither knew much about the sport, but I was supremely confident that under my direction they would soon be cruising down the expert trails. Actually, all three of us were confident.

title: Graham Hill, Top Auto Racer, Is Feared Dead in Plane Crash
description: LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 30 (AP)Graham Hill, the British racing car driver who won the Indianapolis 500 in 1966 and was twice world champion on the European Grand Prix circuit, was listed as being aboard a small airplane that crashed near here last night.

title: FORD SIGNS A BILL TO HELP ELDERLY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) President Ford signed a bill extending the 1965 Older Americans Act for three years, but said that he was distressed by Federal spending levels authorized in the measure.

title: Elisabeth Marsden La Motte Is Married to Jon Joseph Roy
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., yesterday afternoon, Elisabeth Marsden La Motte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Howell La Motte 3d of Poughkeepsie, became the bride of Jon Joseph Roy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Joseph Roy of Millbrook, N.Y.

title: JOHN P. FAUGHNAN
description: John P. Faughnan, former national security director of Columbia Records Inc., died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived at 209 Garth Road, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Federal Aid Helps Cut Car Deaths On Island
description: ALIBANY  Long Island motorists are traveling far more safely than they did nine years ago thanks to a littleknown program for channeling millions of dollars in Federal money into local trafficsafety projects.

title: ReggaeJamaica's InsideOut Rock and Roll
description: During the last several years the driving, infectious soul music of Jamaica has been percolating through American pop culture until it threatens to boil over. The music is called reggae (pronounced regeye) and it comes from the West Kingston shanty town called Ward 12 by the government and Trenchtown by the impoveris4ed Jamaicans forced to make it their home. Like early rock and roll, reggae is black, sensual body musicperfect for dancing and sometimes hypnotic to hear. And, like early rock and roll, reggae combines a fundamentalist religious approach with aggressive imagery of social unrest and rebellion.

title: The Serene Gaiety of Japanese Art
description: Looking at one happy Japanese painting after another in the Metropolitan Museum's current exhibition of loans from the Mary and Jackson Burke collection, was set to wondering whether I could recall a single example of a tragic, sinister or truly violent theme in Japanese art, and, in contrast, just how much of Western art would have to go down the drain if those themes were declared taboo.

title: Workers at Two Paris Luxury Hotels Join Smoothly in the Management
description: PARIS, Nov. 29To the eye of the client, who is paying at least $100 a day for a room, the George V and Plaza Athne look much like the city's other opulent hotels thick carpets, period furniture, glistening chandeliers. But at the George V and the Plaza, workers committees help decide where to put dining rooms, whether to add flowers to the window boxes and whether the management is wasting money.

title: Nancy Reade Has Nuptials

title: ISAAC D. LEVY DEAD; CBS ORGANIZER, 83
description: Isaac D. Levy, Philadelphia lawyer and an organizer of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died yesterday at his home at the Barclay in Philadelphia. He was 83 years old. Mr. Levy had also been founder of the Philadelphia Yellow Cab Company and an organizer of the Atlantic City Race Track.

title: English Tutor's Book Tells of Lives of Czar Nicholas's Children
description: World War 1 and the Communist Revolution lay ahead, but when Edward VII of England visited Czar Nicholas II in 1908, another problem loomed larger. The Czar's children, among them his heir apparent, Alexei, and the Grand Duchess Anastasia were learning to speak English with a Scottish accent. That was not the King's English, and it could not be tolerated as the Czar's English.

title: Paperbacks

A character study of a wellmeaning woman who grows increasingly out of touch with reality as she wanders from her native Australia to the French Riviera to America; this early (1948) novel comes close to establishing its author's claim to the Nobel Prize he won a few years back.

description: HAUPPAUGEIn an effort to tap the increasingly lucrative convention market, officials from the public and private sectors have formed an organization to persuade corporations and other enterprises to hold their business meetings in Suffolk County.

description: Leo E. Owens, former publisher of The St. Paul Dispatch Pioneer Press and later publisher of newspapers in Texas, and California, died yesterday, at his home in Palm Springs,, Calif. He was 86 years old.

title: Mayan themes in modern Guatemala
description: Men of Maize, the Guatemalan Nobel laureate's second novel, was completed in 1949, after he had labored for years on El Senor Presidente, his masterful portrait of a prototypical Guatemalan dictatorship. Men of Maize, the sixth novel of Miguel Angel Asturias to appear in English, is his most richly textured work, and one of the most difficult to translate. In all his novels after

title: Evelyn Waugh
description: Christopher Sykes, most recently the biographer of another impossible figure, Lady Astor, has here written the life of his friend Evelyn Waugh, at the request of Laura Waugh, the novelist's widow (now deceased) and his eldest son Auberon, himself novelist. In spite of its auspices, this is anything but a work of piety: it is very funny, and sometimes very sad, and richly informative, and do not see how anyone interested in English letters and society of this century, and one of its most remarkable writers, can afford not to read it. At the time, I feel constrained to add that, judged by the highest standardto take only a recent .21C ample, Michael Holroyd's brilliant biography of Augustus Johnit is something of a disappointment. Sykes has fallen into a trap of his own devising: he has attempted to write a memoir as well as a biography, and the two forms, despite their kinship, make very different demands upon him, knocking the proportions of the booc askew. It does meander, to allow room for the author's own recollections (which are delightful): it is also,

title: Author's Query
description: For a piece I am doing on the American poet Emma Lazarus (18491887), I would very much appreciate biographical information, letters, and other pertinent material.

title: 2dQuarter Burst Paces Tech Rout
description: Brooklyn Tech exploded for 20 points in the second period yesterday and trounced Far Rockaway High School, 340. Far Rockaway had won its first eight games before losing to Jefferson, the Public Schools Athletic League champion, in the playof semifinals.

title: Money Managers Wary of C. D.'s
description: The prospect of default in New York City or New York State has created widespread upheaval in financial markets and some of the men and women who manage billions of dollars of other people's money are reducing the amounts they are willing to keep on deposit in major New York banks.

title: Ecological Camping: I Sat Up, Freezing, Shouting Obscenities
description: AT 17 degrees below zero, it was a little cold to be sleeping outside. Even in three feet of snow. But at least I wasn't alone. There were 25 of us, 15 men and 10 womenall members of the Sierra Club (the national conservation group) who had paid the club $45 for the privilege of sleeping in the snow for a week in the mountains of Utah. Our ages ranged from 16 to 48, our professions included student, doctor, architect, teacher, business executive, and our muscles varied from tired to exhausted after eight hours a day spent chopping down diseased trees.

title: Write If You Get Work
description: Here we have a book worth buying: a generous selection53 choice bitsfrom the amazing work of Bob Elliott and Ray Goulding, a couple of master comedians who live in a large, comfortable, friendly house right next door to reality.

title: Urbanity and acceptance
description: Poets generally keep to one tone through the years, and it becomes their signature. Almost invariably an Ammons poem can be Identified by its air of reasonableness. In Diversifications, his 11th book, Ammons keeps to the norm. If there is a surprise in this book, it is to discover that he has returned to earlier forms before Sphere, the book that won the Bollingen Award. In Diversifications Ammons tests himself once again in the short, contemplative modes that we read in Uplands and elsewhere in his books, and again the emphasis is on natural forces and processes, especially as they relate to the human. A small number of poems deal with the problems of daily routine, sexuality, the writing of poetry, ambition. Two love poems inject themselves sedately. Several poems go in length beyond the single page of the contemplative lyric. The book is justifiably titled Diversifications on the score of its range of subject matter and forms.

title: Soviet Is Reported Basing Submarines in Cuban Ports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (Reuters)  Soviet Echoclass nuclear powered submarines armed with cruise missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads are operating from Cuban ports, Aviation Week magazine says.

title: Art: Bedtops and Rooftops'; in Trenton
description: TRENTONBedtops and Rooftops is the title of an unassuming, but pleasurable, exhibition et the State Museum. Early American coverlets and weathervanes are on view; they are not handmade folk art, but objects commercially manufactured by skilled craftsmen in workshops of the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: N.E.A. Sues to Protect Jobs of Whites
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov 29 The National Education Association, which has institut ed numerous court actions over the last decade to eliminate discrimination against black teachers in Alabama, has now asked a Federal judge to protect the employment rights of white teachers in a county that has come under black political control.

title: STUDY FINDS CITY AS CLEAN AS IN 74 DESPITE LAYOFFS
description: Despite the layoff of almost 1,500 sanitation workers and a reduction in the frequency of garbage collections, New York City streets and sidewalks were as clean last month as they were a year ago, according to an independent report released yesterday.

title: Antiflood Program Progresses In Cranford
description: CRANFORD  This Union County township of 27,500 persons may have set some kind of a record in digging up dirt over the last two years. And the Township Engineer is deeply involved.

title: Schlesinger Says All He Wanted Was a Big Budget
description: James R. Schlesinger, whom President Ford recently dismissed as Secretary of Defense, has apparently embarked upon a campaign to warn the .nation against what he considers In be dangerous Administration plans for restricting the growth of the defense establishment.

title: PRICE RISE BARRED BY EAST GERMANY
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 28East Germany has pledged not to raise consumer prices for its 17 million people although the country is faced with steep price increases for vital imports, ranging from 130 percent in the case of oil to 12 percent for industrial goods.

description: PARIS, Nov. 29Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Commercedesignate, said here today that he hoped President Ford would be nominated next year but that he would probably support Ronald Reagan if the former California Governor wins the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE COMMERCE DEPARTMENT reported that exports in October exceeded imports by $1.08 billion, owing principally to a surge in agricultural exports and a drop in volume of imported oil. It was the ninth consecutive monthly surplus.  President Ford added 2,272 items to the dutyfree list of imported goods from 98 countries and 39 territories of lessdeveloped countries.  The International Coffee Conference of 61 countries meeting London has reached an agreement in principle for stabilizing coffee prices for the next six years.

title: Dons Win in Soccer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 (AP)  The San Francisco Dons won the National Collegiate Far Western regional soccer championship today with a 32 overtime triumph over California StateFullerton.

title: Boston Population Stable
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP)Preliminary state census data show that Boston's population is holding stable at more than 600,000, Secretary of State Paul H. Guzzi said yesterday. There is no evidence of an exodus of people from the city, he said.

title: Delay in Jersey TransitFare Rise Denied
description: NEWARK, Nov. 29 Federal District Court Judge Frederick B. Lacey refused today to block proposed intrastate railfare increases of from 15 to 50 percent that are scheduled to begin Monday for 70,000 New Jersey commuters.

title: DR. DAVID RUBIN
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 29 (AP)Dr. David Rubin, an ophthalmologist and general practitioner here for more than 30 years, died at his home yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Crime Research Post Filled
description: Vincent O'Leary, a professor at the State University of New York at Albany, has been elected chairman of the research council of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency. Professor O'Leary, who is a member of the faculty at Albany State's School of Criminal Justice, is widely known for his extensive work in the nation's parole programs. He succeeds Dr. Elmer K. Nelson, a professor at the School of Public Administration at the University of Southern California.

title: BONN SEEKS TALKS OF MARKET HEADS
description: BONN  The West German Government wants the heads of governments in the Common Market to start setting budget priorities for the organization directing future spending to projects that really further Euronean unity.

title: Problems Delay Mandatory Use Of Air Crash Warning Systems

title: Queens Art Units Found Thriving
description: Queens is growing as an art community. Within the last five years many artists have moved to the borough and many galleries and museums have opened. The metropolitan area has become increasingly aware that Queens offers one of the most substantial art programs around New York.

description: SMITHTOWN  The New York State Council on the Arts has chosen Smithtown to participate in a pilot project in psblie sculpture. The result will be a vestpocket. park in the town's central business district, on property donated by the Schechter family. The site, 75 by 30 feet, is between two buildings and is across from a shopping center.

She had good reason to ask, since traditional Western clothes have been influenced to such a large extent by African, dian and Polynesian styles. Fabricsfastened nonchalantly by a knot, a binding, a sash a twist drape and layer the body in a way new to Western eyes. These French spring

title: New Justice, Old Issue
description: There is little indication in the first reports on Judge John Paul Stevens, President Ford's highly praised Supreme Court nominee, of his attitude toward capital punishment. But new demands in Britain for the restoration of the death penalty there are a reminder that this is one of the most difficult issues now before the court Judge Stevens is expected to join.

title: HIGH COURT NOMINEE TO BAR INTERVIEWS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UPI)Judge John Paul Stevens, who was chosen yesterday by President Ford for a seat on the United States Supreme Court, released a statement today explaining why he would not consent to interviews.

title: Edison to Hold Parents Liable for Crimes of Minor Children
description: EDISON  An ordinance making parents responsible for crimes committed by their minor children will go into effect here next Friday. Under the law, parents who fail to show that they have exercised control over their children are subject to a $500 fine, 90 days imprisonment or both.

title: Boston Police Overtime
description: BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP)Boston police officers received $1.7 million in overtime pay during October for work involving the city's desegregation program, city officials said.

description: I am a witch, a New Jersey woman told Mayor Beame In a letter. Your city presents a challenge to me.

title: Julia Gaines Wed to J. P. Claypoole
description: Julia Kenna Gaines, daughter of Mrs. T. Stockton Gaines of Montrose, Pa., and the late Mr. Gaines, was married here yesterday afternoon to James Purnell Claypoole, manager of General Spring Ltd. in Prescott, Ontario. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Claypoole of Pittsburgh.

title: Canticks Defeated By Canadiens, 64
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 29 (UPI) Pete Mahovlich broke a 44 tie with a power play goal at 7 minutes 6 seconds of the final period tonight and the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 6.4, in a National Hockey League game.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 29 (UPI)Seven construction workers were killed and one was missing today in a mudslide at a golf course construction site in nearby Chiba Province, the police said

title: RADICAL CHANGES URGED IN DEALING WITH YOUTH CRIME

title: Marital Separation

But many of them are mere entertainment (e.g., the titillating diaries of sexually liberated young divorcees), and many others are howtosurviveitall manuals that dispense trivial or obvious nostrums.

title: ABORTION IN ITALY A POLITICAL ISSUE
description: ROME, Nov. 29  A small group of women shouted and sang outside the Chamber of Deputies this week, stopped traffic, handed out leaflets and condemned both the political right and left.

title: Boys'

Richard William Morton, U.S.A., who is with the Second Infantry Division at Camp Stanley in South Korea. He is the son of Brig. Gen. Richard L. Morton, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Morton of Carlisle, Pa.

description: Marvin Eisenstadt reckons he saves the world a million cavities and three billion calories a day. And as far as he's concerned, it's just a start.

title: RESURRECTION IN CHINA
description: No one will be even mildly surprised when Air Force One rolls to a stop on a runway in Peking this week and the first of China's 12 Deputy Prime Ministers, Teng Hsiaoping, steps forward to greet the second President of the United States to visit his country, Gerald R. Ford. And yet, if you think your way back to the perspective of Richard Nixon's trip nearly four years ago, the longplanned, ritualistic encounter between these two men is nothing less than astounding.

title: Man Slain and Youth Wounded As Police Thwart IND Holdup
description: One man was shot dead and another wounded when two stakedout Transit Authority police officers thwarted the attempted holdup yesterday of an IND subway change booth in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn.

title: PolarBear Pact to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI)  President Ford asked the Senate today to ratify the world's first international agreement protecting polar bears. The agreement was signea two years ago in Oslo by the United States, Canada, Denmark, Norway and the Soviet Union. Mr. Ford said it offered protection for polar bears consisting of a prohibitition of hunting, killing or capturing the mammals subject to specified exceptions.

title: A Winner Every Time
description: You have no doubt been taught that in 1776 the Americans beat the British. so, you have been taught wrong. It was not like that at all  it was our side that won.

title: Injured RightHander Becomes a Lefty
description: What do you do when you suddenly have to stop playing a sport that has been an integral part of your life for 40 years? Well, you just might try switching to the other hand. At least that's what I did.

title: Social Announcements

title: New Hampshire Playoff Victor
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 29 New Hampshire, champion of the Yankee Conference, scored three touchdowns in the fourth period today to defeat Lehigh, 3521, and advance to the semifinals of the National Collegiate Division 2 football playoffs.

title: Erika Lubar Is Wed To Wayne R. Brett
description: Erika Jan Lubar and Wayne R. Brett were married early yesterday evening in the Governor Morris Inn in Morristown, N, J., by Rabbi Samuel Cohen.

title: CARRIER IN NAPLES AFTER SEA COLLISION
description: NAPLES, Italy, Nov 29 (AP) The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy pulled into Naples hark bor today with a fresh coat of paint the only evidence of a nighttime collision with the cruiser Belknap a week ago.

title: Hallinan, Whitman Take Titles
description: Chris Hallinan of Bernards (Bernardsville. N.J.) beat Luis Ostolozaga, the course recordholder, and Walt Whitman of South Huntington, Li., captured team honors yesterday in the Fordham University Eastern States Interscholastic Crosscountry Championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Morris Hills'
description: Mark Geppert threw three touchdown passes to John Sperone as Morris Hills defeated neighboring Morris Knolls, 266, yesterday.

title: Grarnbling Wins, 3317, Shares Title
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (AP) Precision passing by Dale Zimmerman, a reserve quarterback, rallied Grambling to a 3317 victory over Southern University and a onethird share of the Southwestern Athletic Conference championship today before a crowd of 73,214 in the Superdome.

title: Mail Ban to Turkey Eased
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (Reuters)  Turkey has lifted for the Christmas season its ban on the mailing of packages to the 8,000 United States servicemen there, the Defense Department has announced.

title: Ursula Moor Wed To Jason M. Elsas
description: Ursula Beatrice Moor and Jason Morse Elsas, both of New York, were married yesterday. in Brookline, Mass. Justice of the Peace Thomas Connelly performed the ceremony at the home of John Morse, the bridegroom's uncle. The bride, a widow, is the daughter of Mrs. Ludwig Pickardt of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and the late Dr. Pickardt, a lawyer. Her first husband, the late Charles K. Moor, was president of the Consolidated Leather Manufacturing Corporation of Lynn, Mass.

title: Short Hills Revives Jersey Debutante Ball
description: The Short Hills (N.J.) Club revived its Debutante Ball last night after an interval of four years. Young people all seem very eager to return to the traditional, more formal way of doing things, said Mrs. Walter Lindenthal, delighted that her daughter, Kathryn Marie Lindenthal, was willing to dress up in a long white gown and go through all the motions obligatory to a formal presentation. Especially when Kathryn's older sister, Mary Beth Lindenthal, was disinclined for a debut two years ago.

title: Detroit Symphony Musicians Get Accord to End Strike
description: DETROIT, Nov. 29 (UPI)Detroit Symphony Orchestra musicians and management reached a tentative agreement today on a pact to end a strike that has hatled regular Concerts since Sept. 30. Details of the agreement were not released.

title: Electricity's possible cost
description: We Almost Lost Detroit is the fort of book that could back its way into history. Its author, John G. Fuller, intends to awaken a mass audience to the grim possibility that nucleargenerated power, offered as a solution to the energy shortage, may instead ae a dragon that cannot be tamed.

title: Heavenly Rest Bazaar
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will benefit from its third annual Christmas Bazaar, to be held in the church auditorium, 2 East 90th Street, from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M., Thursday, and 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Friday. Admission, $2, Thursday; 50 cents, Friday. Children, free.

title: Emilie L. Kellogg Is Married To G. R. Hinman Jr., a Banker

Hinman Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinman of Port Washington, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur W. Hargate. A reception was held at the Stanwich Club in Greenwich.

title: English Rozelle Rule
description: The retainandtransfer system in England, similar to the highly publicized Rozelle rule in American football, may come to an end. The English League, one of the largest, and strongest in the world, proposed last week a new deal that would end the system and leave professionals free to negotiate their own contracts.

title: Pop Notes: The Recording Odyssey of Bette Midler
description: While most pop superstars produce at least one new disk a season, it has taken Bette Midler two years to record Songs for the New Depression, her abouttobereleased third LP. Why?

He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Leslie Miller Jr. of Kellogg, Idaho, and Scottsdale. Ariz.

title: South Vietnam Opens Key Railroad
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 (Reuters) A major stretch of the wardevastated Saigon Hanoi railway has been reopened, bringing one step closer the reunification of North and South Vietnam, according to railway officials here.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (UPI) Maintenance workers at the Univresity of Pennsylvania were back at their jobs today, working under a new wage contract ratified last night that ended a sixweek strike.

title: Military Miniatures Shown in Paterson
description: PATERSONMilitary miniatures, sculptured plastic and metal figures representing a panoramic view of world history, will be on exhibit at the Paterson Public Library, 250 Broadway, through Dec. 29.

title: Memorial for Dana Friday
description: A memorial service fort Charles A. Dana, industrialilst and philanthropist, will he held next Friday at 12 noon in the chapel of St. James Episcopal, Church on Madison Avenue at .71st Street. Mr. Dana died: Thursday at his home in Wil1 ton, Conn., at the age of 94.

title: Montclair's Special Education Program Is Hailed
description: MONTCLAIR Programs set up for youngsters with learning difficulties, often source of conflict between parents and school authorities, have been scrutinized by a parents group here and rated from superior to outstanding.

description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Nov. 29 While the Rangers were getting pummeled in Pittsburgh, a team of former Rangers called the St. Louis Blues also underwent a beating tonight, losing, 82, to the Islanders in Nassau Coliseum.

title: CORRECTION

title: Flower Mound Keystone Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (AP) Flower Mound, ridden b. Robert Pineda, charged along the inside and overtook Sun and Snow for 2length victory today in the $34,000 Mademoiselle Stakes at Keystone.

title: Water Softeners Solve Many Problems
description: Although water starts out in the upper atmosphere as almost pure, by the time it falls through the air and seeps into the soil it often absorbs an amazing amount of minerals before it finally enters the household plumbing system. It is because of these various contaminants and pollutants that most water has to be treated to make it fit for drinking and other domestic uses.

title: ALABAMA VIOLATION ON VOTING LAW CITED

description: A Federal Court jury has decided that. Lynette Alice Fromme really intended to kill President Ford September 15 in Sacramento; the panel dishelieved her claim that she realized: her gun would not fire and that she pretended an assassination attempt only to win attention for the concerns of the cultist murderer Charles Manson.

description: No matter how much stockholders grumble and Government tax reformers threaten to crack down, fringe benefits for top executives arc getting perkier and perkier.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 An expanding investigation, reaching from America's farms to the foreign markets where the harvests are sold, has found that corruption in the grain industry has already hurt the interests of growers and threatens damage to the economy.

title: Changing O.A.S.: Yes, But How?
description: In the years since it was founded in 1948, the Organization of American States has been subject to two broad and opposite, but probably justified, kinds of criticism. At first, other member nations complained the organization was being used by Washington to provide legitimacy for policies the United States already followed; now, it is the United States that is complaining that the organization has become a forum for attacks on Washington.

title: Ravel
description: Two more apparently different composers would be hard to find in this century, now threequarters gone. Ravel, the tightlipped meticulous professional who could say the artist, in my opinion, should have no other aim than technical perfection, and whose whole life and creative energies were bent to that seemingly constricted objective. Ives, the defiant outsider, the nonprofessional for whom craftsmanship as defined by the musical guilds of his time was only a kind of Montgolfiers balloon, something hollow of meaning except as it might be used to reach higher planes of existence. That, at any rate, sums up what each man thought of himself, and how they have been

title: Giant Talk

description: WASHINGTONAn Independent oil producer from Kansas was inveighing the other day against the comprehensive energy bill that a HouseSenate conference is expected to report back to the two chambers Tuesday.

title: Caasi Cohen Is Wed TO Michael Waters
description: Elizabeth Caasi Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Cohen of Brooklyn, was married there last evening to Michael David Waters of Framingham, Mass., son of Bernard Waters of Natick, Mass., and the late Pauline Waters. The ceremony was performed at Temple Beth Elohim in Brooklyn by Rabbi Eugene J. Sack, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents.

title: December
description: December is late sunrise and early starlight, days that have a deep intensity that seems twice as profound any day in July, nights long and dazzling with all the stars in the universe. December is the year's own summary, even a summary of time up till now. We call the year's ending, as though this orbiting of the sun by our own small planet could have an ending, as though there were an ending to a circle.

title: The Quicksilver World of
description: Nobody can see everything Off Off Broadway. Some 150 OOB theaters produce an average of 50 plays every weekend, an outpouring that varies widely in quality and content. What is important is OOB's availability as an alternative theater, an antidote to the glossiness and timidity of Broadway. The confirmed 00Bgoer does not seek a surefire hit, but wants to catch an interesting work in development, to follow the expanding career of a gifted writer, actor, director or company, to see new, innovative works that simply would not be possible iii the commercial theater without first OOB acclaim.

title: Passaic Map to Aid Bicentennial Guests
description: CLIFTON  New Jersey residents will be taking new look at their state during the nation's Bicentennial celebration next year, and one of the people who will be telling them where to look is Kevin Marion.

title: Alabama Bridge Reopens
description: MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 29 (UPI) The Dauphin Island Bridge, closed since a section of the fourmilelong span was knocked into the water nine days ago by outofcontrol barges, reopened today. Two precast concrete roadway sections, each 34 feet long, were set into place to allow the opening of the bridge connecting the resort island in the Gulf of Mexico to the Alabama mainland.

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: I have Formicacovered kitchen cabinets that are 10 years old. They have a matt finish and are in excellent condition except for a glue residue that has been on them all these years. This glue has yellowed and is especially noticeable along the edges. What will remove this without damaeine the Formica?Mrs. It L.. Scotch Plains. N. J.

title: One Primary Too Many
description: New York Republicans, who switched the state's primary election date to September last year in hope of gaining a partisan advantage that never materialized, are now opposing a return to the traditional June primary although it would save money and would obviate the need for two elections when one world serve the purpose.

title: Torture Inquiry Requested
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 29 (UPI) Ohio Attorney General William J. Brown has been asked to order a special grand jury to investigate the torture of an inmate of the Apple Creek Institute for the Mentally Retarded. The request was made by the attorney of Margaret Leonhart, a widow whose 26yearold daughter, Lottie Ann, who cannot talk or walk, had all of her fingernails, and one toe nail on both feet, ripped out by another inmate.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SALINA, Kan., Nova 29 (AP)Sparked by Alexandr Belov, the Soviet Union poured in 11 straight points in the Wailing minutes last night and defeated Marymount College, 7875 to end its 28day American basketball tour with a 95 wonlost record. Belov's shot from beneath the basket with 4 minutes 25 seconds remaining put the Rusglans ahead, 7069, and with 2:07 remaining the Russians Wad increased their advantage to 7669. Sergei Belov led all scorers with 21 points. Alexandr Belov and Mikail Korkia had 15 apiece. Jim Hearns pumped in 19 for Marymount and Lou Grimsly 14.

title: Rice Milling Machine Comes to a Small Javanese Village and Changes the Indonesians'

title: Nureyev: I'm Learning to Dance All Over Again

I dance more classics than any dancer in the world. But I know I can do Swan Lake and Giselle. I want to expand myself, to explore myself.

title: SelfDefense Course Planned
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29 (UPI) A selfdefense course that combines common sense and dirty fighting will be taught at Duval County high schools to help reduce school crime. The crime rate indicated that we need to offer this kind of program, said Jim Kitchens, the supervisor of physical education. He said the course was not mandatory but was strongly recommended by the school administration.

title: Officer and Wife Die After Holiday Dinner
description: NEWARK, Nov. 29, (UPI) A former patrolman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and his wife died of heart attacks within minutes of each other early yesterday after observing Thanksgiving with their children, according to authorities.

description: NEWARK  Major sports were once big time in this, New Jersey's largest city, and its immediate suburbs.

description: PARIS. Nov. 29  The Government of Valry Giscard d'Estaing, accusing the Socialist Party of trying to weaken discipline in the armed forces, has begun a formal investigation of alleged attempts to subvert national security through the creation of labor unions in military units.

description: Karen Joan Weckstein and Peter Rodney Lessier plan to be married in May. The future bride is a legal assistant and her fianc, a lawyer, with Rosenman Colin Kaye Petschek Freund & Emil, New York law firm.

description: ROME Nov. 29 (AP)A 19yearold youth has been charged with fraud for having celebrated hundreds of masses, performed many weddings and heard many confessions in the center of Roman Catholicism for two years without being an ordained priest.

title: Judges and Prosecutors Set to Fight Street Crime
description: TRENTON  Judges and county prosecutors in New Jersey were formulating plans last week to implement a new get tough policy for violent street crime. Such a policy has been recommended by Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the State Supreme Court.

title: Butcher Shows Her Classes How to Trim Costs
description: RARAMUSAll it takes are three sharp knives, some assorted twine and a very steady hand. Add the professional knowhow of your friendly neighborhood butcher, and it is estimated that the average family of four. can save at least $500 a year on its meat bill.

title: The Rikers Revolt Was for Rights Already Won
description: A revolt at the House of Detention for Men on Rikers Island was ended last week with promises of amnesty for the rioters and without loss of life, but the blowup demonstrated that the city, in its penniless state, is now less able than ever to correct the abuses that led to the riot.

title: Rice Expert Joins Drew Botany Staff
description: MADISONThe director of the research team that developed the strains of rice leading to the green revolution in Asia has joined the Drew University faculty as a visiting lecturer in botany. He is Dr. Peter R. Jennings, a 1953 summa cum laude graduate of Drew, who is now associate director for agricultural sciences at the Rockefeller Foundation in New York.

title: Mrs. King Visits Nigeria,
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 29 (Reuters)Corrctta Scott King, widow of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., and Represent ative Andrew Young, Demo.: crat of Georgia, today paid a courtesy call on Nigeria's External Affairs Commissioner, Col. Joseph Gallia. The Americans were on their way home after visiting Kenya and Zambia, where they dedicated a United States Information Service library.

title: HENRY G. LAMBERT
description: Henry G. Lambert, a retired executive of A.C. Allyn & Companyinvestment bankers, died Friday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived at 9 Cranston Place, Bronxville.

title: Peking Is Dubious About Substantial Improvements
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 29When President Ford arrives in Peking Monday, he will encounter a Chinese leadership that is more dubious about, if not disappointed with, its relations with the United States than at any time since President Nixon's epochal visit three years ago.

title: U.S AIDS SURVIVAL OF RARE ANIMALS

title: Moving a Company Is Moving a Mountain
description: By 7 P.M. a squad of bluejacketed moving men had already laid Masonite lane from the lobby to the elevators, taping the protective boards to the ersatz marble floors. Other teamsters had swathed doors and elevators with quilted pads or had mobilized transport600 dolliesand piled each vehicle high with two or three of the 2,600 cartons scheduled to be evacuated that night along with six safes and a mountain of desks, chairs, tables, typewriters, recorders, calculators and other equipment.

title: Abuses Laid to Police at Rock Concerts
description: MINEOLA  The Nassau Chapter of the New York Civil Liberties Union charged In a report issued last week that the police had regularly conducted searches and seizures of persons and cars unlawfully at rock concerts at the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale in the last twoandahalf years.

description: Henry Delano Wilson Jr., a former satellitesystems specialist with Bell Laboratories, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived at 25 Tillotson Road in nearby Fanwood.

description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sunday, Nov. 30 The National Party ousted the governing Labor Party in an upset victory .in yesterday's general election.
